('61', 0, 1, 2, 42) 1. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('61', 0, 2, 3, 64) April 27, 1933
('61', 0, 3, 4, 79) MIRA, This is Thursday morning before prayer.
('61', 0, 3, 5, 125) Your letter came in yesterday with Ba’s.
('61', 0, 3, 6, 166) A book on Astronomy is being sent to you.
('61', 0, 3, 7, 208) I enclose also a map for the month.
('61', 0, 3, 8, 244) You will find herewith so Dr. Saunders’s 1 letter.
('61', 0, 3, 9, 295) It is satisfactory on the whole.
('61', 0, 3, 10, 328) Letter for Ba will also accompany this.
('61', 0, 3, 11, 368) You may pursue the conduct of the Ashram as much as you like.
('61', 0, 3, 12, 430) It won’t tire me.
('61', 0, 3, 13, 448) It will assist me.
('61', 0, 3, 14, 467) It will enable you to understand my viewpoint better.
('61', 0, 3, 15, 521) You must not accuse yourself of want of faith in me or my wisdom because you do not see a point of mine at once or because having seen it you cannot agree with me.
('61', 0, 3, 16, 685) I am not a perfect being.
('61', 0, 3, 17, 711) Why should you see eye to eye with me in my errors?
('61', 0, 3, 18, 763) That would be blind faith.
('61', 0, 3, 19, 790) Your faith in me should enable you to detect my true error much quicker than a fault finder.
('61', 0, 3, 20, 883) What I would like your faith to do is that when you cannot convince me of my error you should think that it is likely that I see more clearly than you do in matters where I have thought and experienced more.
('61', 0, 3, 21, 1091) That would give you peace of mind.
('61', 0, 3, 22, 1126) Therefore you should not paralyse your thought by suppressing your doubts and torturing yourself that you do not agree with my view in particular things.
('61', 0, 3, 23, 1280) You should therefore pursue the discussion of the Ashram till you have the clearest possible grasp of all my ideas about it.
('61', 0, 3, 24, 1405) You need not have argued about the man being the worse sinner of the two.
('61', 0, 3, 25, 1479) I have always held that view against most, if not all, of my male friends who have expressed their opinion on the point.
('61', 0, 3, 26, 1600) of course I agree with you also that man’s superiority, if it is that, over the brute creation, consists in his capacity for observing brahmacharya.
('61', 0, 3, 27, 1749) It must therefore be an Ashram ideal to be attained immediately if that were possible.
('61', 0, 3, 28, 1836) There is therefore complete agreement.
('61', 0, 3, 29, 1875) between us so far as the fundamental thing is concerned.
('61', 0, 3, 30, 1932) The difficulty or the difference
('61', 0, 4, 31, 1965) 1 The specialist at London who had treated Mirabehn for tubercular glands in 1907. Vide “Letter to Dr. Arthur Saunders”, 5 3 1933.
('61', 1, 0, 1, 2096) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 1, 1, 2, 2136) comes in when we begin to devise ways and means of encompassing the ideal.
('61', 1, 1, 3, 2211) I am becoming more and more confirmed in the view that it must go on as it is now doing, with ample liberty to the manager to regulate fresh admissions.
('61', 1, 1, 4, 2364) Our life should become daily simpler and not more complex.
('61', 1, 1, 5, 2423) We should be progressively more self restrained.
('61', 1, 1, 6, 2472) But we should remain a composite family that we now are.
('61', 1, 1, 7, 2529) The present composition is not the hindrance.
('61', 1, 1, 8, 2575) The hindrance is that we have so few real complete brahmacharis.
('61', 1, 1, 9, 2640) All were broken vessels, all had their own individual passions to conquer.
('61', 1, 1, 10, 2715) But I hold that most of them were and are sincere strivers.
('61', 1, 1, 11, 2775) Therefore we are blind leaders of the blind and ever stumbling.
('61', 1, 1, 12, 2839) When some of us have, by constant striving, become at least matriculates in the effort, we shall certainly do better.
('61', 1, 1, 13, 2957) Therefore the problem resolves itself into each one of us striving to the utmost to approach the ideal.
('61', 1, 1, 14, 3061) Remember my definition of brahmacharya.
('61', 1, 1, 15, 3101) It means not suppression of one or more senses but complete mastery over them all.
('61', 1, 1, 16, 3184) The two states are fundamentally different.
('61', 1, 1, 17, 3228) I can suppress all my senses today but it may take aeons to conquer them.
('61', 1, 1, 18, 3302) Conquest means using them as my willing slaves.
('61', 1, 1, 19, 3350) I can prick the ear drum and suppress the sense of hearing by a simple, painless operation.
('61', 1, 1, 20, 3442) This is worthless.
('61', 1, 1, 21, 3461) I must train the ear so that it refuses to hear gossip, lewd talk, blasphemy, but it.
('61', 1, 1, 22, 3547) is open to the celestial music, it will hear the most distant cry for succour from thousands of miles.
('61', 1, 1, 23, 3650) Saint Ramdas is said to have done so.
('61', 1, 1, 24, 3688) Then how [to] use the organs of generation?
('61', 1, 1, 25, 3732) By transmuting the most creative energy that we possess from creating counterparts of our flesh into creating constructive work for the whole of life, i.e., for the soul.
('61', 1, 1, 26, 3903) We have to rein in the animal passion and change it into celestial passion.
('61', 1, 1, 27, 3979) Read here Chapter II, Verse 64, of the Gita.
('61', 1, 1, 28, 4024) The burden of the Divine Song is not “fly from the battle but face it without attachment”.
('61', 1, 1, 29, 4115) Therefore you and I and every one of us have to stand unmoved in the midst of all kinds of men and women.
('61', 1, 1, 30, 4221) There is no physical seclusion except temporarily for some.
('61', 1, 1, 31, 4281) The Ashram is all right where it is but we must branch out for larger growth.
('61', 1, 1, 32, 4359) But that would be a natural evolution coming in its own time.
('61', 1, 1, 33, 4421) Love from us all.
('61', 1, 3, 34, 4439) From a photostat: C.W, 6269. Courtesy: Mirabehn

('61', 2, 1, 2, 4529) 2. LETTER TO HARRY BOWMAN
('61', 2, 2, 3, 4555) April 27, 1933
('61', 2, 3, 4, 4570) DEAR FRIEND, I thank you for your long letter 1. I had one visit from Miss Mayo when she was in India.
('61', 2, 3, 5, 4673) I have read her book and I wrote also a review 2 on it which at that time had attracted considerable attention.
('61', 2, 3, 6, 4785) It is my firm conviction that the book is filled with half truths, innuendos and deductions drawn from stray facts as if they represented a universal situation.
('61', 2, 4, 7, 4946) Yours sincerely, HARRY BOWMAN, ESQ.
('61', 2, 4, 8, 4982) BEATRICE, NEBRASKA [U.S.A.]

('61', 2, 6, 11, 5137) 3. LETTER TO YVONNE PRIVAT
('61', 2, 7, 12, 5164) April 27, 1933
('61', 2, 8, 13, 5179) MY DEAR BHAKTI, I was delighted to have your letter which you consider is long and which for us is too short.
('61', 2, 8, 14, 5289) I see that you are one in your happiness.
('61', 2, 8, 15, 5331) You are one also in your erosion though you tell me that both of you had the ‘flu, at the same time.
('61', 2, 8, 16, 5432) You still remain the strangest pair I have ever had the good fortune to meet.
('61', 2, 8, 17, 5510) one reads of such couples in Persian poetry but does not meet them in flesh and blood.
('61', 2, 8, 18, 5597) May you for ever remain inseparables.
('61', 2, 8, 19, 5635) Yes, I know, you in Europe are going through very hard tinues, both economically and spiritually.
('61', 2, 8, 20, 5733) But I believe literally in the Biblical saying that “God would not destroy Sodom and Gomorrah so long as there is one good man the” I know that you have in Europe true men and women in all the odd nooks and corners of the Continent.
('61', 2, 8, 21, 5966) I, therefore, feel that in the end all will be well.
('61', 2, 9, 22, 6019) 1 Dated March 12, 1933 (S.N. 19009), expressing his indignation at Katherine Mayo’s Mother India.
('61', 2, 9, 23, 6117) The addressee had written: “.
('61', 2, 9, 24, 6147) advise me if Miss Mayo sticks to truth in this deplorable bool or is she only after publicity money.
('61', 2, 9, 25, 6248) .” 2 Vide “Drain Inspector’s Report”, 15 9 1927.

('61', 3, 1, 2, 6337) I am glad you have got a copy of my little book, Guide to Health.
('61', 3, 1, 3, 6403) It is an indifferent translation and then there are some chapters I would like to revise, and if at all I get the time and permission, I would certainly do so.
('61', 3, 1, 4, 6563) Nature cure has made great strides since Kuhne’s time, and I should like to incorporate the results of new experiments.
('61', 3, 1, 5, 6683) We are all keeping well, and all of us send you and Anand 1 our love.
('61', 3, 1, 6, 6753) I do hear from Mira every week and write to her in return.
('61', 3, 1, 7, 6812) To correspond with me every week she forgoes the pleasure of writing to and meeting other friends.
('61', 3, 1, 8, 6911) I will certainly convey your love to her.
('61', 3, 1, 9, 6953) A letter is going to her today.
('61', 3, 2, 10, 6985) Yours sincerely, BAPU [PS.] Love from Mahadev who is being released on the 19th May.

('61', 4, 9, 20, 8976) Sastri is leaving me only because he wants to attend to his old father and family affairs, not having gone there for some years.
('61', 4, 9, 21, 9105) Latterly, he lost a brother in law.
('61', 4, 9, 22, 9141) But he would gladly like to be able

('61', 5, 10, 22, 10571) 8. LETTER TO M. R. JAYAKAR
('61', 5, 11, 23, 10598) April 27, 1933
('61', 5, 12, 24, 10613) DEAR MR. JAYAKAR,
('61', 5, 13, 25, 10631) I enclose herewith my opinion 1 on Dr. Ambedkar’s proposal to revise the Yeravda Pact in so far as the panel system is concerned.
('61', 5, 14, 26, 10761) 1 Vide “The Yeravda Pact”, 27 4 1933.
('61', 6, 0, 1, 10799) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 7
('61', 6, 1, 2, 10841) hope you will agree with me that Dr. Ambedkar’s proposal is no substitute for the panel system, and that under the guise of joint electorate it sets up an effective separate electorate.
('61', 6, 1, 3, 11027) The proposal copies in my opinion all the worst features of the late Maulana Mahomed Ali’s formula leaving out all its relieving features.
('61', 6, 1, 4, 11166) In my opinion so long as the Harijans are filled with suspicion, and they have every reason to entertain suspicion, as to the conduct towards them of caste Hindus, they have a perfect right to have the first say in the choice of candidates, and for that, the panel system, in my opinion, cannot be excelled.
('61', 6, 2, 5, 11474) Yours sincerely, Enclosure Copy to Dr. Sapru also
('61', 6, 3, 6, 11524) From a photostat: S.N. 21072

('61', 7, 4, 10, 12713) 11. LETTER TO PREMLILA THACKERSEY
('61', 7, 5, 11, 12747) April 27, 1933
('61', 7, 6, 12, 12762) DEAR SISTER, I got your letter just now.
('61', 7, 6, 13, 12803) N. Devi and her son are having their meal with me, and there will be some delay in their reaching your place.
('61', 7, 6, 14, 12913) Kindly forgive me for that.
('61', 7, 6, 15, 12941) I am asking Dr. Spiegel also to accompany them.
('61', 7, 6, 16, 12989) I was very glad to read your letter.
('61', 7, 6, 17, 13026) If you can be frank like this with me, I would feel no hesitation any time.
('61', 7, 6, 18, 13102) on the one hand, there would be no limit to my begging as I am admittedly a beggar.
('61', 7, 6, 19, 13186) But, while making immediate demands, I should also like to respect fully the donor’s own inclination.
('61', 7, 6, 20, 13288) I, therefore, always try to put the prospective donor at ease whenever I hold out my begging bowl.
('61', 7, 6, 21, 13387) I am first sending Shri Nair to the Servants of India Society and inquiring of them.
('61', 7, 6, 22, 13472) If they can accommodate him, I will keep him there.
('61', 7, 6, 23, 13524) In any case a car does have to come daily from there.
('61', 7, 6, 24, 13578) This will mean only one trip more, and I don’t think there will be any difficulty about that.
('61', 7, 6, 25, 13672) I will not fail to avail myself of your offer if there is any difficulty.
('61', 7, 6, 26, 13746) I did not know about the mangoes.
('61', 7, 6, 27, 13780) I do not eat them regularly, but generally depend on papaya.
('61', 7, 6, 28, 13841) I will ask Sardar and let you know how the mangoes were.
('61', 7, 6, 29, 13898) However, I do not want you to worry about such small matters.
('61', 7, 6, 30, 13960) None of us has a delicate palate.
('61', 7, 6, 31, 13994) We eat what we get and offer thanks to God.
('61', 7, 7, 32, 14038) Blessings from BAPU

('61', 8, 1, 2, 14224) 12. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('61', 8, 2, 3, 14254) April 27, 1933
('61', 8, 3, 4, 14269) NARANDAS,
('61', 8, 4, 5, 14279) I got the big post yesterday.
('61', 8, 4, 6, 14309) You must have received the long letter which I dictated for you yesterday.
('61', 8, 4, 7, 14384) I very much liked your letter which arrived in the big post.
('61', 8, 4, 8, 14445) You have exercised good restraint in your language.
('61', 8, 4, 9, 14497) There are signs of impatience here and there, but not much to speak of.
('61', 8, 4, 10, 14569) Your reply is pointed and brief.
('61', 8, 4, 11, 14602) I did not require it at all, but, since I have received it, it will help me to pacify Chhaganlal.
('61', 8, 4, 12, 14700) It will not be necessary for me now to send his complaints to you.
('61', 8, 4, 13, 14767) I will struggle with him in my own way, and try to remove his error.
('61', 8, 4, 14, 14836) I will not waste your time, I have wasted enough of it.
('61', 8, 5, 15, 14892) I suppose you have read Shri Rajbhoj’s 1 letter.
('61', 8, 5, 16, 14941) I liked it very much.
('61', 8, 5, 17, 14963) He says in it that we have used more logic than the heart in dealing with Ramji 2. Since you have welcomed his suggestion, the problem is over.
('61', 8, 5, 18, 15107) Rajbhoj may be mistaken in his view.
('61', 8, 5, 19, 15144) But it is also possible that we have been at fault.
('61', 8, 5, 20, 15196) We should be able to prove to an inpartial Harijan the correctness of our treatment of Ramji in all respects.
('61', 8, 5, 21, 15306) I am writing this not to find fault with anybody, but only to suggest how we should behave in future.
('61', 8, 5, 22, 15408) How can I blame anybody without knowing all the facts?
('61', 8, 5, 23, 15463) Read the letter 3 to Rajbhoj which I am going to write.
('61', 8, 5, 24, 15519) He has suggested a change in the hour for the prayer.
('61', 8, 6, 25, 15573) That suggestion also deserves careful consideration.
('61', 8, 6, 26, 15626) His argument is that everybody should get time to answer the call of nature immediately after getting up.
('61', 8, 6, 27, 15732) He has, therefore, suggested that 45 minutes should be set apart for this purpose instead of 20 as at present.
('61', 8, 6, 28, 15843) This is what he says:
('61', 8, 7, 29, 15865) Before answering the call of nature one is less likely to be able to concentrate at prayer time.
('61', 8, 7, 30, 15962) People also feel very sleepy.
('61', 8, 7, 31, 15992) If the prayer is kept at 4.45, lassitude, the feeling of uneasiness arising from not having answered the call of nature and restlessness, all these three things will disappear.
('61', 8, 8, 32, 16169) 1 P. N. Rajbhoj, a Harijan leader 2 A Harijan weaver in the Ashram 3 Vide “Letter to P.N. Rajbhoj”, 27 4 1933.
('61', 9, 0, 1, 16280) 10 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 9, 1, 2, 16321) This suggestion was made even before.
('61', 9, 1, 3, 16359) But Rajbhoj has put it in a new way.
('61', 9, 1, 4, 16396) He seems to be a thoughtful man.
('61', 9, 1, 5, 16429) He is a fresh worker and is alert, and I also see in him good power of observation.
('61', 9, 1, 6, 16513) He has discrimination, too.
('61', 9, 1, 7, 16541) You should, therefore, have a long talk with him first and if you see some point in his suggestion, make the change suggested by him.
('61', 9, 1, 8, 16675) It was I who insisted on the prayer being kept at 4.20—and I still insist on it—but the lesson of experience should prevail.
('61', 9, 1, 9, 16800) If so many persons require to answer the call of nature before coming to the prayer, 45 minutes should be allowed for the purpose.
('61', 9, 1, 10, 16931) Anyone who does not feel the need may use the time in any way he likes.
('61', 9, 1, 11, 17003) If you decide to make the change, I will make some suggestions about the prayer.
('61', 9, 1, 12, 17084) The chief thing is that you should have a detailed discussion with Rajbhoj.
('61', 9, 1, 13, 17160) His other suggestion is as follows:
('61', 9, 2, 14, 17196) A meeting of all new workers should be held at least twice in a month.
('61', 9, 2, 15, 17267) In these meetings there should be discussions as to how they should work, how they should serve meals, what the Mangalprabhat discourses are about, the significance of the vow of silence, etc.
('61', 9, 2, 16, 17460) I have often observed that the volunteers who serve meals do not do their work courteously and patiently, they throw the vegetables down so carelessly that they fall outside the plate and they let the milk spill over, or serve these items in more than, or even less than, the required quantity.
('61', 9, 2, 17, 17755) Those who are entrusted with washing the floor are so impatient to finish their work that they show no regard for slow eaters and drops of water splash on the latter.
('61', 9, 2, 18, 17922) It is the duty of the chief of this section to explain to the volunteers from time to time how they should work.
('61', 9, 3, 19, 18035) To save time in dictating I have given a Gujarati translation.
('61', 9, 3, 20, 18098) of the sentences instead of the original Hindi.
('61', 9, 3, 21, 18146) However, the translation is literal.

('61', 13, 1, 5, 24961) This is all that I mean.

('61', 13, 4, 11, 25308) 15. LETTER TO P. N. RAJBHOJ
('61', 13, 5, 12, 25336) April 27, 1933
('61', 13, 6, 13, 25351) BHAI RAJBHOJ, Your letter I find is very much to my liking.
('61', 13, 6, 14, 25411) I have written 1
('61', 13, 7, 15, 25428) today to Narandas about this matter.
('61', 13, 7, 16, 25465) Enquire from him fully and then write to me.
('61', 13, 7, 17, 25510) It is bound to pain me if Ramji has not been treated generously.
('61', 13, 7, 18, 25575) Do make yourself well acquainted with Mathuradas 2. Mathuradas is gifted with great tolerance, he does not at all believe in untouchability.
('61', 13, 7, 19, 25716) If in spite of this there has been some shortcoming in the treatment meted out to Ramji it shall of course be rectified.
('61', 13, 7, 20, 25837) Mathuradas is a gentle, sacrificing and sensible man.
('61', 13, 7, 21, 25891) He is quite capable of realizing his own mistakes; open out your heart to him too.
('61', 13, 7, 22, 25974) Now let me give you my experience of R. 3 I was responsible to a great extent in bringing him to the Ashram.
('61', 13, 7, 23, 26083) I am very fond of him and Gangabehn; he has earned well in the Ashram.
('61', 13, 7, 24, 26154) To my knowledge he has been paid adequately for his living.
('61', 13, 7, 25, 26214) I have always instructed that people like R. should be paid liberally; but R. is greedy, hot tempered and suspicious.
('61', 13, 7, 26, 26332) It is extremely difficult to disabuse him of a notion once it gets into his head.
('61', 13, 7, 27, 26414) You may take it that Lakshmidas 4 has become a Harijan.
('61', 13, 7, 28, 26470) Someone asked his daughter Anandi as to her
('61', 13, 8, 29, 26514) 1 Vide “Leter to Narandas Gandhi”, 27 4 1933. 2 Mathuradas P. Asar 3 The name has been omitted.

('61', 14, 0, 1, 26631) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 15
('61', 14, 1, 2, 26674) identity and she called herself a Harijan girl.
('61', 14, 1, 3, 26722) This happened only recently.
('61', 14, 1, 4, 26751) I know it that R. harassed Lakshmidas badly.
('61', 14, 1, 5, 26796) I am not writing this to point out R.’s faults.
('61', 14, 1, 6, 26844) He is just like a son to me.
('61', 14, 1, 7, 26873) But you have evinced such interest in the well being of the Ashram and because I have found you to be simple hearted, I am writing all this so that you may reach the correct conclusion and guide me.
('61', 14, 1, 8, 27072) I have replied 1 to several of your questions in Harijan [Sevak], which you must have seen.
('61', 14, 1, 9, 27164) I now answer the rest of your questions.
('61', 14, 1, 10, 27205) Spiritual progress is possible only through incessant effort.
('61', 14, 1, 11, 27267) The study of philosophical works is helpful in the endeavour but I do not regard it essential because spiritual progress does not depend on the intellect but on the heart.
('61', 14, 1, 12, 27439) The people were unlettered in ancient times but nobody holds the view that none of them could be spiritually advanced.
('61', 14, 1, 13, 27558) We have had hundreds of saints, they were not all learned men.
('61', 14, 1, 14, 27621) Jesus, Mahomed and others were unlettered.
('61', 14, 1, 15, 27664) It should not at all be taken to imply that I am opposed to formal learning but the importance given to it today is beyond proportion.
('61', 14, 1, 16, 27799) Hence I express my opinion whenever questions about learning are asked.
('61', 14, 1, 17, 27871) In my opinion Malaviyaji’s and Dr. Moonje’s aim in teaching the mantras and so on is the same as that of the Arya Samajists, but untouchability has become so deep rooted in the Hindu world that mere teaching of the mantras would not suffice.
('61', 14, 1, 18, 28113) They may teach the mantras, or do whatever they please, but who can bring round the Hindus?
('61', 14, 1, 19, 28205) We have not yet reached the stage when this act will necessarily carry conviction with the public.
('61', 14, 1, 20, 28304) Even the shuddhi performed by the Arya Samaj does not go very far although there is certainly some effect.
('61', 14, 1, 21, 28411) Now we notice that the poison of untouchability has spread among the Indian Christians too.
('61', 14, 1, 22, 28503) God willing, we shall, by strenuous effort and even more strenuous penance, remove this widespread poison.
('61', 14, 1, 23, 28610) The yajna started in September last 2 has not come to an end but is still continuing, it can end only when untouchability is eradicated and no one is considered touchable or untouchable, high or low by birth.
('61', 14, 1, 24, 28819) It is good that letters from Thakkar Bapa and Kakasaheb keep coming.
('61', 14, 1, 25, 28888) Do ask unhesitatingly whatever doubts arise in your mind.
('61', 14, 2, 26, 28946) Blessings from BAPU

('61', 15, 0, 1, 29132) 16 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 15, 1, 2, 29173) 16. WHY NOT `ARYA’?
('61', 15, 2, 3, 29193) A friend writes: 1
('61', 15, 3, 4, 29212) Perhaps the correspondent does not know about the origin of the term ‘Harijan’.
('61', 15, 3, 5, 29292) I must ask him to go through the first number 2 of Harijan Sevak and see how the term originated.
('61', 15, 3, 6, 29390) The term ‘Harijan’ was suggested by a friend who is a Harijan himself and I accepted it.
('61', 15, 3, 7, 29479) The term has not been coined with a view to perpetuating the separate identity of Harijans.
('61', 15, 3, 8, 29571) They have a separate identity today and a separate label to describe them.
('61', 15, 3, 9, 29646) The term ‘untouchable’ savours of contempt.
('61', 15, 3, 10, 29690) We wish to eradicate untouchability and it is not right to go on using the term ‘untouchable’.
('61', 15, 3, 11, 29785) But in so far as untouchables have a distinct identity we must have a name by which to call them.
('61', 15, 3, 12, 29883) Having accepted the necessity for such a name, what name to choose?
('61', 15, 3, 13, 29951) In my view we can find no better name than ‘Harijan’.
('61', 15, 3, 14, 30005) ‘Arya’ will not do because it is the name of a sect.
('61', 15, 3, 15, 30058) A general name ‘Hindu’ is already there.
('61', 15, 3, 16, 30099) The pity is that today a separate identity of the so called untouchables is necessary.
('61', 15, 3, 17, 30186) In Government offices they have a separate list.
('61', 15, 3, 18, 30235) Everywhere they are kept separate.
('61', 15, 3, 19, 30270) Let us pray that this separateness may be done away with so that all of us may become fit to be called ‘Harijans’— men of God.
('61', 15, 3, 20, 30397) A friend rightly said that today caste Hindus have become ‘Arijans’—enemies of Hinduism.
('61', 15, 3, 21, 30486) [From Hindi] Harijan Sevak, 28 4 1933
('61', 15, 4, 22, 30524) 17. FIVE QUESTIONS BY A YOUTH
('61', 15, 5, 23, 30554) A youth asks the following five questions:
('61', 15, 6, 24, 30597) 1. When it is our claim that there is no caste among the Hindus which can be called untouchables, why should we fight unnecessarily over this word?
('61', 15, 7, 25, 30745) 2. When it is our contention that varna is determined by the nature of work, why should we not reform the work of the so called untouchables?
('61', 15, 7, 26, 30887) When their work is degrading, what is the point in fighting with the higher varnas by taking sides with the untouchables?
('61', 15, 8, 27, 31009) 3. When untouchability can be abolished through inter dining and intermarriage, why should we not resort to these too?
('61', 15, 9, 28, 31128) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('61', 15, 9, 29, 31165) The correspondent had suggested that it would be more appropriate to call the untouchables ‘Arya’ rather than ‘Harijans’.
('61', 15, 9, 30, 31287) 2 Dated February 23, vide Why Harijan”, 23 2 1933.
('61', 16, 0, 1, 31338) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 17
('61', 16, 1, 2, 31381) 4. Can the question of temple entry by Harijans be not solved by building separate temples for them?
('61', 16, 2, 3, 31482) 5. Will the orthodox allow Harijans to enter temples when the temple entry Bills are passed?
('61', 16, 3, 4, 31575) I hope you will be able to set my doubts at rest.
('61', 16, 3, 5, 31625) Whether I shall succeed or not, I do not know.
('61', 16, 3, 6, 31672) But I shall certainly try to satisfy that youth and others like him.
('61', 16, 3, 7, 31741) Success lies in the hands of God.
('61', 16, 3, 8, 31775) 1. The claim that there is no such caste as untouchables is made by the reformers, not by the sanatanists.
('61', 16, 3, 9, 31882) Unfortunately, the caste Hindus have dubbed several Hindu castes as untouchables.
('61', 16, 3, 10, 31964) And today in Government offices also these castes are entered as untouchables.
('61', 16, 3, 11, 32043) Therefore, so long as we are not able to convince our sanatanist brothers, it becomes the duty of the reformers to fight for the abolition of this caste born untouchability.
('61', 16, 3, 12, 32217) 2. Whether varna is determined by work or otherwise, is a question which does not arise here.
('61', 16, 3, 13, 32311) Therefore I am leaving it.
('61', 16, 3, 14, 32338) Those who wish to know my opinion in this matter should please read the previous issue 1 of Harijan Sevak.
('61', 16, 3, 15, 32445) So far as the work of the so called untouchables is concerned, if by reform of their work it is meant that they should give up their trades, it is not only unnecessary but also harmful, because these trades are of the nature of public service.
('61', 16, 3, 16, 32689) The washerman, the barber, the cobbler, the Dom 2, the scavenger are all true servants of the people.
('61', 16, 3, 17, 32791) If they were to give up their work, the people would be doomed.
('61', 16, 3, 18, 32855) The reformers believe that in treating these people as untouchables, caste Hindus have made a mistake.
('61', 16, 3, 19, 32958) It is the firm conviction of the reformer that the work of the scavenger and the Dom is sacred.
('61', 16, 3, 20, 33054) It is the duty of the caste Hindus to improve their work.
('61', 16, 3, 21, 33112) The mother removes the excrement and does the washing.
('61', 16, 3, 22, 33167) The doctor cuts flesh, bone and skin.
('61', 16, 3, 23, 33205) But the mother and the doctor do their work neatly and wash themselves afterwards.
('61', 16, 3, 24, 33288) While doing their work they become untouchable.
('61', 16, 3, 25, 33336) We should treat scavengers, etc., in exactly the same way.
('61', 16, 3, 26, 33395) Just as mothers and the doctors are not untouchables by birth, so also the sweeper and others are not born untouchables, even though while doing their work they may be untouchable.
('61', 16, 3, 27, 33576) When we look upon the sweeper and others as our
('61', 16, 4, 28, 33624) 1 Vide “Five Questions on Varnadharma”, 21 4 1933. 2 The lowest among Harijans working at cremation grounds
('61', 17, 0, 1, 33732) 18 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 17, 1, 2, 33773) equals, we will not segregate them from ourselves; on the other hand we shall embrace them with love and we will endeavour to improve their work and their condition.
('61', 17, 1, 3, 33939) Today, in segregating them we perpetrate tyranny on them.
('61', 17, 1, 4, 33997) We do commit violence against them, offend society and bring into contempt the fundamental principles of Hinduism.
('61', 17, 1, 5, 34112) Therefore, it becomes our sacred duty to work for the cause of the Harijans.
('61', 17, 1, 6, 34189) 3. I do not agree that inter dining and intermarriage can bring emancipation to anyone.
('61', 17, 1, 7, 34277) Inter dining and intermarriage are a separate question.
('61', 17, 1, 8, 34333) It has no connection with caste or untouchability.
('61', 17, 1, 9, 34384) It has a separate code.
('61', 17, 1, 10, 34408) In any case, removal of untouchability as we have defined it today does not include inter dining and intermarriage.
('61', 17, 1, 11, 34524) 4. When we consider it our duty to remove untouchability, why should we build separate temples for Harijans?
('61', 17, 1, 12, 34633) They have as much right to worship in common temples as others have.
('61', 17, 1, 13, 34702) 5. No one ever said that with the mere passing of the Bills the orthodox will permit the Harijans to enter temples.
('61', 17, 1, 14, 34818) But the existing law is such that even if one Hindu among the orthodox raises an objection, no public temple can be thrown open to the Harijans.
('61', 17, 1, 15, 34963) When the Bill is passed this obstruction can certainly disappear.
('61', 17, 2, 16, 35029) [From Hindi]
('61', 17, 3, 17, 35042) Harijan Sevak, 28 4 1933

('61', 18, 10, 19, 36556) DEAR FRIEND,
('61', 18, 11, 20, 36569) I have your letter.

('61', 21, 6, 19, 41769) 24. NOTES
('61', 21, 7, 20, 41779) INCONSISTENCIES?
('61', 21, 8, 21, 41796) A correspondent who is a diligent student of my writings finds it difficult to reconcile my recent writings about inter caste dining and inter caste marriage and corresponding writings of some years ago.
('61', 21, 8, 22, 42000) He quotes from my article 2 on “Hinduisum” contributed to Young India of 6th October 1921. I give the quotation below with his omissions:
('61', 21, 9, 23, 42138) Though, therefore, varnashrama is not affected by inter dining and intermarriage, Hinduism does most emphatically discourage inter dining and
('61', 21, 10, 24, 42280) 1 Vide “Telegram to Narandas Gandhi”, 27 4 1933. 2 Vide “Notes”, 6 10 1921.
('61', 22, 0, 1, 42356) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 23
('61', 22, 1, 2, 42399) intermarriage between divisions.
('61', 22, 1, 3, 42432) Hinduism reached the highest limit of self restraint.
('61', 22, 1, 4, 42486) It is undoubtedly a religion of renunciation of the flesh, so that the spirit may be set free.
('61', 22, 1, 5, 42581) By restricting his choice of a bride to a particular group, he exercises rare self restraint.
('61', 22, 1, 6, 42675) Prohibition against intermarriage and inter dining is essential for a rapid evolution of the soul.
('61', 22, 1, 7, 42774) And then he quotes from my statement 1 dated the 4th November last year, which was circulated to the Press.
('61', 22, 1, 8, 42882) I give the quotation again with his omissions:
('61', 22, 2, 9, 42929) Restriction on inter caste dining and inter caste marriage is no part of Hindu religion.
('61', 22, 2, 10, 43018) It is a social custom which crept into Hinduism when perhaps it was in its decline....
('61', 22, 2, 11, 43105) Today these two prohibitions are weakening Hindu society, and emphasis on them has turned the attention of mass mind from the fundamentals which are vital to life’s growth....
('61', 22, 2, 12, 43281) Dining and marriage restrictions stunt Hindu society.
('61', 22, 2, 13, 43335) As I read them with a detached mind, I find no contradiction between the two statements, especially if they are read in their full context.
('61', 22, 2, 14, 43475) In the statement of 1921, I wrote on Hinduism and gave the briefest outline of it.
('61', 22, 2, 15, 43558) On the 4th of November, I had to apply myself to the innumerable castes and caste restrictions.
('61', 22, 2, 16, 43654) The mode of life in the Ashram in 1921 was absolutely the same as it is now.
('61', 22, 2, 17, 43731) Therefore my practice has undergone no change.
('61', 22, 2, 18, 43778) I still believe that restriction imposed by oneself upon inter dining and intermarriage is an act of renunciation of the flesh.
('61', 22, 2, 19, 43906) There is one word that perhaps I would change if I was writing the article of 1921 today.
('61', 22, 2, 20, 43996) Instead of ‘prohibition’, I should repeat the expression used in the same article just a few lines before and say ‘self imposed restriction against intermarriage and inter dining is essential for a rapid evolution of the soul’.
('61', 22, 2, 21, 44224) In spite of my statement of 4th November last, I would say that inter dining and inter caste marriage are in no way essential for the promotion of the spirit of brotherhood or for the removal of untouchability.
('61', 22, 2, 22, 44435) At the same time, a super imposed restriction would undoubtedly stunt the growth of any society, and to link these restrictions to varnadharma or caste is undoubtedly prejudicial to the freedom of the spirit and would make varna a drag upon religion.
('61', 22, 2, 23, 44686) But having said this, I would like to say to this diligent reader of my writings and to others who are interested in them that I am not at all
('61', 22, 3, 24, 44829) 1 Vide “Statement on Untouchability I”, 4 11 1932.
('61', 23, 0, 1, 44880) 24 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 23, 1, 2, 44921) concerned with appearing to be consistent.
('61', 23, 1, 3, 44964) In my search after Truth I have discarded many ideas and learnt many new things.
('61', 23, 1, 4, 45045) Old as I am in age, I have no feeling that I have ceased to grow inwardly or that my growth will stop at the dissolution of the flesh.
('61', 23, 1, 5, 45180) What I am concerned with is my readiness to obey the call of Truth,’ my God, from moment to moment, and therefore, when anybody finds any inconsistency between any two writings of mine, if he has still faith in my sanity, he would do well to choose the later of the two on the same subject.
('61', 23, 2, 6, 45471) Harijan, 29 4 1933
('61', 23, 3, 7, 45490) 25. NOTES
('61', 23, 4, 8, 45500) CARRION EATING
('61', 23, 5, 9, 45515) Hiralal Shah has collected writings from different sources condemnatory of carrion eating and showing how carrion eating has repelled people.
('61', 23, 5, 10, 45657) His first text is from Bhavprakash, Part II, verse 88:
('61', 23, 6, 11, 45712) The flesh of an animal dead from natural causes is debilitating, heavy and liable to cause diarrhoea.
('61', 23, 6, 12, 45814) From Kautilaya he sends me many elaborate rules from which I take the following:
('61', 23, 7, 13, 45895) The flesh of animals which have been killed outside slaughter houses .
('61', 23, 7, 14, 45966) and the flesh of animals which have suddenly died shall not be sold.
('61', 23, 7, 15, 46035) From the Ain i Akbari Sjt.
('61', 23, 7, 16, 46062) Shah sends me several texts recounting ten divisions among Hindus.
('61', 23, 7, 17, 46129) The last division is classed as that of Chandalas, being ‘low caste, eating carrion’.
('61', 23, 7, 18, 46215) The other quotations are from James Forbes’s Oriental Memoirs.
('61', 23, 7, 19, 46278) From these, I take the following:
('61', 23, 8, 20, 46312) From the religious order of Brahmins, I descend to the caste of Chandalas or Pariahs.
('61', 23, 8, 21, 46398) These people are considered so abject as to be employed in the vilest offices, and held in such detestation that no other tribe will touch them; and those Hindus who commit enormous crimes are excommunicated into this caste, which is considered to be a punishment worse than death.
('61', 23, 8, 22, 46680) Describing the Pulaiyas the author says:
('61', 23, 9, 23, 46721) Constant poverty and accumulated misery have entirely debased the human form, and given a squalid and savage appearance to these unhappy beings.
('61', 23, 9, 24, 46866) Yet debased and oppressed as the Pulaiyas are, there exists throughout
('61', 24, 0, 1, 46937) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 25
('61', 24, 1, 2, 46980) India a caste called Pariahs, still more abject and wretched.
('61', 24, 1, 3, 47042) If a Pulaiya by any accident touches a Pariah, he must perform a variety of ceremonies and go through many ablutions, before he can be cleansed from the impurity .
('61', 24, 1, 4, 47206) nor do they eat together; although the only difference in their epicurean banquet is that the Pulaiyas eat of all animal food, exceptbeef, and sometimes of that which dies of itself, the Pariahs not only feast upon dead carcasses, but eat beef and carrion of every kind.
('61', 24, 2, 5, 47477) Harijan, 29 4 1933
('61', 24, 3, 6, 47496) 26. A MODEL TEMPLE
('61', 24, 4, 7, 47515) It was impossible that side by side with the movement for temple entry by Harijans there should not be a demand for temple reform.
('61', 24, 4, 8, 47646) The modern Hindu temple is a hot bed of superstition, as are more or less other ‘Houses of God’.
('61', 24, 4, 9, 47743) I published 1 the other day a letter from an American friend, gently pleading with me not to have anything to do with the temple entry movement.
('61', 24, 4, 10, 47888) A friend who is a devout follower of Islam has carried on a long correspondence with me, trying to do with me in his own way what the American friend did in his own.
('61', 24, 4, 11, 48054) There is undoubtedly a great deal of substance in what they have said.
('61', 24, 4, 12, 48125) But I have not been able to subscribe to their corollarythat the remedy for the abuse lies in the destruction of temples.
('61', 24, 4, 13, 48247) But by far the largest number of persons believe in the reform, not destruction, of’ temples.
('61', 24, 4, 14, 48341) I mentioned only the other day an ambitious scheme set on foot for a model temple in Rajkot.
('61', 24, 4, 15, 48434) 2 Several correspondents have taken me to task for advocating temple entry for Harijans without emphasizing the necessity of temple reform.
('61', 24, 4, 16, 48574) There is no doubt that temple reform is necessary.
('61', 24, 4, 17, 48625) But here, again, there is need for caution.
('61', 24, 4, 18, 48669) Some of them think that it is possible to replace all the existing temples with new ones.
('61', 24, 4, 19, 48759) I do not share that view.
('61', 24, 4, 20, 48785) All temples will never be alike.
('61', 24, 4, 21, 48818) They will always vary, as they have done in the past, with the varying human needs.
('61', 24, 4, 22, 48902) What the reformer should be concerned with is a radical change more in the inward spirit than in the outward form If’ the first is changed the second will take care of’ itself: If’ the first remains unchanged, the second, no matter how
('61', 24, 5, 23, 49138) 1 Vide “Are Temples Necessary?”, 11 3 1933. 2 Vide also “A Model Temple”, 29 4 1933.
('61', 25, 0, 1, 49223) 26 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 25, 1, 2, 49264) radically changed, will be like a whited sepulchre.
('61', 25, 1, 3, 49316) A mausoleum, however beautiful, is a tomb and not a mosque, and a bare plot of consecrated ground may be a real Temple of God.
('61', 25, 1, 4, 49443) Therefore the first desideratum is the priest.
('61', 25, 1, 5, 49490) My ideal priest must be a man of God.
('61', 25, 1, 6, 49528) He must be a true servant of the people.
('61', 25, 1, 7, 49569) He should have the qualifications of a guide, friend and philosopher to those among whom he is officiating.
('61', 25, 1, 8, 49677) He must be a whole timer with the least possible needs and personal ties.
('61', 25, 1, 9, 49751) He should be versed in the Shastras.
('61', 25, 1, 10, 49788) His whole concern will be to look after the welfare of his people.
('61', 25, 1, 11, 49855) I have not drawn a fanciful picture.
('61', 25, 1, 12, 49892) It is almost true to life.
('61', 25, 1, 13, 49919) It is based on the recollection of my childhood.
('61', 25, 1, 14, 49968) The priest I am recalling was looked up to by the prince and the people.
('61', 25, 1, 15, 50041) They flocked round him for advice and guidance in the time of their need.
('61', 25, 1, 16, 50115) If the sceptic says such a priest is hard to find nowadays, he would be partly right.
('61', 25, 1, 17, 50201) But I would ask the reformer to wait for building the temple of his ideal till he finds his priest.
('61', 25, 1, 18, 50301) Meanwhile let him cultivate in himself the virtues he will have in the priest of his imagination.
('61', 25, 1, 19, 50399) Let him expect these from the priests of existing temples.
('61', 25, 1, 20, 50458) In other words, by his gentle and correct conduct, let him expect his immediate surroundings with the need of the times and let him have faith that his thought, surcharged with his own correct conduct, will act more powerfully than the mightiest dynamo.
('61', 25, 1, 21, 50712) Let him not be impatient to see the result in a day.
('61', 25, 1, 22, 50765) A thought may take years of conduct to evolve the requisite power.
('61', 25, 1, 23, 50832) What are years or generations in the life of a great reform?
('61', 25, 1, 24, 50893) Now, perhaps, the reader will follow my view of a model temple.
('61', 25, 1, 25, 50957) I can present him with no architect’s plan and specification.
('61', 25, 1, 26, 51019) Time is not ripe for it.
('61', 25, 1, 27, 51044) But that does not baffle me and it need not baffle the reformer.
('61', 25, 1, 28, 51109) He can choose the site for his future temple.
('61', 25, 1, 29, 51155) It must be as extensive as he can get it.
('61', 25, 1, 30, 51197) It need not be in the heart of a village or a city.
('61', 25, 1, 31, 51249) It should be easily accessible to the Harijans and the other poor and yet it must not be in insanitary surroundings.
('61', 25, 1, 32, 51366) If possible, it should be higher than its surroundings.
('61', 25, 1, 33, 51422) In any case, I would aim at making the plinth of the actual temple as high as possible.
('61', 25, 1, 34, 51510) And on this site I should select my plot for daily worship.
('61', 25, 1, 35, 51570) Round this will come into being a school, a dispensary, a library, secular and religious.
('61', 25, 1, 36, 51660) The school may serve also as a meeting or debating hall.
('61', 25, 1, 37, 51717) I should have a dharmsala or guest house connected with the temple.
('61', 25, 1, 38, 51785) Each one of
('61', 26, 0, 1, 51797) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 27
('61', 26, 1, 2, 51840) these will be a separate institution and yet subordinate to the temple and may be built simultaneously or one after another as circumstances and funds may permit.
('61', 26, 1, 3, 52003) The buildings may or may not be substantial.
('61', 26, 1, 4, 52048) If labour is voluntary, as it well may be, with mud and straw a beginning may be made at once.
('61', 26, 1, 5, 52143) But the temple is not yet built.
('61', 26, 1, 6, 52176) The foundation was laid when the site was procured, the plot for the temple was selected and the first prayer was offered.
('61', 26, 1, 7, 52299) For the Bhagavata says, “Wherever people meet and utter His name from their hearts, there God dwells, there is His temple.” The building, the deity, the consecration, is the province of the priest.
('61', 26, 1, 8, 52497) When he is found, he will set about his task, but the temple began its existence from the time of the first prayer.
('61', 26, 1, 9, 52613) And if it was the prayer of true men and women, its continuous progress was assured.
('61', 26, 1, 10, 52698) So much for the temple of the future.
('61', 26, 1, 11, 52736) The reader who cares to study the Rajkot scheme will find that the outward form of my model temple materially corresponds to that in the scheme.
('61', 26, 1, 12, 52881) Indeed, there is nothing new in my idea or the Rajkot scheme.
('61', 26, 1, 13, 52943) The village temples of yore had almost all the adjuncts suggested by me.
('61', 26, 1, 14, 53016) But we must also deal with the existing temples.
('61', 26, 1, 15, 53065) They can become real Houses of God today, if the worshippers will insist on the priests conforming to the ideal presented by me.

('61', 26, 3, 17, 53213) 27. HUMAN MANUFACTURE [ I]
('61', 26, 4, 18, 53240) The section regarding Depressed Classes in the Bengal Census Report, Part I, is an illuminating document, from which at the moment I reproduce only paragraphs 2 and 3 below, and I hope to occupy the reader’s attention over this portion of the report for a week or two longer.
('61', 26, 5, 19, 53516) MEANING OF THE TERM ‘DEPRESSED CLASSES’
('61', 26, 6, 20, 53556) The expression ‘Depressed Classes’ is of comparatively recent coinage and is in many respects unfortunate.
('61', 26, 6, 21, 53663) It does not translate an y actual vernacular term in common use in Bengal, nor does it describe any class the members of which can be defined with accuracy.
('61', 26, 6, 22, 53820) It is a term in itself indefinite.
('61', 26, 6, 23, 53855) In European countries it is applied to the chronically indigent portion of the population and connotes an economic condition.
('61', 26, 6, 24, 53981) It can be applied anthropologically in a psychological sense to describe that state of mind engendered in a primitive
('61', 27, 0, 1, 54099) 28 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 27, 1, 2, 54140) people when it finds itself in contact with a dominant society based upon principles entirely different from and disregarding the traditionally accepted sactions of tribal life.
('61', 27, 1, 3, 54318) This psychological condition has been convincingly put forward as one at least of the elements leading to the depopulation of Melenesia and it has an interesting counterpart in the ‘discouragement’ from which Mr. George Bernard Shaw makes visitors to the island die off in contact with the civilization of the ancients in “Back to Methuselah”.
('61', 27, 1, 4, 54662) In general use, however, the term in India, though not applying to exactly similar strata of population in different parts, is used to describe those members of the community who in common social estimation are considered to be inferior, degraded, outcaste, or not fit in any way for social and religious intercourse on reasonably equal terms with members of the clean or higher castes.
('61', 27, 1, 5, 55049) It represents a problem which arises only within the fold of Hinduism, namely, the problem of those Hindu groups who by the accident of birth are denied and never can by any individual merit achieve social consideration or spiritual benefits which are the birth right without consideration of personal merit equally of all persons born into the higher castes.
('61', 27, 2, 6, 55409) THE CRITERION OF THE DEPRESSED CLASSES
('61', 27, 3, 7, 55448) It is, however, by no means a simple matter to devise a satisfactory criterion by which to distinguish the Depressed Classes.
('61', 27, 3, 8, 55574) The problem itself being essentially social and religious, the criteria, which have been at various times suggested, themselves depend upon social observance or social precedence.
('61', 27, 3, 9, 55754) During the census of 1901 the castes in Bengal were distinguished into Seven groups upon an elaborate classification.
('61', 27, 3, 10, 55872) The first group contained Brahmins only as the acknowledged superiors of all other classes in the caste hierarchy.
('61', 27, 3, 11, 55987) In the second group were placed castes whose respectability was never in question and who are either twice born or were held to be superior to all other Shudra castes.
('61', 27, 3, 12, 56155) A third group consisted of the so callcd navashakha, or nine branches, now indeed containing more than nine groups but all characterized by being held worthy to offer water the drinking of which would not pollute the higher classes.
('61', 27, 3, 13, 56388) Below this third group were distinguished a fourth containing clean castes with degraded Brahmins; a fifth containing castes lower than group four whose water is not usually accepted, a sixth comprised low castes abstaining from beef, pork and fowls, and seventh embracing castes by whom forbidden food were eaten and who pursue the most degraded occupation as scavengers, etc.
('61', 27, 3, 14, 56766) In 1911 the Census Commissioner for India directed provincial superintendents to enumerate castes and tribes returned as Hindus who do not conform to certain standards or are subject to certain disabilities, “leaving the reader to draw his own inferences”.
('61', 27, 3, 15, 57023) They were
('61', 28, 0, 1, 57033) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 29
('61', 28, 1, 2, 57076) asked to prepare a list of all but the minor castes which qua castes:
('61', 28, 2, 3, 57146) 1. deny the supremacy of the Brahmins;
('61', 28, 3, 4, 57185) 2. do not receive the mantra from a Brahmin or other recognized Hindu guru;
('61', 28, 4, 5, 57261) 3. deny the authority of the Vedas;
('61', 28, 5, 6, 57297) 4. do not worship the great Hindu gods;
('61', 28, 6, 7, 57337) 5. are not served by good Brahmins as family priests;
('61', 28, 7, 8, 57391) 6. have no Brahmin priests at all;
('61', 28, 8, 9, 57426) 7. are denied access to the interior of Hindu temples;
('61', 28, 9, 10, 57481) 8. cause pollution (a,) by touch, (b) within a certain distance;
('61', 28, 10, 11, 57546) 9. bury their dead; or
('61', 28, 11, 12, 57569) 10. eat beef and do not do reverence to cow.
('61', 28, 12, 13, 57614) The enquiry was intended to furnish material, if possible, from which an answer could be given to the difficult question: `Who is a Hindu?’ Up to 1916 in Bengal at least the expression ‘Depressed Classes’ was unknown.
('61', 28, 12, 14, 57832) In 1916 however the Bengal Government was invited to prepare a list of the Depressed Classes and submitted a list including certain criminal tribes and aboriginals and amounting in all to 31 groups This list was used by the Commissioner for Education in writing his quinquennial report on the progress of education in India for the years 1912 17. The term thusintroduced remained and both the Calcutta University Commission (1917 19) and the Census Report for 1921 contained lists of the Depressed Classes.
('61', 28, 12, 15, 58339) In neither of these last instances, however, was any clear criterion set forth to show on what grounds the groups were included.
('61', 28, 12, 16, 58468) The Indian Statutory Commission, without giving any definite criterion, referred to them as the “lowest castes recognized as being within the Hindu religious and social system .
('61', 28, 12, 17, 58646) Their essential characteristics is that according to the tenets of orthodox Hinduism, they are, though within the Hindu system, untouchable—that is to say, that for all other Hindus they cause pollution by touch and defile food and water.
('61', 28, 12, 18, 58885) They are denied access to the interior of an ordinary Hindu temple (though this is also true of some who would not be classed as ‘untouchable’).
('61', 28, 12, 19, 59030) They are not only the lowest in the Hindu social and religious system, but with few individual exceptions are also at the bottom of the economic scale and are generally quite uneducated.
('61', 28, 12, 20, 59217) In the villages they are normally segregated in a Separate quarter and not infrequently eat food which would not be touched by any section of the Hindu community.”
('61', 28, 13, 21, 59381) At a later date the Franchise Committee, driven to lay down simple criteria, adopted No.
('61', 28, 13, 22, 59470) 7 and 8 of the distinctions made in the Census Report of 1911. For Bengal these distinctions have been elaborated on behalf of the Depressed Classes Association as follows:
('61', 29, 0, 1, 59643) 30 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 29, 1, 2, 59684) (a) castes from whose hands the three high castes or even the navashakha (that is, the caste Hindus) would not accept water and whose presence either in the kitchen or in the room where water and cooked food are kept would pollute the same according to their estimation;
('61', 29, 2, 3, 59955) (b) castes who would not be allowed into any public temple and whose presence there would defile articles of worship;
('61', 29, 3, 4, 60073) (c) castes who would not be allowed to enter or to have their meals inside the dining room of an hotel or eating house run by caste Hindus;
('61', 29, 4, 5, 60213) (d) castes at whose socio religious functions Shrotriya Brahmins (that is, the priests) officiating in such functions in the house of the caste Hindus would not officiate; and
('61', 29, 5, 6, 60389) (e) castes who would not be served by the Shrotriya Napit (that is, the barber) whose services are necessary in various socio religious functions of the Hindus.

('61', 29, 8, 9, 60589) Seth Ghanshyamdas Birla writes to me saying that he has received from Lala Kamalapat a donation of Rs. 3,000 and a donation of Rs. 2,000 from Seth Rameshwar Prasad Bagla, both of Cawnpore.
('61', 29, 8, 10, 60778) These can be utilized for the David Scheme or general education work, the only condition being that the donations will be utilized for the Harijans of that Province.

('61', 29, 8, 12, 61082) This amount also is available for the David Scheme or for general education work amongst the Harijans, no matter in what part of India.
('61', 29, 8, 13, 61218) There is not, therefore, any dearth, at least for the present, of scholarships for suitable Harijans, and Seth Ghanshyamdas is bringing into being a special educational board for the examination and selection of Harijan candidates for scholarship, more especially of those coming under the David Scheme.

('61', 35, 3, 4, 73522) 31. A SACRED ACTIVITY
('61', 35, 4, 5, 73544) I give below an interesting but touching account 2 from a Harijan worker’s experiences which I have been giving from time to time in these columns.
('61', 35, 4, 6, 73692) I will not spoil the picture by writing more on it.
('61', 35, 4, 7, 73744) It is possible that because of a long standing bad habit some may feel disgust on reading this.
('61', 35, 4, 8, 73840) Medical books are full of such descriptions.
('61', 35, 4, 9, 73885) He who does not read them will not master the science of biology.
('61', 35, 4, 10, 73951) Moreover, no one should be shocked because I have described the activity as a sacred one.
('61', 35, 4, 11, 74041) That activity itself may appear dirty like that of removing filth.
('61', 35, 4, 12, 74108) But just as removal of filth is for purposes of purification, this activity is meant for cleaning or purifying society.
('61', 35, 4, 13, 74228) Innocent city dwellers do not realize that they won’t be able to live for a moment if these workers do not perform many activities which we despise.
('61', 35, 4, 14, 74377) [From Gujarati] Harijanbandhu, 30 4 1933
('61', 35, 5, 15, 74418) 32. A MODEL TEMPLE
('61', 35, 6, 16, 74437) When Smt.
('61', 35, 6, 17, 74447) Vijayalakshmi Pandit set foot in Kathiawar for Harijan welfare work, a scheme to build a model temple in Rajkot was discussed.
('61', 35, 6, 18, 74574) I have already made a reference to this.
('61', 35, 6, 19, 74615) Shri Parashuram Gopal Masurekar, the well known lawyer of the place, had taken a leading part in the deliberations.
('61', 35, 6, 20, 74731) Under his signature a public appeal has been issued in connection with the scheme.
('61', 35, 6, 21, 74814) The following point 3
('61', 35, 7, 22, 74836) claims our attention.
('61', 35, 8, 23, 74858) 1 Keshav Gandhi, son of Maganlal Gandhi 2 This is not translated here.
('61', 35, 8, 24, 74929) The correspondent had described the process of skinning animals.
('61', 35, 8, 25, 74994) 3 This is not translated here.
('61', 35, 8, 26, 75025) The scheme proposed a temple devoid of any decorations or jewellery and one which was meant for the entire Hindu population, irrespective of caste or community.
('61', 35, 8, 27, 75186) The priest would be a person who did not believe in untouchability.
('61', 35, 8, 28, 75254) And as the aim of the temple was to be service, there should be a night school for adults, a library, a free dispensary, and a religious school attached to it.
('61', 36, 0, 1, 75414) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 37
('61', 36, 1, 2, 75457) It is mentioned in the statement that even some from among those who believe in untouchability have welcomed the scheme and have also agreed to give financial help.
('61', 36, 1, 3, 75622) Shri Masurekar deserves congratulations on this scheme.
('61', 36, 1, 4, 75678) I hope that he will translate it into reality.
('61', 36, 1, 5, 75725) It should not be that the beginning would be made only when many people join the scheme.
('61', 36, 1, 6, 75814) To my mind, a model temple means an ideal priest.
('61', 36, 1, 7, 75864) Bricks and mortar do not make a model temple.
('61', 36, 1, 8, 75910) If the priest is good, even a rough hut will shine forth and earnest devotees will find solace there.
('61', 36, 1, 9, 76012) And when there is no such priest, even a marble temple inlaid with mosaic would be a desolate structure.
('61', 36, 1, 10, 76117) There are today a number of such famous ruins in India.
('61', 36, 1, 11, 76173) There are such ancient places in Mysore which at one time must have been great temples.
('61', 36, 1, 12, 76261) The caves of Karla, Ajanta and Gharapuri were temples once.
('61', 36, 1, 13, 76321) God has disappeared from there because of want of the priest and instead of devotees connoisseurs of art go there to see the works of art.
('61', 36, 1, 14, 76460) Hence I hope: that the proposed temple at Rajkot will get a good priest.
('61', 36, 1, 15, 76533) But whether such a priest is available or not, the scheme for the temple can be taken up for execution from today.
('61', 36, 1, 16, 76648) The first task is to obtain a vast plot of land in the open.
('61', 36, 1, 17, 76709) I would regard it as advantageous if it is at a little distance from the village.
('61', 36, 1, 18, 76791) After selecting a plot for the temple, other institutions mentioned in the scheme can be constructed there.
('61', 36, 1, 19, 76899) To my mind, the foundation stone of the temple will have been laid if the people working in this institution get together in the plot reserved for the temple and repeat the name of God, because there is a dictum in the Bhagavata that God dwells where five people get together and repeat the name of Vasudeva.
('61', 36, 1, 20, 77208) And where He dwells, there the temple stands.
('61', 36, 1, 21, 77254) The Rajkot scheme for the temple is an excellent one whether it materializes or not, whether it materializes early or late.
('61', 36, 1, 22, 77378) Everyone can help implement it to a certain extent.

('61', 37, 4, 6, 78275) 33. STATEMENT ON FAST 1
('61', 37, 5, 7, 78299) [April 30, 1933] 2
('61', 37, 6, 8, 78318) A tempest has been raging within me for some days.
('61', 37, 6, 9, 78369) I have been struggling against it.
('61', 37, 6, 10, 78404) On the eve of the ‘Harijan Day’ the voice became insistent, and said, ‘why don’t you do it?’ I resisted it.
('61', 37, 6, 11, 78512) But the resistance was vain.
('61', 37, 6, 12, 78541) And the resolution was made to go on an unconditional and irrevocable fast for twentyone days, commencing from Monday noon the 8th May and ending on Monday noon the 29th May.
('61', 37, 6, 13, 78716) As I look back upon the immediate past, many are the causes too sacred to mention that must have precipitated the fast.
('61', 37, 6, 14, 78836) But they are all connected with the great Harijan cause.
('61', 37, 6, 15, 78893) The fast is against nobody in particular and against everybody who wants to participate in the joy of it, without for the time being having to fast himself or herself.
('61', 37, 6, 16, 79061) But it is particularly against myself.
('61', 37, 6, 17, 79100) It is a heart prayer for the purification of self and associates, for greater vigilance and watchfulness.
('61', 37, 6, 18, 79206) But nobody who appreciates the step about to be taken is to join me.
('61', 37, 6, 19, 79275) Any such fast will be a torture of themselves and of me.
('61', 37, 6, 20, 79332) Let this fast, however, be a preparation for many such fasts to be taken by purer and more deserving persons than myself.
('61', 37, 6, 21, 79454) During all these months since September last, I have been studying the corres pondence and literature and holding prolonged discussions with men and women, learned and ignorant, Harijans and non Harijans.
('61', 37, 6, 22, 79659) The evil is far greater than even I had thought it to be.
('61', 37, 6, 23, 79717) It will not be eradicated by money, external organization and even political power for Harijans, though all these three are necessary.
('61', 37, 6, 24, 79852) But to be effective, they must follow or at least accompany inward wealth, inward organization and inward power, in other words, self purification.
('61', 37, 6, 25, 80000) This can only come by fasting and prayer.
('61', 37, 6, 26, 80042) We may not approach the God of Truth in the arrogance of strength, but in the meekness of the weak and the helpless.
('61', 37, 7, 27, 80159) 1 This was published under the title, “Fast for Purification”.
('61', 37, 7, 28, 80222) 2 From The Bombay Chronicle, 1 5 1933; also A.I.C.C. File No.
('61', 38, 0, 1, 80284) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 39
('61', 38, 1, 2, 80327) But the mere fast of the body is nothing without the will behind it.
('61', 38, 1, 3, 80396) It must be a genuine confession of the inner fast, an irrepressible longing to express truth and nothing but truth.
('61', 38, 1, 4, 80512) therefore, those only are privileged to fast for the cause of truth who have worked for it and who have love in them even for opponents, who are free from animal passion and who have abjured earthly possessions and ambition.
('61', 38, 1, 5, 80737) No one, therefore, may undertake, without previous preparation and discipline, the fast I have foreshadowed.
('61', 38, 1, 6, 80846) Let there be no misunderstanding about the impending fast.
('61', 38, 1, 7, 80905) I have no desire to die.
('61', 38, 1, 8, 80930) I want to live for the cause, though I hope I am equally prepared to die for it.
('61', 38, 1, 9, 81011) But I need for me and my fellow workers greater purity, greater application and dedication.
('61', 38, 1, 10, 81103) I want more workers of unassailable purity.
('61', 38, 1, 11, 81147) Shocking cases of impurity have come under my notice.
('61', 38, 1, 12, 81201) I would like my fast to be an urgent appeal to such people to leave the cause alone.
('61', 38, 1, 13, 81286) I know that many of my sanatanist friends and others think that the movement is a deep political game.
('61', 38, 1, 14, 81389) How I wish this fast would convince them that it is purely religious.
('61', 38, 1, 15, 81459) If God has more service to take from this body, He will hold it together despite deprivation of earthly food.
('61', 38, 1, 16, 81569) He will send me spiritual food.
('61', 38, 1, 17, 81601) But He works through earthly agents, and everyone who believes in the imperative necessity of removing untouchability will send me the food I need, by working to the best of his or her ability for the due and complete fulfilment of the pledge given to Harijans in the name of caste Hindus.
('61', 38, 1, 18, 81891) Let co workers not get agitated over the coming fast.
('61', 38, 1, 19, 81945) They should feel strengthened by it.
('61', 38, 1, 20, 81982) They must not leave their post of duty; and those who have temporarily retired for much needed rest or for being cured of ailments are as much at the post as healthy workers serving in their respective quarters.
('61', 38, 1, 21, 82194) No one should come to me unless it be for necessary consultation on matters connected with the movement.
('61', 38, 1, 22, 82299) It is, I hope, needless for me to pray to friends that they will not ask me to postpone, abandon or vary the approaching fast in any way whatsoever.
('61', 38, 1, 23, 82448) I ask them to believe me that the fast has come to me literally as described above.
('61', 38, 1, 24, 82532) I, therefore, ask friends in India and all the world over to pray for me and with me that I may safely pass through the ordeal and that, whether I live or die, the cause for which the fast is to be undertaken may prosper.
('61', 39, 0, 1, 82754) 40 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 39, 1, 2, 82795) And may I ask my sanatanist friends to pray that, whatever be the result of the fast for me, the golden lid that hides Truth may be removed?
('61', 39, 2, 3, 82936) Harijan, 6 5 1933
('61', 39, 3, 4, 82954) 34. DISCUSSION WITH VALLABHBHAI PATEL1
('61', 39, 4, 5, 82993) April 30, 1933
('61', 39, 5, 6, 83008) For some time now, I have been vacillating between twentyone days and forty days.
('61', 39, 5, 7, 83090) After all, does one express, can one express, all one’s thoughts to others?
('61', 39, 5, 8, 83166) Three days have passed since I lost my sleep.
('61', 39, 5, 9, 83212) Could it be that I cannot sleep?
('61', 39, 5, 10, 83245) But, for the last three days I have not been getting any sleep for hours at a stretch; I might get up at two in the morning and start work but not once would I doze while I dictated in the morning, nor even would I want to stretch my limbs, as if for the last three days I were preparing myself for the great deluge!
('61', 39, 5, 11, 83562) It is difficult to say since when the excitement started.
('61', 39, 5, 12, 83620) On many occasions, however, thought of a fast would repeatedly come to my mind and I would drive it away.
('61', 39, 5, 13, 83726) In the night when I retired I had no idea that something was coming up today.
('61', 39, 5, 14, 83804) But after eleven I woke up, I watched the stars, repeated Ramanama but the same thought would persistently come to my mind: ‘If you have grown so restless, why don’t you undertake the fast?
('61', 39, 5, 15, 83994) Do it.’ The inner dialogue went on for quite some time.
('61', 39, 5, 16, 84050) At half past twelve came the clear, unmistakable voice: ‘You must undertake the fast.’ That was all.
('61', 39, 5, 17, 84151) Now having resolved to make it a twenty one days’ fast, I took no time in deciding that as a prisoner I should undertake it after eight days’ [notice].
('61', 39, 5, 18, 84303) Without it the task of Harijan service is just impossible.
('61', 39, 5, 19, 84362) If I don’t do this much the rot in Harijan work will reach the heart and destroy it altogether.
('61', 39, 5, 20, 84458) I, therefore, got up and immediately began to write out the statement 2 and I, had just finished the last sentence when you came up for the prayers.

('61', 45, 7, 27, 94718) 45. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS 2
('61', 45, 8, 28, 94747) May 1, 1933
('61', 45, 9, 29, 94759) Almost the first question asked by the Pressmen was, whether it was possible for him under any circumstances to abandon his fast.
('61', 45, 9, 30, 94889) Gandhiji replied:
('61', 45, 10, 31, 94907) 1 Literally, ‘of steady intellect’.
('61', 45, 10, 32, 94943) For the full meaning of the phrase.
('61', 45, 10, 33, 94979) 2 The source had reported: “Gandhiji received Pressmen inside the jail cell, where, for the past few days, he has been holding his office.
('61', 45, 10, 34, 95118) The mango tree is not providing the requisite protection against the increasing heat.”
('61', 46, 0, 1, 95205) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 47
('61', 46, 1, 2, 95248) Humanly speaking, there is absolutely no possibility of my abandoning the fast.
('61', 46, 2, 3, 95328) This was followed by more questions on his statement.
('61', 46, 2, 4, 95382) Asked, if he could throw light on the “shocking cases of impurity” referred to in his statement, Gandhiji
('61', 46, 3, 5, 95488) said that it was not possible for him to do that; but he had no grievance against anybody in particular and, if he had any grievance at all, it was against himself.
('61', 46, 3, 6, 95653) Gandhiji proceeded: I went to bed that night without the slightest feeling that I would take such a step.
('61', 46, 3, 7, 95759) No single event can be held responsible for this decision, but it undoubtedly is the result of the accumulation of a long series of events extending over a fairly long period.
('61', 46, 3, 8, 95935) It is not that I was blind to them before.
('61', 46, 3, 9, 95978) They were producing their silent and unconscious effect on my mind.
('61', 46, 4, 10, 96046) Replying to another question, the Mahatma said: I do expect that my fast is merely a precursor of many such fasts, and if I survive this, I may feel called upon to undertake another fast.
('61', 46, 5, 11, 96234) All these twenty one days I will be sipping Ramarasa 2. If it does not sustain me, how is the juice of mosambis going to help?
('61', 46, 5, 12, 96361) One who wants to destroy the Ravana of untouchability must partake of Ramarasa every now and then.
('61', 46, 5, 13, 96460) And if my devotion to Rama is sincere—and it certainly is—He will not let my body drop for I still wish that Rama will sustain this body dedicated to Him.
('61', 46, 5, 14, 96615) You Harijans, however, must remember one thing.
('61', 46, 5, 15, 96663) You should be amenable to the infallible remedy which I have adopted.
('61', 46, 5, 16, 96733) Realize that for you too there is no other way.
('61', 46, 5, 17, 96781) And let the ‘touchable’ Hindus say and do what they like; you on your part should cleanse your body and soul and become true Harijans.
('61', 46, 5, 18, 96916) Your saviour as well as mine is the Lord above.
('61', 46, 6, 19, 96964) It would be blasphemy to regard me as your saviour.
('61', 46, 6, 20, 97016) And I said to you that the love of God is life sustaining, but then, if you would allow me to say it, what does it matter if the body withers away?
('61', 46, 6, 21, 97164) Do not dead men continue to do work?

('61', 47, 1, 2, 97723) At this stage, it is necessary for the public to understand the very vital difference between the September fast and the impending one.
('61', 47, 1, 3, 97859) The September fast was a conditional one, made for a particular purpose.
('61', 47, 1, 4, 97932) But in this case, it is not directed to any concrete purpose at all.
('61', 47, 1, 5, 98001) Therefore, this fast can be undertaken at any moment and it is after the manner, common enough in Hinduism.
('61', 47, 1, 6, 98109) Whenever a great reformation and revival is going on, people in order to ensure purity and acceleration of their object, undertake a fast.
('61', 47, 1, 7, 98248) Such a fast is universally acknowledged to be a good thing in itself.
('61', 47, 1, 8, 98318) It is its own justification and my fast claims no more merit.
('61', 47, 1, 9, 98380) I might have undertaken it without the tussle I was engaged in, but perhaps, I had no courage.
('61', 47, 1, 10, 98475) I was weighed down with the tremendous responsibility and, therefore, though the prompting came to me more than once, I resisted it.
('61', 47, 1, 11, 98608) A religious movement does not depend for its success on the intellectual or material resources of its sponsors, but it depends solely upon the spiritual resources, and fasting is the best known method of adding to these resources.
('61', 47, 1, 12, 98839) Not every fast brings about the desired result.
('61', 47, 1, 13, 98887) I have given some of the conditions in my statement, and it is claimed in my statement, and it is claimed by those who have conducted religious movements that intellectual, material and other things follow spiritual capital but should never be independent of it.
('61', 47, 2, 14, 99150) Asked, if he hoped to survive the 21 days’ fast, Gandhiji reassuringly said: Oh!
('61', 47, 2, 15, 99231) I survived the twenty one days’ fast 1 that was undertaken ten years ago.
('61', 47, 2, 16, 99305) Weaker men than myself have undertaken longer fasts and survived.
('61', 47, 2, 17, 99371) Spiritual sustenance has great possibilities.
('61', 47, 3, 18, 99417) At this stage, Gandhiji was reminded of his condition during the September fast when six days’ fasting brought him almost to the verge of collapse, but he humorously replied: The age of miracles is not yet over.
('61', 47, 4, 19, 99629) He felt more than optimistic about his ability to go through the ordeal.
('61', 47, 4, 20, 99702) Asked whether he would remain in Poona in case Government released him, Gandhiji replied that it was very difficult for him to say that, because he did not contemplate any release.
('61', 47, 5, 21, 99883) To a suggestion that his fast, which coincided with the sitting of the Joint Select Committee, would be taken as an act dictated by political motives, Gandhiji replied that he had not embarked on the fast voluntarily.
('61', 47, 5, 22, 100101) It had not been in his plan.

('61', 67, 1, 2, 135745) 73. LETTER TO PREMABEHN KANTAK
('61', 67, 2, 3, 135776) May 3, 1933
('61', 67, 4, 4, 135788) I got your heart rending letter.
('61', 67, 4, 5, 135821) How shall I calm you?
('61', 67, 4, 6, 135843) It is extremely difficult for me to let you go.
('61', 67, 4, 7, 135891) I have built high hopes on you.
('61', 67, 4, 8, 135923) But it would be selfish on my part and harm the ideals of the Ashram if I pressed anybody to stay on in it when it was not for his or her good to do so.
('61', 67, 4, 9, 136076) The Ashram represents the sum of the good of all its inmates and the means of its achievement, hence your good and that of the Ashram cannot be mutually contradictory.
('61', 67, 4, 10, 136244) If, however, you feel that this is not so in so far as I am concerned, I have no doubt at all that you should leave the Ashram.
('61', 67, 4, 11, 136372) If your fast is still continuing, I want that you should give it up.
('61', 67, 4, 12, 136441) I will accept whatever decision you arrive at.
('61', 67, 4, 13, 136488) I will not make the final decision; it will have to be made by you.
('61', 67, 4, 14, 136556) As I have loaded Narandas with excessive responsibility, he has loaded you.
('61', 67, 4, 15, 136632) He has not broken down.
('61', 67, 4, 16, 136656) If you break down, I would be unhappy, for I, too, would be as much responsible for that result as anybody else.
('61', 67, 4, 17, 136769) Narandas was helpless.
('61', 67, 4, 18, 136792) Even if you decide to stay on, you ought to reduce the burden on yourself.
('61', 67, 4, 19, 136867) It is contrary to dharma to accept more work than one can do; there is pride, too, in doing so.
('61', 67, 4, 20, 136963) There is greater harm in doing that than in eating more than one can digest.
('61', 67, 4, 21, 137040) There is of course this difference between the two: 99 out of every 100 persons eat excessively, whereas 99_ per cent people do much less work than they can.
('61', 67, 4, 22, 137198) Hence one does not always know whether one has taken upon oneself more work or less than one can do.
('61', 67, 4, 23, 137299) All the same, the ultimate result will be as I have stated.
('61', 67, 4, 24, 137359) If I eat excessively, I alone would suffer.
('61', 67, 4, 25, 137403) If, on the contrary, I take upon myself more Harijan work than I can do, not only the four crore Harijans but probably the whole world would suffer.
('61', 67, 4, 26, 137552) May God give you peace of mind and show you the right path.
('61', 67, 6, 27, 137612) From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 10343. Also C.W. 6782. Courtesy: Premabehn Kantak

('61', 68, 1, 2, 137744) 74. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('61', 68, 2, 3, 137774) May 3, 1933
('61', 68, 3, 4, 137786) NARANDAS, I got your letter.
('61', 68, 3, 5, 137815) I hope you will get without delay the big packet of letters which I dispatched yesterday.
('61', 68, 3, 6, 137905) Read the letter that I have written to Prema.
('61', 68, 3, 7, 137951) In view of what I have written in it I will not say anything about the matter in this letter.
('61', 68, 3, 8, 138045) Just now I am thinking about the changes which I suggested in my letter 1 yesterday.
('61', 68, 3, 9, 138130) I have discussed them with Panditji.
('61', 68, 3, 10, 138167) Even apart from the question whether the Ashram has the capacity or is fit to keep up a chain of fasts, my view expressed in yesterday’s letter remains unchanged.
('61', 68, 3, 11, 138330) The burden on you must be lightened.
('61', 68, 3, 12, 138367) If that is not done, we shall not be able to cultivate even the fitness that we hope to do.
('61', 68, 3, 13, 138459) You should, therefore, stop admitting newcomers, ask those who cannot observe the rules to leave the Ashram if they are recent entrants or to cook in their own kitchens if they are old inmates.
('61', 68, 3, 14, 138653) I don’t like separate kitchens at all.
('61', 68, 3, 15, 138692) But I feel that we have no option but to tolerate the old families.
('61', 68, 3, 16, 138760) The view which I have expressed about Keshu also remains unchanged.
('61', 68, 3, 17, 138828) If you feel that it is your duty, as his guardian father, to help him from your personal money, I think that that money should not be treated as part of Ashram funds just now.
('61', 68, 3, 18, 139004) I feel, too, that the money which you possess should be treated as reserved for one single purpose, namely, for the support of your parents, and should be earmarked as gift to the Ashram after their death.
('61', 68, 3, 19, 139210) It should not become the property either of Jamna or Purushottam and others.
('61', 68, 3, 20, 139287) If you have not made this resolution till now, you should do so at the commencement of the yajna of purification that is about to begin.
('61', 68, 3, 21, 139424) You should discuss the matter with Jamna.
('61', 68, 3, 22, 139466) You may consult Purushottam, too, if you think it necessary.
('61', 68, 3, 23, 139527) But the chief thing is that you yourself should sincerely desire this.
('61', 68, 3, 24, 139598) Your ability to give private help to any relation of yours will be harmful to the Ashram, to you and to the person whom you may help.
('61', 68, 3, 25, 139732) I don’t see anybody else in the Ashram, besides you, who possesses all the other requisite qualities in the degree required.
('61', 68, 3, 26, 139857) The fact that, though you have money of your own, you have not misused it and have remained unaffected by it
