('61', 73, 12, 22, 147978) 82. A HARIJAN’S QUESTIONS
('61', 73, 13, 23, 148004) What should be done to unite the sub castes which exist among Harijans ?
('61', 73, 14, 24, 148077) 2. Wherever, in big cities, sewerages is introduced, the livelihood of Harijans is jeopardized.
('61', 73, 14, 25, 148173) What should they do in such a situation?
('61', 73, 15, 26, 148214) 3. In some towns caste Hindus object to Harijans going riding on such occasions as weddings.
('61', 73, 15, 27, 148307) You have written about what caste Hindus should do.
('61', 73, 15, 28, 148359) Please be so kind as to say also what the Harijans should do.
('61', 74, 0, 1, 148421) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 75
('61', 74, 1, 2, 148464) The above questions have been sent by a Harijan correspondent.
('61', 74, 1, 3, 148527) They are all three difficult questions to answer.
('61', 74, 1, 4, 148577) So long as caste Hindus remain divided in hundreds of sub castes, as they are today, it seems unlikely that caste distinctions among Harijans can be done away with.
('61', 74, 1, 5, 148742) Of course if there is a sudden awakening among the Harijans and they show a marked advance, that would be a different matter.
('61', 74, 1, 6, 148868) I long to see such an awakening and when it comes they will be far in advance of the caste Hindus.
('61', 74, 1, 7, 148967) But the question applies to the present context.
('61', 74, 2, 8, 149016) In the existing conditions all that can be said is that Harijans belonging to the castes that are considered superior should try to come closer to those belonging to lower castes.
('61', 74, 2, 9, 149196) Mahars, for instance, should try to draw closer to Mangs, to inter dine and intermarry with them.
('61', 74, 2, 10, 149294) A Mahar thus mixing with Mangs should be fearless and should be ready to face any hardship that this course may entail.
('61', 74, 3, 11, 149414) The second question is a public question.
('61', 74, 3, 12, 149456) In this transitional period a number of trades are bound to die out.
('61', 74, 3, 13, 149525) A number of new trades are bound to be born.
('61', 74, 3, 14, 149570) This has always been going on.
('61', 74, 3, 15, 149601) This question of sewerage cannot apply to villages.
('61', 74, 3, 16, 149653) Sewerage is peculiar to the city.
('61', 74, 3, 17, 149687) It is in cities that Bhangis in any number are to be found.
('61', 74, 3, 18, 149747) I believe that wherever sewerage is introduced some employment or other is found for the Bhangis.
('61', 74, 3, 19, 149845) It becomes the responsibility of the municipality to find employment for the Bhangis thrown out of work.
('61', 74, 3, 20, 149950) My advice also is that Bhangis should train themselves in some other arts, for instance, weaving.
('61', 74, 3, 21, 150048) In Gujarat I notice that Bhangis, wherever they lost their traditional occupation, have taken up weaving.
('61', 74, 3, 22, 150154) But there can be no uniform answer for all.
('61', 74, 3, 23, 150198) Much depends on individual aptitudes.
('61', 74, 4, 24, 150236) The third question is a particularly difficult one.
('61', 74, 4, 25, 150288) The underlying idea behind the question is that Harijans are wholly in the power of others and living in fear.
('61', 74, 4, 26, 150399) If this is the case the only advice that may be given is that they should seek police help.
('61', 74, 4, 27, 150491) Dr. Ambedkar told me that the police, coming as they do from caste Hindu communities, often do not help, which is likely to be true.
('61', 74, 4, 28, 150624) Under the circumstances all that one could say is that where the police are hostile or apathetic, where no one from among the caste Hindus is ready to help, and where the Harijans themselves have not generated enough strength in themselves, the only thing possible is for the Harijans to have patience.
('61', 74, 4, 29, 150927) The only
('61', 75, 0, 1, 150936) 76 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 75, 1, 2, 150977) consolation which can be offered is that for every individual and society a time comes when no alternative is left but to be patient.
('61', 75, 1, 3, 151111) Otherwise man would become an atheist and forget God.
('61', 75, 1, 4, 151165) Therefore, where there is no non violent recourse possible the Harijans should pray to Hari.
('61', 75, 2, 5, 151258) [From Hindi]
('61', 75, 3, 6, 151271) Harijan Sevak, 5 5 1933

('61', 77, 2, 3, 153861) [May 5, 1933] 1
('61', 77, 3, 4, 153877) NARANDAS,
('61', 77, 4, 5, 153887) I wanted to but could not write to you yesterday.
('61', 77, 4, 6, 153937) I understand what you say regarding Chhaganlal’s criticism.
('61', 77, 4, 7, 153997) Though you have replied as I desired you to do, I see that some of his remarks have hurt you.
('61', 77, 4, 8, 154091) They were in the nature of allegations and were prompted by anger.
('61', 77, 4, 9, 154158) But how can I advise you or anybody else?
('61', 77, 4, 10, 154200) What right have I to do so?
('61', 77, 4, 11, 154228) Yesterday, while talking to a friend like Rajaji whom I love so much, I became impatient and lost my temper with him and with Shankerlal.
('61', 77, 4, 12, 154366) I see now that the matter was of little importance, and that it was I who was foolish.
('61', 77, 4, 13, 154453) What they said or advised was prompted by their love for me.
('61', 77, 4, 14, 154514) They had no other thought but my own good.
('61', 77, 4, 15, 154557) If I lose my temper with them, how can my words of advice to you, when you get angry at Chhaganlal’s thoughtless allegations, have any effect on you?
('61', 77, 4, 16, 154707) It was seen yesterday that the serpent of anger is alive in me and is aroused whenever it is provoked.
('61', 77, 4, 17, 154810) That is why you have not been able to see the anger in your words which I pointed out.
('61', 77, 4, 18, 154897) 2 Your faith that it must be there since I say so does credit to your love for me, but it also proves that I do not deserve it.
('61', 77, 4, 19, 155025) I will not lose heart.
('61', 77, 4, 20, 155048) I will strive to deserve the love of my co workers.
('61', 77, 4, 21, 155100) The forthcoming yajna is a part of such striving.
('61', 77, 4, 22, 155150) I see every moment that this yajna is absolutely necessary for my own purification.
('61', 77, 4, 23, 155234) I cannot forget that the imperfection of the Ashram is a faithful reflection of my own imperfection.
('61', 77, 4, 24, 155335) If I do not know how to take the Ashram forward, there is no meaning in my living on.
('61', 77, 4, 25, 155421) To leave the Asham or to close it down would be nothing but cowardice.
('61', 77, 4, 26, 155492) I must learn the wisdom how to take the Ashram forward.
('61', 77, 4, 27, 155548) I cherish the hope that I shall acquire that strength by the proposed yajna.
('61', 77, 4, 28, 155625) If I succeed in this aim, I may hope to succeed in the other things.
('61', 77, 4, 29, 155694) If I fail in this, I cannot hope to succeed in anything else.
('61', 77, 4, 30, 155756) That will be the meaning of this yajna.
('61', 77, 4, 31, 155796) I should like you to make your full contribution to it.
('61', 77, 4, 32, 155852) You need not get ready just now for a fast, but should only cultivate the fitness to undertake one when the time comes.
('61', 77, 4, 33, 155972) I think you are doing that.

('61', 81, 0, 1, 161129) 82 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 81, 1, 2, 161170) 91. HUMAN MANUFACTURE [ II]
('61', 81, 2, 3, 161198) I am sorry I shall not be able to analyse, as fully as I had intended to, the able monograph on ‘Depressed Classes, in the Bengal and Sikkim Census Report by Mr. A. E. Porter of the Indian Civil Service, from which I reproduced two sections last week.
('61', 81, 2, 4, 161450) 1 In Section 4 the author points out the defects of the criteria suggested on different occasions by different Census Commissioners and others.
('61', 81, 2, 5, 161594) Says Mr. Porter:
('61', 81, 3, 6, 161611) They reduce themselves naturally to religious or social disabilities and in not a single instance is there any criterion put forward which prima facie ought to attract the attention of the administration.
('61', 81, 3, 7, 161816) For they “are entirely matters of social and religious consider ation” and, therefore, “they would be entirely irrelevant to any consideration by Government of the problem of the Depressed Classes”.
('61', 81, 3, 8, 162015) He then goes on to the consideration of some of the criteria.
('61', 81, 3, 9, 162077) Temple entry occupies the first place.
('61', 81, 3, 10, 162116) The whole of the Section is interesting.
('61', 81, 3, 11, 162157) It ends with this significant conclusion:
('61', 81, 4, 12, 162199) Disabilities regarding the right to worship or enter into temples are largely conventional or not immune from change, and in any case do not properly constitute a title to special consideration in the body politic, so long as they are confined purely to the social and religious life of the community.
('61', 81, 4, 13, 162501) I must skip over the Section regarding the service of Brahmins and barbers.
('61', 81, 4, 14, 162577) Even there the author shows that the practice is erratic, in no sense universal and subject to constant change.
('61', 81, 4, 15, 162689) Then comes the Section regarding pollution by touch.
('61', 81, 4, 16, 162742) Says the author:
('61', 81, 5, 17, 162759) There is a similar conventionality and flexibility about the idea of
('61', 81, 6, 18, 162828) uncleanliness and pollution.
('61', 81, 6, 19, 162857) The extent to which members of the higher caste feel themselves polluted differs in respect of the same group from place to place.
('61', 81, 6, 20, 162988) The same thing is applicable to food and drink taboos.
('61', 81, 6, 21, 163043) It should be borne in mind that Mr. Porter has considered the question purely with a view to examining the vexatious question as to who should be included among the ‘Depressed Classes’.
('61', 81, 6, 22, 163229) He, therefore, says:
('61', 81, 7, 23, 163250) 1 Vide “Human Manufacture [ I]”, 29 4 1933.
('61', 82, 0, 1, 163294) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 83
('61', 82, 1, 2, 163337) As a social question, therefore, the problem of the Depressed Classes is primarily one for Hindu society to tackle for itself.
('61', 82, 1, 3, 163464) As an administrative problem demanding the cognizance of Government, social and religious disabilities are unsatisfactory as a test of the classes to be included, whilst the extent to which the Depressed Classes are denied participation in the advantages and conveniences maintained by the administration is so small as to be negligible.
('61', 82, 1, 4, 163802) For the administration, in fact, the problem of the Depressed Classes in Bengal practically does not exist, save in so far as special measures are necessary to improve their economic condition and standard of education.
('61', 82, 1, 5, 164022) The prominence which it acquires is largely due to the questions raised in comparatively recent years as regards separate representation in the Legislatures for members of the Classes.
('61', 82, 1, 6, 164207) For Bengal at least, therefore, the attempt to treat any social usage or any civic disability as a clear criterion 1 by which to distinguish the Depressed Classes is bound to fail and some other distinction must be sought.
('61', 82, 1, 7, 164430) It is necessary to retain the untouchables since the Census Commissioner has explained Depressed Classes as “castes contact with whom entails purification on the part of the high caste Hindus”.
('61', 82, 1, 8, 164624) He added:
('61', 82, 2, 9, 164634) It is not intended that the term should have any reference to occupation as such but to those castes which by reason of their traditional position in Hindu society are denied access to temples, for instance, or have to use separate wells or are not allowed to sit in schools but have to remain outside or have to suffer similar social disabilities.
('61', 82, 3, 10, 164983) The question of preparing a list of the Depressed Classes for each Province was discussed at a meeting of the Superintendents of Census operations in January 1931. As a result of this discussion the Census Commissioner announced:
('61', 82, 4, 11, 165213) “For the purposes of the census of India I propose at present to retain the term ‘Depressed Classes’ to indicate untouchables, whether of the milder or of the more severe degree of untouchability.”
('61', 82, 5, 12, 165411) It was decided also that Muslims and Christians should be excluded and that generally speaking the hill and forest tribes who had not become Hindu but whose religion was returned as ‘tribal’ should also be excluded.
('61', 82, 6, 13, 165627) He then goes on to show why the expression ‘Depressed Classes’ should include not only the untouchables conforming to the various social and religious tests examined by him, but all those of whom
('61', 82, 7, 14, 165823) 1 The source has “contention”.
('61', 83, 0, 1, 165854) 84 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 83, 1, 2, 165895) in the terms of His Majesty’s Instrument of Instructions to the Governor of the Province it would still be true that from their lack of educational and material advantages they rely specially upon the protection of Government and cannot as yet fully rely for their welfare upon joint political action.
('61', 83, 1, 3, 166197) Section 17 contains a most informing comparison between the lists of Depressed Classes in 1921 and 1931. In the British districts only of Bengal, l,801,7l2 persons who are included in the list of 1921 have been excluded from that of 1931 and the number belongs to eight castes, the largest being Rajbangshi.
('61', 83, 1, 4, 166505) Similarly there are some groups who have been for the first time included in the list of 1931. In the group ‘A’ alone of the ‘Depressed Classes’, with which for the moment we are concerned, there are 48 castes in the Census Report of 1931 as against only 19 in 1921. The comparison covers other reports also, but I have confined myself to the Census reports only.
('61', 83, 1, 5, 166869) A careful perusal of the whole of this report dealing with Depressed Classes is necessary for the diligent student.
('61', 83, 1, 6, 166985) He will be amply repaid for his trouble.
('61', 83, 2, 7, 167026) But what I have given is, I hope, sufficient to show that the untouchables are a human manufacture and that, too, by census enumerators, who have nothing to do with religious untouchability, and in accordance with instructions, which were received from their superiors and which varied from time to time, so that an un touchable of yesterday ceases to be an untouchable of today and he who was not an untouchable yesterday through these census operations finds himself to be an untouchable of today.
('61', 83, 2, 8, 167526) I commend this information to honest sanatanists and ask them whether they are satisfied with this state of things or whether they are satisfied with the varying definitions of untouchability or with the fact that the untouchability, in accordance with a particular definition, varies from place to place even regarding the same persons.
('61', 83, 2, 9, 167864) Can all this be enjoined by the Shastras?
('61', 83, 2, 10, 167906) It is possible to multiply this suggestive and awkward question, but I forbear.
('61', 83, 3, 11, 167986) The one thing that should force itself upon the attention of every thoughtful reader is that the State or the Law should have nothing to do with untouchability and that, therefore, the Abolition of Untouchability Bill is a peremptory necessity.
('61', 83, 3, 12, 168231) A custom that is repugnant to the moral sense of mankind, that varies from place to place, from time to time, both in its incidence and in its application to individuals, cannot and ought not to have the sanction of the law of a
('61', 84, 0, 1, 168460) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 85
('61', 84, 1, 2, 168503) secular State representing those who at the one end believe in untouchability, no matter how capricious, and, at the other, regard it as a negation of religion.
('61', 84, 1, 3, 168664) Withdrawal of State recognition of such a custom in no way interferes with the personal belief of any single.
('61', 84, 1, 4, 168774) individual or his social practice.
('61', 84, 1, 5, 168809) It will still be open to a person to regard his fellow as an untouchable at religious and social functions without any interference from law.
('61', 84, 1, 6, 168951) That should satisfy the most orthodox of people, and the reformer would be crossing the limits of justice if he asks for more.
('61', 84, 2, 7, 169078) Another thing that clearly comes out of Mr. Porter’s monograph is that the disabilities for inclusion in the term ‘Depressed Classes’ should not include untouchability.
('61', 84, 2, 8, 169247) They should be disabilities of a civic, political, economic and non religious character, of which the State can and should take notice and for which it is not only possible but it is also the duty of the State to find a remedy.
('61', 84, 2, 9, 169475) That would purge the Depressed Classes list of untouchability and yet enable the State to deal with its incidences that are common to people other than untouchables.
('61', 84, 2, 10, 169641) If the Census operations ignored untouchability, as they should, the wind will be taken out of the sanatanists’ sail.
('61', 84, 2, 11, 169759) Happily for them and for mankind, nature has no indelible mark whereby an untouchable can be detected from the rest of his fellows.
('61', 84, 2, 12, 169891) So far as I can see from my study of various Census Reports and of the general law of the country, there is absolutely no legal difficulty in achieving this end so ably put forth by the author in the monograph under discussion.
('61', 84, 2, 13, 170119) It should be remembered too, that the definition of ‘Depressed Classes’ contemplated in the Yeravda Pact has not yet been arrived at.

('61', 87, 3, 6, 175986) 93. A CONFESSION AND A WARNING
('61', 87, 4, 7, 176017) Though I had read about the coming of this lady 1 to India and her acceptance of Hinduism and yearning to go to the Ashram at Sabarmati, she had never corresponded with me till after the September fast.
('61', 87, 4, 8, 176220) When the possibility of the second fast to start on the 2nd of January last was announced, she wrote to me a long letter telling me that she would join me in the fast.
('61', 87, 4, 9, 176388) I wrote to her, strongly dissuading her from the course and inviting her to see me, if she was not convinced.
('61', 87, 4, 10, 176498) I asked her in one of my letters to let me know something about her past.

('61', 87, 4, 13, 176691) She wrote to me about it.
('61', 87, 4, 14, 176717) This interested me more in her.
('61', 87, 4, 15, 176749) And I wrote back in praise of her work.
('61', 87, 4, 16, 176789) Thus our correspondence grew.

('61', 89, 3, 5, 180697) 94. FOR A HEART AWAKENING
('61', 89, 4, 6, 180723) I am writing this on the morning of Saturday 1. I have heard counsel of a number of friends.
('61', 89, 4, 7, 180816) Through attachment or love they want me not to undertake the mahayajna that is in the offing.
('61', 89, 4, 8, 180910) The inner voice says: ‘It will be a sin to draw back.
('61', 89, 4, 9, 180964) God, in whose name the resolve was taken will fulfil everything according to His wish.’ Outwardly what I see convinces me that I must fast, come what may.
('61', 89, 4, 10, 181119) Pandit Santhanam has sent me a report of the work in the Punjab.
('61', 89, 4, 11, 181184) It contains three points which Lala Mohanlal has made.
('61', 89, 4, 12, 181239) These, in brief, are as follows: l.
('61', 89, 4, 13, 181275) In the Punjab the Arya Samaj, the Sanatana Dharmis, the Sikhs, the Mussalmans and the Christians all want to draw Harijans into their respective folds.
('61', 89, 4, 14, 181427) 2. Harijans have produced leaders who are so covetous that, it is impossible to satisfy them.
('61', 89, 4, 15, 181521) 3. There are rival organizations in the Punjab working for the same cause.
('61', 89, 4, 16, 181596) It may occasion some surprise among readers that my proposed fast is an answer to the above situation.
('61', 89, 4, 17, 181699) The Harijan Sevak Sangh must understand that this work is purely religious and must be carried on in a religious spirit.
('61', 89, 4, 18, 181820) Once this is granted the above three points are automatically answered.
('61', 89, 4, 19, 181892) I do not consider as religious the work that people of other communities and sects are doing.
('61', 89, 4, 20, 181986) If Harijan sevaks work with religious spirit they will see the fruit of service in service itself.
('61', 89, 4, 21, 182085) They can weigh themselves only in the scales of justice.
('61', 89, 4, 22, 182142) If therefore Harijan leaders or others use pressure they will not be affected by it.
('61', 89, 4, 23, 182227) Work done in a religious spirit cannot but have an effect on the rival organizations.
('61', 89, 4, 24, 182313) What is the definition of such wonderful religion ?
('61', 89, 4, 25, 182365) Religion is what purifies the soul, in which there is no hankering for fruits of action, which generates indomitable faith,
('61', 89, 5, 26, 182489) 1 May 6, 1933
('61', 90, 0, 1, 182503) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 91
('61', 90, 1, 2, 182546) and in which there is not an iota of selfishness.
('61', 90, 1, 3, 182596) Only activities conforming to such religion can be said to be religious.
('61', 90, 1, 4, 182669) In activities of this kind the service of Harijans takes on the character of purification of the caste Hindus, an expression of their repentance.
('61', 90, 1, 5, 182815) If this is clearly understood there remains nothing further to ask.
('61', 90, 1, 6, 182883) Let every individual and organization become pure through the service of Harijans; let no one speak ill of others or bear malice towards others.
('61', 90, 1, 7, 183028) There can be no place here for considerations of political profit.
('61', 90, 1, 8, 183095) But this is easier said than done.
('61', 90, 1, 9, 183130) It means that religion is to be grasped not by the intellect but by the heart.
('61', 90, 1, 10, 183209) For an awakening of the heart the only effective means is tapasya.
('61', 90, 1, 11, 183276) Tapasya is the extreme form of renunciation.
('61', 90, 1, 12, 183321) Tapasya begins with fasting.
('61', 90, 1, 13, 183350) Tapasya means to take on suffering.
('61', 90, 1, 14, 183386) Only those who fast know the suffering of fasting.
('61', 90, 1, 15, 183437) I hope to teach through tapasya, that is, fasting, what I cannot teach through arguments.
('61', 90, 1, 16, 183527) But whether I succeed or not I see no peace for myself except in fasting.

('61', 90, 1, 19, 183802) That will be no occasion for grief and sorrowing.
('61', 90, 1, 20, 183852) And what can be more fortunate for me as well as for the cause of Harijan service if I give up my life in that cause?

('61', 91, 2, 3, 184758) May 5/6, 1933
('61', 91, 3, 4, 184772) NARANDAS,
('61', 91, 4, 5, 184782) I had a fairly long discussion with Parashuram.
('61', 91, 4, 6, 184830) Before explaining the conclusion to which I have arrived as a result of it, I will narrate to you a shocking thing which he told me.
('61', 91, 4, 7, 184963) I told him that I did not believe him at all, but asked him to give his story in writing if he wished to do so.
('61', 91, 4, 8, 185075) He did that.
('61', 91, 4, 9, 185088) What he says is that Dr. Sharma is more busy in criticizing the Ashram than with treating the patients, and that too in talking unclean things about it.
('61', 91, 4, 10, 185241) Parashuram says that Dr. Sharma had come with certain fixed prejudices against the Ashram and that he had been talking with several people there and trying to induce them to tell him things by talking to them against other inmates or coaxing them in other ways.
('61', 91, 4, 11, 185503) According to Dr. Sharma, slave mentality prevails in the Ashram and all of you are deceiving an ‘old fool’ like me by nodding ‘yes’ to everything I say.

('61', 100, 1, 2, 202572) appears to me, much later than it should have come.
('61', 100, 1, 3, 202624) But as I cannot be the judge of God Himself, I have submitted to His peremptory injunctions.
('61', 100, 1, 4, 202717) In my opinion, however, I should have undergone a fast like this at the time of the inauguration of the Harijan movement after the sealing of the Yeravda Pact.
('61', 100, 1, 5, 202877) But that was not to be and it came now.
('61', 100, 1, 6, 202917) It is undoubtedly a preparatory yajna (sacrifice) after the fact, it is also a purificatory yajna and it had to be so because it was overdue.
('61', 100, 1, 7, 203059) You should understand that all this is argument after the fact.
('61', 100, 1, 8, 203123) When I felt that I had received a peremptory call, I had no such reasoning in front of me.
('61', 100, 1, 9, 203214) The call simply came and overpowered me.
('61', 100, 1, 10, 203255) ‘Is it not rather an explosion of grief ?’—you ask.
('61', 100, 1, 11, 203307) The answer is quite simple and easy.
('61', 100, 1, 12, 203344) Most emphatically it is not an explosion of grief.
('61', 100, 1, 13, 203395) Penance it undoubtedly is, for in impurities as I call them, improprieties as you call them, but it is included in the purificatory part of it.
('61', 100, 1, 14, 203539) This, too, was inevitable because of the absence of the inaugurative fast.
('61', 100, 1, 15, 203614) ‘Have not the shocking cases of impurity you have referred to in your statement led to the fast?’ This is your last rider.
('61', 100, 1, 16, 203737) I tell you it is absolutely incorrect and I can say this with the greatest assurance, because I can give you the dates on which the shocking incidents came to my notice and at that time I felt there was no warrant for me to fast on account of those individual cases.
('61', 100, 1, 17, 204004) There were decisive reasons why as a prisoner I should not take up the fast for individual cases, as I have done before now.
('61', 100, 1, 18, 204129) But in a great movement like the Harijan movement, it would be beyond the power of a single human being to cope with individual cases by fasting in each case.
('61', 100, 1, 19, 204288) There is, therefore, no doubt in my mind that, whilst these cases must have subconsciously prepared the ground for the fast, I am unable to lay my finger on any one of those single incidents as having been wholly or principally responsible for this sacrifice.
('61', 100, 1, 20, 204548) It is predominantly an inaugurative fast overdue, and subordinately, because it is overdue by way of purification of self and associates.
('61', 100, 1, 21, 204686) I commence the fast at 12 noon Monday, if Monday sees me alive.
('61', 100, 2, 22, 204750) Harijan, 13 5 1933
('61', 100, 3, 23, 204769) 108. THE BEGINNING OF THE YAJNA
('61', 100, 4, 24, 204801) From my childhood I have been taught that good deeds — religious acts—must begin with the purification of the body and the
('61', 100, 5, 25, 204924) 1 This sentence is translated from the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary.
('61', 101, 0, 1, 205000) 102 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 101, 1, 2, 205042) The fast of September last cannot be described as a yajna of this kind.
('61', 101, 1, 3, 205114) The purpose of that fast was to bring about a change in the Government’s scheme.
('61', 101, 1, 4, 205195) Other service to the Harijans necessarily flowed from it.
('61', 101, 1, 5, 205253) There was no alternative for me but to undertake it.
('61', 101, 1, 6, 205306) The purpose was fulfilled with the alteration in the scheme and the fast too was terminated.
('61', 101, 1, 7, 205399) That fast had a condition attached to it and was, to that extent, inferior to the present one.
('61', 101, 1, 8, 205494) The work of Harijan service began later.
('61', 101, 1, 9, 205535) I now feel that it was a poor beginning.
('61', 101, 1, 10, 205576) There was no shuddhi yajna behind it.
('61', 101, 1, 11, 205614) It is possible that owing to lack of that yajna, the war against untouchabilily did not take on a wholly religious form.
('61', 101, 1, 12, 205735) I was not aware of this when the call to fast came.
('61', 101, 1, 13, 205787) It is difficult to name any one thing which was the cause of the fast.
('61', 101, 1, 14, 205858) This fast of mine is distinct from all my other well known fasts.
('61', 101, 1, 15, 205924) Its only object is self purification.
('61', 101, 1, 16, 205962) If I die during this fast, I would regard it as a welcome, though unforeseen, consequence.
('61', 101, 1, 17, 206053) And I would like everyone else to regard it as such.
('61', 101, 1, 18, 206106) If I give up my life thinking of Harijans and with the idea in my mind of doing pure service to them, I would regard it as a good beginning of the work of service.
('61', 101, 1, 19, 206270) However, in this yajna, it is not my intention to render service by dying but by living.
('61', 101, 1, 20, 206359) If God has willed otherwise, who can prevail against Him?
('61', 101, 1, 21, 206417) Just as I have the courage to serve in life, so also have I in death.
('61', 101, 1, 22, 206487) We should therefore look upon life and death as one and the same thing.
('61', 101, 1, 23, 206559) Those who tremble at this fast should give up their attachment to the body.
('61', 101, 1, 24, 206635) Giving up the body does not mean giving up the work.
('61', 101, 1, 25, 206688) If that were the case, what would be the good of living?
('61', 101, 1, 26, 206745) The body perishes but the atman does not.
('61', 101, 1, 27, 206787) It is the atman which acts or does not act.
('61', 101, 1, 28, 206831) It lives for ever; it is immortal.
('61', 101, 1, 29, 206866) Whether we are aware of it or not, whether we wish it or not, all effort is related to the soul—whether it may be uplifting or degrading.
('61', 101, 1, 30, 207004) At the moment, I have only one burning desire, viz., that we should all realize that this task of abolishing untouchability is a religious one and cannot be achieved except through religious means.
('61', 101, 1, 31, 207202) The purification of all other Hindus lies in the service of Harijans.
('61', 101, 1, 32, 207272) Hinduism will not be purified, notwithstanding the improvement in the economic and political condition of the Harijans, if other Hindus are not rendered pure.
('61', 101, 1, 33, 207431) If the filth of untouchability is not swept away, it will devour Hinduism.
('61', 101, 1, 34, 207506) In order to achieve this, it is necessary to bring about a change of heart among the countless Hindus.
('61', 102, 0, 1, 207609) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 103
('61', 102, 1, 2, 207653) It should be clear as daylight to everyone that this filth cannot be got rid of except through self purification.
('61', 102, 1, 3, 207767) The best way to make this clear is to take up the yajna of fasting in thought, word and deed.
('61', 102, 1, 4, 207861) Mere bodily fasting is suffering in vain.
('61', 102, 1, 5, 207903) It may be mere hypocrisy.
('61', 102, 1, 6, 207929) Anyone who does not mentally crave for cereals or fruit, finds that his body readily gives up this craving.
('61', 102, 1, 7, 208037) Anyone who does not actually partake of these, but who mentally thinks of nothing but these, may be said to be constantly eating despite the fact that his body is fasting.
('61', 102, 1, 8, 208209) Many fasts are of this nature.
('61', 102, 1, 9, 208240) From the standpoint of dharma, these are futile and there is every likelihood of their being harmful.
('61', 102, 1, 10, 208342) Hence, it is absolutely essential that the mind should be fully prepared when undertaking a religious fast.
('61', 102, 1, 11, 208450) My soul is witness that I am prepared in this manner.
('61', 102, 1, 12, 208504) It is possible that many persons may perish during such yajnas.
('61', 102, 1, 13, 208568) Nevertheless, without many such yajnas, the abolition of untouchability cannot be accomplished, the filth that has become embedded through centuries cannot be removed.
('61', 102, 1, 14, 208736) It is only right that I should make a beginning in this yajna.
('61', 102, 2, 15, 208799) If my physical self does not survive the twenty one days’ fast, the reader must conclude that it was useless for this or any other service.
('61', 102, 2, 16, 208939) Faith is of the utmost importance here.
('61', 102, 2, 17, 208979) Blind faith is of course to be found in plenty and, as a result, faith itself has become an object of criticism.
('61', 102, 2, 18, 209092) But just as a person with sight is not useless merely because he is amidst many who are blind, but rather becomes the guide of the latter, similarly, the clear sighted faith of one individual can overcome the blind faith of millions.
('61', 102, 2, 19, 209326) I wish to acquire such faith.
('61', 102, 2, 20, 209356) Other men and women should also make that effort.
('61', 102, 2, 21, 209406) In order to do so one or more fasts involving thought, word and deed will be useful.
('61', 102, 3, 22, 209491) [From Gujarati]
('61', 102, 4, 23, 209507) Harijanbandhu, 7 5 1933

('61', 105, 17, 24, 213162) There are more verses than one in the Gita which imply that
('61', 106, 0, 1, 213222) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 107
('61', 106, 1, 2, 213266) God always helps us to complete whatever work is undertaken in His name and at His prompting.
('61', 106, 1, 3, 213360) He is the sole author of everything.
('61', 106, 1, 4, 213397) We, therefore, are responsible for nothing.
('61', 106, 1, 5, 213441) If somebody assaults another with a stick, it is the person using the stick and not the stick that does so.
('61', 106, 1, 6, 213549) Similarly, if we put our body in God’s hands and if He uses it to get some work done, it is God who does the work and not the body.
('61', 106, 1, 7, 213681) Credit for success and discredit for failure will be His.
('61', 106, 1, 8, 213739) You should, therefore, understand that He who has prompted me to undertake this fast will enable me to complete it.

('61', 114, 3, 4, 226437) 137. LETTER TO ANASUYABEHN SARABHAI
('61', 114, 4, 5, 226473) May 7, 1933
('61', 114, 5, 6, 226485) ANASUYABEHN, I can understand your suffering.
('61', 114, 5, 7, 226531) Keeping my company is disastrous.
('61', 114, 5, 8, 226565) I myself am wholly in other hands, not knowing what will happen the next moment.
('61', 114, 5, 9, 226646) I feel my freedom as slavery and slavery to the God of Truth as freedom.
('61', 114, 5, 10, 226719) I did not have the slightest desire to undertake a fast, and yet I have had to do so.
('61', 114, 5, 11, 226805) But now that I have undertaken one, the load that weighed on my mind is lifted in a way that defies description.
('61', 114, 5, 12, 226918) You should therefore rejoice at the fast.
('61', 114, 5, 13, 226960) Nothing untoward will happen to my body, but what even if my faith proves misplaced?
('61', 114, 5, 14, 227045) In that case you may know that there was not further service to be taken from this body.
('61', 114, 5, 15, 227134) Do not therefore feel troubled.
('61', 114, 5, 16, 227166) Keep your mind fixed on the thought that the body is more fragile than a glass bangle and the atman which inhabits it is the only reality, and go on doing whatever service you can.
('61', 114, 5, 17, 227347) Just now Shankerlal and you should rest.
('61', 114, 5, 18, 227388) Come during the last days of the fast.

('61', 121, 6, 18, 239508) 148. STATEMENT EXPLAINING OBJECT OF FAST 2
('61', 121, 7, 19, 239551) May 8, 1933
('61', 121, 8, 20, 239563) Every day brings me fresh justification for the ordeal that God the Truth has sent me.
('61', 121, 8, 21, 239650) The discoveries I am making would have paralysed me, but for the fast.
('61', 121, 8, 22, 239721) Whatever it may mean for the cause, it will certainly be my saving.
('61', 121, 8, 23, 239789) Whether I survive the fast or not, is a matter of little moment.
('61', 121, 8, 24, 239854) Without it I would, in all probability, have been useless for further service of Harijans, and for that matter, any other service.
('61', 121, 8, 25, 239985) Those friends who have sent me urgent wires dissuading me from the step will, I hope, appreciate the fact that for a person built as
('61', 121, 9, 26, 240118) 1 Vide “Telegram to G. D. Birla”, 2 5 1933. 2 The statement was issued at 12 noon, soon after Gandhiji had commenced his fast.
('61', 122, 0, 1, 240245) VOL. 61 : 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 123
('61', 122, 1, 2, 240290) I am, such fasts are indispensable.
('61', 122, 1, 3, 240326) This I say apart from my claim, by which I stand, that it was God’s call.
('61', 122, 1, 4, 240400) The senders of wires will forgive me for not sending individual acknowledgments.
('61', 122, 1, 5, 240481) The pressure upon my time has been so great that it has been physically impossible for me to cope with all wires that poured in upon me.
('61', 122, 1, 6, 240618) Now that the fast will begin within two hours of writing this, I invite all friends and well wishers to pray for strength for enabling me to go through the ordeal without weakening.
('61', 122, 1, 7, 240800) I confess that I have no strength except what God may give me.
('61', 122, 1, 8, 240863) That He has never failed me hitherto gives me the confidence that He will not fail me now.
('61', 122, 1, 9, 240954) A telegram was received by me from a Harijan Association that my fast was unnecessary, as the Harijans do not stand in need of assistance from the caste Hindus.
('61', 122, 1, 10, 241115) From its own standpoint, the Association is right.
('61', 122, 1, 11, 241166) Only it should be clearly understood that the fast is taken not to oblige the Harijans, but for purification of self and associates.
('61', 122, 1, 12, 241299) Harijan service is a duty the caste Hindus owe to themselves.
('61', 122, 1, 13, 241361) It is a part of the penance they must do for the wrongs they have done to their own kith and kin.
('61', 122, 1, 14, 241459) I can well understand the indignantrepudiation by some of the Harijans.
('61', 122, 1, 15, 241531) Let me hope that it is not yet too late for the vast majority to accept the penance.
('61', 122, 1, 16, 241616) The numerous messages I have received from them leave no room for doubting such an acceptance.
('61', 122, 1, 17, 241711) Sanatanist Hindus scent further coercion in this fast.
('61', 122, 1, 18, 241766) When they realize that it cannot be broken before its period, even if every temple was opened and untouchability wholly removed from the heart, they will perhaps admit that it cannot be regarded as in any way coercive.
('61', 122, 1, 19, 241985) The fast is intended to remove bitterness, to purify hearts and to make it clear that the movement is wholly moral, to be prosecuted by wholly moral persons.
('61', 122, 1, 20, 242143) May God bless the ordeal and fulfil its purpose.

('61', 123, 5, 10, 242946) 150. STATEMENT SUSPENDING CIVIL DISOBEDIENCE MOVEMENT
('61', 123, 6, 11, 243000) May 8, 1933
('61', 123, 7, 12, 243012) I cannot regard this release with any degree of pleasure.
('61', 123, 7, 13, 243070) As Sardar Vallabhbhai rightly remarked to me yesterday, how can I take advantage of this release in order to prosecute the civil disobedience campaign or to guide it?
('61', 123, 7, 14, 243237) This release, therefore, puts upon me, as a seeker after Truth and a man of honour, a tremendous burden and strain.
('61', 123, 7, 15, 243353) This fast has to continue.
('61', 123, 7, 16, 243380) I had hoped, and I still hope, not to excite myself over anything and not to take part in discussions of any nature whatsoever.
('61', 123, 7, 17, 243508) The whole purpose of the fast will be frustrated if I allowed my brain to be occupied by any extraneous matter, that is, any matter outside the Harijan work.
('61', 123, 7, 18, 243666) At the same time, having been released, I should be bound to give a little of my energies to a study of the civil disobedience movement.
('61', 123, 7, 19, 243803) Of course, for the moment, I can only say that my views about civil disobedience have undergone no change whatsoever.
('61', 123, 7, 20, 243921) I have nothing but praise for the bravery and self sacrifice of the numerous civil resisters, but having said that, I cannot help saying that the
('61', 123, 8, 21, 244067) 1 The source had reported: “At Lady Thackersey’s house, Gandhiji told the Associated Press representative that he was informed of his release only at quarter to seven by Col.
('61', 123, 8, 22, 244242) Doyle, Inspector General of Prisons.
('61', 123, 8, 23, 244279) Asked if he will be staying at Lady Vithaldas Thackersey’s house throughout the fast, Gandhiji said that he was not now sure about this.”
('61', 124, 0, 1, 244417) VOL. 61 : 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 125
('61', 124, 1, 2, 244462) secrecy that has attended the movement is fatal to its success.
('61', 124, 1, 3, 244526) If, therefore, the movement must be continued, I would urge those who are guiding the movement in different parts of the country to discard all secrecy.
('61', 124, 1, 4, 244679) I do not care if, thereby, it becomes difficult to secure a single civil resister.
('61', 124, 1, 5, 244762) There can be no doubt that fear has seized the common mass.
('61', 124, 1, 6, 244822) The ordinances have cowed them down, and I am inclined to think that the secret methods are largely responsible for the demoralization.
('61', 124, 1, 7, 244958) The movement of civil disobedience does not depend so much upon the quantity as on the quality of men and women taking part in it, and if I were leading the movement, I should sacrifice quantity and insist on quality.
('61', 124, 1, 8, 245176) If this could be done, it would immediately raise the level of the movement.
('61', 124, 1, 9, 245253) Mass instruction on any other terms is an impossibility.
('61', 124, 1, 10, 245310) I can say nothing as to the actual campaign.
('61', 124, 1, 11, 245355) The reflections I have given, I had bottled up all these many months, and I can say that Sardar Vallabhbhai is one with me in what I have said.
('61', 124, 1, 12, 245499) One word I would say.
('61', 124, 1, 13, 245521) Whether I like it or not, during these three weeks, all civil resisters will be in a state of terrible suspense.
('61', 124, 1, 14, 245634) It would be better if the President of the Congress, Bapuji Madhavrao Aney, were to officially declare suspension for one full month or even six weeks.
('61', 124, 1, 15, 245786) Now, I would make an appeal to the Government.
('61', 124, 1, 16, 245833) If they want real peace in the land, and if they feel that there is no real peace, if they feel that Ordinance Rule is no rule, they should take advantage of this suspension, and unconditionally discharge all the civil resisters.
('61', 124, 1, 17, 246063) If I survive the ordeal, it will give me time to survey the situation, and to tender advice both to the Con gress leaders and if I may venture to do so, to the Government.
('61', 124, 1, 18, 246235) I would like to take up the thread at the point where I was interrupted on my return from England.
('61', 124, 1, 19, 246334) If no understanding is arrived at between the Government and the Congress as a result of my effort, and civil disobedience is resumed, it will be open to the Government, if they so choose, to revive the Ordinance Rule.
('61', 124, 1, 20, 246553) If there is the will on the part of the Government, I have no doubt that a modus operandi can be found.
('61', 124, 1, 21, 246657) Of this, so far as I am concerned, I am absolutely certain that civil disobedience cannot be withdrawn so long as so many civil resisters are imprisoned.
('61', 124, 1, 22, 246811) No settlement can be arrived at so long as Sardar Vallabhbhai, Khan Saheb, Abdul Ghaffar Khan and Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru and others
('61', 125, 0, 1, 246944) 126 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 125, 1, 2, 246986) are buried alive.
('61', 125, 1, 3, 247004) Indeed, to call off civil resistance is not within the power of any of the men who are out of prison.
('61', 125, 1, 4, 247106) It is possible only for the Working Committee to do so.
('61', 125, 1, 5, 247162) I refer to the Working Committee that was in existence at the time I was arrested.
('61', 125, 1, 6, 247245) I shall say no more on the civil disobedience movement.
('61', 125, 1, 7, 247301) Perhaps, I have already said too much, but if I was to say anything, I could say so only whilst I have strength left in me.
('61', 125, 1, 8, 247425) I would urge Pressmen not to worry me any more.
('61', 125, 1, 9, 247473) I would urge also would be visitors once more to restrain themselves.
('61', 125, 1, 10, 247543) Let them regard me as being still in prison.
('61', 125, 1, 11, 247588) I shall be unfit for holding political discussions or any other discussions.
('61', 125, 1, 12, 247665) I would like to be left in perfect peace, and I would like to tell the Government that I shall not abuse the release.
('61', 125, 1, 13, 247783) If I come safely through the ordeal, and if I find the political atmosphere as murky as it is today, without taking a single step secretly or openly in furthe rance of civil disobedience, I shall invite them to take me back to Yeravda to join the companions whom I almost seem to have deserted.
('61', 125, 1, 14, 248078) It was a great privilege for me to have been with Sardar Vallabhbhai.
('61', 125, 1, 15, 248148) I was well aware of his matchless bravery and his burning love for the country, but I had never lived with him as I had the good fortune to do during the last sixteen months.
('61', 125, 1, 16, 248323) The affection with which he covered me recalls to me that of my own dear mother.
('61', 125, 1, 17, 248404) I neverknew him to possess motherly qualities.
('61', 125, 1, 18, 248451) If the slightest thing happened to me, he would be out of his bed.
('61', 125, 1, 19, 248518) He superintended every little detail in connection with my comforts.

('61', 125, 1, 21, 248842) His solicitude for the farmers of Bardoli and Kaira I can never forget.

('61', 127, 4, 5, 251546) 153. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('61', 127, 5, 6, 251577) C/O LADY VITHALDAS THACKERSEY, ‘PARNAKUTI’, POONA, May 9, 1933
('61', 127, 6, 7, 251640) NARANDAS,
('61', 127, 7, 8, 251650) I have been released a little unexpectedly, otherwise Mahadev would have written a letter and a long one.
('61', 127, 7, 9, 251756) But now I myself must dictate one.
('61', 127, 7, 10, 251791) I got your letter.
('61', 127, 7, 11, 251810) Please go on writing to me daily.
('61', 127, 7, 12, 251844) Anybody who has something special to write about may also write.
('61', 127, 7, 13, 251909) I welcome the changes which you say have been introduced, but there is one danger.
('61', 127, 7, 14, 251992) Read about it in my letter to the women.
('61', 127, 7, 15, 252033) If all the people have accepted them willingly, there will be no difficulty at all and their health will soon improve.
('61', 127, 7, 16, 252152) Everybody should eat as one takes medicine, and be fully satisfied with the type and the quantity of the food that he gets.
('61', 127, 7, 17, 252276) Any item which one does not like should be declined.
('61', 127, 7, 18, 252329) It is not likely that one will not like anything from among milk, wheat, fruit and uncooked vegetable.
('61', 127, 7, 19, 252432) If that happens, the only remedy for such a person is a fast.
('61', 127, 7, 20, 252494) I have not known any person who did not like fruits.
('61', 127, 7, 21, 252547) Let everybody start drinking fresh, unboiled milk without any fear.
('61', 127, 7, 22, 252615) The person who is in charge of cooking should take care that every item is well cooked.
('61', 127, 7, 23, 252703) If anything is not cooked sufficiently well, it should be thrown away.
('61', 127, 7, 24, 252774) You should make it a general rule to serve only the vegetables which grow in the Ashram itself.
('61', 127, 7, 25, 252870) Totaramji 1 should know that he must supply tomatoes, salad, etc., all the year round.
('61', 127, 7, 26, 252957) I will not mind if this means more expense just now.
('61', 127, 7, 27, 253010) Similarly, fruit trees also should be planted.

('61', 134, 9, 10, 265840) 162. TO THE READER1
('61', 134, 10, 11, 265860) All should know that, even though I am supposed to be a free man, the Harijan will continue to be edited just as if I was in prison.
('61', 134, 10, 12, 265993) It will still be solely devoted to the Harijan cause and will scrupulously exclude all politics.
('61', 134, 10, 13, 266090) It is a matter of regret to me that for three weeks I shall not be able to write anything for the Harijan.
('61', 134, 10, 14, 266197) But, if God spares me, I hope to write for the Harijan with better qualifications.
('61', 134, 10, 15, 266280) I hope, further, that in the mean while the Harijan cause will make rapid progress, that reformers and sanatanists will combine, wherever possible, to serve Harijans, that reformers will work the rest of the programme without wounding the susceptibilities of the sanatanists and that the Harijans themselves will, by vigorously prosecuting internal reforms to which I have drawn attention so often in these columns, make it easier for sanatanists and reformers to recognize that Harijans are truly ‘Harijans’ and that they are capable of responding to love precisely in the same manner and to the same degree as others.

('61', 135, 16, 25, 267814) A true Brahmin is one who possesses the attributes of a Kshatriya, a Vaishya and a Shudra, and has in addition learning.
('61', 135, 16, 26, 267935) Shudras are not of course wholly devoid of learning, but service is their chief characteristic.

('61', 137, 1, 2, 270586) 167. NOT BY BIRTH BUT BY MERIT
('61', 137, 2, 3, 270617) The reader may not know that among the many devotees of the Harijan cause are two lepers.
('61', 137, 2, 4, 270707) One is a Kshatriya who has caught the infection through service among the poor with whom some years ago he cast in his lot, taking with him almost all his wealth.
('61', 137, 2, 5, 270870) His leprosy has not deterred him from the self chosen service.
('61', 137, 2, 6, 270933) Another is a Brahmin pundit well versed in Sanskrit.
('61', 137, 2, 7, 270986) He often sends me selections from the Shastras in support of the reformer’s position on untouchability.
('61', 137, 2, 8, 271090) Below is the translation of his latest collection: l.
('61', 137, 2, 9, 271144) “one who has purified himself by pure deeds and who has restrained his senses deserves to be treated as a Brah min even though he may be a Shudra”, said God Brahma himself.
('61', 137, 2, 10, 271317) 2. Even though a Shudra, one who is noble of nature and deed should be regarded as the best among the twice born.
('61', 137, 2, 11, 271431) 3. Neither birth nor lineage, neither culture nor knowledge of the Vedas, can render one a twice born.
('61', 137, 2, 12, 271534) Good conduct is the only deciding cause.
('61', 137, 2, 13, 271575) 4. It is good conduct alone which makes one a Brahmin.
('61', 137, 2, 14, 271630) A person of good conduct, even though a Shudra, acquires Brahminhood.
('61', 137, 2, 15, 271700) 5. He who lives for the performance of dharma (duty), whose dharma is consecrated to God and whose day and night are devoted to good deeds—he is declared by Gods to be a Brahmin.
('61', 137, 2, 16, 271879) 6. He who is content with whatever food and clothes and bed are offered to him is declared by Gods to be a Brahmin.
('61', 137, 2, 17, 271995) —Mahabharata: “Shanti Parva” Commenting on this, the compiler truly exclaims: “Surely the Harijans of India today fulfil this test.” 7. For a Brahmin truth is Brahman; austerity is Brahman; control of the senses is Brahman; compassion for the whole creation is Brahman.
('61', 137, 2, 18, 272265) —Parashara Smriti 8. A Brahmin is one possessed of self restraint, austerity, self control, charity, truth, purity, compassion, knowledge of the Vedas, learning, wisdom, faith.
('61', 137, 2, 19, 272442) —Vasishtha
('61', 138, 0, 1, 272453) VOL. 61 : 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 139
('61', 138, 1, 2, 272498) 9. Only those Brahmins are capable of saving (mankind) who are completely self controlled, whose ears are full of the music of Vedic chants, who have conquered their senses, who have abjured injury to all sentient beings and who shrink from possession.

('61', 138, 11, 26, 274105) The correspondent had reported that three Harijan sevaks of his village had invited Harijans to dinner on the Ramanavami Day and served them drinking water in their own lotas.
('61', 138, 11, 27, 274281) As a result of this the orthodox sections of the village had ostracized them and the barber and the washerman had refused to serve them.

('61', 139, 0, 1, 274488) 140 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 139, 1, 2, 274530) lotas in the market we do not stop to ask as to who might have used them.
('61', 139, 1, 3, 274604) What peculiar quality does a lota come to possess as soon as it falls into our hands so that it becomes useless to us if a Harijan happens to use it?
('61', 139, 1, 4, 274754) The villagers in question have given their answer.
('61', 139, 1, 5, 274805) They have declared it a sin to lend the lotas to Harijans for drinking water and they are meting out rough treatment to the three young Harijan sevaks for having committed this sin.
('61', 139, 1, 6, 274987) What should they do?
('61', 139, 1, 7, 275008) What the villagers have condemned as a sin I consider a meritorious deed.
('61', 139, 1, 8, 275082) They must therefore suffer in patience even if corporal punishment were to be meted out to them, to say nothing of denying them the services of the washerman and the barber.
('61', 139, 1, 9, 275256) They may wash their own clothes and cut their own hair.
('61', 139, 1, 10, 275312) If they cannot do the latter they may let their hair grow.
('61', 139, 1, 11, 275371) But they must never give up.
('61', 139, 2, 12, 275400) One must not however under any condition be angry with the villagers.
('61', 139, 2, 13, 275470) What after all can they do?
('61', 139, 2, 14, 275498) They have been taught adharma in the name of dharma They are, if anything, to be pitied.
('61', 139, 2, 15, 275587) That the removal of untouchability is a religious act has been realized by no more than three young men there.
('61', 139, 2, 16, 275698) The rest of the villagers continue to languish in the well of ignorance.
('61', 139, 2, 17, 275771) Under the circumstances, it becomes the duty of the three young men by their firmness, purity, tapasya, sacrifice, patience and generosity to change the hearts of these villagers lost in darkness and at the same time to teach the Harijans the habits of cleanliness.
('61', 139, 2, 18, 276037) They can under no circumstance take the matter to a court of law.

('61', 151, 10, 12, 294994) PARNAKUTI, POONA 6, June 7, 1933
('61', 151, 11, 13, 295027) MIRA, I must not write.
('61', 151, 11, 14, 295051) The last letter that I wrote to you caused much strain upon the hand.
('61', 151, 11, 15, 295121) I am, therefore, dictating this letter, in reply to yours of the 5th instant.
('61', 151, 11, 16, 295199) You say that the brief sentence 2 I wrote at the end of the letter written by Mahadev, gave you pangs.
('61', 151, 11, 17, 295302) It is wonderful how we create misery for ourselves where there is not even the slightest cause.
('61', 151, 11, 18, 295398) My sentence had reference to your fever, which you yourself had said was due to over anxiety on your part.
('61', 151, 11, 19, 295505) You had explicitly mentioned that you were ill able to bear the separation.
('61', 151, 11, 20, 295581) It was in answer to this that I wrote that sentence.
('61', 151, 11, 21, 295634) It had reference only to enforced separation.
('61', 151, 11, 22, 295680) There was no thought whatsoever that you should live out of sight even when it was possible for you to be with me, that is, if we were both not imprisoned.
('61', 151, 11, 23, 295836) Of course, in that case, you would be most naturally with me, But to be out of prison is not my natural life.
('61', 151, 11, 24, 295946) My natural life is that of a prisoner and therefore I suggest that you should learn to do without my physical presence.
('61', 151, 11, 25, 296066) Is not this as clear as daylight?
('61', 151, 11, 26, 296100) I do not like this loss of weight by you.
('61', 151, 11, 27, 296142) There is something radically wrong in your carrying this load of anxiety on your
('61', 151, 12, 28, 296223) 1 Addressee’s daughter 2 Vide “Letter to Mirabehn”, 3 6 1933.
('61', 152, 0, 1, 296285) VOL. 61 : 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 153
('61', 152, 1, 2, 296330) shoulders.
('61', 152, 1, 3, 296341) It is incompatible with a living faith in a living God.
('61', 152, 1, 4, 296397) As days pass I feel this living presence in every fibre of my vein.
('61', 152, 1, 5, 296465) Without that feeling I should be demented.
('61', 152, 1, 6, 296508) There are so many things that are calculated to disturb my peace of mind.
('61', 152, 1, 7, 296582) So many events happened that would, without the realization of that presence, shake me to the very foundation.
('61', 152, 1, 8, 296693) But they pass me by leaving me practically untouched.
('61', 152, 1, 9, 296747) I want you to share that reality with me.
('61', 152, 1, 10, 296789) Then you would not be disturbed because you cannot be physically near me.
('61', 152, 1, 11, 296863) Remember that no heroic effort is necessary in order to be able to bear such enforced separation, as you and I have to put up with.
('61', 152, 1, 12, 296995) Millions of human beings do so without any effort.
('61', 152, 1, 13, 297046) Do not make the mistake of thinking that they bear such separation because their nature is not sensitive to such things.
('61', 152, 1, 14, 297167) If we would examine them we would find that they are just as sensitive as you and I are likely to be.
('61', 152, 1, 15, 297269) Only they have a natural faith in God of which they have not even the knowledge.
('61', 152, 1, 16, 297350) Ours is, beside theirs, a laboured faith.
('61', 152, 1, 17, 297392) Hence we have to put forth a Herculean effort to bear separation.
('61', 152, 1, 18, 297458) Anyway that is my analysis of your mentality.
('61', 152, 1, 19, 297504) If it is not true you will make your own analysis and somehow or other cure yourself of the terrible anxiety.
('61', 152, 1, 20, 297614) Carefully ponder over Krishna’s discourses in the second chapter of the Gita.
('61', 152, 1, 21, 297692) Then go to the twelfth chapter, and see whether you cannot find real peace and calmness of mind.
('61', 152, 1, 22, 297789) Do not try to give me a detailed reply to this argument of mine.
('61', 152, 1, 23, 297854) I do not want you to go through that strain.
('61', 152, 1, 24, 297899) I have advanced the argument simply to soothe you, if at all I can.
('61', 152, 1, 25, 297967) I know that argument is vain when one’s whole being is in rebellion against itself.
('61', 152, 1, 26, 298051) Perhaps the painful process through which you are passing is preliminary to the coming realization of the living presence of God.
('61', 152, 1, 27, 298181) May it be so.
('61', 152, 1, 28, 298195) Anyway do not again allow the thought to cross your mind that there is any question whatsoever of your having to live in separation from me when we both find ourselves out of prison.

('61', 159, 1, 2, 308823) Devdas’s marriage 1 is fixed for the 16th.
('61', 159, 1, 3, 308866) It would perhaps be better if you come on a date later than that.
('61', 159, 1, 4, 308932) The general rule that nobody need come from there to attend a wedding may as well be observed on this occasion.

('61', 159, 1, 11, 309752) It is from this point of view that it has been considered desirable to be content with [the services of] Lakshman Shastri [as priest] who is quite near Poona and without those of Panditji.
('61', 159, 1, 12, 309941) Combined with all these considerations, there is of course the desire to save expense.
('61', 159, 1, 13, 310028) Though enjoying royal facilities myself, 2 I just cannot forget our poverty.
('61', 159, 1, 14, 310105) Maybe these royal facilities are not unpleasing to me, but they are certainly not pleasing either.
('61', 159, 1, 15, 310204) My conscience bears witness to the fact that seen from the point of view of truth, they are more unpleasing than pleasing.

('61', 162, 8, 26, 314956) Goats are milked early morning after the udders are properly washed with permanganate of potash and the milkman’s hands washed with hot water.

('61', 163, 0, 1, 315378) 164 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 163, 1, 2, 315420) there for a higher purpose and a higher influence.You being there are able to hold together all those who are friendly to the cause and what is more you must be silently and imperceptibly permeating the best English mind with the truth that is in you.
('61', 163, 1, 3, 315672) All this will tell in the end.
('61', 163, 1, 4, 315703) Whilst God is great and omnipotent and works in mysterious ways and therefore all things are possible for Him, humanly speaking I see not the slightest immediate cause for hope of improvement in the present position which so far as I can see is as bad as it can possibly be.
('61', 163, 1, 5, 315978) This Ordinance rule has struck the people dumb.
('61', 163, 1, 6, 316026) The ignorant mass have become terror struck.
('61', 163, 1, 7, 316071) They do not know what is in store for them on the morrow.
('61', 163, 1, 8, 316129) The well to do are trembling in their shoes simply thro ugh a vague fear of their being overtaken by some Governmental Act.
('61', 163, 1, 9, 316253) They feel that their only safety lies in an abject surrender to the will of what to them is a power which seems even to override Providence itself—a power that will compel subjection to its will at any cost.
('61', 163, 1, 10, 316461) And so there is a kind of dead calm which even in my bed, isolated though I am from contact with people through the orders of doctors, I can’t help sensing.
('61', 163, 1, 11, 316618) It is the peace of the cemetery as Lord Irwin once or twice said in 1930 when he refused to make further use of the terrible powers which it was possible for the Government of India to use whenever they liked.
('61', 163, 1, 12, 316828) Though therefore I see no hope in the near future, whilst you and I do not ignore it, we have in view the distances in working for and at truth.
('61', 163, 1, 13, 316973) Time does not count, or if it does, it counts in our favour.
('61', 163, 1, 14, 317034) For here there is all hope, no cause for despair, for there is a certainty of the final triumph of truth, so long as there is some living representative of it.
('61', 163, 1, 15, 317194) Thanks be to God, so far as I can see there are certainly several, if not many, representatives of truth today in India who will count no cost too great for the vindication of truth.
('61', 163, 1, 16, 317377) Having got this immovable faith in me in the rightness of the cause, there is no danger on this side of any precipitate action.
('61', 163, 1, 17, 317505) Every step that is necessary will be taken with the greatest deliberation.
('61', 163, 1, 18, 317580) I shall personally leave no stone unturned to secure an honourable peace.
('61', 163, 1, 19, 317654) So far as I can judge I shall fail, but that does not worry me.
('61', 163, 1, 20, 317718) The harder General Smuts became the harder and the oftener I knocked at his door till it was banged in my face, but patience was rewarded and so it will be in this case.
('61', 163, 1, 21, 317888) Abdul Ghaffar Khan cannot be sacrificed.
('61', 163, 1, 22, 317929) Khorshed Naoroji over 30 years in age, a woman free of hysterics, full of faith and spirituality, went to the Frontier, lived with Abdul Ghaffar Khan, came in intimate touch with people.
('61', 163, 1, 23, 318116) Devdas next went and both these told me that they were convinced that there was
('61', 164, 0, 1, 318196) VOL. 61 : 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 165
('61', 164, 1, 2, 318241) no guile about Abdul Ghaffar Khan, that he always said what he meant and meant what he said.
('61', 164, 1, 3, 318334) They admit that he is hot tempered, hasty in action, but has no belief in violence, is in secret league with neither Amanullah nor anybody else.
('61', 164, 1, 4, 318479) His sole ambition is to see his people happy and free from terrorism.
('61', 164, 1, 5, 318549) My own personal experience is that he is amenable to control and discipline.
('61', 164, 1, 6, 318626) I do not remember his having ever refused to carry out his promises.
('61', 164, 1, 7, 318695) He has come to me whenever I have wanted him.
('61', 164, 1, 8, 318741) My own firm opinion is that he is much misrepresented in the official circles and that what they do not want is his influence among his people.
('61', 164, 1, 9, 318885) This he undoubtedly has, because he is self sacrificing, simple and brave.
('61', 164, 1, 10, 318960) It is once more a repetition of the old policy of cutting off tall poppies.
('61', 164, 1, 11, 319036) If what is insinuated about Abdul Ghaffar Khan is true, that must be proved by an impartial tribunal and neither the Congress nor I personally would have anything to say if the charges against him are true.
('61', 164, 1, 12, 319243) But the tribunal must be an acceptable tribunal.
('61', 164, 1, 13, 319292) I do not want a second edition of the Meerut Case 1. As you know full well I have no sympathy with Communism, most of the Meerut prisoners were daggers at me.
('61', 164, 1, 14, 319451) They missed no occasion to vilify or insult me.
('61', 164, 1, 15, 319499) But that is of no conseq uence.
('61', 164, 1, 16, 319531) They have been punished for holding particular opinions, not for any act that they have done!
('61', 164, 1, 17, 319625) And what a punishment!
('61', 164, 1, 18, 319648) But that is merely symptomatic of the deep seated disease.
('61', 164, 1, 19, 319707) There is no intention whatsoever on the part of the Indian Civil Service to give up power and all it means, nor for that matter is there any intention on the part of Mr. Baldwin or Sir Samuel Hoare to do otherwise.
('61', 164, 1, 20, 319922) Now for your important argument about untouchability.
('61', 164, 1, 21, 319976) But there is this initial flaw about it.
('61', 164, 1, 22, 320017) My life is one indivisible whole.
('61', 164, 1, 23, 320051) It is not built after the compartmental system—satyagraha, civil resistance, untouchability, Hindu Muslim unity and several other things I could name are not different things to be taken and handled.

('61', 174, 1, 5, 337029) I have seen so many such cases.
('61', 174, 1, 6, 337061) Therefore, what I suggest to you is to calmly analyse the reason for being late and to avoid it.
('61', 174, 1, 7, 337158) You have given the reason in these cases yourself for not leaving your work in time for prayer.
('61', 174, 1, 8, 337254) Therefore you should now be careful and leave the work in time to reach the prayer ground in peace.
('61', 174, 1, 9, 337354) Constant watch over one’s minutes guards one from all such difficulties.
('61', 174, 1, 10, 337427) Your long letter of 13th instant is too imaginative and too poetic for me.
('61', 174, 1, 11, 337502) You have plenty of poetry in you.
('61', 174, 1, 12, 337536) Your imagination knows no bounds.
('61', 174, 1, 13, 337570) I want you to transmute these into an inexhaustible power for real service.
('61', 174, 1, 14, 337646) We have all to aspire after being childlike.
('61', 174, 1, 15, 337691) We cannot become children because that is impossible.
('61', 174, 1, 16, 337745) But we can all become like children.
('61', 174, 1, 17, 337782) In spite of the knowledge gained, we can become simple, guileless, candid and natural like them.
('61', 174, 1, 18, 337879) Here the word ‘natural’ has a definite meaning.
('61', 174, 1, 19, 337927) All the virtues that we may prize should not be an artificial growth, possible only in a hothouse, but they must be as natural to us as perhaps mischief is natural to children.
('61', 174, 1, 20, 338104) We love their mischief because it is so natural to them.
('61', 174, 1, 21, 338161) The mischief of grown up ones lies in their being naturally good, restrained, humble and proof against temptation.
('61', 174, 1, 22, 338276) I want to warn you against putting the construction you have put upon the scarcity of the monthly flow.
('61', 174, 1, 23, 338380) My fear is that the decrease is not, in you, a healthy sign.
('61', 174, 1, 24, 338441) You are not yet free from the sex emotion, and unless you are entirely from it in thought, word and deed, irregularity on scarcity in your monthly condition must be regarded as a sign of some internal derangement.
('61', 174, 1, 25, 338655) I am afraid that ordinarily speaking, you will take a long time to reach that condition, unless you and I and the Ashram are so blessed that you suddenly reach the requisite condition of natural purity that would stop the monthly flow and be a sign of perfect health.
('61', 174, 1, 26, 338923) When you reach that state you will have no boils, etc., and no other bodily or mental ailment.
('61', 174, 1, 27, 339018) You will be the happy possessor of the qualities that we pray for every evening at the prayer time.
('61', 174, 1, 28, 339118) I refer you to the last verses of the second chapter of the Gita.
('61', 174, 2, 29, 339184) Pray, do not disturb yourself over the milk treatment though I know that 10 lb.
('61', 174, 2, 30, 339264) of milk is an unnatural diet.
('61', 174, 2, 31, 339294) As a medicinal treatment

('61', 177, 3, 8, 343524) 229. LETTER TO JAIKRISHNA P. BHANSALI
('61', 177, 4, 9, 343562) June 20, 1933
('61', 177, 5, 10, 343576) BHANSALI,
('61', 177, 6, 11, 343586) I was delighted to see a letter from you after so many days, I mean so many months, but I was also pained to read it.
('61', 177, 6, 12, 343704) I hold that the remedies you are adopting for attaining self realization are not right.
('61', 177, 6, 13, 343792) If anybody stitches up his lips in order to observe silence, his silence would not be the real thing.
('61', 177, 6, 14, 343894) One can observe silence even by cutting off one’s tongue, but that also will not be real silence.
('61', 177, 6, 15, 343992) He is truly silent, who, having the capacity to speak, utters no idle word.
('61', 177, 6, 16, 344068) The type of tapas which you are practising is described by the author of the Gita as tamasi tapas, and I think that is correct.
('61', 177, 6, 17, 344196) You eat uncooked flour, but that is against medical science.
('61', 177, 6, 18, 344257) Shastras never enjoin anybody to do so.
('61', 177, 6, 19, 344297) If you have decided to eat nothing but uncooked things, you can eat only fruits, etc.
('61', 177, 6, 20, 344383) You may add milk or curds, that would be complete food.
('61', 177, 6, 21, 344439) I think it would be better if you gave up this unnatural effort completely.
('61', 177, 6, 22, 344515) Reflect over the bhajan given below:
('61', 177, 7, 23, 344552) Oh good man!
('61', 177, 7, 24, 344565) Natural communion is best.
('61', 177, 7, 25, 344592) Ever since by the Grace of God it was achieved, it has been growing.
('61', 177, 7, 26, 344661) Wherever I wander it is a circuit round the Deity, whatever I do is an act of service, every lying down of mine is an act of prostration before God.
('61', 177, 7, 27, 344810) Every utterance of mine is God’s name—1 worship no other God—and all hearing is a remembrance of God.
('61', 177, 7, 28, 344912) Eating and drinking are acts of worship and living in a house or in the wilderness are the same to me.
('61', 177, 7, 29, 345015) I shut not my eyes, neither do I stuff my ears; to no torture do I subject myself.
('61', 177, 7, 30, 345098) I open my eyes to find nothing but the beautiful manifestation of God everywhere to greet and delight me.
('61', 177, 7, 31, 345204) My mind ever intent on Him, all corrupt thought has left me; so very much I am engrossed in contemplation of Him that there is no room in me for aught else.
('61', 177, 7, 32, 345361) Kabir says—This is a state to
('61', 178, 0, 1, 345391) VOL. 61 : 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 179
('61', 178, 1, 2, 345436) be silently enjoyed but I have dared to sing about it.
('61', 178, 1, 3, 345491) It is a state beyond misery and bliss, I am merged in it.

('61', 178, 2, 5, 345657) You may then, in the course of time, attain self realization if you are fortunate enough.

('61', 183, 4, 21, 355199) 236. LETTER TO DR.
('61', 183, 4, 22, 355218) SYED MAHMUD
('61', 183, 5, 23, 355230) ‘PARNAKUTI’, POONA, June 26, 1933
('61', 183, 6, 24, 355264) DEAR DR.
('61', 183, 6, 25, 355273) MAHMUD, Domestic sorrow dogs your footsteps, no matter wherever you go.
('61', 183, 6, 26, 355345) I see now that Begum Mahmud is probably suffering from typhoid and that you have taken her to Delhi.
('61', 183, 6, 27, 355446) A big risk, but I suppose it was worth taking in order to put her under Dr. Ansari’s care.
('61', 183, 6, 28, 355537) I hope that she is making steady progress.
('61', 183, 6, 29, 355580) Devdas showed me the presents that you had brought.
('61', 183, 6, 30, 355632) Whilst I appreciated your and Jalbhai’s 3 affection underlying those presents, I felt that silk things ought not to be accepted because consistently with the past profession and practice, Lakshmi could not, if she can help it, wear silken things.
('61', 183, 6, 31, 355879) Having given that opinion, I left the decision to Lakshmi, Rajaji and Devdas.
('61', 183, 6, 32, 355957) They all felt like me, as to the use of silken things, but they had some delicacy about returning such gifts to
('61', 183, 7, 33, 356069) 1 Illegible 2 ibid.
('61', 183, 7, 34, 356089) 3 Grandson of Dadabhoy Naoroji
('61', 184, 0, 1, 356120) VOL. 61 : 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 185
('61', 184, 1, 2, 356165) friends who had presented them out of affection.
('61', 184, 1, 3, 356214) I undertook to perform the task if they agreed that such gifts should be returned.
('61', 184, 1, 4, 356297) When Mrs. Naidu heard all this discussion, she said that if perchance your gift was not accepted she should take charge of it.
('61', 184, 1, 5, 356424) I, therefore, took the liberty of returning your sari to her.
('61', 184, 1, 6, 356486) Jalbhai’s sari is being returned to him.
('61', 184, 1, 7, 356527) Mathuradas is presently going to Bombay for a day or so when he will take it.
('61', 184, 1, 8, 356605) But the bag and the other contents have been retained and I hope that you will be satisfied that they would be a constant reminder to Devdas and Lakshmi of your affection.
('61', 184, 1, 9, 356777) The third friend, who sent silken saris, was Ghanshyamdas Birla.
('61', 184, 1, 10, 356842) I spoke to him about them.
('61', 184, 1, 11, 356869) He appreciated our difficulty and gladly took them back.
('61', 184, 1, 12, 356926) The moral of this, I would like to point out.
('61', 184, 1, 13, 356972) Next time you happen to make presents to friends you should make yourself acquainted with their capacity for taking and using them.
('61', 184, 1, 14, 357104) Romain Rolland thought that he should give each of us a memento of our visit to his hermitage, and he seems to have passed an anxious night discussing with his sister what he should give me.
('61', 184, 1, 15, 357295) He could not think of books, or any other useful articles.
('61', 184, 1, 16, 357354) Therefore, he parted with a trifling but a most artistic box, meant possibly to be a snuff box.
('61', 184, 1, 17, 357450) Even that is too valuable a treasure for me.
('61', 184, 1, 18, 357495) It will, therefore, go to the Vidyapith Museum.
('61', 184, 1, 19, 357543) Of course, I had no compunction about accepting that little box.
('61', 184, 1, 20, 357608) I have mentioned this very beautiful incident as it is so relevant and as I know it would please you and at the same time emphasize what I want to say.
('61', 184, 1, 21, 357760) I do not know as to what your movement will be.
('61', 184, 1, 22, 357808) If you are not able to come this way and that pretty soon, I would like you to give me your views on the political situation.
('61', 184, 1, 23, 357934) What will you have me to do and what should be done by Congressmen in general?
('61', 184, 1, 24, 358013) Where is Sherwani?
('61', 184, 1, 25, 358032) If this reaches you in Delhi, I would like you to, at least, share this part of the letter with Dr. Ansari and if he is not likely to see me early next month, I would like him to give me his opinion.
('61', 184, 2, 26, 358232) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI DR.

('61', 185, 1, 2, 358405) 237. LETTER TO MOTILAL ROY
('61', 185, 2, 3, 358432) June 26, 1933
('61', 185, 3, 4, 358446) DEAR MOTIBABU, You will pardon me for not replying to your letter earlier.
('61', 185, 3, 5, 358521) The fact is that I am still confined to bed and have only limited energy for dictating letters.
('61', 185, 3, 6, 358617) Much of my time is passed in attending to the bodily needs.
('61', 185, 3, 7, 358677) As you will see from the current issue of the Harijan 1 a portion of your letter dealing with the opening of temples had already been reproduced 2. Extraordinary care has been taken to publish only verifiable statements and yet errors will creep in.
('61', 185, 3, 8, 358927) Thank God, there are watchmen like you who do not fail to draw attention to any error that might creep into the columns of the Harijan.
('61', 185, 3, 9, 359063) It is difficult, in human affairs, to ensure cent per cent accuracy and it is equally difficult to keep out reports of relevant events for fear of inaccuracy creeping in.
('61', 185, 3, 10, 359234) All, therefore, that we fallible human beings can do, is to be over cautious about all our speech, action and thought and ever be ready to retrace our steps and confess our errors whenever we meet them.
('61', 185, 3, 11, 359437) As soon as I am in a fit state, I propose to write in the Harijan on the fast.
('61', 185, 3, 12, 359516) 3 I, therefore, say nothing about it here.
('61', 185, 3, 13, 359559) I am glad the affairs with you are shaping well.
('61', 185, 3, 14, 359608) The doctor about whom I wrote to you, just now happens to be here.
('61', 185, 3, 15, 359675) As soon as I have had sufficient experience of him I will write to you.
('61', 185, 3, 16, 359747) You ought to attend to your eye trouble without delay.
('61', 185, 4, 17, 359802) Yours, BAPU SJT.
('61', 185, 4, 18, 359819) MOTILAL ROY PRAVARTAK SANGH, CHANDRANAGORE
('61', 185, 5, 19, 359862) From a photostat: G.N. 11045
