('61', 186, 1, 2, 360039) 238. LETTER TO M. ASAF ALI 1
('61', 186, 2, 3, 360068) June 26, 1933
('61', 186, 3, 4, 360082) MY DEAR ASAF ALI, I have your long letter for which I thank you.
('61', 186, 3, 5, 360147) I do not at all mind your having sent it to the Press.
('61', 186, 3, 6, 360202) You had a perfect right to send me that letter and I appreciate the frankness with which you have expressed your views.
('61', 186, 3, 7, 360322) I am, as yet, unable to say anything on the present situation because I am still bed ridden and have not been able to make an analytical study of it.
('61', 186, 3, 8, 360472) I want you, however, to understand my fundamental difficulty which constitutes also my limitation.
('61', 186, 3, 9, 360571) Non violence for me is not a mere experiment.
('61', 186, 3, 10, 360617) It is part of my life and the whole of the creed of satyagraha, non co operation, civil disobedi ence, and the like are necessary deductions from the fundamental proposition that non violence is the law of life for human beings.
('61', 186, 3, 11, 360846) For me it is both a means and an end and I am more than ever convinced that in the complex situation that faces India, there is no other way of gaining real freedom.
('61', 186, 3, 12, 361012) In applying my mind to the present situation I must, therefore, test everything in terms of non violence.
('61', 186, 4, 13, 361118) Yours sincerely M. ASAF ALI, ESQ., BAR AT LAW KUCHA CHELAN, DELHI
('61', 186, 5, 14, 361184) From a photostat: S.N. 19108

('61', 191, 1, 2, 366973) 250. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('61', 191, 2, 3, 366997) June 29, 1933
('61', 191, 3, 4, 367011) MIRA, It is now 5.30 a.m.
('61', 191, 3, 5, 367037) Thursday.
('61', 191, 3, 6, 367047) Your letter is before me.
('61', 191, 3, 7, 367073) It makes me glad to think that you are well again and daily gaining strength.
('61', 191, 3, 8, 367151) We have to acquire the faculty for keeping well under all weathers—a difficult task I know.
('61', 191, 3, 9, 367243) But it is not beyond human reach.
('61', 191, 3, 10, 367277) The mind plays a great part in it.
('61', 191, 3, 11, 367312) If we can completely detach ourselves from the externals in terms of the 6th chapter, we can attain that state.
('61', 191, 3, 12, 367424) That it appears to be beyond our reach for the present need not baffle us.
('61', 191, 3, 13, 367499) The author of the Gita invites us to the effort and says from his abundant experience that it never fails.
('61', 191, 3, 14, 367606) It may take long but success is a certainty.
('61', 191, 3, 15, 367651) Yes, I did not take salt during the fast.
('61', 191, 3, 16, 367693) It was a virtue of necessity.
('61', 191, 3, 17, 367723) I simply could not take it.
('61', 191, 3, 18, 367751) I never attempted it because there was repugnance towards it and there was no necessity for it as there was about soda which therefore I took willynilly.
('61', 191, 3, 19, 367905) My weight yesterday was 97_ and I walked altogether 44 minutes in three periods without feeling fatigued.
('61', 191, 3, 20, 368011) It was therefore a good record.
('61', 191, 3, 21, 368043) Nor is there difficulty about some conversation.
('61', 191, 3, 22, 368092) Radha and Keshu are with me just now.
('61', 191, 3, 23, 368130) Radha is somewhat better.
('61', 191, 3, 24, 368156) She goes back to Deolali today.
('61', 191, 3, 25, 368188) Keshu will be with me for a few days to finish his conversations.
('61', 191, 3, 26, 368254) Poor Prabhudas !
('61', 191, 3, 27, 368271) The contemplated tie is off.
('61', 191, 3, 28, 368300) Therefore there has to be a further search.
('61', 191, 4, 29, 368344) Devdas and Lakshmi and Rajaji with his widowed daughter 2 and his son are still here and are likely to be for some time.
('61', 191, 4, 30, 368465) As for the Mahabharata reading, you should take down the names of all the persons with their short history and their connection with one another and have an alphabetical index to enable you at once to find the history of any name in your note book.
('61', 191, 4, 31, 368714) The preparation of such a book will clear your mind and be of great use to others too, if it is accurately prepared.
('61', 191, 4, 32, 368831) You are quite right when you say that a Hindi translation reads

('61', 192, 10, 15, 369517) 253. LETTER TO MARGARETE SPIEGEL
('61', 192, 11, 16, 369550) ‘PARNAKUTI’, POONA, June 30, 1933
('61', 192, 12, 17, 369584) AMALA, In spite of your grandmotherly advice I must persist in the course I have adopted about my diet.

('61', 194, 1, 2, 372048) 254. LETTER TO N.
('61', 194, 2, 3, 372066) June 30, 1933
('61', 194, 4, 4, 372080) I have your letters by me.
('61', 194, 4, 5, 372107) I deal with the last first.
('61', 194, 4, 6, 372135) You are going through a terrible but wonderful trial and I hope that God will give you the strength to stand it.
('61', 194, 4, 7, 372248) If you will but realize that we are an utterly poor family, that we are far away from the ideal of poverty, you will find the burden easy to bear and the illness of S. an ordinary occurrence in the lives of poor people.
('61', 194, 4, 8, 372468) You will have a doctor, not so the bona fide poor.
('61', 194, 4, 9, 372519) They do not even know what a doctor can be.
('61', 194, 4, 10, 372563) They have the utterly incompetent village physician and they have to be satisfied with what services his often selfish nature would permit him to render.
('61', 194, 4, 11, 372717) You will, therefore, be quite content with whatever relief can be afforded to S. in the Ashram itself.
('61', 194, 4, 12, 372820) You will not compare yourself to some of the pampered Ashramites whom your keen faculty for observation could not have missed.
('61', 194, 4, 13, 372947) But when you have a feeling of irritation over this knowledge and resentment that neither you nor S. can be pampered, recall the fact that one whom you have adopted as your father is the first among the pampered Ashramites and if you are prepared to suffer my being pampered, then you will find it easy to tolerate the pampering of others and then, perhaps, you will find why they are pampered, if they are pampered, and then you will make the further discovery that compared to yet others you yourself might also be ranked amongst the pampered for there are degrees in pampering.
('61', 194, 4, 14, 373528) Anyway, I want you to be happy, calm, and contented in the face of S.’s illness and your own boils.
('61', 194, 4, 15, 373628) You and I sail in the same boat in the distrust of doctors, but that distrust has to have its recognized limitations and must be based upon enlightenment.
('61', 194, 4, 16, 373783) You are wholly unjust to the doctors who are attending upon me.
('61', 194, 4, 17, 373847) They have been most careful, conscientious and helpful.
('61', 194, 4, 18, 373903) They have not stopped oranges as you imagine.
('61', 194, 4, 19, 373949) What they have said is according to the latest natural healing methods.
('61', 194, 4, 20, 374021) They know that I am not likely to accept any of their nostrums and therefore they are making an honest effort to suit my peculiarities.
('61', 194, 4, 21, 374157) I can describe to you what they have prescribed, what exactly I am doing and perhaps you will feel that they have said or done nothing that should offend against the laws of natural healing.
('61', 194, 4, 22, 374348) The use that I want to make of

('61', 196, 1, 2, 376378) 255. LETTER TO B. S. RAO
('61', 196, 2, 3, 376403) June 30, 1933
('61', 196, 3, 4, 376417) MY DEAR GOPALA RAO, I was glad to receive your letter, but I was pained over your persistence in the advice that you have repeated in spite of the very bitter experience of your experiment 1 at the Ashram amongst 40 people under the best of auspices.
('61', 196, 3, 5, 376668) Have you forgotten the complete failure of your experiment?
('61', 196, 3, 6, 376728) Have you forgotten that Mirabai was at death’s door because of her valiant continuance of your experiment in spite of her being deathpale, and in spite of my having almost fallen prostrate with weakness?
('61', 196, 3, 7, 376932) I had warned you against your failure and ignorant persistence in your prescribing uncooked starch.
('61', 196, 3, 8, 377032) I also drew your attention to the fact that you had no scientific mind and that you were utterly indifferent to the well being of those who had the misfortune to be under your care.
('61', 196, 3, 9, 377214) Your vegetable substitute for milk is poison for babies, and I would plead with you to desist from a practice which you must know to have failed.
('61', 196, 3, 10, 377360) That in some cases you might have achieved temporary success only shows how kind and forbearing Nature is.
('61', 196, 3, 11, 377467) She suffers her children to break her laws for a long time and you are taking an undue advantage of Nature’s kindness.
('61', 196, 3, 12, 377586) You will be, perhaps, sorry to learn that I am flourishing on goat’s milk and fruit and there is no prospect of my taking the substitute that you would have me to take.
('61', 196, 3, 13, 377755) I would only plead with you to desist from further endangering the health of simple people who may, trusting you, come to you to have themselves cured.
('61', 196, 3, 14, 377907) I have written strongly because I know the danger with which your ill conceived dietary is fraught, and I shall be happy if you could tell me that you would no longer persist in your experiment which has proved to be wrong.
('61', 196, 4, 15, 378131) Yours sincerely,
('61', 196, 5, 16, 378148) BOLLAPRAGUDU SUNDARAGOPALA RAO

('61', 201, 6, 13, 385134) 266. DISCUSSION WITH HARIJAN WORKERS, POONA1
('61', 201, 7, 14, 385179) [July 2, 1933] 2
('61', 201, 8, 15, 385196) I am not against propaganda of the right kind on the right lines.
('61', 201, 8, 16, 385262) Temperance propaganda among Harijans would certainly be welfare work, but it should be done with the minimum of expense.
('61', 201, 8, 17, 385383) If Harijans of spotless character could be found to go to Harijan areas to carry on this propaganda, all the money would go into Harijans’ pockets, and propaganda, too, would be most effectively done.
('61', 201, 8, 18, 385584) A question is asked whether I would prefer an inefficient Harijan teacher to an efficient savarna Hindu teacher of character.
('61', 201, 8, 19, 385710) Here, as on all questions of the character, I would say I would endeavour to secure a Harijan teacher of character and then try to bring him up to the mark, so far as educational qualifications are concerned.
('61', 201, 8, 20, 385919) I would no doubt think of
('61', 201, 9, 21, 385945) 1 Extracted from “Sparks from the Sacred Fire IX” by Mahadev Desai who had reported “For the first time after the fast, Gandhiji met a fairly large gathering of workers and talked to them.
('61', 201, 9, 22, 386134) The Servants of Untouchables Society had its General Board meeting in the Servants of India Society, but the members came in a body to ‘Parnakuti’ to ascertain Gandhiji’s views on certain questions.
('61', 201, 9, 23, 386333) Was it to be propaganda v.
('61', 201, 9, 24, 386360) welfare work, or propaganda cum welfare work, or no propaganda and only welfare work?
('61', 201, 9, 25, 386446) Gandhiji had insisted on strictly limiting ‘overhead charges’ and administration expenditure.
('61', 201, 9, 26, 386540) But many points werer aised Interpreting this rule.
('61', 201, 9, 27, 386592) For instance, would expenses on village propaganda, say, against the drink evil among Harijans, be considered to be money well spent?
('61', 201, 9, 28, 386726) I shall try to summarize Gandhiji’s views on this question.” 2 Vide the postscript to the following item.
('61', 202, 0, 1, 386832) VOL. 61 : 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 203
('61', 202, 1, 2, 386877) the children’s own good rather than of accommodating a particular Harijan candidate, but all questions would have to be decided on merits.
('61', 202, 1, 3, 387016) All that I would say is: ‘Don’t make a fetish of efficiency.’ But we can make one general rule as regards propaganda: Let propaganda charges be voted each time.
('61', 202, 1, 4, 387177) The more I think the more convinced I feel that, if our work is to abide, we shall have to cut down mere propaganda expenses to a minimum.
('61', 202, 1, 5, 387316) Where there is the possibility of recurring expenditure on propaganda, let our expenses be divided into three parts: 20 per cent administration charges; 20 per cent propaganda; 60 per cent welfare work.
('61', 202, 1, 6, 387519) You ask whether a Harijan Day should be observed as we have been doing.
('61', 202, 1, 7, 387591) I would say: observe it, but if it is properly observed, no expense need be incurred.
('61', 202, 1, 8, 387677) The Harijan Day should not mean carving a slice out of the little balance you may have.
('61', 202, 1, 9, 387765) In the same way, I should not spend Rs. 75 to get a donation of Rs. 100, i.e., a net donation of Rs. 25. I do not say that propaganda is bad; propaganda wisely directed is necessary.
('61', 202, 1, 10, 387948) But I would say that propaganda could be made selfsupporting.
('61', 202, 1, 11, 388010) Do not touch your funds for, say, a reception or a procession; recover the charges from sympathetic local friends and don’t burden your accounts with them.
('61', 202, 1, 12, 388166) Let us always remember that severe critics are watching us If we do everything in a religious spirit, without any reward, our work is bound to tell.

('61', 210, 5, 16, 404603) If there is truth in the epigram that in the midst of life we are in death, is not the converse true also that in the midst of death we are in life?
('61', 210, 5, 17, 404752) That at any rate was my feeling during a friend’s interview with Gandhiji the other day.
('61', 210, 6, 18, 404841) He had waited some days to tell me that he wanted a few minutes with Gandhiji before he returned to his place.

('61', 217, 5, 10, 416826) It is, perhaps, meet that the very first writing for the Press I should attempt after the fast should be for the Harijan, and that in connection with the fast.
('61', 217, 5, 11, 416986) God willing, I hope now to contribute my weekly quota to the Harijan as before the fast.
('61', 217, 5, 12, 417075) Let no one, however, run away with the idea that I have regained my pre fast capacity for work.

('61', 217, 5, 14, 417215) Correspondents will, therefore, have mercy on me.

('61', 217, 5, 16, 417353) Whatever they may have for my special attention will have still to wait for some time, probably yet another month.
('61', 217, 5, 17, 417468) Who knows what will happen a month hence?
('61', 217, 5, 18, 417510) We are short lived and do not know even what will happen the next moment.
('61', 217, 5, 19, 417584) Then what can one say about the ambitions of a Harijan worker like myself?
('61', 217, 5, 20, 417659) To those who buy and read Harijanbandhu in a spirit of service, my advice is that they should not wait for my writings and opinions.
('61', 217, 5, 21, 417792) The way for rendering service to Harijans is quite clear.
('61', 217, 5, 22, 417850) The field is vast.
('61', 217, 5, 23, 417869) Harijanbandhu endeavours to give an idea of the week’s activities.
('61', 217, 5, 24, 417936) It also attempts to indicate what needs to be done, what can be done and how it is to be done.
('61', 217, 5, 25, 418031) From that all could find one or the other way of service.
('61', 217, 5, 26, 418089) Then where is the need of my writing or opinion?
('61', 217, 5, 27, 418138) If I am tempted to write about it, it is only for my own satisfaction.
('61', 217, 5, 28, 418209) I have to write only when I have something to say or explain to the readers.
('61', 217, 5, 29, 418286) I hope readers won’t be disheartened and will maintain their relations with Harijanbandhu irrespective of whether I have something to write or not and whether I have the strength and the leisure.

('61', 218, 0, 1, 418576) VOL. 61 : 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 219
('61', 218, 1, 2, 418621) Now for the fast.
('61', 218, 1, 3, 418639) The first question that has puzzled many is about the Voice of God.
('61', 218, 1, 4, 418707) What was it?
('61', 218, 1, 5, 418720) What did I hear?
('61', 218, 1, 6, 418737) Was there any person I saw?
('61', 218, 1, 7, 418765) Ifnot, how was the Voice conveyed to me?
('61', 218, 1, 8, 418806) These are pertinent questions.
('61', 218, 1, 9, 418837) For me the voice of God, of Conscience, of Truth or the Inner Voice or ‘the still small Voice’ mean one and the same thing.
('61', 218, 1, 10, 418961) I saw no form.
('61', 218, 1, 11, 418976) I have never tried, for I have always believed God to be without form.
('61', 218, 1, 12, 419047) One who realizes God is freed from sin for ever.
('61', 218, 1, 13, 419096) He has no desire to be fulfilled.
('61', 218, 1, 14, 419130) Not even in his thoughts will he suffer from faults, imperfections or impurities.
('61', 218, 1, 15, 419212) Whatever he does will be perfect because he does nothing himself but the God within him does everything.
('61', 218, 1, 16, 419317) He is completely merged in Him.
('61', 218, 1, 17, 419349) Such realization comes to one among tens of millions.
('61', 218, 1, 18, 419403) That it can come I have no doubt at all.
('61', 218, 1, 19, 419444) I yearn to have such realization but I have not got it yet and I know that I am yet very far from it.
('61', 218, 1, 20, 419546) The inspiration I had was quite a different thing.
('61', 218, 1, 21, 419597) Moreover, many get such inspiration quite often or at some time.
('61', 218, 1, 22, 419662) There is certainly need for a particular type of sadhana 1 to obtain such inspiration.
('61', 218, 1, 23, 419749) If some efforts and some sadhana are necessary even to acquire the ability to have the commonest thing, what wonder if efforts and sadhana are needed to get divine inspiration?
('61', 218, 1, 24, 419926) The inspiration I got was this: The night I got the inspiration, I had a terrible inner struggle.
('61', 218, 1, 25, 420024) My mind was restless.
('61', 218, 1, 26, 420046) I could see no way.
('61', 218, 1, 27, 420066) The burden of my responsibility was crushing me.
('61', 218, 1, 28, 420115) But what I did hear was like a Voice from afar and yet quite near.
('61', 218, 1, 29, 420182) It was as unmistakable as some human voice definitely speaking to me, and irresistible.
('61', 218, 1, 30, 420270) I was not dreaming at the time I heard the Voice.
('61', 218, 1, 31, 420320) The hearing of the Voice was preceded by a terrific struggle within me.
('61', 218, 1, 32, 420392) Suddenly the Voice came upon me.
('61', 218, 1, 33, 420425) I listened, made certain that it was the Voice, and the struggle ceased.
('61', 218, 1, 34, 420498) I was calm.
('61', 218, 1, 35, 420510) The determination was made accordingly, the date and the hour of the fast were fixed.
('61', 218, 1, 36, 420596) Joy came over me.
('61', 218, 1, 37, 420614) This was between 11 and 12 midnight.
('61', 218, 1, 38, 420651) I felt refreshed and began to write the note 2 about it which the reader must have seen.
('61', 218, 1, 39, 420740) Could I give any further evidence that it was truly the Voice that I heard and that it was not an echo of my own heated imagination?
('61', 218, 1, 40, 420873) I have no further evidence to convince the sceptic.
('61', 218, 1, 41, 420925) He is free to say that it was all self delusion or hallucination.
('61', 218, 1, 42, 420991) It may well have been so.
('61', 218, 1, 43, 421017) I can offer no proof to the contrary.
('61', 218, 1, 44, 421055) But I can say this—that not the
('61', 218, 2, 45, 421087) 1 Spiritual effort 2 Vide “Statement on Fast”, 30 4 1933.
('61', 219, 0, 1, 421145) 220 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 219, 1, 2, 421187) unanimous verdict of the whole world against me could shake me from the belief that what I heard was the true voice of God.
('61', 219, 1, 3, 421311) But some think that God Himself is a creation of our own imagination.
('61', 219, 1, 4, 421381) If that view holds good, then nothing is real, everything is of our own imagination.
('61', 219, 1, 5, 421466) Even so, whilst my imagination dominates me, I can only act under its spell.
('61', 219, 1, 6, 421543) Realest things are only relatively so.
('61', 219, 1, 7, 421582) For me the Voice was more real than my own existence.
('61', 219, 1, 8, 421636) It has never failed me, and for that matter, anyone else.
('61', 219, 1, 9, 421694) And everyone who wills can hear the Voice.
('61', 219, 1, 10, 421737) It is within everyone.
('61', 219, 1, 11, 421760) But like everything else, it requires previous and definite preparation.
('61', 219, 1, 12, 421833) The second question that has puzzled many is whether a fast in which an army of doctors watch and guide the fasting person, as they undoubtedly and with extraordinary care and attention watched and guided me, when he is coddled in various other ways as I was, could be described as a fast in answer to the call of the Inner Voice.
('61', 219, 1, 13, 422164) Put thus, the objection seems valid.
('61', 219, 1, 14, 422201) It would undoubtedly have been more in keeping with the high claim made for the fast, if it had been unattended with all the extraordinary, external aids that it was my good fortune or misfortune to receive.
('61', 219, 1, 15, 422409) But I do not repent of having gratefully accepted the generous help that kind friends extended to me.
('61', 219, 1, 16, 422511) I was battling against death.
('61', 219, 1, 17, 422541) I accepted all the help that came to me as godsend, when it did not in any way affect my vow.
('61', 219, 1, 18, 422635) As I think over the past, I am not sorry for having taken the fast.
('61', 219, 1, 19, 422703) Though I suffered bodily pain and discomfort, there was indescribable peace within.
('61', 219, 1, 20, 422787) I have enjoyed peace during all my fasts but never so much as in this.
('61', 219, 1, 21, 422858) Perhaps, the reason was that there was nothing to look forward to.
('61', 219, 1, 22, 422925) In the previous fasts there was some tangible expectation.
('61', 219, 1, 23, 422984) In this there was nothing tangible to expect.
('61', 219, 1, 24, 423030) There was undoubtedly faith that it must lead to purification of self and others and that workers would know that true Harijan service was impossible without inward purity.
('61', 219, 1, 25, 423203) This, however, is a result that could not be measured or known in a tangible manner.
('61', 219, 1, 26, 423288) I had, therefore, withdrawn within myself.
('61', 219, 1, 27, 423331) The nature of the fast deserves some more consideration.
('61', 219, 1, 28, 423388) Was it mere mortification of the flesh?
('61', 219, 1, 29, 423428) I firmly believe that a fast taken for mortification of the flesh does some good from the medical point of view; apart from that it produces no particular effect.
('61', 219, 1, 30, 423591) I know my fast
('61', 220, 0, 1, 423606) VOL. 61 : 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 221
('61', 220, 1, 2, 423651) was not at all meant for the mortification of the flesh.
('61', 220, 1, 3, 423708) Nor was I ready for it.
('61', 220, 1, 4, 423732) The time of the fast was beyond my imagination.
('61', 220, 1, 5, 423780) From the letters then written to friends it is clear that I did not foresee any immediate fast.
('61', 220, 1, 6, 423876) For me, this fast was a supplication or prayer to God coming from the depth of my heart.
('61', 220, 1, 7, 423965) The fast was an uninterrupted twenty one days, prayer whose effect I can feel even now.
('61', 220, 1, 8, 424053) I know now more fully than ever that there is no prayer without fasting, be the latter ever so little.
('61', 220, 1, 9, 424156) And this fasting relates not merely to the palate, but all the senses and organs.
('61', 220, 1, 10, 424238) Complete absorption in prayer must mean complete exclusion of physical activities till prayer possesses the whole of our being and we rise superior to, and are completely detached from, all physical functions.
('61', 220, 1, 11, 424448) That state can only be reached after continual and voluntary crucifixion of the flesh.
('61', 220, 1, 12, 424535) Thus all fasting, if it is a spiritual act, is an intense prayer or a preparation for it.
('61', 220, 1, 13, 424625) It is a yearning of the soul to merge in the divine essence.
('61', 220, 1, 14, 424686) My last fast was intended to be such a preparation.
('61', 220, 1, 15, 424738) How far I have succeeded, how far I am in tune with the Infinite, I do not know.
('61', 220, 1, 16, 424819) But I do know that the fast has made the passion for such a state intenser than ever.
('61', 220, 2, 17, 424905) Looking back upon the fast, I fed it to have been as necessary as I felt it was when I entered upon it.
('61', 220, 2, 18, 425009) It has resulted in some revelations of impurities among workers of which I had no knowledge whatsoever, and but for the fast I would never have gained that knowledge.
('61', 220, 2, 19, 425176) All the letters that have come under my notice go to show that it has led to greater purification among the workers.
('61', 220, 2, 20, 425293) The fast was meant not for the purification of known workers only who had been found wanting, but for all the workers, known and unknown, in the Harijan cause.
('61', 220, 2, 21, 425453) Nothing probably could have brought home to the workers so well as this fast the fact that the movement is purely religious in the highest sense of the term, to be handled in a religious spirit by workers of character above reproach.
('61', 220, 3, 22, 425687) The work of removal of untouchability is not merely a social or economic reform whose extent can be measured by so much social amenities or economic relief provided in so much time.
('61', 220, 3, 23, 425869) Its goal is to touch the hearts of the millions of Hindus who honestly believe in the present day untouchability as a God made institution, as old as the human race itself.
('61', 220, 3, 24, 426042) This, it will be admitted, is a task infinitely higher than mere social and economic reform.
('61', 220, 3, 25, 426135) Its accomplishment undoub tedly includes all these and much more.
('61', 220, 3, 26, 426201) For it means nothing short of a complete revolution in the Hindu thought and the disappearance of
('61', 221, 0, 1, 426299) 222 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 221, 1, 2, 426341) the horrible and terrible doctrine of inborn inequality and high and lowness, which has poisoned Hinduism and is slowly undermining its very existence.
('61', 221, 1, 3, 426493) Such a change can only be brought about by an appeal to the highest in man.
('61', 221, 1, 4, 426569) And I am more than ever convinced that that appeal can be made effective only by self purification, i.e., by fasting conceived as the deepest prayer coming from a lacerated heart.
('61', 221, 1, 5, 426749) I believe that the invisible effect of such fasting is far greater and far more extensive than the visible effect.
('61', 221, 1, 6, 426864) The conviction has, therefore, gone deeper in me that my fast is but the beginning of a chain of true voluntary fasts by men and women who have qualified themselves by previous preparation for them and who believe in prayer as the most effective method of reaching the heart of things.
('61', 221, 1, 7, 427150) How that chain can be established I do not know as yet.
('61', 221, 1, 8, 427206) But I am striving after it.
('61', 221, 1, 9, 427234) If it can be established, I know that it will touch, as nothing else will, the hearts of Hindus, both the opponents of reform and the Harijans.
('61', 221, 1, 10, 427378) For the Harijans have also to play their part in the movement no less than the reformers and the opponents.
('61', 221, 1, 11, 427486) And I am glad to be able to inform the reader that the Harijans have not been untouched by the fast.
('61', 221, 1, 12, 427587) A number of letters received from abroad suggest that even there many hearts have awakened.
('61', 221, 1, 13, 427679) If an imperfect fast by a man like me could create such awakening, who could then estimate how great and far reaching the result would be if innocent men and women unassumingly, without any hope of medical or other aid and without one or the other concession, sacrifice their lives in an unbroken chain of fasts?
('61', 221, 2, 14, 427992) Harijan, 8 7 1933

('61', 223, 5, 10, 429838) ‘PARNAKUTI’, POONA 6, July 9, 1933
('61', 223, 6, 11, 429873) DEAR MR. MACRAE, I thank you for sending me the first page of your father’s letter containing his reference to my fast.
('61', 223, 6, 12, 429993) My position in regard to the principal religions of the world has been explained fairly often in the pages of Young India and elsewhere.
('61', 223, 6, 13, 430130) I believe in the truth of them all and I have studied them to the best of my ability, not as a critic but as a seeker after Truth and therefore have received much assistance from their study.
('61', 223, 6, 14, 430322) So far as I know it, a change in the fundamental position that I hold today is not likely.
('61', 223, 6, 15, 430413) Whilst I regard Jesus to be one of the greatest religious teachers, I do not believe in His exclusive divinity.
('61', 223, 6, 16, 430525) You will be surprised to know that my belief in fasting, as a form of intense prayer, began before I knew anything of the teachings of Jesus.
('61', 223, 6, 17, 430667) But when I came to read the Bible, the Koran and the other scriptures, my position was further fortified by the knowledge that they advocated fasting as a help to heartfelt prayer and communion with God.
('61', 223, 6, 18, 430871) I return the page from your father’s letter.
('61', 223, 7, 19, 430916) Yours sincerely, Enclosure

('61', 225, 4, 9, 432863) 291. SPEECH AT LEADERS’ CONFERENCE, POONA 1
('61', 225, 5, 10, 432907) July 12, 1933
('61', 225, 6, 11, 432921) Gandhiji, speaking next, 3 is reported to have narrated to the conference as to why he undertook the fast.
('61', 225, 6, 12, 433028) After the fast he had received several suggestions regarding the position of the movement in the country.
('61', 225, 6, 13, 433134) Severa1 Congressmen had urged him to call off the movement and in order to ascertain their views, this Workers’ Conference had been called.
('61', 225, 6, 14, 433274) He said that it had been suggested that Messrs Shastri and Birla should also be invited to the conference but he was of opinion, that if Messrs Shastri and Birla were invited, others of similar views should not be left uninvited.
('61', 225, 6, 15, 433504) The Conference being of the Congressmen, Gandhiji advised that no invitation should be sent to non Congressmen.
('61', 225, 7, 16, 433616) That he was very keen about establishing peace in the country, and that he would certainly try his but to secure it, Mr. Gandhi is reported to have remarked in the course of his speech.
('61', 225, 8, 17, 433802) Mr. Gandhi stated that the necessity for calling the conference had arisen not because circumstances had altered or that the Government had offered terms, but because of the peculiar circumstances created by his fast and his consequent release.
('61', 225, 8, 18, 434047) He felt ashamed that one man should have been responsible for this, but he could not help it.
('61', 225, 9, 19, 434141) Asking the delegates to express their views freely and frankly, Mr. Gandhi stated that he would like to have their views whether they wanted suspension of the civil disobedience movement indefinitely or for a definite period with conditions, as he had gathered that some were of opinion that it should be an unconditional calling off, while others thought it should be a kind of truce and some conditions should be laid down for acceptance by the Government.
('61', 225, 9, 20, 434600) After hearing their views, Mr. Gandhi

('61', 227, 11, 22, 438535) The same position has been consistently maintained by Government in numerous subsequent statements.

('61', 228, 0, 1, 439087) VOL. 61 : 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 229
('61', 228, 1, 2, 439132) acceptance of conditional freedom to carry on propaganda regarding untouchability, and (3) suspension of civil disobedience movement.
('61', 228, 1, 3, 439266) As regards change in the communal award I had stated at the Round Table Conference that I would perish in fighting against separate electorates for untouchables.
('61', 228, 2, 4, 439428) Consistent with that statement he had to get the communal award changed, and hence had to carry on correspondence with Government.
('61', 228, 2, 5, 439559) Fast and further propaganda from inside the jail were the natural consequences.
('61', 228, 3, 6, 439639) Answering the third charge, Gandhiji is reported to have stated that as soon as jail gates were banged behind him he thought he would not be able to sustain during the fast ale hearing of reports of arrests, lathi charges, etc., and hence requested Mr. Aney to suspend the movement.
('61', 228, 4, 7, 439922) Speaking about civil disobedience movement Gandhiji is stated to have spoken in the following strain: I have carefully heard the speeches of everyone, the more so of those speaking for withdrawal; I have heard their arguments, but I am still unconvinced.
('61', 228, 4, 8, 440177) I would use the very same arguments in favour of continuation of the movement.
('61', 228, 4, 9, 440256) I was sorry to hear several speakers say that workers were tired and wanted rest.
('61', 228, 4, 10, 440338) I would have appreciated if they had said they themselves were tired.
('61', 228, 4, 11, 440408) The workers were not tired.
('61', 228, 4, 12, 440436) The country was not tired.
('61', 228, 4, 13, 440463) The country was prepared to continue.
('61', 228, 4, 14, 440501) I am sorry at the lack of confidence of certain leaders.
('61', 228, 4, 15, 440558) I am definite that withdrawal of the movement without an honourable settlement would be a false and fatal [step], attended by deadly consequences.
('61', 228, 4, 16, 440705) We should be betraying the confidence of the nation reposed in us.
('61', 228, 4, 17, 440772) The Government wants complete surrender.
('61', 228, 4, 18, 440813) I would rather be reduced to dust than surrender.
('61', 228, 4, 19, 440863) How can we call off the movement when Government had not granted the national demand?
('61', 228, 4, 20, 440949) It is a mistake to say that the movement began in 1930. The real movement began in 1920, and the fight is being continued, though there was a lull of a few years.
('61', 228, 4, 21, 441112) It cannot be withdrawn now.
('61', 228, 4, 22, 441140) A true satyagrahi will go on fighting till the end, till he got what he had aimed at.
('61', 228, 4, 23, 441226) I have heard several speakers referring to lack of numbers.
('61', 228, 4, 24, 441286) Those who say this do not know the A.B.C. of satyagraha.
('61', 228, 4, 25, 441343) I do not mind numbers.
('61', 228, 4, 26, 441366) I can quote historical facts where a handful have fought against heavy odds, and won.
('61', 228, 5, 27, 441452) The speaker felt sorry at the attitude taken by people who stood for withdrawal.
('61', 228, 5, 28, 441533) He said the country was not tired but a few leaders were.
('61', 228, 5, 29, 441591) He gave an
('61', 229, 0, 1, 441602) 230 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 229, 1, 2, 441644) example of Kathiawar bullocks.
('61', 229, 1, 3, 441675) When one of the two bullocks sat down the other also was forced to sit down, but if the one that was standing was strong enough, the other that was sitting would be made to stand up.
('61', 229, 1, 4, 441858) Gandhiji is stated to have said that due to repression it was not possible to carry on mass civil disobedience, and hence he had prepared a scheme for individual satyagraha, where every worker was his own leader.
('61', 229, 1, 5, 442071) Referring to the constructive programme suggested by several speakers, Gandhiji is said to have stated that it was a delusion.
('61', 229, 1, 6, 442198) It was impossible to carry on any constructive programme in the country if the movement was withdrawn.
('61', 229, 1, 7, 442301) Referring to another speaker’s suggestion that one crore of Congress members should be enrolled, Gandhiji said that it was an impossible programme.
('61', 229, 1, 8, 442449) Not even six members could be enrolled in Bardoli if the movement were to be withdrawn.
('61', 229, 1, 9, 442537) Concluding, Gandhiji said that he was hankering for peace and he would explore all avenues to arrive at an honourable settlement, before resuming civil disobedience.
('61', 229, 1, 10, 442703) Certain friends had objected to his writing to the Viceroy.
('61', 229, 1, 11, 442763) He said a true satyagrahi should not be ashamed to make overtures.
('61', 229, 1, 12, 442830) He must try his best to arrive at an honourable settlement.
('61', 229, 1, 13, 442890) Overture was not being made due to weakness, but with a feeling of full strength.
('61', 229, 1, 14, 442972) He appealed to the Conference that if they thought necessary, he should be authorized to seek unconditional interview from the Viceroy and try to arrive at an honourable settlement.
('61', 229, 1, 15, 443154) Gandhiji who opposed unconditional withdrawal of the movement said that the demand of Government for unconditional withdrawal before negotiations was a trap into which he asked members not to fall.
('61', 229, 1, 16, 443352) After his speech he called upon different members to express their views on his statement.
('61', 229, 1, 17, 443443) He wanted speakers to be frank, and not support him due to personal loyalty to himself.

('61', 229, 3, 19, 443563) 295. THE WRONG WAY
('61', 229, 4, 20, 443582) The following extracts from the letter of a professor who claims to be a sanatanist will be read with interest:
('61', 229, 5, 21, 443694) I am an orthodox sanatanist Brahmin.
('61', 229, 5, 22, 443731) I have rendered my humble services to the cause of sanatana dharma in various capacities.
('61', 229, 5, 23, 443821) I have even written books and published articles concerning sanatana dharma.
('61', 229, 5, 24, 443898) Various
('61', 229, 6, 25, 443906) 1 After Gandhiji’s speech the conference was adjourned for one hour to allow members to discuss and express their opinions.
('61', 229, 6, 26, 444030) When the conference reassembled, Gandhiji answered several questions put by the delegates; vide Appendix “Answers to Questions”, 14 7 1933. The Conference authorized Gandhiji to seek unconditional interview with the Viceroy; vide the preceding item.
('61', 230, 0, 1, 444280) VOL. 61 : 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 231
('61', 230, 1, 2, 444325) orthodox sanatanist organizations and leaders will bear me out in my statement.
('61', 230, 1, 3, 444405) So I have proved my bona fides to speak for sanatana dharma.
('61', 230, 1, 4, 444466) Up till now, I was also an opponent of temple entry by Harijans but my inner voice today, all of a sudden, spoke to me that, unless the so called untouchables are given the right of having darshan of patitapavana Bhagavan in temples, Hinduism is doomed.
('61', 230, 1, 5, 444720) Bitter experiences of past months have compelled me to revolutionize my views now.
('61', 230, 1, 6, 444803) 1 know my statement will surprise many.
('61', 230, 1, 7, 444843) Most of them may even call me a renegade now, but to me safety of Hindus and of Hinduism is a sacred religious duty for which I will not mind vilification.
('61', 230, 1, 8, 444999) The plight of Hindus in these days is very pathetic.
('61', 230, 1, 9, 445052) They have now become a constant prey to untold sufferings and agonies.
('61', 230, 1, 10, 445123) Whenever I see a Hindu in distress, tears flood my eyes and I try my best to relieve him or her of it.
('61', 230, 1, 11, 445226) I rather prefer death to seeing Hindus in such a melancholy condition.
('61', 230, 1, 12, 445297) But, in order to persuade orthodox sanatanists to agree with me, I request you with all the emphasis at my command to accept a condition that only those Harijans may be freely allowed to enter a temple who have taken a solemn vow to bathe daily, to wear clean clothes, and to discard beef and carrion.
('61', 230, 1, 13, 445599) Poor sanatanists are also not to be blamed.
('61', 230, 1, 14, 445643) It is these unclean habits that are really responsible for the practice of untouchability itself.
('61', 230, 1, 15, 445741) Harijans are themselves to be blamed to a great extent for the disabilities under which they are groaning.
('61', 230, 1, 16, 445848) To ask sanatanists to allow Harijans to enter temples without, at the same time, rebuking them for their evil habits is, I fear, tantamount to putting a premium on them (habits).
('61', 230, 2, 17, 446027) So I entreat you to accept my suggestion, and I assure you that I shall leave no stone unturned to see that it is consented to by my orthodox sanatanist friends too.
('61', 230, 2, 18, 446193) I will also carry on intense propaganda in its favour, and I am confident by grace of Providence I will attain succes.
('61', 230, 2, 19, 446312) Let not the reader think that the reference to the Inner Voice has any connection with my claim regarding the fast.
('61', 230, 2, 20, 446428) It is an independent thought.
('61', 230, 2, 21, 446458) For the letter is dated 25th April last.
('61', 230, 2, 22, 446499) The Editor has unearthed old undisposed of correspondence which was to receive attention.
('61', 230, 2, 23, 446589) I do not know whether the learned professor retains the views expressed in his letter or whether he has modified the position taken up by him as to the conditional temple entry by Harijans.
('61', 230, 2, 24, 446779) But the position taken up by him is typical.
('61', 230, 2, 25, 446824) It is, therefore, necessary to show the fallacy underlying it.
('61', 230, 2, 26, 446887) Whilst I appreciate the conversion of the writer on the temple entry question, I cannot help saying that the condition he seeks to impose upon the Harijans will frustrate the very end he has in view.
('61', 230, 2, 27, 447087) He forgets that caste Hindus are responsible for the present condition of the Harijans.
('61', 230, 2, 28, 447175) We have, therefore, to receive
('61', 231, 0, 1, 447206) 232 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 231, 1, 2, 447248) them as they are and have faith that our contact and love will, if we are true, make them shed all those habits that may be repugnant to decent society.
('61', 231, 1, 3, 447401) To blame the Harijans for their present condition is like a slave holder blaming his slave for the misery and squalor the latter may be living in.
('61', 231, 1, 4, 447548) We would ridicule the slave holder, perhaps even accuse him of insincerity, if he made the removal of squalor by the slave as a condition precedent to the grant of freedom.
('61', 231, 1, 5, 447721) It should also be borne in mind that the Harijans will enter temples subject to the same condition that is applicable to the rest of Hindus.
('61', 231, 1, 6, 447862) Nature has not made of Harijans a separate species distinguished from caste Hindus by definite unmistakable signs.
('61', 231, 1, 7, 447977) Hundreds, if not thousands, of Harijans enter temples without being detected.
('61', 231, 1, 8, 448055) The studies of census reports published in these columns 1 must make it clear to anybody that those who were not classified as untouchables must have entered temples without let or hindrance.
('61', 231, 1, 9, 448247) The mere fact of a new enumeration, for the first time including certain classes and excluding certain other classes from the Harijan list, surely cannot be used as any test of untouchability or touchability.
('61', 231, 1, 10, 448456) Only Hindus can claim no merit for the undetected entry of the so called State made untouchables into temples.
('61', 231, 1, 11, 448567) What is now claimed is that caste Hindus should seek merit, in other words, purify themselves, by deliberately banishing untoucha bility from their midst as a sin.
('61', 231, 1, 12, 448731) I cannot repeat too often that by untouchability I mean the thing as it is practised today.
('61', 231, 1, 13, 448823) Let the professor and those who think like him remember that [what] the reform, the anti untouchability campaign, stands for is no mere make shift for placating Harijans.
('61', 231, 1, 14, 448994) I tstands for a fundamental change in Hindu practice, it stands for the total abolition of the practice of high and lowness that has crept into Hinduism in spite of its lofty and unequivocal declaration that all life is one and that differentiation is maya, is false.
('61', 231, 1, 15, 449262) Practice of equal treatment of all human beings should be the least direct outcome of that belief not reserved for sannyasis but for the ordinary man in his ordinary dealings with fellowmen.

('61', 237, 1, 2, 457138) 306. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS
('61', 237, 2, 3, 457166) POONA, July 18, 1933
('61', 237, 3, 4, 457187) Asked about his immediate programme, he stated that he was going to the Sabarmati Ashram simply for the sake of visiting the people at the Ashram.
('61', 237, 3, 5, 457334) It would be a matter of regret for me if I did not go to the Ashram before being imprisoned.
('61', 237, 3, 6, 457427) Imprisonment is a certainty whether it comes today or in a few days.
('61', 237, 4, 7, 457496) What do you think of the Viceroy’s reply 1?
('61', 237, 4, 8, 457540) In my opinion, the Viceregal reply has created a regret table situation fraught with grave danger.
('61', 237, 4, 9, 457639) The doctrine laid down in that reply, in my opinion, is altogether new.
('61', 237, 4, 10, 457711) I do not know that civilized States have refused to carry on conversations with their rebellious subjects for the sake of peace.
('61', 237, 4, 11, 457840) Whilst hitherto they have parleyed with rebels, who have been armed from top to toe, in the present instance the civil resisters are admittedly non violent.
('61', 237, 4, 12, 457997) 2 It is also a matter of deep regret that His Excellency should have taken any notice whatsoever of unauthorized Press reports of confidential proceedings in answering a simple request for an interview for the promotion of peace.

('61', 237, 4, 16, 458450) I cannot imagine greater degradation or humiliation than for one to deny his faith.
('61', 237, 5, 17, 458534) Questioned regarding the exact purpose of the conference Gandhiji said it was an informal conference.
('61', 237, 5, 18, 458636) Without fear of any contradiction I can say that it was convened solely for the purpose of ascertaining whether Congressmen desired peace or not.
('61', 237, 5, 19, 458782) I would not have been a party to convening this informal conference had I not been in utter ignorance of the situation in the country.

('61', 238, 1, 2, 459489) conference as a whole was not prepared to give up or call off civil disobedience, undoubtedly there was every desire to withdraw the movement on honourable terms.

('61', 238, 3, 9, 460470) Asked about the future of Congress policy, Gandhiji stated: Mr. Aney will be issuing a statement, and I betray no secret when I say that his statement will be found to advise the country to suspend mass movement for the time being.
('61', 238, 3, 10, 460702) There are causes for this step into which I need not go presently.
('61', 238, 3, 11, 460769) He will also be advising the cessation of all Congress organizations and secret methods which alone made their functioning possible.

('61', 238, 4, 13, 461277) Asked if he would be the All India Dictator, he said: I am just now in the role of a humble adviser.

('61', 239, 0, 1, 461819) 240 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 239, 1, 2, 461861) time to the Harijan movement.
('61', 239, 1, 3, 461891) These do not understand me and without any disparagement to any of them I would say that they do not understand all the implications of what they thought.
('61', 239, 1, 4, 462046) In the first instance, my life is not divided into watertight compartments but is one indivisible whole and therefore I could not possibly give up the activities of a lifetime which are as dear to me as the Harijan movement itself.
('61', 239, 1, 5, 462278) My activities react upon one another.
('61', 239, 1, 6, 462316) Therefore if I excluded other activities my Harijan service would itself suffer.
('61', 239, 1, 7, 462397) Then again I could not all the twenty four hours of the day be doing Harijan work.
('61', 239, 1, 8, 462480) That is an impossible thing; and if it was suggested that I could give up prison life which the civil disobedience movement implied, for the sake of Harijan work, it means that I should give up a life principle.

('61', 244, 2, 14, 473392) 312. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS OF INDIA
('61', 244, 3, 15, 473436) July 19, 1933
('61', 244, 4, 16, 473450) I have seen a report of Sir Samuel Hoare’s speech in the House of Commons on the India estimates debate.
('61', 244, 4, 17, 473555) It is another surprise equally painful like the Viceregal telegram.
('61', 244, 4, 18, 473623) I may say that since the fast I have not been able to read newspapers regularly, and, during the fast, for ten or twelve days I have not even looked at the newspapers for the simple reason that I have had no time.
('61', 244, 4, 19, 473837) I, therefore, cannot say whether reports in newspapers are truly reflective of the proceedings of the informal conference.
('61', 244, 4, 20, 473960) My point, however, was not that the reports are necessarily untrue, but it was that no notice should have been taken of unauthorized reports of confidential proceedings.
('61', 244, 4, 21, 474130) Surely, it ought not to have mattered to the Viceroy what I or anybody had said at the informal conference.
('61', 244, 4, 22, 474238) The Viceroy could have judged for himself what I might have said at the interview, had it been granted.
('61', 244, 4, 23, 474342) The proceedings were kept confidential purposely, in order not to prejudice my request for an interview, I have been asked even now to deny the accuracy of the reports.
('61', 244, 4, 24, 474511) How am I to do so without going through the files of newspapers, and
('61', 245, 0, 1, 474580) 246 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 245, 1, 2, 474622) how many newspapers am I to read?
('61', 245, 1, 3, 474656) I venture to suggest that it is not a business proposition.
('61', 245, 1, 4, 474716) It ought to be sufficient that my request was not fettered by any conditions.
('61', 245, 1, 5, 474794) It was a mere request for an interview to explore possibilities of peace, and I think that it should have been considered on its merits.
('61', 245, 1, 6, 474931) But perhaps the proper question to put to me at this stage is whether I personally repent having advised the country to take up civil disobedience and whether I would still advise withdrawal.
('61', 245, 1, 7, 475123) That question I have already answered 1 before now.
('61', 245, 2, 8, 475175) The interviewer then asked if the door for negotiation had been finally closed.
('61', 245, 2, 9, 475255) Gandhiji readily replied: Not for me.
('61', 245, 2, 10, 475293) So far as I am concerned, the door will never be closed, and whenever I see the slightest opportunity, I would not hesitate to knock at the Viceregal door.
('61', 245, 2, 11, 475449) But I suppose that so far as authorities are concerned, they have finally closed the door, unless the Congress will call off civil disobedience altogether which, I hope, the Congress will never do.
('61', 245, 3, 12, 475647) Asked if he was likely to do anything to promote civil disobedience before 31st July, Gandhiji said: I shall do nothing overt before the end of the month during which civil disobedience stands suspended.

('61', 245, 5, 14, 475883) 313. INTERVIEW TO REPRESENTATIVE OF “THE TIMES OF INDIA”
('61', 245, 6, 15, 475940) July 20, 1933
('61', 245, 7, 16, 475954) In mass civil disobedience a large number of people act like sheep, therefore fact under leadership and sink or swim together.
('61', 245, 7, 17, 476081) In individual civil disobedience everyone is his own leader and the weakening of one cannot affect any other person.
('61', 245, 7, 18, 476198) One million individuals may offer individual civil disobedience but that would mean that each one of them has acted independently of others and on his own responsibility.
('61', 245, 7, 19, 476369) This again does not mean that the people do not have one mind and that they pull in opposite directions and, on the contrary, if individuals act with one aim and under one banner although they may act independently of one another, they will pull in same direction.
('61', 245, 7, 20, 476634) The beauty of individual
('61', 245, 8, 21, 476659) 1 Vide “Interview to the Press”, 18 7 1933.
('61', 246, 0, 1, 476703) VOL. 61 : 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 247
('61', 246, 1, 2, 476748) satyagraha lies in the fact that in it there is no such thing as defeat and it can never be circumvented by an earthly power, no matter how great it is.
('61', 246, 1, 3, 476901) Individual civil disobedience includes anything and everything that an individual conceives as proper and is permitted by Congress under the creed of non violence and truth.
('61', 246, 2, 4, 477075) Q. Prison bar helpful country [sic]?
('61', 246, 3, 5, 477112) A. If I did not think so I would cease to offer civil disobedience.
('61', 246, 3, 6, 477180) The truth lying behind civil disobedience is that under an unjust system a freedom loving man considers himself to be freer in a prison than outside.
('61', 246, 4, 7, 477330) Q. As a result of Poona Conference don’t you feel [that there will be a] split into two or more parties?
('61', 246, 5, 8, 477435) A. I do not anticipate any such result at all.
('61', 246, 5, 9, 477482) Whilst there were sharp differences of opinion among Congressmen, I have never known more cordiality and less acrimony and prompter obedience to the chair as at Poona Conference.
('61', 246, 5, 10, 477661) Indeed I believe that there will be no split in Congress ranks and it will be found that the revised scheme when it is published by the acting President, accomm[odates] almost it every shade of opinion in Congress.
('61', 246, 6, 11, 477876) Q. Call off civil disobedience by instalments [sic]?
('61', 246, 7, 12, 477929) A. would never consider admissions of a setback in a movement either as humi[liation] or as weakness and It is for that reason that I have advised cessation of mass civil disobedience which is clearly an admission of setback, and if I had felt that there was no other form of civil disobedience, I would have advised complete withdrawal, had I been the sole representative of that opinion; but in satyagraha individual civil disobedience is the final factor, it is indefensible [sic] and it’s for that reason that I have contended that it is an invincible force.
('61', 246, 7, 13, 478492) So far as interview with Viceroy was concerned, it was because I was anxious as was the conference that even individual civil disobedience should be stopped if any honourable settlement could be secured had I got the interview.
('61', 246, 7, 14, 478720) You will therefore see that there was, behind request for interview, no obstinate refusal to call off even individual civil disobedience under any circumstances whatsoever.
('61', 246, 7, 15, 478893) I am here during the pleasure of Government, but otherwise at least up to the end of suspension period [that is] 31st July.
('61', 246, 7, 16, 479017) In my opinion, friends in England can do very little at present.

('61', 247, 1, 2, 479124) am clear—Viceroy’s position [is] wholly untenable.

('61', 248, 4, 12, 481248) 316. AN AMERICAN CRITICISM1
('61', 248, 5, 13, 481276) The vast majority of letters received from the West on the recent fast have been full of goodwill and appreciation of it and the motive lying behind it.
('61', 248, 5, 14, 481429) The following letter balances the opinion reflected in the friendly letters and probably represents the majority opinion:
('61', 248, 6, 15, 481551) Now that your twenty one day fast is ended, as announced in small notices in the daily Press, what did it avail?
('61', 248, 6, 16, 481664) The world was told that it was for the benefit of the untouchables so called.
('61', 248, 6, 17, 481742) Just what did it do for them?
('61', 248, 7, 18, 481772) (The Mahatma Gandhi is no longer front page news; we must search the inside pages to find him in the daily Press.)
('61', 248, 8, 19, 481887) India, whose culture and civilization goes back far beyond record, which was given the new tongue of Christ Jesus by Thomas, the disciple, in the first century, and in the centuries just past has been given many opportunities to face the light, still remains in pagan darkness, its caste system of society the greatest sore spot on the modern world.
('61', 248, 9, 20, 482237) What is the answer?
('61', 248, 9, 21, 482257) Certainly not a fast, of whatever duration, by a lone man, of whatever sincerity, a man who late in life took off his clothes, and walked barefoot through the streets of London.
('61', 248, 9, 22, 482435) That smacks too much of some of the grosser forms of American publicity methods to be effective.
('61', 248, 10, 23, 482532) No one thing can raise the lower classes of India out of their poverty and degradation; if it is ever accomplished, it must be the workingof many influences, each contributing to the one end.
('61', 248, 10, 24, 482724) And the start must be from within themseles.
('61', 248, 11, 25, 482769) It must be a mental urge for something better.
('61', 248, 12, 26, 482816) 1 A summary of the article had appeared in The Bombay Chronicle, 22 7 1933 under the date line, “Poona, July 21, 1933”.
('61', 249, 0, 1, 482936) 250 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 249, 1, 2, 482978) No race whose women are subservient—or “without a soul” as you have it—has ever risen high in the scale of human progress.
('61', 249, 2, 3, 483101) Cleanliness is next to Godliness; and the nauseating filth in which the millions of your people live would preclude a start upward, until they begin to emerge from this mire.
('61', 249, 3, 4, 483276) A clean mind and a clean body will begin to turn their thought to a new life, which can have in it none of the ‘persecution of the body’ for the ‘sake of the spirit’.
('61', 249, 3, 5, 483443) For instance, your ‘Holy Men’, Sitting for years in some deformed position, publicly torturing the body to liberate the soul, are no longer taken seriously by any enlightened person; I doubt if by themselves.
('61', 249, 3, 6, 483652) Do they sit and think; or do they just sit?
('61', 249, 4, 7, 483696) The pagan religious rites, of sticking the body full of nails, spears through the tongue, and other revolting tortures, now widely known in America and throughout the world, bring nothing but disgust, and the feeling that they are, indeed, ‘untouchable’.
('61', 249, 5, 8, 483951) I have not read Mother India by Katherine Mayo, but am told on good authority (India’s resentment to the contrary notwithstanding, that it is a compilation of facts—so horrible that I have known cases of extreme illness from reading it.
('61', 249, 6, 9, 484188) If you really want to do something for the unfortunates of India, whose cause you have so nobly championed, why not cease your attempts at cheap publicity, found an educational system, work out a method by which large and increasing numbers may be enabled to take advantage of it; then see the support the enlightened nations of the world, especially America, would give you.
('61', 249, 6, 10, 484564) It is a big job, with sixty millions to reach, and it is increasing so rapidly because of unwholesome social conditions which education would correct, and tradition of many hundreds of years to overcome.
('61', 249, 6, 11, 484768) It will take generations but it will work, and this would be a substantial foundation upon which to build your future greatness.
('61', 249, 7, 12, 484897) And a united nation of sixty million people, united in knowledge, in progress, in ambition, in spiritu1 desire for self government, cannot be held in bondage, either by a minority of their own countrymen, or by another powerful nation.
('61', 249, 8, 13, 485133) After all people who are hostile to certain steps taken by a public man do not trouble themselves to express their disapprobation to him.
('61', 249, 8, 14, 485271) They ventilate it in the local Press.
('61', 249, 8, 15, 485309) And since in the great Harijan movement I would love to retain the friendliness of the world, it is well to reply to the letter.
('61', 250, 0, 1, 485438) VOL. 61 : 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 251
('61', 250, 1, 2, 485483) But it is a difficult letter to notice.
('61', 250, 1, 3, 485523) For it starts with a bias and ends with it.
('61', 250, 1, 4, 485567) The caste system does not become “the greatest sore spot on the modern world”.
('61', 250, 1, 5, 485646) He does not even seem to know what that system is.
('61', 250, 1, 6, 485697) I have myself raised my voice against the evil that has crept into the system, but the evil of it is foreign to the original, and can be removed as it is being removed, Untouchability is the greatest excrescence, and the world knows what Herculean efforts are being made to combat the evil.
('61', 250, 1, 7, 485988) The fast which the writer belittles was intended to help the movement.
('61', 250, 1, 8, 486059) I must be unmoved by the writer’s mixing up the fast and my mode of dress with “the grosser forms of American publicity methods”.
('61', 250, 1, 9, 486189) The proof of the pudding will be in the eating.
('61', 250, 1, 10, 486237) But one can heartily endorse the opinion that “no one thing can raise the lower classes of India out of their poverty and degradation” and that “the start must be from within themselves”.
('61', 250, 1, 11, 486425) Almost the very next sentence repeats the exploded libel about the women of India being “without a soul”.
('61', 250, 1, 12, 486531) It is, perhaps, useless to tell the correspondent that many foreign writers of note have marvelled at the comparative freedom enjoyed by the women of India.
('61', 250, 1, 13, 486688) This is not to say that there is not much to be done for the amelioration of their condition.
('61', 250, 1, 14, 486782) But this can be said without fear of contradiction that whilst the betterment of the condition of women of the West is of recent growth, the women of India have from ancient times enjoyed in essential matters a freedom which has not escaped foreign observers.
('61', 250, 1, 15, 487042) The correspondent has evidently read literature containing ignorant and interested distortions about Indian habits and customs.
('61', 250, 1, 16, 487170) No one, perhaps, has written more severely than I have done about our insanitation.
('61', 250, 1, 17, 487254) But to describe it as “nauseating filth” is a gross libel.
('61', 250, 1, 18, 487313) It betrays violent intolerance of habits other than one’s own.
('61', 250, 1, 19, 487376) The correspondent would not have been betrayed into the wild generalization he has indulged in about the tortures which so called yogis undergo, if instead of relying upon ignorant and sensational literature he had seen things with his own eyes.
('61', 250, 1, 20, 487622) Just as one swallow does not make a summer, so cannot one yogi so called resorting to self tortures warrant the libel that self torture is the general practice of those who seek liberation of the soul through crucifixion of the flesh, a practice general to mankind and indispensable for the subjugation of the body to the soul.
('61', 251, 0, 1, 487950) 252 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 251, 1, 2, 487992) I must pass by Miss Catherine Mayo and “the unknown cases of extreme illness” from the reading of her libellous production Mother India.
('61', 251, 1, 3, 488129) One can but pity the readers, if there were any such, who made themselves sick by reading a book which opened the drains of India and made the readers believe that they were India.
('61', 251, 1, 4, 488310) In the concluding sentences, the correspondent advises the course to be adopted for the amelioration of the lot of the “untouchables”.
('61', 251, 1, 5, 488445) The pages of Harijan can tell him what constructive work is being attempted all over India by the Servants of Untouchables Society.
('61', 251, 1, 6, 488577) It is up to American friends who are giving moral support to the movement to put before the American public a digest of the work reported in these pages from week to week.

('61', 257, 4, 6, 497581) 329. LETTER TO A. I. S. A.
('61', 257, 5, 7, 497608) AHMEDABAD, July 25, 1933
('61', 257, 6, 8, 497633) THE HONORARY SECRETARY ALL INDIA SPINNERS’ ASSOCIATION MIRZAPUR, AHMEDABAD
('61', 257, 7, 9, 497708) DEAR SIR,
('61', 257, 8, 10, 497718) With reference to your letter of 20th instant I have to state that, in my opinion, ‘handling’ means portable and capable of being housed in a tiny hut, and easily movable by one person from place to place.
('61', 257, 8, 11, 497924) With reference to the 5th condition, the price includes the carding attachment of the machine, if special slivers are necessary.
('61', 257, 8, 12, 498053) But I must state that the meaning I give to the conditions cannot be allowed to weigh with the judges.
('61', 257, 8, 13, 498156) They must be left wholly uninfluenced by any opinion that I may have on the conditions.
('61', 257, 8, 14, 498244) This is, therefore, purely for your guidance, in the choice of machines and in directing the inventors as to what they should do.
('61', 257, 9, 15, 498374) Yours sincerely,
