('61', 257, 11, 17, 498420) 330. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS OF INDIA
('61', 257, 12, 18, 498464) July 25, 1933
('61', 257, 13, 19, 498478) Mahatma Gandhi announced to the representative of the Associated Press today that he had decided to disband his Sabarmati Ashram which had been in existence for nearly 18 years.
('61', 257, 13, 20, 498656) Asked his reasons for taking such a serious step, Mahatma Gandhi said: The reason is quite obvious for me.
('61', 257, 13, 21, 498763) Hundreds or thousands who took part in the struggle have lost their all.
('61', 257, 13, 22, 498836) Having heard the story of the brave suffering of the villagers, I felt that some drastic action was necessary on my part.
('61', 257, 13, 23, 498958) What was it that I could sacrifice?
('61', 258, 0, 1, 498994) VOL. 61 : 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 259
('61', 258, 1, 2, 499039) nothing on this earth which I can call my own; but I have some things which are more precious than what might be considered to be mine, and among these precious things, the Ashram is perhaps the most precious and I felt that on the eve of my embarking upon what is to me a fresh and sacred mission in life, I should invite fellow workers of the Ashram to join me and give up for the time being the activities in which they have been engaged all these precious years, and I am glad to be able to say that not one of them had the slightest hesitation in believing that the time had come for the Ashram to make the sacrifice.
('61', 258, 2, 3, 499662) Asked what would happen to the many activities of the Ashram, Gandhiji said: This is a question somewhat difficult to answer; but I can say generally that if the activities were true and fulfilled some of the real wants of India, they will live in spite of the disbandment of the Ashram.
('61', 258, 2, 4, 499950) For example, the whole of the khadi activity will certainly survive the disbandment.
('61', 258, 2, 5, 500035) Indeed, the only thing that the Ashram was doing was to make experiments in khadi manufacture by devising new types of spinning wheels and perfecting those that are in existence, supporting many Harijan families and teaching candidates all the hand processes that cotton goes through before it comes out as khadi.
('61', 258, 2, 6, 500349) This is undoubtedly an essential work and very important, but I have faith that the work will be continued even after the Ashram ceases to exist as an institution and this may be said more or less of all other activities of the Ashram.
('61', 258, 3, 7, 500585) Asked what he was going to do now, Gandhiji said: I am afraid I must not at the present moment go beyond what I have stated.
('61', 258, 3, 8, 500710) I hope to make a further statement 1 in the course of the next few days.
('61', 258, 4, 9, 500783) The Bombay Chronicle, 26 7 1933; also The Hindu, 25 7 1933
('61', 258, 5, 10, 500842) 331. STATEMENT ON M. S. ANEY’S STATEMENT
('61', 258, 6, 11, 500883) [July 26, 1933] 3
('61', 258, 7, 12, 500901) The statement issued by Sjt.
('61', 258, 7, 13, 500930) Aney closely follows the advice tendered by me at the informal conference.
('61', 258, 7, 14, 501005) It does not give any
('61', 258, 8, 15, 501026) 1 Vide the following item.
('61', 258, 8, 16, 501053) 2 This sentence is reproduced from The Hindu, 25 7 1933. 3 From contemporary Press reports and The Indian Annual Register, Vol. II, P. 333
('61', 259, 0, 1, 501192) 260 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 259, 1, 2, 501234) reasons for the decision taken.
('61', 259, 1, 3, 501266) It was left to me to give them.
('61', 259, 1, 4, 501298) This does not mean that they are necessarily the reasons that guided Sjt.
('61', 259, 1, 5, 501372) Aney and all those friends who accepted my advice.
('61', 259, 1, 6, 501423) They must be taken, therefore to be solely mine.
('61', 259, 2, 7, 501472) In my opinion, it would have been disastrous if, in the existing circumstance, civil disobedience had been altogether withdrawn.
('61', 259, 2, 8, 501601) The technique of satyagraha, as I have known it, requires continuance even by one person so long as such continuance does not defeat the ends of truth and ahimsa.
('61', 259, 2, 9, 501764) It may not be given up either because of the weakness of the people taking part in it or (which is the same thing) the seeming victory of the opponent.
('61', 259, 2, 10, 501916) The greater the repression the greater the strength of a true civil resister.
('61', 259, 2, 11, 501994) The continuance of civil resistance, even by one person, insures its revival by those who might have given it up through despair or weakness.
('61', 259, 3, 12, 502136) But radical changes in the programme were absolutely necessary.
('61', 259, 4, 13, 502200) Aney’s instructions taboo secret methods.
('61', 259, 4, 14, 502242) There is nothing inherently wrong in them.
('61', 259, 4, 15, 502285) I fully admit the purity of purpose and the great cleverness of the workers in conducting the campaign by secret methods, devised to meet the situation created by repressive measures of the Government.
('61', 259, 4, 16, 502487) But secrecy is repugnant to satyagraha and hampers its progress.
('61', 259, 4, 17, 502552) It has undoubtedly contributed in a great measure to the present demoralization of the people.
('61', 259, 4, 18, 502647) I know that a ban on secrecy will stop some of the activities which appeared to keep the Congress before the public eye.
('61', 259, 4, 19, 502768) But this doubtful benefit will be outweighed by the certain elimination of a method which is foreign to the spirit of satyagraha and which interferes with its efficacy.
('61', 259, 5, 20, 502937) Another change made is the stoppage of the mass movement.
('61', 259, 5, 21, 502995) The masses have acted bravely and suffered much wherever they have responded to the national call.
('61', 259, 5, 22, 503094) But ample evidence is forthcoming to show that they are not able any longer to suffer the prolonged torture of the Ordinance Rule now crystallized into statute by the so called legislatures.
('61', 259, 5, 23, 503285) The Congress as an organization finds it increasingly difficult day by day to render them effective aid.
('61', 259, 5, 24, 503390) The stoppage of secrecy would prevent even the little relief that it was possible to give them.
('61', 259, 5, 25, 503486) The masses have not yet learnt to act as one man and without direction.
('61', 259, 5, 26, 503558) They need more training and experience through the example of individuals.
('61', 260, 0, 1, 503633) VOL. 61 : 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 261
('61', 260, 1, 2, 503678) Civil disobedience is, therefore, to be confined to individuals on their own responsibility although they would be acting on behalf of and in the name of the Congress.
('61', 260, 1, 3, 503846) Those who will so act may expect no financial or other assistance from the Congress.
('61', 260, 1, 4, 503931) They should be prepared for indefinite incarceration whether ill or well.
('61', 260, 1, 5, 504005) They may not come out of jails except by termination of their sentences in due course or through the strength of the people.
('61', 260, 1, 6, 504130) on termination of their sentences they should seek re imprisonment on the first opportunity.
('61', 260, 1, 7, 504223) They should be prepared to brave all the risks attendant upon their action including uttermost penury and the loss of all their possessions, movable or immovable, or physical torture such as lathi blows.
('61', 260, 1, 8, 504427) Naturally such action can only be expected from a small number, especially in the beginning.
('61', 260, 1, 9, 504520) The very enumeration of the hardships is likely to frighten many people.
('61', 260, 1, 10, 504593) But experience of patriots and reformers all the world over shows that Nature provides us with the capacity for suffering when it is taken up in the true spirit.
('61', 260, 1, 11, 504755) It follows that such response, if it comes at all, must come in the first instance from the intelligentsia.
('61', 260, 1, 12, 504863) Their example will prove infectious in the long run and pervade the whole nation resulting in a mass awakening that cannot possibly be crushed by any repression, be it ever so ferocious.
('61', 260, 1, 13, 505050) Moreover, individuals from among the masses can certainly act even now.
('61', 260, 1, 14, 505122) Only they must understand the implications of individual civil disobedience.
('61', 260, 1, 15, 505199) I am convinced that these men and women will represent the national spirit and the nation’s determination to win independence in every sense of the term.
('61', 260, 1, 16, 505353) It may be objected that the heroic suffering of a few individuals, however praiseworthy in itself, is of no practical value and cannot affect British policy.
('61', 260, 1, 17, 505511) I differ from such a view.
('61', 260, 1, 18, 505538) In my opinion, the seemingly long or almost interminable process adumbrated by me will in practice be found to be the shortest.
('61', 260, 1, 19, 505666) For I hold that true independence, i.e., independence in terms of and on behalf of the masses, can be proved in India’s case to be unattainable by any other method.
('61', 260, 1, 20, 505831) The method of non violence which is an integral part of the Congress constitution demands the course suggested by me.
('61', 260, 1, 21, 505949) It must be clear to the dullest intellect that British policy cannot change through a constitution which registers the British will and ignores the wish or the welfare of the nation.
('61', 260, 1, 22, 506132) Any constitution imposed upon India by the British will, unaffected by anything done in and by India, must in the nature of things harden and perpetuate
('61', 261, 0, 1, 506285) 262 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 261, 1, 2, 506327) the British policy.
('61', 261, 1, 3, 506347) It can and will be changed by adequate action taken by India in the face of British repression.
('61', 261, 1, 4, 506443) In other words, Britain cannot work out our salvation.
('61', 261, 1, 5, 506498) We must work it out ourselves.
('61', 261, 1, 6, 506529) Our independence should mean the registration not of Britain’s will but of our will.
('61', 261, 1, 7, 506614) I have suggested the only way that will forge the necessary sanction for the registration of our will, that is, the will of the dumb millions.
('61', 261, 1, 8, 506757) For individual action must, in the long run, affect the masses.
('61', 261, 1, 9, 506821) Let us not forget the uniqueness of India’s case.
('61', 261, 1, 10, 506871) I know of no parallel in history.
('61', 261, 1, 11, 506905) In India British will is enforced through India’s own men and, shall I say, even women.
('61', 261, 1, 12, 506993) India supplies the civilian and the soldier, India supplies money and other resources for the subjugation and exploitation of the masses.
('61', 261, 1, 13, 507131) If this terribly immoral state of things is not altered in a day or even in a century, it need cause no surprise.
('61', 261, 1, 14, 507245) But our success is ensured the moment we take the right route to our goal.
('61', 261, 1, 15, 507320) I claim that we took it in 1920. And though it cannot be visibly demonstrated, we have since then taken long strides toward purna swaraj.
('61', 261, 1, 16, 507458) We could not have gone nearer the goal by any other way.
('61', 261, 1, 17, 507515) Who can deny that during the past thirteen years we have seen an awakening among the masses, never witnessed during the hundred years preceding September 1920. My advice does not proceed from a sense of despair, or defeat; I have neither.
('61', 261, 1, 18, 507754) I am filled with joy that the national response has been so great as it has been.
('61', 261, 1, 19, 507836) The greatest cause for joy is that the individuals as well as the masses have observed non violellce in action, in spite of themselves and in the face of almost inconceivable provocation.
('61', 261, 1, 20, 508024) We are too near the time to judge the merit of the non violence observed by the Frontier Pathans.
('61', 261, 1, 21, 508122) They might have used violent language.
('61', 261, 1, 22, 508161) But they have refrained from violent action in a way they have never done before within living memory.
('61', 261, 1, 23, 508264) Such is the testimony of several sober independent witnesses.
('61', 261, 1, 24, 508326) If non violence becomes rooted in the Pathan heart, it will solve several difficult problems for us.
('61', 261, 1, 25, 508427) What is true of the Frontier Pathan is largely true of the civil resisters throughout India.
('61', 261, 1, 26, 508520) I must not he misunderstood.
('61', 261, 1, 27, 508549) My claim is humble.
('61', 261, 1, 28, 508569) Danger of a sudden outburst of Violence is always present so long as the violence of the heart is not eradicated.
('61', 261, 1, 29, 508683) I am sorry to say that there is ample violence in our breasts.
('61', 261, 1, 30, 508746) We have acted non violently out of policy, out of helplessness.
('61', 261, 1, 31, 508810) We would inflict violence if we could do so with
('61', 262, 0, 1, 508859) VOL. 61 : 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 263
('61', 262, 1, 2, 508904) effect.
('61', 262, 1, 3, 508912) I would have India to abjure violence even if it had the power to wield it.
('61', 262, 1, 4, 508988) I would have it appreciate the fact that if the masses are to work out their own independence, they are so numerous us that if they achieved anything through violent means, it would not be indepen dence but a fiendish thing that would devour them and perhaps bring ruination to the whole world.
('61', 262, 1, 5, 509283) The one lesson that the Western nations teach the world in flaming letters, is that violence is not the way to peace and happiness.
('61', 262, 1, 6, 509415) The cult of violence has not made them or those who have contact with them any the happier or better.
('61', 262, 1, 7, 509517) If ever we, as a nation, reach that living faith in non violence and banish violence from our hearts we would not even need resort to civil disobedience.
('61', 262, 1, 8, 509671) The latter is required whilst we are trying non violence as a mere policy or expedient.
('61', 262, 1, 9, 509759) Even as a policy it is any day far more effective than violence.
('61', 262, 1, 10, 509824) Under the Dictator’s instructions secret organizations naturally disappear.
('61', 262, 1, 11, 509900) Every civil resister will be his or her own leader.
('61', 262, 1, 12, 509952) He or she will carry the burden of the Congress on his or her own shoulders.
('61', 262, 1, 13, 510029) Such civil resisters will be trustees of national honour.
('61', 262, 1, 14, 510087) Whilst Congressmen may be counted by the crore, civil resistance, under the new scheme, will be represented only by a few thousand or even less.
('61', 262, 1, 15, 510232) If these few are true men and women, I am certain that they will multiply into millions.
('61', 262, 1, 16, 510321) Meanwhile the remaining Congressmen will engage in various other constructive activities of the Congress such as Harijan service, communal unity, khadi production and distribution, total prohibition, boycott of foreign cloth and other goods that compete with indigenous manufactures or are otherwise detrimental to the interests of the nation, the manufacture of new goods, the improvement of the methods of indigenous manufacture, and in this connection development or resuscitation of village industries, improvement of agriculture and cattle breeding, organization of labour unions, not for political exploitation but for the betterment of the condition of workers and improvement in the relations between capital and labour.
('61', 262, 1, 17, 511050) In fact, no branch of national activity may be left untouched by the Congress.
('61', 262, 1, 18, 511129) This will be possible if we will get rid of the very wrong idea that there is no other Congress activity save that of civil resistance or that the latter blocks all other activities.
('61', 262, 1, 19, 511312) This will be true, perhaps when there is mass civil disobedience and the campaign has to be swift and sharp.
('61', 262, 1, 20, 511421) But till that time is reached, due importance must be given to every one of nation building activities and none should be neglected.
('61', 262, 1, 21, 511554) Civil resisters represent the non violent army of the nation.
('61', 262, 1, 22, 511616) And just as every citizen
('61', 263, 0, 1, 511642) 264 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 263, 1, 2, 511684) cannot be a soldier on the active list, every citizen cannot be a civil resister on the active list.
('61', 263, 1, 3, 511785) And if a soldier may not consider himself a superior being because he fights at the risk of his life for his nation much less may a civil resister will undergoes sufferings for the sake of his nation.
('61', 263, 1, 4, 511986) Those outside the rank of fighters are equally important limbs of their nation if they regard themselves as national servants dedicating their talents for the nation’s welfare, and not engaging in any activity, private or public, that may be in conflict with the national interest.
('61', 263, 2, 5, 512268) Moreover, whilst the Congress as an organization cannot openly help civil resisters, and must under my plan avoid all secret methods, it will be the duty of Congressmen and even others who sympathize with the Congress methods and aim, wherever possible to give relief to the indigent families of civil resisters especially to the utterly destitute peasantry who joined the no tax campaign.
('61', 263, 2, 6, 512658) For they must be assured that every inch of the land confiscated during the campaign (I think lawlessly and wrongly) will be returned to them or their progeny when the nation comes to her own as it must some day.
('61', 263, 2, 7, 512871) I have learnt that at great personal risk to the workers engaged in the task the Congress has successfully administered secret relief to the peasants who have chosen for the sake of national freedom to risk their all.
('61', 263, 2, 8, 513089) Such relief will be impossible of administration in the future, not merely because of the contemplated stoppage of secret methods but also because the Congress has no ceaseless source of income.
('61', 263, 2, 9, 513284) The burden of reaching relief openly to such families must on pure humanitarian grounds, if no other, fall on the shoulders of those who are not engaged in civil resistance.
('61', 263, 2, 10, 513458) The Government cannot have it both ways.
('61', 263, 2, 11, 513499) If they will slop even private and open relief, they must imprison the dependants of civil resisters or otherwise maintain them.
('61', 263, 2, 12, 513628) The world would be staggered to know the number of those who once in fair circumstances have courted ruination and are living on doles of three or four rupees per head, per month.
('61', 263, 2, 13, 513808) I understand that even their houses are in danger of being attached.
('61', 263, 3, 14, 513877) I have left the Council programme untouched.
('61', 263, 3, 15, 513922) To think now of working the reforms to come is, in my opinion, altogether premature.
('61', 263, 3, 16, 514007) We do not know what they are to be, when they are to come, if at all.
('61', 263, 3, 17, 514077) It would behove those who are inclined to participate, to wait for the reforms before they commit themselves to a policy.
('61', 263, 3, 18, 514199) Then there remain the existing Legislatures.
('61', 263, 3, 19, 514244) I can give no decisive opinion on this
('61', 264, 0, 1, 514283) VOL. 61 : 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 265
('61', 264, 1, 2, 514328) question as I can on civil disobedience.
('61', 264, 1, 3, 514369) My head reels at the very thought of entering Councils for the sake of winning independence.
('61', 264, 1, 4, 514462) They may give some relief in specific cases but that is the miasma to keep the nation from its goal.
('61', 264, 1, 5, 514563) They have no temptation for me in spite of my having sought through Sjt.
('61', 264, 1, 6, 514636) Rajagopalachari and others the co operation of the Legislatures and the Government in the matter of the untouchability Bills.
('61', 264, 1, 7, 514762) The primary responsibility for seeking it lies not on his shoulders but mine.
('61', 264, 1, 8, 514840) I offer no apology for having sought it.
('61', 264, 1, 9, 514881) It is wholly consistent with the doctrine of non co operation.
('61', 264, 1, 10, 514944) There is one thing on which Sjt.
('61', 264, 1, 11, 514977) Aney has differed from me and some other friends.
('61', 264, 1, 12, 515027) I have felt strongly that the office of All India Dictator and Provincial Dictators should also be abolished.
('61', 264, 1, 13, 515137) But he felt equally strongly that the office should be retained if only as a symbol.
('61', 264, 1, 14, 515222) But I see grave difficulties in our way.
('61', 264, 1, 15, 515263) Dictators under the new scheme must, like others, offer civil resistance as soon as they are appointed.
('61', 264, 1, 16, 515367) All the best men and women must quickly find their way to prison.
('61', 264, 1, 17, 515433) Therefore a time must soon come when men and women who can really dictate will not be available.
('61', 264, 1, 18, 515530) Then there could only be dummy Dictators as they have been before.
('61', 264, 1, 19, 515597) These may easily produce embarrassing situations.
('61', 264, 1, 20, 515647) Lastly, when every civil resister is expected to be his own leader, there seems to be no warrant for having Dictators.
('61', 264, 1, 21, 515766) Indeed their mere existence may well stop the flow of individual civil resisters.
('61', 264, 1, 22, 515848) For they may wait for Dictators’ instructions whereas the new scheme provides for no further instructions.
('61', 264, 1, 23, 515955) The Congress as an organization should live in its ideal in the final instructions issued by Sjt.
('61', 264, 1, 24, 516053) I, there fore, still feel that Dictators should abolish themselves, if my argument appeals to them.
('61', 264, 1, 25, 516153) The Viceroy’s refusal to see me even for the sake of exploring possibilities of peace, renders it unnecessary to examine the conditions under which even without purna swaraj but in furtherance of it, civil disobedience may be discontinued.
('61', 264, 1, 26, 516393) But I may repeat what I have said so often that all non co operation is undertaken to ensure real co operation in the place of forced one and all civil disobedience of laws is resorted to for the sake of rendering voluntary obedience instead of forced obedience.
('61', 264, 1, 27, 516656) Therefore, I have no doubt that the Congress would be ever ready for honourable peace.

('61', 265, 0, 1, 516772) 266 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATM GANDHI
('61', 265, 1, 2, 516813) 332. LETTER TO HOME SECRETARY, GOVERNMENT OF BOMBAY
('61', 265, 2, 3, 516865) AHMEDABAD, July 26, 1933
('61', 265, 3, 4, 516890) TO THE SECRETARY TO THE GOVERNMENT OF BOMBAY (HOME DEPARTMENT) POONA
('61', 265, 4, 5, 516959) DEAR SIR, My first constructive act on return to India in 1915 was to found the Satyagraha Ashram for the purpose of serving Truth.
('61', 265, 4, 6, 517091) The inmates are under the vows of truth, ahimsa, celibacy, control of palate, poverty, fearlessness, removal of untouchability, swadeshi with khadi as the centre, equal respect for all religions and bread labour.
('61', 265, 4, 7, 517304) The present site for the Ashram was bought in 1916. It conducts today certain activities mostly through the labour of inmates.
('61', 265, 4, 8, 517431) But it does need to supplement that labour with ordinary paid labour.
('61', 265, 4, 9, 517501) Its principal activities are: khadi production as a village industry without the aid of power driven machinery, dairy, agriculture, scientific scavenging and literary education.
('61', 265, 4, 10, 517679) The Ashram has 107 inmates at present (men 42, women 31, boys 12 and girls 22).
('61', 265, 4, 11, 517759) This number excludes those who are in prison and those who are otherwise engaged outside.
('61', 265, 4, 12, 517849) Up to now it has trained nearly 1,000 persons in the manufacture of khadi.
('61', 265, 4, 13, 517924) Most of these, so far as my knowledge goes, are doing useful constructive work and earning an honest livelihood.
('61', 265, 4, 14, 518037) The Ashram is a registered trust.
('61', 265, 4, 15, 518071) The funds at its disposal are ear marked.
('61', 265, 4, 16, 518113) Whilst the aim has been to make every department self supporting, it has hitherto been obliged to receive donations from friends to meet all the obligations.
('61', 265, 4, 17, 518271) Experience has shown that so long as it remains a predominantly educational service (using the term in the widest sense) and not only charges no fees but actually feeds and clothes the learners, it cannot be wholly self supporting.
('61', 265, 4, 18, 518503) The Ashram owns immovable property estimated at about Rs. 3,60,000 and movables including cash estimated at over Rs. 3,00,000 1.
('61', 265, 5, 19, 518632) 1 “Over Rs. 3,00,000” was later on corrected as “nearly Rs. 2,00,000”; vide the following item.
('61', 266, 0, 1, 518728) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 267
('61', 266, 1, 2, 518772) The Ashram takes no part in politics so called.
('61', 266, 1, 3, 518820) But it does believe in non co operation and civil disobedience as indispensable, under certain circumstances, for the observance of truth and non violence.
('61', 266, 1, 4, 518976) Hence, the civil disobedience campaign of 1930 was started by the march to Dandi of nearly eighty inmates of the Ashram.
('61', 266, 1, 5, 519097) Time has now arrived for the Ashram to make a greater sacrifice in the face of the existing situation—on the one hand the growing terrorism by the Government and on the other the equally growing demoralization among the people.
('61', 266, 1, 6, 519325) The statements that have come under my observation since the breaking of my fast show that
('61', 266, 2, 7, 519416) 1. methods of torture have been adopted by the police in various parts of India in order to cow down individual civil resisters, 2. women have been insulted, 3. free movement of people has become almost impossible, 4. in many parts of India, village work by Congressmen has become all but impossible, 5. civil resistance prisoners have been subjected to humiliations and bodily injury in many lock ups and prisons, 6. unconscionably heavy fines have been imposed and gross irregularities committed for their recovery, 7. peasants withholding revenue or rent have been punished in a manner out of all proportion to their offence, obviously with a view to terrifying them and their neighbours into subjection 1, 8. the public Press has been gagged, 9. in short, freedom with self respect has become impossible throughout the length and breadth of the land.
('61', 266, 3, 8, 520271) I have no doubt that these statements will be denied or explainedaway in official circles.
('61', 266, 3, 9, 520362) It may be that they are not free from exaggerations.
('61', 266, 3, 10, 520415) But in common with many Congressmen I believe in them and therefore they are able to arouse us to action.
('61', 266, 3, 11, 520521) Hence, mere incarceration can bring little satisfaction.
('61', 266, 3, 12, 520578) Moreover, I quite clearly see that the vast constructive programme of the Ashram cannot be carried on with safety, unless the Ashram ceases entirely to have anything to do with the campaign.
('61', 266, 3, 13, 520769) To accept such a position will
('61', 266, 4, 14, 520800) 1 The two words “into subjection” are reproduced from Bombay Secret Abstracts.
('61', 267, 0, 1, 520879) 268 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATM GANDHI
('61', 267, 1, 2, 520920) be to deny the creed.
('61', 267, 1, 3, 520942) Up to now I had hoped that the existence of the Ashram side by side with the civil resistance of its individual members was possible and that there was bound to be an honourable peace between Government and the Congress in the near future even though the Congress goal might not be immediately realized.
('61', 267, 1, 4, 521246) The unfortunate rejection by His Excellency the Viceroy of the honest advance of the Congress through me, in the interest of peace, shows clearly that the Government do not seek or desire peace, they want an abject surrender by the largest and the admittedly most, if not the only, popular political organization in the country.
('61', 267, 1, 5, 521575) This is impossible so long as the Congress continues to repose confidence in its present advisers.
('61', 267, 1, 6, 521674) The struggle therefore is bound to be prolonged and calls for much greater sacrifice than the people have hitherto undergone.
('61', 267, 1, 7, 521800) It follows that the greatest measure of sacrifice is to be expected of me as the author of the movement.
('61', 267, 1, 8, 521905) I can therefore only offer that which is nearest and dearest to me and for the building of which I and many other members of the Ashram have laboured with infinite patience and care all these eighteen years.
('61', 267, 1, 9, 522113) Every head of cattle and every tree has its history and sacred associations.
('61', 267, 1, 10, 522190) They are all members of a big family.
('61', 267, 1, 11, 522228) What was once a barren plot of land has been turned by human endeavour into a fair sized model garden colony.
('61', 267, 1, 12, 522338) It will not be without a tear that we shall break up the family and its activities.
('61', 267, 1, 13, 522422) I have had many and prayerful conversations with the inmates and they have, men and women, unanimously approved of the proposal to give up the present activities.
('61', 267, 1, 14, 522585) Those who are at all able have decided to offer individual civil disobedience after the suspension period is over.
('61', 267, 2, 15, 522700) It may not be superfluous to mention that the Ashram has for the past two years refused to pay revenue dues and consequently goods of considerable value have been seized and sold in respect of them.
('61', 267, 2, 16, 522899) I make no complaint of the procedure.
('61', 267, 2, 17, 522937) But it cannot be a matter of pleasure or profit to carry on a great institution in such precarious circumstances.
('61', 267, 2, 18, 523051) I fully realize that whether a State is just or unjust and whether it is under popular or Foreign control, the citizen’s possessions may at any time be forcibly taken away from him by the State, if he comes in conflict with it.
('61', 267, 2, 19, 523279) In the circumstances, it seems to me to be simple prudence to anticipate the inevitable in a conflict which promises to be indefinitely prolonged.
('61', 267, 3, 20, 523426) But whilst it has been decided to break up the Ashram we want everything to be used for public purpose.
('61', 267, 3, 21, 523530) Therefore, unless the
('61', 268, 0, 1, 523552) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 269
('61', 268, 1, 2, 523596) Government for any reason desire to take charge of any or all of the movables including cash, l propose to hand them over to those friends who will take them and use them for public benefit and in accordance with the earmarking.
('61', 268, 1, 3, 523825) Thus the khadi stock and contents of the workshop and the weaving sheds will be handed over to the All India Spinners’ Association on whose behalf that activity has been carried on.
('61', 268, 1, 4, 524007) The cows and other cattle will be handed to a representative of the Goseva Sangh on whose behalf the dairy has been conducted.
('61', 268, 1, 5, 524134) The library will be handed probably to an institution that will take care of it.
('61', 268, 1, 6, 524215) The moneys and articles belonging to the various parties will be returned [to] them or kept for them by friends who will care to take charge of them.
('61', 268, 1, 7, 524365) Then there remain the land, the buildings and the crops.
('61', 268, 1, 8, 524422) I suggest that the Government take possession of these and do what they like with them.
('61', 268, 1, 9, 524510) I would gladly have handed these also to friends but I cannot be party to their paying the revenue dues.
('61', 268, 1, 10, 524615) And naturally I may not hand them to fellow resisters.
('61', 268, 1, 11, 524670) All, therefore, I wish is that beneficial use be made of the land, buildings and the valuable trees and crops instead of being allowed to run to waste as I see has been done in many cases.
('61', 268, 1, 12, 524859) There is a plot of land with buildings occupied by Harijan families.
('61', 268, 1, 13, 524928) They have hitherto paid no rent.
('61', 268, 1, 14, 524961) I have no desire to invite them to take part in civil resistance.
('61', 268, 1, 15, 525027) They will now pay the nominal rent of one rupee per year to the trustees of the Ashram and be responsible for the revenue due on that portion.
('61', 268, 1, 16, 525170) If for any reason, the Government decline to take of the property mentioned, the Ashram will still be vacated by the inmates as soon as may be after the expiry of the suspension period, viz., 31st instant unless the date is anticipated by the Government.
('61', 268, 1, 17, 525425) I request a telegraphic reply to this letter, at least, I so far as the Government’s wishes regarding the movables are concerned so as to enable me to remove them in due time if I am to remove them at all.
('61', 268, 3, 18, 525631) Yours faithfully,

('61', 269, 7, 10, 526254) 334. LETTER TO SYED MAHMUD
('61', 269, 8, 11, 526281) July 26, 1933
('61', 269, 9, 12, 526295) DEAR DR.
('61', 269, 9, 13, 526304) MAHMUD, I have your two letters.
('61', 269, 9, 14, 526337) I must not make the declaration that you suggest.
('61', 269, 9, 15, 526387) No declarations unaccompanied by immediate action are of any value at the present moment.
('61', 269, 9, 16, 526477) Even action taken under a sense of duty and with the purest of motives is wholly misinterpreted.
('61', 269, 9, 17, 526574) But I can repeat my conviction to you that I would not care to go to heaven without taking the Mussalman friends with me.
('61', 269, 9, 18, 526696) The fact is, the more I examine myself the more I fed that deep down in me there is no distinction between Hindus, Mussalmans, Christians and others.
('61', 269, 9, 19, 526846) I would disdain to thrive at their expense.
('61', 269, 9, 20, 526890) As to your other suggestion about the Benares Hindu University, whilst Malaviyaji is capable of immense sacrifice, he will not sacrifice the University.
('61', 269, 9, 21, 527043) He is philosophic enough to let it go, if he could not retain it, consistently with his notion of self respect.
('61', 269, 9, 22, 527155) But, if I know him rightly, he would consider it a great mistake deliberately to sacrifice the University.
('61', 269, 9, 23, 527262) What is more, those who are its co trustees would never allow him to take that step and what is still more is that
('61', 270, 0, 1, 527377) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 271
('61', 270, 1, 2, 527421) the students have no desire whatsoever to suspend their training.
('61', 270, 1, 3, 527487) Whatever, therefore, you and I may desire, the step suggested by you seems to me to be incapable of being taken.
('61', 270, 1, 4, 527600) With reference to your second letter, what you say may be half true, namely that I want some individuals to go to prison in order to keep up the attitude of defiance.
('61', 270, 1, 5, 527767) But I want them to go to prison in order that out of the imprisonment of a few pure civil resisters may rise a manifestation which would be unmistakable and irresistible.
('61', 270, 1, 6, 527938) I am glad Begum Mahmud is better and I hope she will be thoroughly restored.
('61', 270, 1, 7, 528015) For your own health, how I wish you could take nature cure at Dr. Mehta’s sanatorium.
('61', 270, 1, 8, 528101) I have no doubt that you can be thoroughly restored.
('61', 270, 2, 9, 528154) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI [PS.] Salaams from Mahadev.

('61', 273, 3, 5, 532634) I had simply said that had the interview been granted, I would have been able to put forth something that would have been acceptable both to the Government and the people.
('61', 273, 3, 6, 532806) If you ask me what I would have put before the Viceroy, I cannot tell you, not because it is a secret but because I do not know.

('61', 273, 5, 12, 533536) 339. INTERVIEW TO “THE HINDU”
('61', 273, 6, 13, 533566) July 26, 1933
('61', 273, 7, 14, 533580) The disbandment of the Ashram would mean that every inmate would constitute a walking ashram, carrying with him or her the responsibility for realizing the Ashram ideal, no matter where situated, whether in prison or outside.
('61', 273, 8, 15, 533806) Mr. Gandhi added that the impending disbandment would not mean loss or diminution of incentive, but it would be a greater incentive to greater effort, greater dedication and greater sacrifice.
('61', 273, 8, 16, 533999) He would disband the Ashram as early as possible after the end of the month.
('61', 273, 8, 17, 534076) He declared: Every step regarding the Ashram will be taken with the full knowledge of the authorities.
('61', 273, 9, 18, 534179) Asked if he was closing the Ashram for want of funds, Mr. Gandhi said:
('61', 273, 10, 19, 534250) 1 The source had reported that Gandhiji was asked as to “what scheme he had in view to unfold to the Viceroy if the latter had granted him an interview”.
('61', 274, 0, 1, 534404) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 275
('61', 274, 1, 2, 534448) It is malicious and baseless to say so.
('61', 274, 1, 3, 534488) The Ashram has plenty of friends who have never kept it in want.

('61', 274, 2, 5, 534676) He declared: I am not only not seriously disappointed, but I am convinced that the majority of the inmates have made all endeavours, humanly possible to come up to the ideal.

('61', 274, 6, 17, 535802) 340. LETTER TO RABINDRANATH TAGORE
('61', 274, 7, 18, 535837) AHMEDABAD, July 27, 1933
('61', 274, 8, 19, 535862) DEAR GURUDEV,
('61', 274, 9, 20, 535876) I have read your Press message 1 regarding the Yeravda Pact, in so far as it applies to Bengal.
('61', 274, 9, 21, 535972) It caused me deep grief to find that you were misled by very deep affection for me and by your confidence in my judgment into approving of a Pact which was discovered to have
('61', 274, 10, 22, 536147) 1 Vide Appendix “Cable from Rabindranath Tagore to Sir Nripendranath Sircar”, after 22 7 1933. Rabindranath Tagore had forwarded a copy of this message along with his letter dated July 28, 1933 to Gandhiji; vide 1st footnote to “Letter to Rabindranath Tagore”, 7 8 1933.
('61', 275, 0, 1, 536418) 276 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATM GANDHI
('61', 275, 1, 2, 536459) done a grave injustice to Bengal.
('61', 275, 1, 3, 536493) It is now no use my saying that affection for me should not have affected your judgment, or that confidence in my judgment ought not to have made you accept a Pact about which you had ample means for coming to an independent judgment.
('61', 275, 1, 4, 536728) Knowing as I do your very generous nature, you could not have acted otherwise than you did and in spite of the discovery made by you that you have committed a grave error you would continue to repeat such errors if the occasions too were repeated.
('61', 275, 2, 5, 536976) But I am not at all convinced that there was any error made.
('61', 275, 2, 6, 537037) As soon as the agitation for an amendment of the Pact arose, I applied my mind to it, discussed it with friends who ought to know and I was satisfied that there was no injustice done to Bengal.
('61', 275, 2, 7, 537231) I corresponded with those who complained of injustice.
('61', 275, 2, 8, 537286) But they, too, including Ramanandbabu, could not convince me of any injustice.
('61', 275, 2, 9, 537365) Of course, our points of view were different.
('61', 275, 2, 10, 537411) In my opinion, the approach to the question was also wrong.
('61', 275, 3, 11, 537471) A Pact arrived at by mutual arrangement cannot possibly be altered by the British Government except through the consent of the parties to the Pact.
('61', 275, 3, 12, 537619) But no serious attempt seems to have been made to secure any such agreement.
('61', 275, 3, 13, 537696) Your appearance, therefore, on the same platform as the complainants, I, for one, welcome, in the hope that it would lead to a mutual discussion, instead of a futile appeal to the British Government.
('61', 275, 3, 14, 537896) If, therefore, you have, for your own part, studied the subject and have arrived at the opinion that you have now pronounced, I would like you to convene a meeting of the principal parties and convince them that a grave injustice has been done to Bengal.
('61', 275, 3, 15, 538151) If it can be proved, I have no doubt that the Pact will be re considered and amended so as to undo the wrong said to have been done to Bengal.
('61', 275, 3, 16, 538294) If I felt convinced that there was an error of judgment, so far as Bengal was concerned, I would strain every nerve to see that the error was rectified.
('61', 275, 3, 17, 538447) You may know that up to now I have studiously refrained from saying anything in public in defence of the Pact, save by way of reiterating my opinion accompanied by the statement that if injustice could be proved, redress would be given.
('61', 275, 3, 18, 538684) I am, therefore, entirely at your service.
('61', 275, 4, 19, 538727) Just now, I am absorbed in disbanding the Ashram and devising means of saving as much as can be for public use.
('61', 275, 4, 20, 538839) My service will, therefore, be available after I am imprisoned, which event may take
('61', 276, 0, 1, 538924) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 277
('61', 276, 1, 2, 538968) place any day after the end of this month.

('61', 277, 1, 2, 540687) 342. LETTER TO S. SADANAND
('61', 277, 2, 3, 540714) July 27, 1933
('61', 277, 3, 4, 540728) MY DEAR SADANAND,
('61', 277, 4, 5, 540746) I have had rough notes for the last two days from Maganbhai whom I had asked to read the file left by you.
('61', 277, 4, 6, 540853) He says that the headlines often give an impression wholly different from the contents which they describe.
('61', 277, 4, 7, 540961) Often events appear which have no basis in fact.
('61', 277, 4, 8, 541010) Just now I have been reading the Free Press during the few moments that I have allowed myself for newspaper reading and I want to tell you that I am not happy over my reading.
('61', 277, 4, 9, 541186) Your reporters seem to thrive more on gossip than on actualities.
('61', 277, 4, 10, 541252) Therefore, many things reported do not inspire belief.
('61', 277, 4, 11, 541307) What I would like you to do is to give the public only such news that have a good foundation and when the news consist of a forecast of events to come, the reporters should have substantial grounds for giving their forecast.
('61', 277, 4, 12, 541532) I have one forecast in my mind.
('61', 277, 4, 13, 541564) If it comes to pass I shall certainly congratulate you and your reporters.
('61', 277, 4, 14, 541639) In any case, you know that the ban no longer exists.
('61', 277, 5, 15, 541692) Yours sincerely, SJT.
('61', 277, 5, 16, 541714) S. SADANAND EDITOR, “FREE PRESS JOURNAL” DALAL STREET, FORT, BOMBAY

('61', 278, 6, 12, 542777) 345. INTERVIEW TO “THE DAILY HERALD”3
('61', 278, 7, 13, 542815) July 27, 1933
('61', 278, 8, 14, 542829) My merely going to jail is not sufficient sacrifice in the face of the sacrifices and sufferings of thousands of men and women of which I have had knowledge since the breaking of the fast.
('61', 278, 8, 15, 543018) The Ashram has three lakhs worth of immovable property, that is, land and buildings, and movable property worth nearly two lakhs, including a rich library containing 11,000 volumes.
('61', 278, 8, 16, 543200) We estimate the value of the books at least at Rs. 40,000. The members of the Ashram and I came to the conclusion that we should no longer enjoy these things when others have been deprived of what was just as precious as the, things of the Ashram to the Ashram people.
('61', 278, 8, 17, 543469) Moreover, many members of the Ashram having decided to offer individual civil disobedience, it would be wrong to expect the Government to treat the Ashram differently from other properties similarly affected.
('61', 278, 8, 18, 543678) Of course, there is a fundam ental difference.
('61', 278, 8, 19, 543725) The Ashram is a public trust, with well defined objects; and if the members of such a public institution adopt an
('61', 278, 9, 20, 543839) 1 Harilal Gandhi’s sister in law 2 Harilal Gandhi’s daughter 3 This was reported as “from a special correspondent”.
('61', 279, 0, 1, 543955) 280 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATM GANDHI
('61', 279, 1, 2, 543996) attitude which brings upon them the heavy hand of the law, good or bad, the property which is the subject matter of the trust might not be easily affected.
('61', 279, 1, 3, 544152) It is for this reason that we have decided that we should voluntarily give up possession of the properties to the Government.
('61', 279, 1, 4, 544278) Hence this step to be taken of disbanding the Ashram.
('61', 279, 2, 5, 544332) Replying to supplementary questions, the Mahatma said: The immovable property will revert to the Government.
('61', 279, 2, 6, 544441) The movable property, subject to what the Government have to say, will be given to public institutions.
('61', 279, 3, 7, 544545) Gandhiji said that he had not finally decided on his method of individual civil disobedience.
('61', 279, 3, 8, 544639) He added: I shall resort to no overt act of disobedience without first informing the Government.
('61', 279, 3, 9, 544736) I shall be ready with my plan on the 1st August.
('61', 279, 4, 10, 544785) Asked about the reports current that he is contemplating another march, Gandhiji said: That is all bazaar gossip.
('61', 279, 4, 11, 544899) I have not decided on anything yet.
('61', 279, 4, 12, 544935) It might be another march or might not be.
('61', 279, 4, 13, 544978) I cannot say yet.
('61', 279, 5, 14, 544996) The Hindu, 28 7 1933
('61', 279, 6, 15, 545017) 346. INTERVIEW TO “THE TIMES OF INDIA”

('61', 279, 8, 18, 545302) Mr. Gandhi said: They are all qualifying themselves for Harijan service.

('61', 281, 6, 17, 548409) 350. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS OF INDIA
('61', 281, 7, 18, 548453) AHMEDABAD, July 28, 1933
('61', 281, 8, 19, 548478) Asked by a representative of the Associated Press as to how he would vacate the Ashram and who would take charge of it, Mr. Gandhi said that it was a question which could be better answered by the Government than by him, for the simple reason that when the members of the Ashram vacated the property, it naturally would become Government’s care, but the question was somewhat premature.
('61', 281, 8, 20, 548865) They would all know in a few days, what would happen to the Ashram property.
('61', 281, 8, 21, 548942) Asked if this referred to the movable property also, Mr. Gandhi said he hoped not.
('61', 281, 8, 22, 549025) That question too would be decided inside two or three days.
('61', 281, 8, 23, 549086) It is understood that Mr. Gandhi has written a letter 1 to the Government of Bombay in this connection, a reply to which is awaited by him.
('61', 281, 8, 24, 549226) Asked what he thought of the rumours published in the Press that the Government would not give him this time, if he went to jail, the facility for Harijan work that was given to him before, Mr. Gandhi stated that he did not believe the
('61', 281, 9, 25, 549462) 1 Vide “Letter to Home Secretary, Government of India”, 26 7 1933.
('61', 282, 0, 1, 549529) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 283
('61', 282, 1, 2, 549573) rumour at all.
('61', 282, 1, 3, 549588) He had not a shadow of doubt that the Government would not go back upon the policy deliberately adopted by them—a policy which was implied in Yeravda Pact—and for which he had never given, so far as he was aware, the slightest reason.
('61', 282, 1, 4, 549823) The Hindu, 28 7 1933
('61', 282, 2, 5, 549844) 351. NOTES
('61', 282, 3, 6, 549855) A NOTEWORTHY DONATION
('61', 282, 4, 7, 549877) A Brahmin, who has lost his sister and sister’s daughter, sends me a cheque for Rs. 1,750 to be invested and the interest to be used for the benefit of Harijans, in any manner that may commend itself to me.
('61', 282, 4, 8, 550084) In the course of his letter he says:
('61', 282, 5, 9, 550121) I had set apart Rs. 2,000 for charity in connection with the death of my dear sister and daughter.
('61', 282, 5, 10, 550220) I have used Rs. 250 out of the sum so far for the local charities and I am sending you the balance for Harijan uplift.
('61', 282, 5, 11, 550339) My own suggestion is that this money should be invested to form the nucleus of a permanent fund whose interest only should be used for the benefit of Harijans.
('61', 282, 5, 12, 550499) But you are at liberty, if you think it more advisable, to use the capital in any manner you like in connection with the Harijan service.
('61', 282, 5, 13, 550637) I would like you not to disclose my name.
('61', 282, 5, 14, 550679) I respect both the wishes of the donor and I am handing the cheque to the Gujarat Branch of the Servants of Untouchables Society with instructions to invest it and to use the interest for the benefit of Harijans, with my approval, wherever such approval can be easily procured.
('61', 282, 5, 15, 550957) I hope that this example will be followed by others.
('61', 282, 6, 16, 551010) AN OVERSEER’S CONFESSION
('61', 282, 7, 17, 551035) Letters continue still to come as evidence of the indirect influence that the fast had on several workers.
('61', 282, 7, 18, 551142) One such worker from Gujarat writes a pathetic letter in Gujarati which I condense below: When you were in Poona, I often took up the pen to write to you, but my courage failed me.
('61', 282, 7, 19, 551323) But today, early in the morning, I said to myself that whilst you were so near me I should disburden myself of my sin and tell you how I had robbed poor people.
('61', 282, 7, 20, 551484) It happened this way: In 1900, you may remember, there was a big famine.
('61', 282, 7, 21, 551557) I was in charge oflabourers who were employed at some famine work.
('61', 282, 7, 22, 551624) I was then a mere lad, and I saw nothing wrong in helping myself out of the wages that
('61', 283, 0, 1, 551711) 284 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATM GANDHI
('61', 283, 1, 2, 551752) were paid to the labourers under my charge.
('61', 283, 1, 3, 551796) It is likely that I must have taken nothing less than Rs. 100 in this fashion.
('61', 283, 1, 4, 551875) I was engaged for nearly eight months.
('61', 283, 1, 5, 551914) The saddest part of the story is that the labourers were all Harijans, whom I was instrumental in engaging.
('61', 283, 1, 6, 552022) I was otherwise kind to them and they always seemed to be pleased with me.
('61', 283, 1, 7, 552097) But I helped myself with one pice per head, out of eight to be paid to the full day labourer.
('61', 283, 1, 8, 552191) I was so mean that I could not help taking away one pice from the wages of a boy of about 6 years old.
('61', 283, 1, 9, 552294) The fact that this boy helped me considerably at the time of distribution of wages enhances my guilt.
('61', 283, 1, 10, 552396) I drowned my conscience and flattered myself with the belief that I could safely steal the money I did from these poor people, because I was instrumental in finding them employment.
('61', 283, 1, 11, 552578) I had under me non Harijan labourers also.
('61', 283, 1, 12, 552621) They did not always relish my taking one pice per head from their wages and I had to threaten them with dismissal if they did not let me steal the pice from them.
('61', 283, 1, 13, 552784) But the poor Harijans never said a word in protest when I helped myself regularly every day in the manner I have described.
('61', 283, 1, 14, 552908) Nor does the recital of misdeeds stop here.
('61', 283, 1, 15, 552952) I could not even keep my relations with women labourers quite pure.
('61', 283, 1, 16, 553020) Though I may not say anything in self defence I must inform you that the whole atmosphere around me was soul killing.
('61', 283, 1, 17, 553138) There was only one Parsi Engineer who, I believe, was incorruptible.
('61', 283, 1, 18, 553207) As some penance for my misdeeds I enclose herewith notes for Rs. 250 of which Rs. 50 are marked for the use of Harijans to be distributed as follows: Rs. 28 towards education.
('61', 283, 1, 19, 553383) Rs. 20 towards supply of water to them and Rs. 10 for propaganda.
('61', 283, 1, 20, 553449) The other Rs. 200 you can use as you like.
('61', 283, 1, 21, 553492) What this young man did in 1900 was undoubtedly the common practice amongst overseers and I fear very much that it still continues.
('61', 283, 1, 22, 553624) Poor Harijans, unable to find work, otherwise make a virtue of necessity and even feel thankful to those who rob them.
('61', 283, 1, 23, 553743) They feel that if they resisted the robbery they were in danger of losing the only means of earning a miserable pittance.
('61', 283, 1, 24, 553865) But such regular robbery of a portion of their hard earned daily wage cannot
('61', 284, 0, 1, 553942) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 285
('61', 284, 1, 2, 553986) but leave an unpleasant memory behind.
('61', 284, 1, 3, 554025) I congratulate the writer of the letter on his frankness and his penance.
('61', 284, 1, 4, 554099) Let this letter be a warning to all Harijan workers and let it serve the purpose of making them clean.
('61', 284, 2, 5, 554202) Harijan, 29 7 1933
('61', 284, 3, 6, 554221) 352. SOME DANGEROUS BELIEFS
('61', 284, 4, 7, 554249) A professor of English writes as follows: 1
('61', 284, 5, 8, 554293) My reading of the situation in Cochin and Travancore is that there will be a most unhappy split if temple entry for Harijans is your next step, unless people are convinced that the tapasya you have performed has endowed you with the power to understand our temples.
('61', 284, 5, 9, 554559) Even non caste Hindus are not convinced that you are completing the work of Shri Narayana Guru, because he built them separate temples.
('61', 284, 5, 10, 554695) I humbly beg you to visit personally a temple or two in Kerala with Malaviyaji, if possible.
('61', 284, 6, 11, 554788) My own orthodoxy borders on superstition.
('61', 284, 6, 12, 554830) Your fast perplexed me, I fasted and prayed for guidance, and then I felt I must go to Chottanikary temple to pray for your life.
('61', 284, 6, 13, 554960) There I met the Brahmin devotee about whom I have written once, and after days of discussion we found we could not agree.
('61', 284, 6, 14, 555082) On the seventh day I had a feeling that you would successfully terminate the fast.
('61', 284, 7, 15, 555165) At the temple I witnessed two cures of what new psychology would call hysteria or multiple personality.
('61', 284, 7, 16, 555269) The cure of mental and nervous disease is common in many temples.
('61', 284, 8, 17, 555335) The orthodox people fear that any departure from usage may lessen the sanctity of temples.
('61', 284, 8, 18, 555426) The Catholic Church at Ettumanur was once noted for such cures.
('61', 284, 8, 19, 555490) The slackening of caste rules among Catholics is believed to be the cause of the partial disappearance of the power.
('61', 284, 8, 20, 555607) It is almost impossible to convince people that such explanations are absurd.
('61', 284, 8, 21, 555685) They live in a narrow static universe....
('61', 284, 8, 22, 555727) I am not so much concerned over the feared unhappy split on the temple entry question as over the dangerous beliefs to which the professor refers.
('61', 284, 8, 23, 555874) Suffice it to say that I shall leave no stone unturned to avoid a split.
('61', 284, 8, 24, 555947) But my goal is quite clear.
('61', 284, 8, 25, 555975) It is not to have Harijans regarded as a separate body in Hinduism or outside it.
('61', 284, 8, 26, 556057) I shall be satisfied with nothing less than complete removal of untouchability as it is known to us today.
('61', 284, 8, 27, 556164) The beliefs, however, to which the professor refers seem to me to be most dangerous.
('61', 284, 9, 28, 556249) 1 Only excerpts are reproduced here.
('61', 285, 0, 1, 556286) 286 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATM GANDHI
('61', 285, 1, 2, 556327) doubt imagination goes a long way in making us do certain things and to refrain from doing certain other things.
('61', 285, 1, 3, 556440) People have been known to die of fright because they have mistaken a rope for a snake.
('61', 285, 1, 4, 556527) But it would be highly improper to cultivate the habit of entertaining such imaginary beliefs.
('61', 285, 1, 5, 556622) Therefore, in spite of the professor’s testimony about the cures, I am unable to endorse the deduction the professor draws from these cures that the extraordinary beliefs, entertained by people in Malabar about the curative powers of certain idols in certain temples in Malabar, are justified.
('61', 285, 1, 6, 556916) I feel that it is necessary to educate the people out of such beliefs.
('61', 285, 1, 7, 556987) They cannot promote healthy thinking.
('61', 285, 1, 8, 557025) And in any case I do not see how the entry of ‘untouchables’ can pollute temples or deities installed therein.
('61', 285, 1, 9, 557136) And it is clear from the very nature of things that the powers, curative or any other, come not from deities but from the imaginary imputing of those powers to the temples or their deities.
('61', 285, 1, 10, 557326) Surely many ‘untouchables’ must have entered these temples without being detected and without the efficacy of the deities being in any way affected.
('61', 285, 1, 11, 557475) In my humble opinion, therefore, it is up to every educated man and woman in Malabar to make a serious effort to rid Hinduism of the beliefs described by the correspondent.
('61', 285, 1, 12, 557648) Surely it is no matter for joy or congratulation that even the Catholic Church has been affected by the virus of untouchability.
('61', 285, 2, 13, 557777) Harijan, 29 7 1933
('61', 285, 3, 14, 557796) 353. AN EXAMPLE TO COPY
('61', 285, 4, 15, 557820) A European correspondent writes: 1
('61', 285, 5, 16, 557855) My object in writing this letter is not to deal with points in Harijan but to draw your attention to (or rather to remind you of—you have surely heard of it) the work being done at Hampton Institute, Hampton, Virginia, and at Tuskegee Institute, Alabama, U.S. for the American Negroes.
('61', 285, 5, 17, 558141) To some extent the problem of the masses of the Harijans of today is the problem of the American slaves on their emancipation in 1865 (I think that was the date).
('61', 285, 5, 18, 558304) In the Story of Hampton .
('61', 285, 5, 19, 558330) is unfolded the story of how noble white American men and women tackled this problem.
('61', 285, 5, 20, 558416) Again in Up from Slavery, My Larger Education and Tuskegee and Its People by Booker T. Washington .
('61', 285, 5, 21, 558516) is revealed the story of what noble black Americans (many of them graduates of
('61', 285, 6, 22, 558595) 1 Only excerpts are reproduced here.
('61', 286, 0, 1, 558632) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 287
('61', 286, 1, 2, 558676) Hampton Institute) have done and are doing for their people and not only for their own people but for others.
('61', 286, 1, 3, 558786) The scientific experiments in farming carried on at Tuskegee, for example, have benefited the country all round.
('61', 286, 1, 4, 558899) Might I also suggest that it might not be amiss if some of those in charge of Harijan education paid a visit to these American institutions.
('61', 286, 1, 5, 559040) The advance of American Negro reads like a wonder tale.
('61', 286, 1, 6, 559096) Of course, in no case must manual training be emphasized at the expense of higher literary and artistic training.
('61', 286, 1, 7, 559210) The two should go hand in hand.
('61', 286, 1, 8, 559242) My ideal is that every shoemaker should have a University degree and that every University graduate should be skilled in some form of manual work.
('61', 286, 1, 9, 559389) Thus and thus only would varnashrama become without offence to any, but thus also would the whole point of varnashrama fall away.
('61', 286, 1, 10, 559519) I note that you suggest that wealthy people might build new temples, but does it require wealthy people to do that?
('61', 286, 1, 11, 559635) Should not the great feature of such new temples be their simplicity?
('61', 286, 1, 12, 559705) Are not the reformers, the puritans of Hinduism?
('61', 286, 1, 13, 559754) Cannot Harijans and reformers, with their own hands, build these temples?
('61', 286, 1, 14, 559828) Neither the Hampton Institute nor the Tuskegee are unfamiliar to me, but they cannot be familiar to the Indian readers of the Harijan.
('61', 286, 1, 15, 559963) There is no doubt that the work of Armstrong at the Hampton Institute and of Booker T. Washington at the Tuskegee is worth studying by all Harijan workers and Harijans.
('61', 286, 1, 16, 560132) The analogy, however, does not hold good in all respects.
('61', 286, 1, 17, 560190) The work of the white men at Hampton Institute corresponds to some of the work being done by the so called high caste Hindus among Harijans.
('61', 286, 1, 18, 560331) But I feel sure that the duty owing by the former to Harijans, is far more imperative than that of white men towards American Negroes.
('61', 286, 1, 19, 560466) For we have made of the artificial and assumed superiority of so called high castes over Harijans a matter of religion and therefore the work of the Hindu reformer in India is more urgent than that of the white reformer in America, as it also becomes far more difficult.
('61', 286, 1, 20, 560737) And yet I have no doubt that we have nothing corresponding to Hampton Institute in India.
('61', 286, 1, 21, 560827) That Institute is a very great enterprise and a noble monument of the industrious and exceedingly well informed zeal of a handful of white reformers.
('61', 286, 1, 22, 560977) The Tuskegee Institute is a model for Harijans.
('61', 286, 1, 23, 561025) Booker Washington has shown to the world what a man of a despised race can do in the teeth of enormous odds.
('61', 286, 1, 24, 561134) He was able to build that noble edifice at Tuskegee because of his limitless faith and equally limitless application.
('61', 286, 1, 25, 561252) Indeed, both the Institutes, apart from their special usefulness for Harijans and Harijan sevaks, have a very high value from the general educationist’s point of view.
('61', 286, 1, 26, 561420) I hope some
('61', 287, 0, 1, 561432) 288 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATM GANDHI
('61', 287, 1, 2, 561473) day, therefore, to give in these pages a gist of the work done by and in both the Institutes.
('61', 287, 1, 3, 561567) Meanwhile, let it be noted that in both, great stress is laid upon the dignity of manual labour and the endeavour in both is to draw out the best in the students that flock to them.
('61', 287, 2, 4, 561749) As to my correspondent’s reference to varnashrama, evidently the whole point of it has been missed, for, as I have interpreted varnadharma, there is no bar in any shape or form to the highest mental development.
('61', 287, 2, 5, 561961) The bar altogether moral is against change of hereditary occupation for the sake of bettering one’s material condition, and thus setting up a system of unhealthy and ruinous competition which is today robbing life of all its joy and beauty.
('61', 287, 3, 6, 562202) As to the temples, I refer to my description of the model temple!
('61', 287, 3, 7, 562268) I am trying to think that my model temple more than fulfill the requirements of my correspondent.
('61', 287, 3, 8, 562366) But my reason for reproducing from the letter the reference to new temples is to emphasize the fact that Western thinkers are watching this movement for the removal of untouchability and that they would have us not merely to be satisfied with the mere destruction of the outward form, but they would have us to carry out a thorough going reform so as to revolutionize many old rooted ideas and so to purify Hindu society as to affect the whole of mankind.
('61', 287, 4, 9, 562822) Harijan, 29 7 1933
('61', 287, 5, 10, 562841) 354. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS OF INDIA
('61', 287, 6, 11, 562885) AHMEDABAD, July 29, 1933
('61', 287, 7, 12, 562910) Asked by a representative of the Associated Press what he had to say regarding the fears entertained in some quarters that the suspension of the Congress Committees would plunge the country into chaos, Mr. Gandhi stated that behind the question there lay a grave misconception of the situation.
('61', 287, 7, 13, 563205) The question presupposed that there were lawfully working Congress organizations all over the country, which the acting Congress President had dissolved.
('61', 287, 7, 14, 563359) The fact was that all such organizations had been declared illegal.
('61', 287, 7, 15, 563427) What was therefore working were secret organizations, and shadow cabinets, and this was calculated to lead to chaos.
('61', 287, 7, 16, 563544) That condition had been anticipated, and stopped by the action of the acting President.
('61', 287, 7, 17, 563632) If there was any chaos now, it would be confined to individuals.
('61', 288, 0, 1, 563697) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 289
('61', 288, 1, 2, 563741) The more he read the criticism levelled at Mr. M. S. Alley’s action, Mr. Gandhi said, the more convinced he felt that, as time passed, people would understand the necessity for his action, as also its beauty.
('61', 288, 1, 3, 563950) It was the only action possible in order to save the Congress and the national honour and the national spirit that had been awakened among the masses.
('61', 288, 1, 4, 564101) Asked if it was true as hinted in the Press report that he had offered to Government to take possession of his Ashram in anticipation of confiscation, Mahatma Gandhi said: “No.” He asked the people patiently to await events, instead of anticipating them.
('61', 288, 2, 5, 564356) Asked whether he had decided his plan of civil disobedience, Mr. Gandhi said there were undoubtedly many schemes floating in his brain, which it would be purposeless to recount, but as soon as anything took a definite shape, he would gladly share it with the public.
('61', 288, 2, 6, 564623) But he would share it first with the Government.
('61', 288, 2, 7, 564672) He said the Harijans were more than friends to him and he might not invite them to joint him.
('61', 288, 2, 8, 564766) Asked whether he would launch his civil disobedience on the 1st August and call upon anybody to join him, Mr. Gandhi said that, whether it would be 1st August or when, he was unable to say.
('61', 288, 3, 9, 564956) The Hindustan Times, 30 7 1933; also The Hindu, 31 7 1933
('61', 288, 4, 10, 565014) 355. STATEMENT ON SENGUPTA DAY
('61', 288, 5, 11, 565045) AHMEDABAD, July 30, 1933
('61', 288, 6, 12, 565070) I have received a message from Mr. Santosh Basu, Mayor of Calcutta, and others asking me to announce 6th August as the All India Sengupta Day.
('61', 288, 6, 13, 565213) I also have seen Mr. Aney’s appeal in the same connection.
('61', 288, 6, 14, 565272) I associate myself heartily with the appeal made by the acting President of the Congress and I hope that at public meetings that may be convened, striking features of the departed patriot’s life will be recalled and endeavour will be made by all to reproduce them in their own lives.
('61', 288, 7, 15, 565556) The Hindustan Times, 1 8 1933

('61', 289, 1, 2, 565740) 356. STATEMENT TO ASSOCIATED PRESS OF INDIA1
('61', 289, 2, 3, 565785) July 30, 1933
('61', 289, 3, 4, 565799) On the eve of what is to me an act of greater dedication than perhaps ever before, I would like to urge all Congressmen not to fritter away their energy in debating over the decision of the acting President regarding individual civil disobedience.
('61', 289, 3, 5, 566047) As an expert I reiterate my opinion that the decision was the only right course to take.
('61', 289, 3, 6, 566136) In my opinion it is also constitutional.
('61', 289, 3, 7, 566177) I would urge every Congressman to study my statement 2 carefully and it will be found that if the programme is zealously worked out the Congress will become a much more powerful organization than it has ever been.
('61', 289, 3, 8, 566391) Without civil disobedience there is no safety and no freedom.
('61', 289, 3, 9, 566453) Civil disobedience can become impregnable only in the manner pointed out by me.
('61', 289, 3, 10, 566533) To non Congressmen I would say: Help the largest organization in the country in every way you can.
('61', 289, 3, 11, 566632) It is not a sectional body.
('61', 289, 3, 12, 566660) It is national in every sense of the term.
('61', 289, 3, 13, 566703) To the Englishmen, whether belonging to the services or others, I would say: If you want peace in the land and real friendship with India, Ordinance Rule is not the way, that of the Congress is the only way.
('61', 289, 3, 14, 566911) I say this as a friend of the English people.
('61', 289, 3, 15, 566957) Some of you may regard me today as your enemy.
('61', 289, 3, 16, 567004) I make bold to prophesy that a day will come when the mists will have rolled away and you will admit my claim.
('61', 289, 4, 17, 567115) M. K. GANDHI
('61', 289, 5, 18, 567128) From a photostat: S.N. 21541

('61', 290, 19, 23, 568176) 358. APPEAL TO PEOPLE OF GUJARAT 1
('61', 290, 20, 24, 568211) July 30, 1933
('61', 290, 21, 25, 568225) It was no easy thing to decide to sacrifice the Ashram, but it was very clear to every inmate of the Ashram that the sacrifice was inevitable.
('61', 290, 21, 26, 568368) This sacrifice is nothing before the suffering and sacrifice that has been gone through by the peasants of Karnatak, Midnapore and Kaira, the U. P. and of the Frontier.
('61', 290, 21, 27, 568537) They have been so far given secret relief which has now been stopped or will be stopped, and should be stopped.
('61', 290, 21, 28, 568649) But that does not mean that those who are starving should be deprived of public relief simply because they were satyagrahis.
('61', 290, 21, 29, 568774) I hope that all the peasants who are in distress will receive
('61', 290, 22, 30, 568836) 1 The first and the third paragraphs of this were omitted in the Press reports.
('61', 291, 0, 1, 568916) 292 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATM GANDHI
('61', 291, 1, 2, 568957) the needed relief from the public and, should Government prohibit the distribution of such relief, those who give the relief will have the ability to resist it and take the consequences.
('61', 291, 1, 3, 569144) But whether they have the ability or not, the way is clear for me.
('61', 291, 1, 4, 569211) I have sacrificed my all.
('61', 291, 1, 5, 569237) On Tuesday morning I propose, God willing, to march from the Ashram with 33 companions.
('61', 291, 1, 6, 569325) Some of these will be even physically weaker than I, for there are nearly as many women with me this time as men.
('61', 291, 1, 7, 569439) But I could not resist their desire to sacrifice themselves.
('61', 291, 1, 8, 569500) It was to them a call they could not resist.
('61', 291, 1, 9, 569545) We hope and pray that God will help us to carry out our pledge.
('61', 291, 1, 10, 569609) Our immediate destination is Ras.
('61', 291, 1, 11, 569643) In case we are allowed to reach there, we shall proceed further.
('61', 291, 1, 12, 569708) But it is quite likely that we may all be arrested as we proceed on the march.
('61', 291, 1, 13, 569787) If we are not so arrested, it is our plan to carry the message of fearlessness to every village home.
('61', 291, 1, 14, 569889) We will not invite them to offer mass civil disobedience, but we will certainly ask such as may be ready to offer individual civil disobedience, we will ask those who drink to refrain from it, the liquor dealer to give up his trade, the foreign cloth dealer to deal exclusively in khaddar and we shall carry the message of hand spinning to every home.
('61', 291, 1, 15, 570241) We shall ask the so called high class Hindus to wash themselves clean of untouchability and to befriend the Harijans.
('61', 291, 1, 16, 570359) We shall ask the Harijans to observe the rules of hygiene and abjure carrion, and we shall call upon all the communities to achieve communal unity, thus fulfilling the whole of the constructive programme of the Congress.
('61', 291, 2, 17, 570580) Let me set out in brief what we shall expect of the villages we visit.
('61', 291, 2, 18, 570651) We will not have a copper on us, we shall cheerfully and thankfully accept what humble fare the villagers may offer us.
('61', 291, 2, 19, 570771) The coarsest fare lovingly served will mean to us the choicest treat.
('61', 291, 2, 20, 570841) As this is the rainy season, we shall be thankful to be put up in a cottage having a roof and we shall march by easy stages, as many amongst us are not physically strong, and our programme will not be rigid.
('61', 291, 2, 21, 571049) We shall halt whenever our legs cannot carry us further but we don’t propose to spend more than a single night at one place.
('61', 291, 2, 22, 571174) It is possible that the Government may take me before Tuesday.
('61', 291, 2, 23, 571237) Even then the march will continue so long as there is any marcher left free.
('61', 291, 2, 24, 571314) I am confident that if the sacrifice that we are offering is pure, it
('61', 291, 3, 25, 571384) 1 What follows is taken from the photostat source.
('61', 292, 0, 1, 571435) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 293

('61', 295, 7, 18, 576324) 367. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS
('61', 295, 8, 19, 576352) July 30, 1933
('61', 295, 9, 20, 576366) Interviewed by Pressmen, Gandhiji said that there was no truth in the Press report that he had drafted a letter to the Viceroy.
('61', 295, 9, 21, 576494) He said he knew only one fetish in life and that was Truth, and he was not sorry for having made of it a fetish.
('61', 295, 9, 22, 576607) In his opinion, prestige came unasked and unsought from right conduct, right speech and right thought.
('61', 295, 9, 23, 576710) His endeavour ever since he entered public life was to regulate it by those three golden rules.
('61', 295, 9, 24, 576806) Replying to a question whether his request to the Viceroy for an interview was accompanied by a threat of revival of civil disobedience, Gandhiji declared that in no
('61', 295, 10, 25, 576972) 1 In July 1933, Gandhiji had offered to hand over the Sabarmati Ashram to the Government; vide also “Interview to Associated Press of India”, 25 7 1933 and 301 4. However, the Ashram was finally given over to the Harijan Sevak Sangh; vide also “Letter to Vallabhbhai Patel”, 24 9 1933. 2 The figure has been struck off in the source.
('61', 295, 10, 26, 577306) 3 T. Titus 4 Vide also “Letter to Vallabhbhai Patel”, 24 9 1933.
('61', 296, 0, 1, 577371) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 297
('61', 296, 1, 2, 577415) sense was the request for an interview accompanied by threat of any kind whatsoever, whether direct or indirect, open or veiled.
('61', 296, 1, 3, 577544) It was for the sake of avoiding the slightest suspicion of threat that the proceedings of the informal conference were made confidential.
('61', 296, 1, 4, 577682) It was a public misfortune that the present code of conduct of newspapers not only permitted, but seemed even to applaud the gaining of confidential information by hook or crook, and gave it publicity.
('61', 296, 1, 5, 577884) That at an informal conference many things were said in connection with the possibilities that might arise if the interview was not granted or if granted, proved infructuous, could not in any way be interpreted as threat.
('61', 296, 1, 6, 578106) The relevant fact was that his request for interview carried with it no condition.

('61', 300, 3, 6, 584151) On the contrary, I make bold to say that I have made the best endeavour possible to promote public peace and I can show several instances in which I have attained very considerable success in preserving and promoting public peace.

('61', 302, 9, 18, 587778) DEAR SIR, What purports to be an authentic report in The Times of India dated the 2nd instant, says that I am to be released after being served with an order 2 which will restrict my movements to Poona and preclude any activities connected with the civil disobedience movement.
('61', 302, 9, 19, 588056) It then goes on: “Should he ignore this order he will be re arrested.” If the report be true, I would like to say, in order to save
('61', 302, 10, 20, 588188) 1 A German lady who was working as a nurse in V. S. Hospital, Ahmedabad 2 Vide Appendix “Order Restraining Gandhiji’s Movements”, before 18 8 1933; also the following item.
('61', 303, 0, 1, 588361) 304 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATM GANDHI
('61', 303, 1, 2, 588402) Government possible, unnecessary embarrassment, and to conserve my energy, which I am still regaining since the breaking of the fast, that in accordance with my belief in civil disobedience, I shall be unable to conform to the order reported to be under contemplation.
('61', 303, 1, 3, 588671) If the object be to secure my conviction I have no doubt that the sweeping powers possessed by Government enable them to do so without going through the vexatious procedure described in the above mentioned report.
('61', 303, 1, 4, 588885) I gratefully observe that Government have kept Sjt.
('61', 303, 1, 5, 588937) Mahadev Desai with me.
('61', 303, 1, 6, 588960) He therefore desires me to say that civil disobedience is as much a life principle with him as with me, and that he can no more refrain than I can from preaching or practising it.

('61', 304, 7, 8, 590224) 383. TRIAL AT POONA3
('61', 304, 8, 9, 590245) August 4, 1933
('61', 304, 9, 10, 590260) After the Magistrate had explained the circumstances under which the trial was
('61', 304, 10, 11, 590339) taking place, Gandhiji suggested that as he intended to plead guilty to the charge,
('61', 304, 11, 12, 590423) witnesses might not be examined.

('61', 304, 12, 14, 590502) procedure required him to record some evidence.
('61', 304, 13, 15, 590550) GANDHIJI: I think in 1922, when I pleaded guilty all evidence was dispensed with.

('61', 304, 16, 21, 590799) much as possible.
('61', 304, 17, 22, 590817) Asked by the Court if he wished to cross examine the witness, Gandhiji
('61', 304, 18, 23, 590888) 1 Given before R. V. Martin, the Superintendent, Yeravda Central Prison 2 Vide Appendix “Order Restraining Gandhiji’s Movements”, before 18 8 1933. Gandhiji broke the order forthwith and was re arrested and taken back to Yeravda Jail for trial; vide the following item.
('61', 304, 18, 24, 591158) 3 Gandhiji, on his release at 9 a.m., was served with an order to remain within Poona city limits.
