('61', 305, 0, 1, 591583) 306 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATM GANDHI
('61', 305, 1, 2, 591624) replied in the negative.
('61', 305, 2, 3, 591649) Gandhiji declined to cross examine this witness also saying: No, thanks.
('61', 305, 3, 4, 591722) To a question put by the Court, Gandhiji stated that his age was 64, and that he was a Hindu by caste.
('61', 305, 4, 5, 591825) M. What is your occupation?
('61', 305, 5, 6, 591853) G. (Hesitatingly) I am by occupation a spinner, a weaver and a farmer.
('61', 305, 6, 7, 591924) M. Your residence?
('61', 305, 7, 8, 591943) G. Yeravda Jail now.
('61', 305, 7, 9, 591964) (Laughter)
('61', 305, 8, 10, 591975) M. Now, of course, but otherwise?

('61', 305, 10, 12, 592056) M. Have you anything to say regarding the prosecution evidence recorded?
('61', 305, 11, 13, 592129) G. I think that the statements that several prosecution witnesses have made are quite correct.
('61', 305, 12, 14, 592224) Gandhiji, proceeding, stated that he desired to make a brief statement as to why he had committed a breach of the order.
('61', 305, 12, 15, 592345) The court consenting, he dictated off hand a brief statement in slow and measured tones.
('61', 305, 12, 16, 592434) He stated: I would like to make a brief statement as to why I have committed what must be described as a wilful and deliberate breach of orders of the Government of Bombay.
('61', 305, 12, 17, 592607) It cannot be a matter of pleasure to me to commit a breach of orders of a constituted authority.
('61', 305, 12, 18, 592704) I am a lover of peace, and I regard myself a good citizen voluntarily tendering obedience to the laws of the State to which I may belong.
('61', 305, 12, 19, 592842) But there are occasions in the lifetime of a citizen when it becomes his painful duty to disobey laws and orders of his State.
('61', 305, 12, 20, 592969) As is well known, such a painful duty came upon me in 1919 and I have not only regarded it as my duty to offer civil disobedience but also to preach it to others.
('61', 305, 13, 21, 593132) 1 Lt. Col.
('61', 305, 13, 22, 593143) Martin, Superintendent, Yeravda Jail, the second witness to be examined, stated that it was he who served the order on Gandhiji.
('61', 305, 13, 23, 593272) Then, Assistant Superintendent of Police, the third witness, deposed that Gandhiji and Mahadev Desai were found at 9.40 a.m.
('61', 305, 13, 24, 593397) still within Yeravda limits having gone out of the jail in a private taxi.
('61', 305, 13, 25, 593472) On being told to quit the place at once, they refused to do so.
('61', 305, 13, 26, 593536) After ten minutes, they were reminded of the order, and on their refusal to comply with it, they were both re arrested by the witness and brought back to Yeravda Jail.
('61', 305, 13, 27, 593704) 2 The taxi driver in whose taxi Gandhiji drove to Golf Iinks was the last witness.
('61', 305, 13, 28, 593787) He corroborated the other witnesses.
('61', 306, 0, 1, 593824) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 307
('61', 306, 1, 2, 593868) This law or Act under which I have been tried, is a glaring instance in proof of my contention that the system under which India is being governed today is not merely unjust, but is dragging her down economically and morally.
('61', 306, 1, 3, 594094) I have had recently a spell of freedom and was in the midst of people and had an opportunity of coming into contact with a very large number of men and women.
('61', 306, 1, 4, 594253) I made what was to me a most painful discovery, that men high and low, educated and uneducated, rich and poor, were demoralized, and were living in a perpetual fear of loss of liberty and their possessions.
('61', 306, 1, 5, 594460) It was a trial for me to live in the midst of that atmosphere.
('61', 306, 1, 6, 594523) Being by nature from my childhood a confirmed believer in the methods of non violence, I sought shelter in self suffering such as might fall to my lot.
('61', 306, 1, 7, 594675) That was the only way in which I could relieve myself of some of the agony that was burning in me.
('61', 306, 1, 8, 594774) It is for reasons such as this that I am offering all resistance to this system of Government—a resistance that is within my capacity and resistance that a peaceful man like me could offer.
('61', 306, 1, 9, 594964) One word more.
('61', 306, 1, 10, 594979) I think, you, Sir, or Government would, after sentencing me, classify me.
('61', 306, 1, 11, 595053) I must state that I intensely dislike the procedure of classification of prisoners into A, B and C classes.
('61', 306, 1, 12, 595161) I have no desire whatsoever to enjoy the special comforts to which other fellow prisoners might not be entitled.
('61', 306, 1, 13, 595274) I would like to be classified amongst those whom the Government may consider to be the lowest.
('61', 306, 1, 14, 595369) I would like, in conclusion, to state that the authorities with whom I had come in contact during these few days have treated me with courtesy and consideration for which I am thankful to them.
('61', 306, 2, 15, 595563) After making the above statement, Gandhiji read through it as recorded by the Magistrate and stated that it was all right.
('61', 306, 3, 16, 595686) The Magistrate then framed a charge under Section 14 of the Bombay Special Powers Act 1932, for intentionally disobeying an order of the Government under Section 4 of the same Act requiring him among other things to remove himself before 9.30 a.m.
('61', 306, 3, 17, 595934) outside Yeravda village limits.
('61', 306, 3, 18, 595966) Asked if he pleaded guilty, Gandhiji replied in the affirmative.
('61', 306, 4, 19, 596031) Gandhiji also stated that he did not want to call defence witnesses.
('61', 306, 4, 20, 596100) At this stage the police prosecutor said that considering Gandhiji’s age he did not press for a deterrent sentence.
('61', 306, 5, 21, 596216) The Magistrate delivered judgment and observed that it had been proved that Gandhiji disobeyed an order of the Government.
('61', 306, 5, 22, 596339) As such he convicted him under
('61', 307, 0, 1, 596370) 308 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATM GANDHI
('61', 307, 1, 2, 596411) Section 14 of the Bombay Special Powers Act of 1932 and sentenced him to one year’s simple imprisonment....
('61', 307, 2, 3, 596519) M. I am passing a light sentence considering your age and the present state of your health and also because the prosecution has not pressed for a deterrent sentence.
('61', 307, 3, 4, 596685) This concluded the trial and Gandhiji rose after bowing to the Magistrate and was taken by the jailor to his cell.
('61', 307, 3, 5, 596800) Gandhiji has been placed in ‘A’ class.
('61', 307, 4, 6, 596839) The Bombay Chronicle, 5 8 1933
('61', 307, 5, 7, 596870) 384. LETTER TO HOME SECRETARY, GOVERNMENT OF BOMBAY
('61', 307, 6, 8, 596922) YERAVDA CENTRAL PRISON, August 4, 1933
('61', 307, 7, 9, 596961) SECRETARY TO GOVERNMENT HOME DEPARTMENT

('61', 307, 9, 12, 597182) There is no reply to it as yet.
('61', 307, 9, 13, 597214) Government know that I have been controlling the policy of the weekly newspaper Harijan and its Gujarati edition, and partly also the Hindi edition.
('61', 307, 9, 14, 597363) This is only part of the anti untouchability work I am doing in fulfilment of my promise to myself and the Harijans as an integral part of the Yeravda Pact.
('61', 307, 9, 15, 597520) This work may not be interrupted except at the peril of my life.
('61', 307, 9, 16, 597585) I would therefore esteem a reply by Monday next, so as to enable me to attend to next week’s Harijan and to deal with certain important matters that were left pending at the time of my arrest.
('61', 307, 10, 17, 597778) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('61', 308, 1, 2, 598088) 385. ETHICS OF FASTING
('61', 308, 2, 3, 598111) A learned correspondent from the West thus writes about my late fast:
('61', 308, 3, 4, 598181) I have read your reply 1 to a correspondent querying the ethics of your fast.
('61', 308, 3, 5, 598259) I don’t quite see your point.
('61', 308, 3, 6, 598289) You seem to think that the fact of your suffering removes all offence from such a deed; but every man who does wrong suffers—according to your reasoning, then, there is no such thing as wrongdoing.
('61', 308, 3, 7, 598487) If, instead of identifying yourself with your body, you, for a moment, regard your body objectively, is it not then clear to you that violence to or unnatural treatment of that body is as much an infringement of the law of ahimsa as such unnatural or violent treatment of any other extraneous object?
('61', 308, 3, 8, 598788) The fact that good men in other ages have contemplated and even perpetrated such fasts is no argument.
('61', 308, 3, 9, 598891) This argument has been advanced before, but not so seriously as has been done by my correspondent.
('61', 308, 3, 10, 598990) As I hold that fasting as a powerful means of purification ought to occupy an important part in the life of the human family, it is best to examine the argument.
('61', 308, 3, 11, 599152) The fact of a fast even by the offender does not remove the offence from his deed, much less can it do so when it is vicarious.
('61', 308, 3, 12, 599280) What the fast does is to prevent repetition of evil.
('61', 308, 3, 13, 599333) Most, if not all, evil comes from attachment to the flesh.
('61', 308, 3, 14, 599392) If, therefore, the flesh is mortified, attachment to it is likely to decrease.
('61', 308, 3, 15, 599471) No doubt this is dependent on the motive with which a fast is undertaken.
('61', 308, 3, 16, 599545) There is a great deal of truth in the saying that man becomes what he eats.
('61', 308, 3, 17, 599621) The grosser the food, the grosser the body.
('61', 308, 3, 18, 599665) Plain living is said to go hand in hand with high thinking.
('61', 308, 3, 19, 599725) But plain living is only a few steps removed from fasting.
('61', 308, 3, 20, 599784) Plain living may itself be said to be a mode of fasting.
('61', 308, 3, 21, 599841) Complete fasting is a forcible reminder of the fact that ‘man does not live by bread alone’.
('61', 308, 3, 22, 599934) ‘But assume that there is some force in the argument you advance for the offender’s fast, what about vicarious fasting?’ might say the correspondent.
('61', 308, 3, 23, 600084) The answer is that just as there is identity of spirit, so is there identity of matter and in essence the two are inseparable.
('61', 308, 3, 24, 600211) Spirit is matter rarefied to the utmost limit.
('61', 308, 3, 25, 600258) Hence, whatever happens to the body must affect the whole of matter and the whole of spirit.
('61', 308, 3, 26, 600351) It is within the experience of us all that often wrongdoers are touched by the loving acts of their friends and
('61', 308, 4, 27, 600463) 1 Vide “An American Criticism”, 22 7 1933.
('61', 309, 0, 1, 600506) 310 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATM GANDHI
('61', 309, 1, 2, 600547) relatives especially when they consider the latter to be better than they.
('61', 309, 1, 3, 600622) Fasting for the sake of loved ones is a forcible and unmistakable expression of love and therefore affects those for whose sake it is undertaken.
('61', 309, 1, 4, 600768) Those whose love encircles the whole of life cannot but affect the whole creation by a supreme act of love.
('61', 309, 1, 5, 600876) If the necessity of fasting is admitted, the argument that it is unnatural or an act of violence to one’s own body falls to pieces.
('61', 309, 1, 6, 601008) Just as a fast for regaining lost health is neither unnatural nor criminal self torture, so is not a fast for purification of self or others.
('61', 309, 1, 7, 601150) But all my argument is useless if it cannot be sustained by practice.
('61', 309, 1, 8, 601220) And if there is any soundness in it, the unbroken practice of all the sages and others from time immemorial clinches the argument.
('61', 309, 1, 9, 601351) Sceptics, however, need not rely either upon argument or past testimony.
('61', 309, 1, 10, 601424) Let them acquaint themselves with the rules and the science of fasting for purification and then test its efficacy themselves.
('61', 309, 1, 11, 601551) That fasting does not appeal to people brought up in the midst of the dazzling materialism is an additional reason for people like my correspondent not to reject summarily one of the most potent methods of purification and penance.
('61', 309, 2, 12, 601783) Harijan, 5 8 1933
('61', 309, 3, 13, 601801) 386. LETTER TO R. V. MARTIN
('61', 309, 4, 14, 601829) August 5, 1933
('61', 309, 5, 15, 601844) DEAR COL.
('61', 309, 5, 16, 601854) MARTIN, You were good enough this morning to tell me that according to rules I had to pay for any rations I needed outside the scale ordinarily provided for prisoners and that therefore I should tell you what I considered to be my minimum wants.
('61', 309, 5, 17, 602100) I may say in the first instance that I do not desire to pay for any extra food that I may need.
('61', 309, 5, 18, 602196) I was admitted as a convict in 1922 and I was not called upon to pay for anything in the shape of food or otherwise, but I recognize that Government may adopt a different policy this time, and if they do, that would be no cause for complaint by me.
('61', 309, 5, 19, 602445) I should be satisfied with whatever food was provided so long as it did not interfere with the restrictions that I have observed now for many years.
('61', 309, 5, 20, 602594) The food that I need and has been provided hitherto by the prison authorities is goat’s milk, fresh and dried fruit, fresh vegetables, and, whenever I have needed it, bread.
('61', 310, 0, 1, 602768) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 311
('61', 310, 1, 2, 602812) You have asked me also to tell you what facilities I should like in the shape of newspapers, etc.
('61', 310, 1, 3, 602910) I do not know that I have any choice in the matter.
('61', 310, 1, 4, 602962) I must therefore leave it to the Government to decide what they would allow.
('61', 310, 1, 5, 603039) As to correspondence and visits however, I have to write some business letters in connection with the disbandment of the Ashram, the affairs of the estate of the late Dr. P. J. Mehta and other social and religious obligations and to have visits thereanent.
('61', 310, 1, 6, 603296) I would like the Government to extend to me the same facilities that they have given me hitherto.
('61', 310, 1, 7, 603394) There are however two things which are vital needs, just as much as food for the body.
('61', 310, 1, 8, 603481) One of these is the conduct of the anti untouchability movement on which I have already addressed the Government.
('61', 310, 1, 9, 603595) The second is humanitarian contact with companions who are fellow prisoners.
('61', 310, 1, 10, 603672) This last was recognized even during myfirst incarceration as a convict and has continued ever since.
('61', 310, 1, 11, 603774) I hope that the practice will be so continued during the present incarceration.
('61', 310, 2, 12, 603854) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('61', 310, 3, 13, 603884) From a photostat: G.N. 3896; also Bombay Secret Abstracts, Home Department, Special Branch, File No.

('61', 311, 1, 10, 605189) They were at the Sabarmati Ashram.

('61', 311, 1, 15, 605539) Vinoba who is in charge of Wardha Ashram and who is to look after them.
('61', 311, 1, 16, 605611) There are other matters no less important, but which can await a few days’ delay.
('61', 311, 1, 17, 605693) I venture to hope therefore that pending their decision, Government will grant me by tomorrow the facilities requested about the three matters I have mentioned.
('61', 311, 2, 18, 605854) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('61', 313, 1, 2, 608002) 390. LETTER TO HOME SECRETARY, GOVERNMENT OF BOMBAY
('61', 313, 2, 3, 608054) August 8, 1933
('61', 313, 3, 4, 608069) SECRETARY TO GOVERNMENT HOME DEPARTMENT, POONA
('61', 313, 4, 5, 608116) DEAR SIR,
('61', 313, 5, 6, 608126) I have to thank you for the very prompt reply to my letter of the 6th containing three requests.
('61', 313, 5, 7, 608223) I have thankfully taken advantage, pending orders on my general request about Harijan work, of the permission granted on the first request, and of the very limited permission granted on the second and the third requests.
('61', 313, 5, 8, 608444) I may however state that in making my requests I have not been influenced by the fact of my being classified as an ‘A’ class prisoner.
('61', 313, 5, 9, 608579) Having lodged my protest at my trial against classification, I did not and do not want to make unnecessary fuss about it, and I know that it is open to me not to avail myself of any of the privileges allowed to ‘A’ class prisoners.
('61', 313, 5, 10, 608811) Moreover, I am quite aware that I allow myself to enjoy physical facilities not granted by Government to other prisoners of even ‘A’ class.
('61', 313, 5, 11, 608951) I do so not because I have been classified ‘A’, but because those facilities are of physical or medical necessity for me.
('61', 313, 5, 12, 609073) But I need other facilities which are higher than these and without which life itself becomes an intolerable burden.
('61', 313, 5, 13, 609190) They arise from the cravings of the soul.
('61', 313, 5, 14, 609232) But I am anxious as a prisoner to avoid all controversy with Government.
('61', 313, 5, 15, 609305) I would ask them therefore to be as considerate in regard to my supra physical needs, as they have been in regard to my physical needs.
('61', 313, 6, 16, 609441) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('61', 313, 7, 17, 609471) From a photostat: G.N. 3898; also Bombay Secret Abstracts, Home Department, Special Branch, File No.

('61', 314, 2, 3, 609691) August 10, 1933
('61', 314, 3, 4, 609707) SECRETARY TO GOVERNMENT HOME DEPARTMENT1 POONA,

('61', 314, 4, 10, 610212) In my humble opinion they are unequivocal.

('61', 314, 6, 12, 610285) From a photostat: G.N. 3899; also Bombay Secret Abstracts, Home Department, Special Branch, File No.
('61', 314, 6, 13, 610386) 800(40)(14), Pt. V, p.
('61', 314, 7, 14, 610409) 392. TRUE INWARDNESS
('61', 314, 8, 15, 610430) An Arya Samajist writes a long letter in Hindi.
('61', 314, 8, 16, 610478) Here is the gist: 1. Should Harijans in order to rise in the social scale remain Hindus or will it serve the same purpose if they became Christians or Mussalmans?
('61', 314, 8, 17, 610641) 2. Is not untouchability determined merely by the name of the caste to which one may belong?
('61', 314, 8, 18, 610734) 3. If untouchability is to be removed from Hinduism, why not invite untouchables to join the Arya Samaj?
('61', 314, 8, 19, 610839) 4. What is the speciality of Hinduism for which a Hindu need cling to it?
('61', 314, 8, 20, 610913) In my opinion these questions betray the ignorance of the questioner about the true scope of the reform that is being attempted.
('61', 314, 9, 21, 611042) 1 Received by Gandhiji on November 3, 1932.
('61', 315, 0, 1, 611086) 316 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATM GANDHI
('61', 315, 1, 2, 611127) The pages of the Harijan make it clear from week to week that it is the so called higher classes that have to reform themselves by getting rid of untouchability, of high and lowness.
('61', 315, 1, 3, 611310) It is they who have to repent and purify themselves.
('61', 315, 1, 4, 611363) They have to come in contact with Harijans not for the sake of the latter, not as their patrons but for the sake of themselves and as the servants of Harijans.
('61', 315, 1, 5, 611523) Therefore the object is not served by Harijans forsaking Hinduism.
('61', 315, 1, 6, 611590) And in my opinion religion is a much deeper thing than the questioner would allow.
('61', 315, 1, 7, 611673) It is not a matter of convenience or of bettering one’s social or material condition.
('61', 315, 1, 8, 611759) People have been known to cling to their religion although they have had to face social ostracism, material ruin and much worse.
('61', 315, 1, 9, 611888) One’s religion keeps one true in the face of the greatest adversity.
('61', 315, 1, 10, 611957) It is the sheet anchor of one’s hope in this world and even after.
('61', 315, 1, 11, 612024) It binds one to one’s God, to Truth as to nothing else.
('61', 315, 1, 12, 612080) Therefore, whilst Harijans must know best what is good for them, I, in their place, could not be satisfied by change of religion.
('61', 315, 1, 13, 612210) From the practical point of view, they seem to me to be so inextricably mixed up with the so called higher classes that the vast majority simply cannot help remaining Hindus.
('61', 315, 1, 14, 612385) It is this helplessness which lays a double burden upon ‘the higher classes’ of doing the much belated reparation by regarding them as respected members of the Hindu family in spite of some of their habits.
('61', 315, 1, 15, 612592) Indeed, whatever is evil in their habits is due to the criminal neglect of ‘the higher classes’.
('61', 315, 1, 16, 612689) The quickest way to remove the evil is to remove untouchability and receive them as they are as full fledged Hindus.
('61', 315, 1, 17, 612806) The answer to the second question is in the affirmative.
('61', 315, 1, 18, 612863) That just shows how precarious untouchability is.
('61', 315, 1, 19, 612913) If the Harijans would conceal their caste name and simply declare themselves as Hindus they will, as in many cases they do, pass muster except in their immediate neighbourhood.
('61', 315, 1, 20, 613090) But from the standpoint that I have suggested, such subterfuge can only protract the agony.
('61', 315, 1, 21, 613182) It cannot cure ‘the high classes’ of the taint of superiority and touch me notism .
('61', 315, 1, 22, 613266) As to the third question, what I have said above makes it clear that the admission of Harijans to the Arya Samaj does not solve the difficulty.
('61', 315, 1, 23, 613410) The hearts of millions of non Arya Samajists will not be touched by the Harijans’ acceptance of the Arya Samaj.
('61', 315, 1, 24, 613522) It is the ‘superior’ Hindu heart that has to melt.
('61', 315, 1, 25, 613573) It is the whole of Hinduism that has to be purified and purged.
('61', 315, 1, 26, 613637) What I am aiming at, what I hope the Servants of Untouchables Society is aiming at, is the greatest
('61', 316, 0, 1, 613737) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 317
('61', 316, 1, 2, 613781) reform of the age.
('61', 316, 1, 3, 613800) That it may take time to achieve it, does not much matter.
('61', 316, 1, 4, 613859) The reform is assured, if there are reformers enough who will not be baffled by any difficulty and will not lower the flag on any account whatsoever.
('61', 316, 1, 5, 614009) They will not, if the conviction has gone home that for Hinduism to live, untouchability has got to go.
('61', 316, 1, 6, 614113) The fourth is an invidious question.
('61', 316, 1, 7, 614150) Perhaps it is also profitless.
('61', 316, 1, 8, 614181) But I must answer it, if only to show what I mean by religion.
('61', 316, 1, 9, 614244) The closest, though very incomplete, analogy for religion I can find is marriage.
('61', 316, 1, 10, 614326) It is or used to be an indissoluble tie.
('61', 316, 1, 11, 614367) Much more so is the tie of religion.
('61', 316, 1, 12, 614404) And just as a husband does not remain faithful to his wife, or wife to her husband, because either is conscious of some exclusive superiority of the other over the rest of his or her sex but because of some indefinable but irresistible attraction, so does one remain irresistibly faithful to one’s own religion and find full satisfaction in such adhesion.
('61', 316, 1, 13, 614760) And just as a faithful husband does not need, in order to sustain his faithfulness, to consider other women as inferior to his wife, so does not a person belonging to one religion need to consider others to be inferior to his own.
('61', 316, 1, 14, 614991) To pursue the analogy still further, even as faithfulness to one’s wife does not presuppose blindness to her shortcomings, so does not faithfulness to one’s religion presuppose blindness to the shortcomings of that religion.
('61', 316, 1, 15, 615216) Indeed faithfulness, not blind adherence, demands a keener perception of shortcomings and therefore a livelier sense of the proper remedy for their removal.
('61', 316, 1, 16, 615373) Taking the view I do of religion, it is unnecessary for me to examine the beauties of Hinduism.
('61', 316, 1, 17, 615469) The reader may rest assured that I am not likely to remain Hindu, if I was not conscious of its many beauties.
('61', 316, 1, 18, 615580) Only for my purpose they need not be exclusive.
('61', 316, 1, 19, 615628) My approach to other religions, therefore, is never as a fault finding critic but as a devotee hoping to find the like beauties in the other religions and wishing to incorporate in my own the good I may find in them and miss in mine.
('61', 316, 2, 20, 615862) Harijan, 12 8 1933
('61', 317, 0, 1, 615881) 318 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATM GANDHI
('61', 317, 1, 2, 615922) 393. LETTER TO HOME SECRETARY, GOVERNMENT OF BOMBAY
('61', 317, 2, 3, 615974) August 14, 1933
('61', 317, 3, 4, 615990) SECRETARY TO GOVERNMENT HOME DEPARTMENT POONA
('61', 317, 4, 5, 616036) DEAR SIR,
('61', 317, 5, 6, 616046) It is now noon of Monday, and I am yet without any answer to my request for resumption of Harijan work on the same terms as before my fast.
('61', 317, 5, 7, 616186) This request was first conveyed on the 1st instant from the Central Prison at Ahmedabad and has since been thrice repeated.
('61', 317, 6, 8, 616310) The strain of deprivation of this work is becoming unbearable.
('61', 317, 6, 9, 616373) If therefore I cannot have the permission by noon next Wednesday, I must deny myself all nourishment from that time, save water and salts.
('61', 317, 6, 10, 616512) That is the only way I can fulfil my vow and also relieve myself somewhat of the strain mentioned above.
('61', 317, 6, 11, 616617) I do not want the proposed suspension of nourishment in any way to act as a pressure on the Government.
('61', 317, 6, 12, 616721) Life ceases to interest me if I may not do Harijan service without let or hindrance.
('61', 317, 6, 13, 616806) As I have made it clear in my previous correspondence, and as the Government of India have admitted permission to render that service is implied in the Yeravda Pact to which the British Government is a consenting party, in so far as its consent was necessary.
('61', 317, 6, 14, 617066) Therefore I do indeed want the permission, but only if the Government believe that justice demands it and not because I propose to deprive myself of food if it is not granted.
('61', 317, 6, 15, 617242) That deprivation is intended purely for my consolation.
('61', 317, 7, 16, 617298) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('61', 318, 9, 15, 617908) MARTIN,
('61', 318, 10, 16, 617916) With reference to the two communications received by you from Government, I beg to state as follows: 1. As to the reply to my letter 2 of the 10th instant addressed to the Government, whilst I am thankful for the permission to hand over the Harijan manuscript to the acting Editor and give instructions, this permission does not meet immediate requirements.
('61', 318, 10, 17, 618274) It is difficult without being in touch with correspondence from day to day to write usefully for the Harijan.
('61', 318, 10, 18, 618384) Again, to be in touch with the correspon dents on untouchability is just as urgent as editing the Harijan.
('61', 318, 10, 19, 618491) For instance a difficult experiment under my supervision is being carried on in connection with a Harijan school.
('61', 318, 10, 20, 618605) I have to be in contact withthe teacher if the school is to be a success.
('61', 318, 10, 21, 618679) I have put some Ashram girls and boys in a Harijan boarding house, an experiment probably the first of its kind.
('61', 318, 10, 22, 618792) It cannot go on without my constant attention.
('61', 318, 10, 23, 618839) This was started on the eve of my arrest.
('61', 318, 10, 24, 618881) These are but two out of the many instances I can cite, of matters demanding my personal attention.
('61', 318, 10, 25, 618981) The least therefore that I require at once is: (a) the delivery of all the correspondence in your possession with permission to reply to so much of it as may have any connection with untouchability;
('61', 318, 11, 26, 619180) 1 Vide the preceding item.
('61', 318, 11, 27, 619207) 2 Vide “Letter to Home Secretary, Government of Bombay”, 10 8 1933.

('61', 319, 1, 2, 619316) (b) access to, and disposal of, all correspondence received at the Harijan office; (c) access to newspapers received by you or the Harijan office so as to enable me to deal with points on untouchability that may have been discussed in those papers.
('61', 319, 1, 3, 619565) If the permission is given on these three matters, pending final orders on my request, I shall not need to fast from tomorrow noon, as stated in my letter 1 to Government yesterday.

('61', 319, 1, 8, 620061) I have no desire to receive a fortnightly letter under the classification rules.
('61', 319, 1, 9, 620142) The bulk of my correspondence is likely to have a bearing on untouchability and would demand my personal attention or instructions.
('61', 319, 1, 10, 620274) If the correspondence is handed to me I would gladly return that which may not pertain to untouchability.
('61', 319, 1, 11, 620380) There are likely to be letters concerning business affairs.
('61', 319, 1, 12, 620440) I should take the Government instructions regarding such letters.
('61', 319, 1, 13, 620506) The fact of the matter is that I have many public activities besides the political, and as I told you personally this morning, in my opinion the just way to deal with me is, after insuring my strict abstention from participation directly or indirectly in civil disobedience, to give me the facilities mentioned in my letter 2 to you of the 5th instant.
('61', 319, 2, 14, 620859) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('61', 320, 8, 15, 622066) It shows how disinclined I am to starve.

('61', 321, 1, 4, 623422) It pains me to have to write this letter, but it will give much greater pain if I break the fast now and have to enter upon a prolonged controversy with the Government on many matters that need elucidation.
('61', 321, 1, 5, 623629) I miss Government response to the meticulous care with which I am endeavouring to observe jail discipline and as a prisoner tender co operation which as a citizen outside prison walls I consider it a religious duty to withhold.

('61', 321, 1, 8, 624286) Will you therefore please withdraw the milk and the fruit already received by me, and accept my apology for having hurriedly told you that I would break the fast?

('61', 321, 5, 13, 624631) August 17, 1933
('61', 321, 6, 14, 624647) DEAR COL.
('61', 321, 6, 15, 624657) MARTIN, With reference to our conversation of this morning, before I can break my fast the following points require to be settled: l.
('61', 321, 6, 16, 624791) I should see Kakasaheb Kalelkar or Sjt.
('61', 321, 6, 17, 624831) Anand Hingorani before 12 o’clock today for handling manuscript and giving.
('61', 321, 6, 18, 624907) instructions.
('61', 321, 6, 19, 624921) 2. All the letters and newspapers in your possession should be handed to me, subject to the condition mentioned in my letter 1 of 15th instant.
('61', 321, 7, 20, 625065) 1 Vide “Letter to R. V. Martin”, 15 8 1933..
('61', 322, 0, 1, 625110) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 323
('61', 322, 1, 2, 625154) 3. The notes 1 you showed me bind me to the non publication of interviews in the Press.
('61', 322, 1, 3, 625242) This is a physical impossibility as I can have no control over persons who would see me.
('61', 322, 1, 4, 625331) It is not contemplated that I would only see those who would be subject to my discipline.
('61', 322, 1, 5, 625421) I would be seeing hot opponents, perhaps more often, than friends.
('61', 322, 2, 6, 625488) 4. The notes contemplate two visitors a day.
('61', 322, 2, 7, 625533) I can never conduct the movement if I am thus restricted.
('61', 322, 2, 8, 625591) I have to see visitors as they come if I am to influence them.
('61', 322, 3, 9, 625654) 5. As a journalist of 29 years’ standing I can say that restriction as to the sending of instructions to the Editor three times per week is wholly unworkable, and it is not clear whether the Editor or Editors are to see me personally or not.
('61', 322, 4, 10, 625896) 6. The notes contemplate a limited number of letters to other correspondents.
('61', 322, 4, 11, 625974) I do not know what the Government have in mind by the term ‘limited’.
('61', 322, 4, 12, 626044) I had to send, during the last dispensation, on an average something like thirty letters a day.
('61', 322, 5, 13, 626140) 7. There is no mention in the notes about letters.
('61', 322, 5, 14, 626191) I take it that it is an unintended omission and that I shall have all the letters and newspapers, whether received by you or the Harijan office, my work on them being strictly confined to untouchability.
('61', 322, 6, 15, 626395) You will now see what a gulf exists between my requirements and the concessions the Government are prepared to grant.
('61', 322, 6, 16, 626513) If the Government would permit me to handle the tremendous movement of anti untouchability affecting millions of human beings, they should give full effect to the Government of India orders under the last dispensation.
('61', 322, 6, 17, 626732) There was in them a frank recognition of my submission and therefore a full response to it.
('61', 322, 6, 18, 626824) I miss it altogether in the notes.
('61', 322, 6, 19, 626859) So far as I am aware I have given no cause whatever for change of policy.
('61', 322, 6, 20, 626933) If permission is given as requested by me, I can give my absolute assurance that I shall take no undue advantage of it, I shall confine myself strictly to anti untouchability work and shall endeavour to the best of my ability to consult the convenience of the prison staff.
('61', 322, 7, 21, 627207) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('61', 322, 8, 22, 627237) 1 Vide the preceding item.
('61', 323, 0, 1, 627264) 324 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATM GANDHI
('61', 323, 1, 2, 627305) [PS.] I take it that the convict typist is also a shorthand typist, and that, if everything is satisfactorily settled, I shall have the assistance as before of Sjt.
('61', 323, 1, 3, 627470) Mahadev Desai and Chhaganlal Joshi.
('61', 323, 2, 4, 627506) M. K. G.
('61', 323, 3, 5, 627515) From a photostat: G.N. 3905; also Bombay Secret Abstracts, Home Department, Special Branch, File No.
('61', 323, 3, 6, 627616) 800(40)(14), Pt. V, pp.
('61', 323, 4, 7, 627640) 399. QUANTITY v.
('61', 323, 4, 8, 627657) QUALITY
('61', 323, 5, 9, 627665) There is no doubt that workers in a cause are as a rule tempted more by quantitative than by qualitative results of their labours.
('61', 323, 5, 10, 627796) And though the volume of work done throughout India, as a result of anti untouchability movement represented by the Servants of Untouchables Society, is not by any means unsatisfactory as a whole, it looks insignificant when it is distributed over the respective provinces and when it is considered relatively to the goal which is complete removal of untouchability, that is, of the high and lowness mentality that pervades Hinduism.
('61', 323, 5, 11, 628230) There was, therefore, despondence markedly reflected at the meetings of anti untouchability workers that were called during my convalescence after the recent fast.
('61', 323, 5, 12, 628394) I did not share the despondence myself.
('61', 323, 5, 13, 628434) For, I had only quality in mind whereas I saw that the co workers had consciously or unconsciously quantity in mind.
('61', 323, 5, 14, 628551) I would have one good teacher in preference to fifty indifferent ones, I would be satisfied with the constant attendance of five children instead of the sporadic attendance of fifty.
('61', 323, 5, 15, 628734) I would have five workers concentrating their attention on compact, small, selected areas rather than having them to cover large areas to which they could never give concentrated attention.
('61', 323, 5, 16, 628924) If this preference for quality is good, as it is for any movement, it is especially so for an essentially religious movement like that of anti untouchability.
('61', 323, 5, 17, 629083) In religion, indifference to quality may even lead to disaster.
('61', 323, 5, 18, 629147) If teachers are a stop gap, if school children come when they like and workers go about from place to place without establishing personal contact with Harijans, it may be found that both the Harijans and the caste men may have their hearts untouched at the end, say, of ten years’ labours, and the result may be a reaction against the movement on the part both of Harijans and caste men.
('61', 324, 0, 1, 629535) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 325
('61', 324, 1, 2, 629579) In a religious movement faith plays an important part.
('61', 324, 1, 3, 629634) Therefore many factors are necessarily unknown and unknowable.
('61', 324, 1, 4, 629697) No one can fathom the movement from time to time as we can most secular movements in which most factors are known and under control.
('61', 324, 1, 5, 629830) If I want to manufacture one million yards of khadi, given the hands and cotton I would be able to say when I can.
('61', 324, 1, 6, 629945) But if I have to touch the hearts of five Hindus and wean them from untouchability, I should not know when, if at all, I could accomplish the task.
('61', 324, 1, 7, 630093) I have simply to work in the belief that my cause being just, if I am a pure enough person to handle it, I must touch the hearts of the five Hindus amongst whom I have been called upon to work.
('61', 324, 1, 8, 630287) I may not, therefore, have any despondence over my mission nor may I change the venue of my work, nor ambitiously extend its scope beyond my capacity.
('61', 324, 1, 9, 630438) On the contrary, I must believe that not only shall I be able by gentleness and patience to affect the five fellow Hindus, but that when I have succeeded with them I shall not be long in succeeding with five millions.
('61', 324, 1, 10, 630656) This, and no other, is the meaning of the saying, “Faith can move mountains” or “To those who work assiduously and in My name I always grant success”.
('61', 324, 1, 11, 630807) Therefore, what we need is boundless faith backed by perfect purity of character.
('61', 324, 1, 12, 630889) An impure mind and a religious spirit go ill together.
('61', 324, 1, 13, 630944) By purity of character is here meant truth, love and chastity in thought, word and deed.
('61', 324, 1, 14, 631033) If we have not these we shall neither move the caste men nor the Harijans.
('61', 324, 1, 15, 631108) If we have not this triple purity, not only shall we fail to steal the hearts of either, but by our failure we shall discredit not merely ourselves but the great cause we represent.
('61', 324, 1, 16, 631290) Hence, I have no hesitation in saying that in our campaign against untouchability, if we will take care of quality, quantity will take care of itself.
('61', 324, 1, 17, 631441) It is hardly necessary to point out that what is said here about quality applies as well to Harijan workers as to caste workers.
('61', 324, 1, 18, 631570) If the former are to carry out an internal moral reformation, I was going to say, revolution among Harijans, they will do so only by producing workers of unimpeachable purity and integrity, working with single mindedness in limited areas where they can establish personal contacts.
('61', 324, 2, 19, 631852) Harijan, 19 8 1933
('61', 325, 0, 1, 631871) 326 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATM GANDHI
('61', 325, 1, 2, 631912) 400. LETTER TO HOME SECRETARY, GOVERNMENT OF BOMBAY
('61', 325, 2, 3, 631964) August 19, 1933
('61', 325, 3, 4, 631980) THE SECRETARY TO GOVERNMENT HOME DEPARTMENT POONA
('61', 325, 4, 5, 632030) DEAR SIR, Col.
('61', 325, 4, 6, 632045) Martin has kindly given me a copy of your reply 1 to my letter 2 of the 17th instant addressed to him.
('61', 325, 4, 7, 632148) I regret to observe that your reply realizes my worst fears.
('61', 325, 4, 8, 632209) Where I thought there was a possibility of a more favourable construction on some of the points, your reply now makes it clear that there was no warrant for any such construction.
('61', 325, 4, 9, 632389) It therefore becomes unnecessary for me to take up the various points in your letter.
('61', 325, 4, 10, 632475) But I have now understood through Mr. Andrews that the difficulty in the way of Government carrying out the orders of the Government of India to which I have already referred is that instead of being a State prisoner I am now a convicted prisoner.
('61', 325, 4, 11, 632723) If that be the cause for a radical departure from a policy explicitly laid down by the Government, not by way of concession, but as the Government of India have admitted, ‘‘because it is necessary that he (I) should have freedom in regard to visitors and correspondence on matters strictly limited to removal of untouchability”, ‘‘there being no restrictions on publicity”, I cannot understand how what was considered to be necessary for me becomes any the less necessary now, by reason of my being a convicted prisoner.
('61', 325, 4, 12, 633244) Just as Government have recognized my physical wants and satisfied them in spite of my being a convict, even so, I venture to submit, do my spiritual wants regarding untouchability demand full recognition from Government.
('61', 325, 4, 13, 633466) The last paragraph of your letter grieves me.
('61', 325, 4, 14, 633512) The reminder contained in it comes as an added injury to my wounded soul, for I have stated to Government more than once that civil disobedience under circumstances like the present is a part of my creed.
('61', 325, 4, 15, 633717) But I recognize that what I consider as a perfectly lawful and moral activity,
('61', 325, 5, 16, 633796) 1 For a summary of this in a cable dated August 18 from Viceroy to Secretary of State, London, vide Appendix “Excerpts from Viceroy’s Cable to Secretary of State”, 18 8 1933. 2 Vide “Letter to R. V. Martin”, 17 8 1933.
('61', 326, 0, 1, 634015) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 327
('61', 326, 1, 2, 634059) Government consider as unlawful and probably even immoral.
('61', 326, 1, 3, 634118) I must therefore be content to be their prisoner not merely for the natural term of the present confinement, but for such time as India comes to her own if I live long enough to see that day—if, that is to say, there is any possibility still left of Government fulfilling their solemn obligation and my coming safely out of the ordeal through which I am going.
('61', 326, 2, 4, 634479) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('61', 326, 6, 9, 634679) DEAR COL.
('61', 326, 6, 10, 634689) MARTIN, For the last three or four days you have been sending me mutilated copies of The Times of India.
('61', 326, 6, 11, 634794) I have surmised that the mutilations are due to references to my fast.
('61', 326, 6, 12, 634865) If my surmise is correct, I venture to think the mutilation is not fair to me.
('61', 326, 6, 13, 634944) If anything has been said by or on behalf of Government, I should at least know what it is, so that I could make my submission to the Government if there was anything that I might consider unfair in the statements appearing in the Press.

('61', 326, 8, 16, 635487) From a photostat: G.N. 3907; also Bombay Secret Abstracts, Home Department, Special Branch, File No.
('61', 326, 8, 17, 635588) 800(40)(14), Pt. V, p.
('61', 326, 9, 18, 635611) 402. A SILENT WORKER IN THE HARIJAN CAUSE
('61', 326, 10, 19, 635653) In the year 1919 when I lay ill in Mani Bhuvan, a well built gentleman came to see me.
('61', 326, 10, 20, 635740) I have a faint recollection that he had brought along some money too.
('61', 326, 10, 21, 635810) I asked him whose son he was.
('61', 327, 0, 1, 635840) 328 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATM GANDHI
('61', 327, 1, 2, 635881) replied that he was the son of Hariprasad Desai of Bhavnagar.
('61', 327, 1, 3, 635943) Hearing this, I was reminded of the days when my father was alive.
('61', 327, 1, 4, 636010) Even in my childhood, I had heard of this well known family of Bhavnagar.
('61', 327, 1, 5, 636084) Hence I said to Bhai Yashwant prasad that our friendship was old enough to entitle me to exploit him, to which he readily agreed saying that all that he had was available for my work.
('61', 327, 1, 6, 636268) I had come to know about his Barsi mill and other enterprises.
('61', 327, 1, 7, 636331) The contact then established became increasingly closer and in the end we became like father and son.
('61', 327, 1, 8, 636433) His contribution was always there in all my activities.
('61', 327, 1, 9, 636489) Whether for the sake of khadi or any other activities, he always allowed himself to be exploited.
('61', 327, 1, 10, 636587) I have never had to beg from him.
('61', 327, 1, 11, 636621) Time and again, of his own accord he put sums of money into my hands.
('61', 327, 1, 12, 636691) He was a sincere worker for the Harijan cause.
('61', 327, 1, 13, 636738) He made no difference between himself and Harijans.
('61', 327, 1, 14, 636790) When khadi work had just begun, he first thought of Harijans and he had thought of going to Bhavnagar to revive the craft of weaving with the help of Harijans.
('61', 327, 1, 15, 636950) ‘He was aware that the Harijans of Kathiawar were looking around for a living in Bombay, their craft of weaving having almost died.
('61', 327, 1, 16, 637082) Here I have spoken of the time when he had just begun serving Harijans.
('61', 327, 1, 17, 637154) And the end of his career was worthy of this beginning.
('61', 327, 1, 18, 637210) He has never recognized untouchability.
('61', 327, 1, 19, 637250) He never had the vanity or the moha that he belonged to one of the highest ranking and well known Nagar 1
('61', 327, 2, 20, 637356) families.
('61', 327, 2, 21, 637366) He never indulged in long arguments, his motto was to quietly render whatever service came his way.
('61', 327, 2, 22, 637466) I have just received the news of his passing away.
('61', 327, 2, 23, 637517) His death is certainly a loss to his family, but I myself have lost a true comrade.
('61', 327, 2, 24, 637601) And Harijans have lost a sincere and silent worker.
('61', 327, 2, 25, 637653) May God bless his soul and may He give his children and the other members of the family the wisdom to follow in his footsteps and carry on his beneficent work.
('61', 327, 3, 26, 637813) [From Gujarati]
('61', 327, 4, 27, 637829) Harijanbandhu, 20 8 1933
('61', 327, 5, 28, 637854) 403. TO THE HARIJANS OF GUJARAT
('61', 327, 6, 29, 637886) During my last visit to Ahmedabad, I had a good opportunity to meet Harijan brothers and sisters.
('61', 327, 6, 30, 637984) I was able to speak to them quite freely.
('61', 327, 6, 31, 638026) I repeat here what I expect from them.
('61', 327, 7, 32, 638065) 1 A sub caste of Brahmins
('61', 328, 0, 1, 638091) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 329
('61', 328, 1, 2, 638135) 1. The so called caste Hindus have a personal obligation to fulfil towards you which they must do unconditionally; it is their atonement.
('61', 328, 1, 3, 638273) But, whether or not they atone for their deeds you will still have much work to do independently and unconditionally.
('61', 328, 1, 4, 638391) One does not go to heaven without first dying.
('61', 328, 1, 5, 638438) Whether in this world or the next, it is for each one to free oneself from bondage by one’s own effort.
('61', 328, 1, 6, 638542) Harijans should not look upon themselves as lowly, weak or crippled.
('61', 328, 1, 7, 638611) 2. The atonement by caste Hindus is not for your salvation but for their own and it involves service to you.
('61', 328, 1, 8, 638720) You should be liberal in accepting their services.
('61', 328, 1, 9, 638771) In this way, you will readily overlook any shortcomings in it.
('61', 328, 1, 10, 638834) If you are not large hearted, you will only see their failings.
('61', 328, 1, 11, 638898) But I am confident you will never be mean.
('61', 328, 1, 12, 638941) 3. Magnify your own faults so that they appear to be as big as mountains and then make constant efforts to overcome them.
('61', 328, 1, 13, 639063) In it lies the key to obtaining the rights which you want.
('61', 328, 1, 14, 639122) Never believe that since others have the same faults we need not mind our own.
('61', 328, 1, 15, 639201) No matter what others do, it is your dharma to overcome the failings which you find in yourselves.
('61', 328, 1, 16, 639300) I see no need to recount them all here.
('61', 328, 1, 17, 639340) I have often shown them to you, but it should not be necessary for me or anybody to do so.
('61', 328, 1, 18, 639431) You will not be able, at the behest of others, to overcome what you yourselves do not look upon as failings.
('61', 328, 1, 19, 639540) Hence, it should suffice to say that you should shake off whatever faults you can find in yourselves.
('61', 328, 1, 20, 639642) I do not write all this as a caste Hindu; as I see it, varnadharma no longer exists and it cannot be revived by keeping you out of its fold.
('61', 328, 1, 21, 639783) However, if varnadharma is to be reprieved in my lifetime, know my varna to be the same in which you would be placed, because I claim to have voluntarily become a Harijan.
('61', 328, 1, 22, 639955) It is by virtue of this relationship that I entertain the above expectation of you.
('61', 328, 1, 23, 640039) Please do fulfil it.
('61', 328, 1, 24, 640060) I share your misery and, believe me, I shall be happy [only] when you become happy.
('61', 328, 2, 25, 640144) [From Gujarati]
('61', 328, 3, 26, 640160) Harijanbandhu, 20 8 1933
('61', 328, 4, 27, 640185) 404. TO KATHIAWARIS
('61', 328, 5, 28, 640205) Generally speaking one province should not be burdened with the work of another, just as in a well organized society the burden of one family’s needs is not borne by another.
('61', 328, 5, 29, 640380) In accordance with this
('61', 329, 0, 1, 640404) 330 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATM GANDHI
('61', 329, 1, 2, 640445) principle, the needs of Kathiawar should be met by Kathiawaris, whether they happen to live in Kathiawar or elsewhere.
('61', 329, 1, 3, 640564) Hence the burden of Harijan work in Kathiawar should be borne by Kathiawaris.
('61', 329, 1, 4, 640642) When I visited Ahmedabad for a few days, I met workers connected with the Harijan Schools and ashrams functioning in Kathiawar.
('61', 329, 1, 5, 640770) Not a single school or ashram should be obliged to close down solely for want of funds.
('61', 329, 1, 6, 640858) It is a different matter altogether if an institution were to be closed for the sake of better organization, for the conservation of our energies, or, for the prevention of unnecessary expenditure.
('61', 329, 1, 7, 641056) I have often spoken of my experience that no benevolent work, in fact, stops for lack of funds.
('61', 329, 1, 8, 641152) Any work which enlists workers willing to serve by offering their all, will find money readily coming its way.
('61', 329, 1, 9, 641263) I hope workers will regard the service of Harijans in this spirit.
('61', 329, 1, 10, 641330) It is universal experience that, in the last analysis, every institution and every work depends upon the devoted efforts of one individual.
('61', 329, 1, 11, 641470) This does not imply that such a person can work single handed.
('61', 329, 1, 12, 641533) To entertain such a thought is only a sign of arrogance, but the world is so ordered that there can be only one organizer.
('61', 329, 1, 13, 641656) The world is not governed by many.
('61', 329, 1, 14, 641691) The Governor or the Lord of the world, whatever you call Him, is only one.
('61', 329, 1, 15, 641766) He has countless men and women workers, but He calls Himself a servant of servants and does the work of one.
('61', 329, 1, 16, 641875) Similarly, it can be said that there can be only one president, secretary or manager for any work.
('61', 329, 1, 17, 641974) And, if he does not consider himself the master but rather the humblest of servants, the work which he has taken up will make progress.
('61', 329, 1, 18, 642110) And he should have steadfast devotion to the work.
('61', 329, 1, 19, 642161) I know there are such devoted workers in Kathiawar and that there is no dearth of money there.
('61', 329, 1, 20, 642256) Among the Kathiawaris spread all over the country, I see men and women who can, if they would, individually bear the expenditure on service of Harijans in Kathiawar.
('61', 329, 1, 21, 642422) So I fail to understand the reason why even a single institution serving Harijans should have to close down for want of funds.
('61', 329, 2, 22, 642549) [From Gujarati]
('61', 329, 3, 23, 642565) Harijanbandhu, 20 8 1933
('61', 330, 0, 1, 642590) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 331
('61', 330, 1, 2, 642634) 405. THE BREATH OF MY LIFE
('61', 330, 2, 3, 642661) God’s ways are inscrutable!
('61', 330, 2, 4, 642689) The most unexpected event of my life has happened.
('61', 330, 2, 5, 642740) 1 I have been used to the most unexpected things in the course of a very long public life, but this is the most unexpected of all.
('61', 330, 2, 6, 642871) What is now in store for me?
('61', 330, 2, 7, 642900) How I shall use this life out of prison, I do not know.
('61', 330, 2, 8, 642956) But I must say this that whether in prison or outside prison, Harijan service will be always after my heart and will be the breath of life for me, more precious than the daily bread.
('61', 330, 2, 9, 643139) I can live for some days at least without the daily bread, but I cannot live without Harijan service for one single minute.
('61', 330, 2, 10, 643263) It is a constant prayer to the Almighty that this blot of untouchability may be removed in its entirety foam Hinduism and that the millions of caste Hindus may see the Sun of Truth which shines upon us, if we would only remove the scales from our eyes, as I have repeatedly said in these columns.
('61', 330, 2, 11, 643560) My life is a dedication to this cause and I shall consider no penance too great for the vindication of this Truth.
('61', 330, 2, 12, 643675) ‘Parnakuti’ August 23, 1933, 5.30 p.m.

('61', 337, 4, 13, 652748) 419. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS 2
('61', 337, 5, 14, 652778) August 25, 1933
('61', 337, 6, 15, 652794) Gandhiji commenced by expressing his thanks to Col.
('61', 337, 6, 16, 652846) Candy, Civil Surgeon, Poona, his staff and nurses for the very great care with which they had looked after him and also to Lt.
('61', 337, 6, 17, 652973) Martin, Superintendent of Yeravda Prison and his staff for their kind treatment during the early stages of his fast.
('61', 337, 6, 18, 653090) Gandhiji said: I would like the public to be assured about my condition.
('61', 337, 6, 19, 653163) Generally a week’s fast is nothing for me, and though this time the fast, whilst it lasted, caused terrible physical agony because of my inability to take the necessary quantity of water, I feel on the second day after the breaking of the fast that I shall be able to regain my lost strength within a reasonable time.
('61', 337, 6, 20, 653481) There need be, therefore, no cause for any anxiety.
('61', 337, 6, 21, 653533) This time my discharge having come upon me absolutely unexpectedly, I confess I have no knowledge whatsoever of how I would shape my movements, after my convalescence is over.
('61', 337, 6, 22, 653709) So I must repeat what I have said so often before, but this time with much greater force than before, that I shall be constantly praying for light and guidance.
('61', 337, 7, 23, 653870) 1 The Harijan Children’s Ashram at Ahmedabad being run by the addressee 2 The Bombay Chronicle had reported: “Looking remarkably well, Gandhiji received a group of journalists at 10 a.m.
('61', 337, 7, 24, 654057) today in the spacious hall of Lady Thackersey’s bungalow.
('61', 337, 7, 25, 654115) Gandhiji spoke very clearly and often with emotion.
('61', 337, 7, 26, 654167) Towards the end of the interview which lasted nearly an hour, signs of exhaustion were however perceptible, and at Mrs. Naidu’s suggestion Press representatives stopped asking more questions.
('61', 338, 0, 1, 654359) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 339
('61', 338, 1, 2, 654403) I shall seek peace much more eagerly than imprisonment and a possible repetition of fast.
('61', 338, 1, 3, 654493) I shall therefore again use this unexpected freedom from imprisonment for the sake of exploring avenues of peace.
('61', 338, 1, 4, 654607) One thing, however, I do want to make clear.
('61', 338, 1, 5, 654652) This discharge is a matter of no joy for me; possibly it is a matter of shame that I took my comrades to prison and came out of it by fasting.
('61', 338, 1, 6, 654795) The statement made on behalf of the Government in connection with the fast, I have not had time to study at all fully.
('61', 338, 1, 7, 654914) During the fast and a few days previous to it, I was deprived of all news that was published in the Press 1 in connection with it.
('61', 338, 2, 8, 655045) In reply to a question, Gandhiji explained this point further and said that the
('61', 338, 3, 9, 655125) Times of India given to him during this period was mutilated, portions bearing on the
('61', 338, 4, 10, 655211) fast having been cut out of it.
('61', 338, 4, 11, 655243) 2 Gandhiji proceeded:
('61', 338, 5, 12, 655265) Therefore I do not know all that has been stated in the Press regarding the fast But what little I had the energy to read yesterday shows that Government have not done me justice.
('61', 338, 5, 13, 655445) It should be remembered that when I took my fast in Yeravda in September last, Government gave me fullest facilities for seeing people, giving interviews and writing letters in the matter of anti untouchability work, not because I was a State prisoner, but because they recognized it was justly due to me to give me those facilities, if they held me in their custody.
('61', 338, 5, 14, 655813) If, therefore, a mistake was made by them, it was made at that very first fast.
('61', 338, 5, 15, 655893) Had they chosen, they could have unconditionally discharged me as they did at the time of the 21 days’ fast or this time.
('61', 338, 5, 16, 656015) The question of jail discipline was just as pertinent then as now, but they did not do so.
('61', 338, 5, 17, 656106) They thought it a better policy for them to keep me in custody and give me the facilities I have referred to.
('61', 338, 5, 18, 656216) Within two days after the Poona Pact was made, facilities for doing Harijan work were suddenly stopped to my surprise and I immediately sent in a respectful protest; but that protest having
('61', 338, 6, 19, 656406) 1 The Times of India, 26 8 1933, had reported that while answering questions on Gandhiji’s fast in Legislative Assembly at Simla on August 24, it was stated that “decision to release Gandhiji” was taken as “Mr. Gandhi was apparently determined to commit suicide.
('61', 338, 6, 20, 656669) Government were not prepared to allow him to die in jail nor to order forcible feeding to save his life” 2 Vide also “Letter to R. V. Martin”, 19 8 1933.

('61', 339, 1, 2, 656864) evoked no satisfactory response, I had perforce to send a letter 1 saying that unless Government gave me facilities for Harijan work without let or hindrance, life would not be worth living for me and in reply to that on November 3 last the following orders 2 were conveyed to me: These orders were passed with the full knowledge of my requirements and with full knowledge of what they meant in September.
('61', 339, 1, 3, 657270) I say once more that when Government arrested me again after the 21 days’ fast, they had to face my request for doing Harijan work without let or hindrance, whether they took me in as a State prisoner or any other.
('61', 339, 1, 4, 657485) In my opinion, classification is wholly irrelevant to the issue.
('61', 339, 1, 5, 657550) The sole issue was in September, in November and today is this, namely, my life and the Harijan work in jail or no Harijan work in jail and my death; and so long as I live that will be the issue that will face me, face the Government and face the public.
('61', 339, 1, 6, 657805) If I am wrong in thinking that, whether outside or inside the prison, I should have the fullest liberty to carry on the programme of anti untouchability which I have undertaken as a solemn obligation, then my fast should be considered impertinent and should not count either with the Government or the public; but if I am right, then my fast should be treated as a sacrificial seal.
('61', 339, 1, 7, 658188) One thing more.
('61', 339, 1, 8, 658204) It has been said on behalf of the Government that when, owing to the 21 days’ fast I was discharged, I gave more attention to political than Harijan work.
('61', 339, 1, 9, 658359) I cannot imagine a grosser misrepresentation of facts, which are all capable of being proved today.
('61', 339, 1, 10, 658459) But I will give a few outstanding instances.
('61', 339, 1, 11, 658504) The whole of the 21 days and the subsequent days, during which I was unable to do anything at all, I could only pray and think and not do writing or talking; and I can say that during this period I thought of nothing else but God and God’s children, the Harijans.
('61', 339, 1, 12, 658768) Then when I was at all able to carry on sustained conversation with a group of men, my first act was to address 3 a meeting of Harijan workers in this very hall, whilst I was lying in bed.
('61', 339, 1, 13, 658957) When I was able to do any public writing, my first writing 4 was for the Harijan.
('61', 339, 2, 14, 659039) 1 Vide “Letter to E. E. Doyle”, 25 10 1932. 2 Vide footnote to “Telegram to Home Secretary, Govewrnment of India”, 3 11 1932. 3 Vide “Discussion with Harijan Workers, Poona”, 2 7 1933. 4 Vide “All About the Fast”, 8 7 1933.
('61', 340, 0, 1, 659263) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 341
('61', 340, 1, 2, 659307) True, while I was in Poona I did attend the informal conference 1
('61', 340, 2, 3, 659373) and held frequent conversations with political co workers on the subject of civil disobedience.
('61', 340, 2, 4, 659469) There was no secret about it and I am not ashamed of it.
('61', 340, 2, 5, 659526) Civil disobedience is an integral part of my life.
('61', 340, 2, 6, 659577) But the fact is that the bulk of my time was not given to civil disobedience work.
('61', 340, 2, 7, 659660) As a matter of fact, in view of the advice I tendered to the conference, it was not necessary.
('61', 340, 2, 8, 659755) Then when I went to Ahmedabad, people may think that the sacrificing of the Ashram must have occupied a tremendous amount of my time, but I am again able to say that tremendous amount of my time was taken up with Harijan service.
('61', 340, 2, 9, 659985) Thousands gathered at prayer time and every time, if I spoke at all to these crowds, I spoke on untouchability and I collected funds at every one of these meetings with more or less generous response, every pice of which went to the Harijan Fund.
('61', 340, 2, 10, 660232) If challenged, I would multiply instances of this character.
('61', 340, 2, 11, 660293) It, therefore, in my opinion, ill becomes all body much more a Government official, to recklessly charge me with having done a thing which I have not done and then to justify the procedure which, to a simple mind like mine, appears to be a manifest and gross breach of promise, deliberately made to a prisoner in their custody.
('61', 340, 3, 12, 660621) When Gandhiji’s attention was drawn to the Home Member’s statement in the Assembly that Gandhiji wished to combine simultaneously two incompatible policies, deliberate incarceration and complete freedom to carry on social work as an ordinary man, Gandhiji replied: I do not consider that there is anything incompatible in it.
('61', 340, 3, 13, 660947) I would be asking for incompatible things if I had asked for conducting civil disobedience campaign from inside the prison walls.
('61', 340, 4, 14, 661077) Mahatma Gandhi was then asked if in his opinion his political campaign during the last few months had done the country any good.
('61', 340, 5, 15, 661206) Gandhiji replied that he was unable to reply to the question as he had no opportunity to gauge the reaction of his movement on the people.
('61', 340, 5, 16, 661345) But it was his firm conviction that the movement which was the cleanest weapon possible in the hands of self respecting people to resist injustice could not but have done good.
('61', 340, 6, 17, 661522) Asked whether the concessions given by the Government were not adequate enough, Gandhiji replied in the negative and said there still remained tremendous work to be done in connection with the anti untouchability work.
('61', 340, 6, 18, 661741) The political part

('61', 341, 1, 2, 661976) of it formed only very little.
('61', 341, 1, 3, 662007) The task before the reformers was to bring about a change of heart on the part of the Hindus.
('61', 341, 1, 4, 662101) Gandhiji, continuing, said that he could not describe the grief it caused him when on a matter of this character where Government orders had been so explicit in November last, the same officials should have been responsible for goading him on to a fast and then to say that he wanted to become a dictator.
('61', 341, 1, 5, 662407) This was the unkindest cut of all.
('61', 341, 1, 6, 662442) Asked if Mr. Rajagopalachari, for example, who had been a party to the Poona Pact and who was now in jail, could not seek permission for doing Harijan work like himself, Gandhiji replied in the negative and added: I will side with the Government in resisting Mr. Rajagopalachari because Mr. Rajagopalachari was not present at the Round Table Conference.
('61', 341, 1, 7, 662796) I was there as the sole representative of Mr. Rajagopala chari and other Congressmen and I made a declaration that I shall resist with my life separate electorates for the Depressed Classes and therefore it became a matter of sacred obligation to me to conduct this campaign even from inside the jail.
('61', 341, 2, 8, 663098) Regarding political situation, Gandhiji was asked what form his efforts for peace would take.
('61', 341, 2, 9, 663192) Gandhiji replied that he did not know what it would be at the present moment.
('61', 341, 2, 10, 663270) It was still in the lap of future.
('61', 341, 2, 11, 663305) It was all impenetrable darkness for him just now.
('61', 341, 2, 12, 663356) But if Government had the will for peace—and he knew that the Congress had the will—then peace could be had.
('61', 341, 2, 13, 663465) But on what terms, he could not say at the present moment, not having all the strings in his hand today.
('61', 341, 2, 14, 663570) Asked if he would be approaching the Viceroy again for an interview, he replied that he could not say definitely, but it was quite on the cards.
('61', 341, 2, 15, 663715) Gandhiji concluded by saying that he hoped to be restored to health in the course of a week or more and he was now on milk diet and free from pain or discomfort.

('61', 343, 7, 13, 666185) 423. I SHALL DANCE TO HIS TUNE
('61', 343, 8, 14, 666216) No one can understand God’s ways.
('61', 343, 8, 15, 666250) I did not even dream that after my twenty one days’ fast, I would have to go on another fast within three months and, as a result, I would be out of jail.
('61', 343, 8, 16, 666405) Who knows what God meant by this play.
('61', 343, 8, 17, 666444) I, for one, do not know it.
('61', 343, 8, 18, 666472) But I know this much that whether in jail or outside, I shall not fail to make any effort, of which I am capable in thought, speech and act, to wash Hinduism of the dross of untouchability.
('61', 343, 8, 19, 666662) When an attempt was made to thwart the effort, I gave up food.
('61', 343, 8, 20, 666725) I shall not allow a thing bought so dearly to slip out of my hands.
('61', 343, 8, 21, 666793) But God knows how I can make that effort.
('61', 343, 8, 22, 666835) I shall dance to His tune.
('61', 343, 8, 23, 666862) I shall be guided by Him.
('61', 343, 8, 24, 666888) I have every hope that all men and women will help me in this attempt.
('61', 343, 9, 25, 666959) [From Gujarati]
('61', 343, 10, 26, 666975) Harijanbandhu, 27 8 1933

('61', 346, 6, 8, 669663) 431. LETTER TO V. S. SRINIVASA SASTRI
('61', 346, 7, 9, 669701) August 30, 1933
('61', 346, 8, 10, 669717) DEAR BROTHER,
('61', 346, 9, 11, 669731) I treasure your letter 1. I do not mind anything you have said.
('61', 346, 9, 12, 669795) On the contrary, I appreciate all you have said.
('61', 346, 9, 13, 669844) Having said this, I must say that I utterly dissent from your interpretation of Government orders.
('61', 346, 9, 14, 669943) If you saw all the correspondence, perhaps you will revise your judgment.
('61', 346, 9, 15, 670017) I am not given to special pleading consciously.
('61', 346, 9, 16, 670065) You may not have noticed that the Government have themselves dropped the idea of ‘another set of conditions’.
('61', 346, 9, 17, 670175) On the contrary, they said that they made a mistake in making what you call ‘concession in the first instance’, and the mistake made was not one on merits but had reference to their own convenience.
('61', 346, 9, 18, 670374) However, I shall not strive with you in connection with your pronouncement upon my statement, but if you will care to study the whole question I would gladly send you the whole of the correspondence.
('61', 346, 9, 19, 670574) I hope that you yourself do not consider me to be capable of desiring to blame the Government for the sake of doing so or that that performance would be dearer to me than Harijan uplift.
('61', 346, 9, 20, 670761) I consider myself capable of a just discrimination and therefore of knowing when the Government is in the right.
('61', 346, 9, 21, 670874) But this is all beside the point.
('61', 346, 9, 22, 670908) I have taken so much space with what is now immaterial, in order to tell you that I do not plead guilty to the charge you have
('61', 346, 10, 23, 671035) 1 Dated August 27; vide Appendix “Letter from V. S. Srinivasa Sastri”, 27 8 1933.
('61', 347, 0, 1, 671117) 348 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATM GANDHI
('61', 347, 1, 2, 671158) made against me.
('61', 347, 1, 3, 671175) Now for the central point of your letter.
('61', 347, 1, 4, 671217) I quite agree with you that I am wholly unfit for the constitution building at the present stage.
('61', 347, 1, 5, 671315) In my opinion that time is not yet.
('61', 347, 1, 6, 671351) It will come only when the nation has developed a sanction for itself.
('61', 347, 1, 7, 671422) I would therefore gladly retire from the Congress and devote myself to the development of civil disobedience outside the Congress and to Harijan work.
('61', 347, 1, 8, 671573) The difficulty is, how to do it?
('61', 347, 1, 9, 671606) Can I do it by seceding from the Congress?
('61', 347, 1, 10, 671649) That was the question that troubled me at the time of the informal conference and that is the question that confronts me again.
('61', 347, 1, 11, 671777) I am seeking light.
('61', 347, 1, 12, 671797) As soon as I have regained sufficient strength, I shall again sound the mind of Congressmen and if I can possibly retire from the Congress I shall gladly do so.
('61', 347, 1, 13, 671958) My impression, however, is that the Congress mentality has not changed.
('61', 347, 1, 14, 672030) Whilst it is true that a large number of Congressmen have got tired, very few would care to subscribe to the White Paper or work for securing certain improvements in it.
('61', 347, 1, 15, 672200) They want a radical change.
('61', 347, 1, 16, 672228) But I am in no hurry to come to any final decision.
('61', 347, 1, 17, 672280) I can give you this assurance that nothing will deter me from taking any steps that might be in the best interests of the nation.
('61', 347, 1, 18, 672410) There is no question even of self effacement.
('61', 347, 1, 19, 672456) Performance of duty I have held always to be a thing of beauty and a joy for ever.
('61', 347, 1, 20, 672539) The awful fact, however, has often been to know where duty lies.
('61', 347, 1, 21, 672604) You won’t give me up, but continue to guide me and you will not hesitate to come if you felt like coming.
('61', 347, 1, 22, 672710) I am not going to hesitate to ask you to come when I feel that I need your personal contact and a constant exchange of thoughts.
('61', 347, 2, 23, 672839) M. K. GANDHI
('61', 347, 3, 24, 672852) Letters of Srinivasa Sastri, pp.
