('61', 351, 11, 18, 678476) 441. NOTE
('61', 351, 12, 19, 678486) THE DISTINCTION BETWEEN THE TWO
('61', 351, 13, 20, 678518) Deenabandhu Andrews wrote last week on the untouchability of South Africa and showed how there was the temple entry question even there.
('61', 351, 13, 21, 678655) It is, however, worth noting the distinction between the two untouchabilities.
('61', 351, 13, 22, 678734) In South Africa, it is based upon colour prejudice and has no sanction either in religion or in law.
('61', 351, 13, 23, 678835) In India,
('61', 352, 0, 1, 678845) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 353
('61', 352, 1, 2, 678889) unfortunately, it is claimed by a large number of Hindus to have religious sanction and we know that it has also the sanction of law.
('61', 352, 1, 3, 679023) The Indian untouchability is, therefore, much worse than the South African.
('61', 352, 1, 4, 679099) Both are, no doubt, equally mischievous, so far as the victims are concerned.
('61', 352, 1, 5, 679177) Both deserve equal condemnation.
('61', 352, 1, 6, 679210) Only, in India it seems that the fight is likely to be much harder than in South Africa.
('61', 352, 2, 7, 679299) Harijan, 2 9 1933
('61', 352, 3, 8, 679317) 442. THE TEMPLE ENTRY BILL1
('61', 352, 4, 9, 679345) It is sad to think that the anti untouchability measure has been hung up for one year by the Legislative Assembly and that the amendment to hang it up received the support of the Government.
('61', 352, 4, 10, 679536) But the reformers may not rest till untouchability is blotted out of the Statute Book.
('61', 352, 4, 11, 679623) Meanwhile, the process of having temples opened by consent of trustees and temple goers and the general propaganda in favour of opening temples should continue.
('61', 352, 4, 12, 679784) But I observe that a Harijan Conference at Agra has passed the following resolution: 2
('61', 352, 5, 13, 679871) This Jatav Conference .
('61', 352, 5, 14, 679895) considers that the methods and system of work of the movement is not satisfactory.
('61', 352, 5, 15, 679978) Harijan movement lays stress on the temple entry problem more than on economic and educational problems.
('61', 352, 5, 16, 680083) The former .
('61', 352, 5, 17, 680096) will produce slave mentality, .
('61', 352, 5, 18, 680128) Hence .
('61', 352, 5, 19, 680136) great emphasis must be laid on the educational and economic aspect of the progress.
('61', 352, 5, 20, 680220) Inter caste marriage and inter dining must be on the programme of the movement.
('61', 352, 5, 21, 680300) The economic and educational uplift is no doubt an essential part of true repentance by caste Hindus.
('61', 352, 5, 22, 680402) It is a test of the sincerity of their professions.
('61', 352, 5, 23, 680454) But the uplift will not be complete without the throwing open of temples.
('61', 352, 5, 24, 680528) The throwing open of temples will be an admission of the religious equality of Harijans.
('61', 352, 5, 25, 680617) It will be the surest sign of their ceasing to be the outcastes of Hinduism, which they are today.
('61', 352, 5, 26, 680716) It is beside the point that tens of thousands of Harijans do not want to enter temples.
('61', 352, 5, 27, 680804) If it were properly probed, the fact would be
('61', 352, 6, 28, 680850) 1 Untouchability Abolition Bill.
('61', 352, 6, 29, 680883) It was introduced by C. S. Ranga Iyer on March 24, 1933; vide 6th footnote to “Letter to ranchhoddas Patwari”, 11 1 1933. 2 Only excerpts are reproduced here.
('61', 353, 0, 1, 681042) 354 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATM GANDHI
('61', 353, 1, 2, 681083) found to be quite otherwise.
('61', 353, 1, 3, 681112) Thousands of Harijans do want to enter temples.
('61', 353, 1, 4, 681160) Only they have been so accustomed to the prohibition that the very hope of entering temples had dried up in them.
('61', 353, 1, 5, 681274) They believe that admission to temples on a par with the other Hindus is an impossibility.
('61', 353, 1, 6, 681365) But whether Harijans desire the consolation of temple entry or not, whether, if temples are thrown open to them, they will make use of them or not, caste Hindus have to perform their simple duty.
('61', 353, 1, 7, 681561) They have to open their temples for Harijans to offer worship in, precisely on, the same terms as for themselves.
('61', 353, 1, 8, 681675) A debtor is not absolved from the duty of payment because his creditor does not care for the payment, or has forgotten the debt altogether.
('61', 353, 1, 9, 681815) And when temples are thrown open to Harijans, schools, wells and many similar facilities will be automatically open to Harijans.
('61', 353, 1, 10, 681944) It is surely easy enough to realize that untouchability may subsist side by side with economic uplift.
('61', 353, 1, 11, 682047) Many Ezhawas in Travancore and Namashudras in Bengal possess decent fortunes and are yet treated as pariahs of society.
('61', 353, 1, 12, 682167) The bar sinister is all the more galling to them by reason of their flourishing condition.
('61', 353, 1, 13, 682258) Dr. Ambedkar suffers from the curse in spite of his high educational attainments and his superior economic condition.
('61', 353, 1, 14, 682376) He is naturally more sensitive to the insult of untouchability.
('61', 353, 1, 15, 682440) But the reproach will be automatically removed, immediately caste Hindus proclaim the banishment of untouchability by admitting Harijans to their temples on terms of absolute equality with themselves.
('61', 353, 1, 16, 682641) It will not then become necessary for any Harijan individually to go to temples, if he does not desire to do so.
('61', 353, 1, 17, 682754) The declaration of the opening of temples will cover him with the rest.
('61', 353, 1, 18, 682826) It will be like the abolition of slavery.
('61', 353, 1, 19, 682868) It will be a vast and glorious step in the much needed and overdue purification of Hinduism.
('61', 353, 1, 20, 682961) Temple entry permission, to be of use, has naturally to be a voluntary act on the part of Hindus.
('61', 353, 1, 21, 683059) It has to be, therefore, a genuine change of heart in the caste Hindus.
('61', 353, 1, 22, 683131) Legislation is nevertheless necessary because of the fact that in law the entry of Harijans into caste Hindu temples is said to be prohibited.
('61', 353, 1, 23, 683274) Legislation will constitute the seal of approval of the vast mass of Hindus.
('61', 353, 1, 24, 683351) I personally should not want, that legislation in the teeth of universal caste Hindu opposition.
('61', 353, 1, 25, 683448) My own belief is that caste Hindus as a whole do not oppose temple entry by Harijans.
('61', 353, 1, 26, 683534) I should abide by the result of an honestly conducted referendum.
('61', 353, 1, 27, 683600) Anyway, let the reformers realize that, whatever happens in the Legislature at Delhi, the movement for temple entry and the necessary legislation must continue.
('61', 354, 0, 1, 683761) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 355
('61', 354, 1, 2, 683805) There are other things in the resolution quoted above which call for explanation or criticism.
('61', 354, 1, 3, 683900) This must be postponed for a future issue of the Harijan.
('61', 354, 2, 4, 683958) Harijan, 2 9 1933

('61', 357, 1, 2, 687784) 449. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS OF INDIA1
('61', 357, 2, 3, 687829) September 2, 1933
('61', 357, 3, 4, 687847) I am unconscious of any error in giving my previous advice.
('61', 357, 3, 5, 687907) However, I admit that this unexpected release has produced a situation that demands special treatment.
('61', 357, 3, 6, 688010) At this stage I can only say that I am giving the matter my earnest and prayerful consideration.
('61', 357, 3, 7, 688107) I have no ready made plan before me.
('61', 357, 3, 8, 688144) I shall consult all friends, listen to all advice and come to no hasty decision.
('61', 357, 3, 9, 688225) I reiterate my earnest desire for peace.
('61', 357, 3, 10, 688266) Therefore I shall leave no stone unturned to bring it about in so far as it lies within my power.

('61', 357, 5, 14, 688459) 450. ADVICE TO FRIENDS 2
('61', 357, 6, 15, 688484) [Before September 3, 1933]
('61', 357, 7, 16, 688511) It is nothing less than a new life for me.
('61', 357, 7, 17, 688554) On my part I had given up all hope.
('61', 357, 7, 18, 688590) On the 23rd 3 night after the nausea, I felt I would not survive for long, that I could no longer battle with death.
('61', 357, 7, 19, 688707) On the afternoon of the 24th I even gave away whatever I had with me.
('61', 357, 7, 20, 688777) Things which are more or less routine for us neither fascinate nor pain us, however they may be, pleasant or unpleasant.
('61', 357, 7, 21, 688898) And whether or not I wish, fasts have become almost a daily occurrence for me.
('61', 357, 7, 22, 688977) Why should they pain you?
('61', 357, 7, 23, 689003) You should understand that fasts have become a part of my life and for this reason ought to give up the ignorant attachment to my body.
('61', 357, 7, 24, 689139) No doubt I had to undergo some privation, but then who has attained Krishna without great suffering?

('61', 358, 1, 2, 689792) 451. DISCUSSION WITH A PARSI GENTLEMAN 1
('61', 358, 2, 3, 689833) [Before September 3, 1933]
('61', 358, 3, 4, 689860) Q. I am very much pained to see that in many places Harijan work is carried on with a feeling of obliging the Harijans rather than in a spirit of service.
('61', 358, 4, 5, 690015) A. That is true.
('61', 358, 4, 6, 690032) That is why I go on telling the caste Hindus that whatever they do, they must do for their own sake.
('61', 358, 4, 7, 690133) That is their atonement, their purification.
('61', 358, 5, 8, 690178) Q. But the work is not being done in the manner you desire.
('61', 358, 5, 9, 690238) The feeling of high and low pervades every vein.
('61', 358, 6, 10, 690287) A. I admit it.
('61', 358, 6, 11, 690302) Untouchability cannot be said to have disappeared so long as this feeling persists.
('61', 358, 6, 12, 690386) It is not enough to ‘‘touch” Harijans.
('61', 358, 7, 13, 690425) Q. Such a feeling of high and low prevails even among us, Parsis.
('61', 358, 7, 14, 690491) We have amongst us the first, the second and the third which do not mix with one another.
('61', 358, 8, 15, 690581) A. You are bound to be influenced by us since you have lived with us for so many years.
('61', 358, 8, 16, 690669) Once a Parsi gentleman came to me and told me that the differences of high and low were created by God.
('61', 358, 8, 17, 690773) I told him: “You are a Parsi and yet talk like this.
('61', 358, 8, 18, 690826) But you have been influenced by us and now you have come to repeat it.”
('61', 358, 9, 19, 690898) Q. This feeling prevails among Muslims too.
('61', 358, 10, 20, 690942) A. The same is true of Christians as well.
('61', 358, 10, 21, 690985) Recently, there was a conference of Christian untouchables in Madras.
('61', 358, 10, 22, 691055) Has the world ever heard of anything like this?
('61', 358, 11, 23, 691103) Q. I think the feeling of untouchability has to be banished from our hearts, is it not?
('61', 358, 12, 24, 691191) A. Everything would be incomplete without it.
('61', 358, 12, 25, 691237) If untouchability disappears from Hindu religion, many other problems will be solved.
('61', 358, 12, 26, 691323) I also expect the Hindu Muslim problem to solve itself, because it also has its root in the feeling of high and low.
('61', 358, 13, 27, 691440) Q. As a matter of fact, Zoroaster himself never intended to establish a religion.
('61', 358, 13, 28, 691522) The religion came to be established later.
('61', 358, 13, 29, 691565) Now the feeling of distinction between themselves and others has gone deep in the minds of Parsis.
('61', 358, 13, 30, 691664) A. It has been taken from the Hindu religion.
('61', 358, 13, 31, 691710) It comes from the Indian atmosphere.
('61', 358, 13, 32, 691747) If it disappears from the Hindu religion, it will
('61', 358, 14, 33, 691797) 1 This appeared under the sub title, “For the Whole World”.
('61', 359, 0, 1, 691857) 360 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATM GANDHI
('61', 359, 1, 2, 691898) disappear from elsewhere too.
('61', 359, 1, 3, 691928) Do you think that I would be convinced that untouchability was wiped out just because some wells had been dug for them or some temples had been thrown open to them?
('61', 359, 1, 4, 692093) These are only indications.
('61', 359, 1, 5, 692121) If even this much does not happen, all our talking would be in vain.
('61', 359, 1, 6, 692190) But we shall have to go much further.
('61', 359, 2, 7, 692228) Q. For Harijan work, do you have only Hindus in mind or the other people as well?
('61', 359, 3, 8, 692310) A. The thought of others is of course implied—in the same way as India’s independence is for the good of the entire world.
('61', 359, 3, 9, 692433) But I do not go on harping on that point; I talk only about swaraj for India.
('61', 359, 3, 10, 692511) Similarly, I am absolutely confident that there are going to be widespread consequences of the solution of the Harijan problem.
('61', 359, 3, 11, 692639) It would affect the whole world.
('61', 359, 3, 12, 692672) Unless I had that hope, why should I get involved in Harijan work?
('61', 359, 3, 13, 692739) It is already implied in my writings.
('61', 359, 3, 14, 692777) I have asserted that I wish to serve the whole world through it.
('61', 359, 4, 15, 692842) [From Gujarati]
('61', 359, 5, 16, 692858) Harijanbandhu, 3 9 1933
('61', 359, 6, 17, 692882) 452. ADVICE TO A HARIJAN WORKER 1
('61', 359, 7, 18, 692916) [Before September 3, I933]
('61', 359, 8, 19, 692943) I do not need any scheme.

('61', 359, 8, 21, 693000) What purpose would a scheme serve without a person to carry it out?

('61', 359, 8, 35, 693763) It is in Cuttack.
('61', 359, 8, 36, 693781) It is no longer under him.
('61', 359, 8, 37, 693808) I do not know its present condition.

('61', 359, 8, 39, 693910) Like Madhusudan Das you too should first master

('61', 360, 4, 8, 694244) 453. DISCUSSION ON FASTING1
('61', 360, 5, 9, 694272) [Before September 3, 1933]
('61', 360, 6, 10, 694299) What we regard as dharma, they [the orthodox] regard as adharma.
('61', 360, 6, 11, 694364) It is ignorance; but you cannot undertake a fast unto death to counter it.
('61', 360, 6, 12, 694439) It is not a matter for fasting unto death.
('61', 360, 6, 13, 694482) Such a fast can be undertaken on very rare occasions.
('61', 360, 6, 14, 694536) It is a very strong measure.
('61', 360, 6, 15, 694565) This problem is very complex.
('61', 360, 6, 16, 694595) A conditional fast can be undertaken only in exceptional circumstances.
('61', 360, 6, 17, 694667) That is why I thought of an unconditional fast 2, a fast without any conditions, for the purification of the Hindu religion.
('61', 360, 6, 18, 694792) It would be good to have a relay fast just as Ganga water kavad 3. If the right persons undertook a right fast for the purification of religion, it is bound to have its impact on the people.
('61', 360, 6, 19, 694983) It is not an asuri 4 act, but a purely daivi 5 act.
('61', 360, 6, 20, 695035) No one can call it coercion if somebody resorted to a 21 day or a 50 day fast for ridding the Hindu religion of the evil that has entered into it, because that fast would not to be broken, whatever the people might do.
('61', 360, 7, 21, 695254) Q. How do you see coercion in my proposed fast unto death?
('61', 360, 8, 22, 695313) A. You are not concerned with the trustees of the temple.
('61', 360, 8, 23, 695371) What appears adharma to you is regarded as dharma by them.
('61', 360, 8, 24, 695430) How can you undertake a fast in protest against it?
('61', 360, 8, 25, 695482) Can you make anyone give up his dharma by resorting to a fast?
('61', 360, 8, 26, 695545) Let me explain to you when a conditional fast can be undertaken.
('61', 360, 8, 27, 695610) Suppose my brother is a drunkard.
('61', 360, 8, 28, 695644) He considers drinking an evil but is not able to give it up.
('61', 360, 8, 29, 695705) It would be justifiable if I went on a fast till he gave up drinking.
('61', 360, 8, 30, 695775) But when he declares his intention of renouncing his Hindu faith and
('61', 360, 9, 31, 695844) 1 This appeared under the sub title, ‘‘Limitations of Fasting”.
('61', 360, 9, 32, 695908) 2 From May 8 to 29, 1933 3 Ganga water used to be transported by a relay of runners in a kavad, i.e., a pole carried on the shoulder with pots at the ends.
('61', 360, 9, 33, 696064) 4 Demoniacal 5 Godly
('61', 361, 0, 1, 696085) 362 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATM GANDHI
('61', 361, 1, 2, 696126) embracing Christianity, my fast to prevent him from doing it would be coercion.
('61', 361, 1, 3, 696206) So, for the time being, your duty is to meet the trustees, argue your point with them, convey your stand through their friends, create public opinion.
('61', 361, 1, 4, 696357) If public opinion is favourable it must be demonstrated to the trustees, as was done in Guruvayur referendum 1. If public opinion is found to be favourable, maybe the trustees might agree.
('61', 361, 1, 5, 696546) Such a poll cannot be conducted by just asking people to raise their hands at a public meeting; you should go from door to door to collect the votes.
('61', 361, 2, 6, 696696) Q. In spite of all this, if they are not convinced, what should I do except going on a fast unto death?
('61', 361, 3, 7, 696800) A. Even then it cannot be said that a fast unto death may be undertaken.
('61', 361, 3, 8, 696873) This is not going to purify the Hindu religion.
('61', 361, 3, 9, 696921) There are many features of the Hindu religion that call for reform, but people are still not agreeable to it.
('61', 361, 3, 10, 697031) I have said that the Hindu religion would be wiped out unless untouchability is removed.
('61', 361, 3, 11, 697120) And it is literally true.
('61', 361, 3, 12, 697146) But what are we going to do if God Himself has willed that the Hindu religion should perish?
('61', 361, 3, 13, 697239) We must be prepared to lay down our lives; but there should be an occasion for it.

('61', 361, 6, 16, 697362) 454. NO EXAGGERATION 2
('61', 361, 7, 17, 697385) The following is the gist of a letter from a Gujarati correspondent: I have read in the Harijanbandhu of the 27th August an article 3 by you in which you say, “I can live some days atleast without the daily bread, but I cannot live without Harijan service for one single minute.” I have observed an exaggeration of expression in many of your writings.
('61', 361, 7, 18, 697737) People are often confused by utterances like this.
('61', 361, 7, 19, 697788) If every moment of your life is occupied in Harijan service, how can you find time for other activities?
('61', 361, 7, 20, 697893) You cannot serve two masters at one and the same time.
('61', 361, 7, 21, 697948) I realize that for you life is an indivisible whole and your various
('61', 361, 8, 22, 698017) 1 In December 1932. 2 The original Gujarati appeared in Harijanbandhu, 3 9 1933. This was published as “condensed from Gujarati”.
('61', 361, 8, 23, 698147) 3 Vide “The Breath of My Life”, 23 8 1933.
('61', 362, 0, 1, 698190) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 363
('61', 362, 1, 2, 698234) activities are only different phases of it.
('61', 362, 1, 3, 698278) But the masses cannot comprehend this thing.
('61', 362, 1, 4, 698323) They would naturally infer from the foregoing sentence that you are going to devote the rest of your life to Harijan service.
('61', 362, 1, 5, 698449) But that is incorrect, for you will no doubt take up other activities also as occasion arises.
('61', 362, 1, 6, 698544) This exaggeration of expression has, I believe, even in the past created a confusion in people’s minds.
('61', 362, 1, 7, 698648) Therefore, if you keep more sense of proportion in your speech and writing, chances of misunderstanding could be reduced to a minimum.
('61', 362, 1, 8, 698783) I have written this out of regard for you and ask to be forgiven if I am found guilty of presumption.
('61', 362, 2, 9, 698885) It is not clear to me whether the correspondent is himself confounded by my ‘exaggeration’ or whether he represents the confusion of others only.
('61', 362, 2, 10, 699031) I should be pained, if it is true that many are confounded by my writings.
('61', 362, 2, 11, 699106) For I believe I have a keen sense of proportion.
('61', 362, 2, 12, 699155) As a worshipper of Truth I must eschew all exaggeration.
('61', 362, 2, 13, 699212) What I have written about Harijan service is, I believe, literally true.
('61', 362, 2, 14, 699285) But Harijan service does not exclude all other service.
('61', 362, 2, 15, 699341) One can devote oneself simultaneously to several things which are connected with one another.
('61', 362, 2, 16, 699435) What I have said of Harijan service can, for instance, with equal truth be said of the service of Daridranarayana 1 also, for that service is not inconsistent with the service of the Harijans.
('61', 362, 2, 17, 699628) Human life is not mechanical.
('61', 362, 2, 18, 699658) To every one of us there are things as dear as life itself, and one can say that life would be impossible without them.
('61', 362, 2, 19, 699778) The measure of the truthfulness of such statements would depend on the intensity of one’s devotion to the causes espoused.
('61', 362, 2, 20, 699901) While in the case of some people separation from a cause claimed to be dear as life itself will not kill them, with others such a separation will be nothing less than a sentence of death.
('61', 362, 3, 21, 700089) But it would be wrong to take such devotion to imply that outward activity connected with the object of devotion must go on from moment to moment.
('61', 362, 3, 22, 700236) It certainly does imply that outward action must be taken whenever occasion demands it.
('61', 362, 3, 23, 700324) The seed we sow in the ground does not sprout immediately, but if it is not dead, it grows every minute, though we see it as a plant or tree only after many days or months.
('61', 362, 3, 24, 700497) The process of growth we see in the physical world we should expect to see in the mental and spiritual world also.
('61', 362, 4, 25, 700612) 1 God in the form of the poor
('61', 363, 0, 1, 700642) 364 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATM GANDHI
('61', 363, 1, 2, 700683) The truth of my statement about Harijan service can be measured, if at all, only after my death.
('61', 363, 1, 3, 700780) The full measure is known only to the all knowing God.
('61', 363, 1, 4, 700835) For He alone knows our intentions.
('61', 363, 1, 5, 700870) it can, therefore, try to satisfy the correspondent, and others who think like him, only by repeating that there is no exaggeration in my claim that Harijan service is the breath of my life and that, therefore, I cannot live for one moment without it.
('61', 363, 2, 6, 701122) Harijan, 30 9 1933

('61', 366, 4, 15, 706711) 460. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('61', 366, 5, 16, 706742) September 4, 1933
('61', 366, 6, 17, 706760) NARANDAS,

('61', 370, 12, 24, 712276) [September 7, 1933] 2
('61', 370, 13, 25, 712298) The Servants of Untouchables Society has declared 24th of this month to be the Harijan Day.
('61', 370, 13, 26, 712390) It is the anniversary of the Yeravda Pact, miscalled Poona Pact.
('61', 370, 13, 27, 712455) It is a happy coincidence that 24th is a Sunday.
('61', 370, 13, 28, 712504) It is to be hoped that the day will be celebrated in a manner befitting the occasion.
('61', 370, 13, 29, 712590) Each person, each Harijan organization, should take stock of his or its year’s activity and contribution to the removal of the canker of untouchability.
('61', 370, 13, 30, 712743) Societies and individuals can make a budget or resolution for the year to follow.
('61', 370, 13, 31, 712825) Subscriptions can be collected from door to door for the work to be done.
('61', 370, 13, 32, 712899) All the various activities that have hitherto been followed on Harijan Days will,

('61', 371, 1, 2, 713106) I have no doubt, be taken up with greater emphasis on the 24th instant.

('61', 371, 3, 7, 713614) 469. INTERVIEW ON GOSEVA1
('61', 371, 4, 8, 713640) September 8, 1933 2
('61', 371, 5, 9, 713660) GANDHIJI: I don’t have sufficient enthusiasm to give a message, 3
('61', 371, 6, 10, 713726) because nobody does goseva in accordance with my views.
('61', 371, 6, 11, 713782) I had explained these views to your President.
('61', 371, 6, 12, 713829) I had also suggested the lines along which improvements could be made in the present movement.
('61', 371, 6, 13, 713924) The President had agreed to implement my suggestions and had even assured me that he would do so.
('61', 371, 6, 14, 714022) But he didn’t keep his promise.
('61', 371, 6, 15, 714054) What is the use, then, of my giving a message?
('61', 371, 7, 16, 714101) INTERVIEWER: This refers to only some of the workers engaged in goseva.
('61', 371, 7, 17, 714173) Many other persons and goshalas are doing this work.
('61', 371, 7, 18, 714226) They all can know your views on this movement only through a message.
('61', 371, 7, 19, 714296) If you wish you can in the same message point out the shortcomings and suggest improvements.
('61', 371, 8, 20, 714389) G. I may dispose of you with an ordinary message in the same way as when a goseva worker approaches one for contribution; one usually disposes of him by paying him a few coins.
('61', 371, 8, 21, 714566) But I don’t think that any useful purpose will be served by such a message.
('61', 371, 9, 22, 714642) I. Well, leaving aside the subject of message, may I ask you whether you would like, after all these years, to revise any of your views on goseva expressed earlier?
('61', 371, 9, 23, 714807) What you had said was: ‘(I) goseva alone will bring swaraj nearer.
('61', 371, 9, 24, 714874) (2) As long as cows are being slaughtered, I feel myself being slaughtered.
('61', 371, 9, 25, 714950) My efforts to save cows are
('61', 371, 10, 26, 714978) 1 This is published as “Introduction” in the source.
('61', 371, 10, 27, 715031) 2 The interview was concluded on a subsequent date, which is not ascertainable.
('61', 371, 10, 28, 715111) 3 The interviewer, a representative of an institution, had asked Gandhiji for a message for his monthly.
('61', 372, 0, 1, 715216) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 373
('61', 372, 1, 2, 715260) going on uninterruptedly.
('61', 372, 1, 3, 715286) All my efforts are directed to stopping cow slaughter.
('61', 372, 1, 4, 715341) Anyone who is not ready to give his life to save the cow is not a Hindu.
('61', 372, 1, 5, 715414) (3) My deepest aspirations are, eradication of untouchability and service of the cow.
('61', 372, 1, 6, 715500) We shall achieve swaraj only when we succeed in these two tasks.
('61', 372, 1, 7, 715565) I see moksha lies in their achievement.’
('61', 372, 2, 8, 715606) G. I wish to make no change in this statement of my views.
('61', 372, 2, 9, 715665) But in interpreting them, the context of the circumstances in which I expressed them and the wide meaning which I give to goseva should be kept in mind.
('61', 372, 2, 10, 715818) In goseva of my conception, I include all living creatures.
('61', 372, 2, 11, 715878) Probably you do not know that I have said much more than the remarks you have quoted.
('61', 372, 2, 12, 715964) For instance, I had also said that the ideal of cow protection was the most important gift of Hinduism to mankind.
('61', 372, 2, 13, 716079) But this remark of mine referred only to goseva of my peculiar conception.
('61', 372, 3, 14, 716154) I. I see what you mean.
('61', 372, 3, 15, 716178) I will now ask one more question relating to the same aspect.
('61', 372, 3, 16, 716240) Some people say that while doing cow protection work in a disinterested spirit, one need not make any distinction between truth and untruth, and that any means can be adopted for cow protection.
('61', 372, 3, 17, 716435) What is your view in this regard?
('61', 372, 4, 18, 716469) G. To sacrifice truth for the sake of cow protection would amount to sacrificing the cow herself.
('61', 372, 4, 19, 716567) Similarly to betray truth for the sake of a public cause is to betray that cause itself.
('61', 372, 4, 20, 716656) These peculiar views of mine have not commended themselves to the people, and they are not convinced by them.
('61', 372, 4, 21, 716766) I have, therefore, no desire to interest myself in the present cow protection movement.
('61', 372, 4, 22, 716854) In fact, even today I am doing my utmost for cow protection.
('61', 372, 4, 23, 716915) How that is so is a riddle.
('61', 372, 4, 24, 716943) What appears in newspapers will not help you to solve it.
('61', 372, 4, 25, 717001) But I myself am convinced about it.
('61', 372, 4, 26, 717037) Maybe you have found the solution.
('61', 372, 5, 27, 717072) I. Yes Sir, I understand what you mean.
('61', 372, 6, 28, 717112) G. I have made a deep study of the problem of goseva.
('61', 372, 6, 29, 717166) Very few would have visited as many goshalas as I have.
('61', 372, 6, 30, 717222) I have carefully studied the working of every institution I visited and have even written down my opinion of them in the visitors’ books.
('61', 372, 7, 31, 717360) I. Will you then describe the defects that you have noticed in the present cow protection work?
('61', 372, 8, 32, 717456) G. Those are mostly of the nature described in what you read out.
('61', 372, 9, 33, 717522) I. Well, then, according to you how can the cow be protected?
('61', 372, 10, 34, 717584) G. I will explain all that, but now the time allotted for this
('61', 373, 0, 1, 717647) 374 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATM GANDHI
('61', 373, 1, 2, 717688) interview is over.
('61', 373, 1, 3, 717707) So please come once again after fixing an appointment.
('61', 373, 1, 4, 717762) I will certainly grant an interview.
('61', 373, 1, 5, 717799) We will discuss the problem further then, and if you are really enthusiastic about this work, then either I will co operate with you or you will co operate with me and we will do this work together.
('61', 373, 3, 6, 717998) [After September 8, 1933]
('61', 373, 4, 7, 718024) I. If I have properly understood you, then the distinctive feature of your idea of cow protection is complete adherence to truth and non violence, absence of communal ill will, utmost forbearance and love, and attention to the economic aspect, that is, increasing the number of dairies and tanneries and thereby the value of cows.
('61', 373, 4, 8, 718355) Isn’t this your particular point of view regarding goseva?
('61', 373, 5, 9, 718414) G. Perfectly true.
('61', 373, 5, 10, 718433) Those who slaughter cows are ignorant people.
('61', 373, 5, 11, 718479) Their ignorance cannot be removed by killing them.
('61', 373, 5, 12, 718530) To remove their ignorance efforts of a different kind, love and sympathy, are required.
('61', 373, 5, 13, 718618) And from the economic point of view also, there is no other way but to increase the value of cows.
('61', 373, 6, 14, 718717) I. Surely it is not your view that, while doing all this, we need not share or try to preserve the peculiar religious sentiment, that is, the feeling of reverence for cows?
('61', 373, 7, 15, 718890) G. No, no.
('61', 373, 7, 16, 718901) on the contrary, this sentiment or feeling of reverence will be kept alive and preserved only by implementing all the items in my plan of goseva.
('61', 373, 8, 17, 719047) I. If we accept your idea, what should we do in future for the progress of the work?
('61', 373, 8, 18, 719132) Would you suggest a yearly or three yearly plan?
('61', 373, 9, 19, 719181) G. Whether you have a yearly or a three yearly plan, you must do these things: 1. Stress should be laid on consumption of cow’s milk and consumption of other milk should be stopped; 2. efforts should be made to utilize all the parts of the dead body of a cow and to see that no part is wasted, and propaganda should be carried on in this regard; 3. efforts should be made to improve the breed of cows; 4. the cow’s yield of milk should be improved, etc.
('61', 373, 10, 20, 719635) I. Do you expect goseva workers who are engaged in these activities to work also for removal of untouchability and for Hindu Muslim unity?
('61', 373, 11, 21, 719774) G. Not at all.
('61', 373, 11, 22, 719789) It would be enough if they realize the wider
('61', 374, 0, 1, 719834) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 375
('61', 374, 1, 2, 719878) significance of goseva.
('61', 374, 1, 3, 719902) Much can be done through such awareness itself.
('61', 374, 1, 4, 719950) It would only mean that you had taken up one special aspect of goseva.
('61', 374, 1, 5, 720021) It is in this sense that I claim to be doing goseva work while working for the removal of untouchability.
('61', 374, 2, 6, 720127) I. If we wish to work in the manner suggested by you, what help or co operation from you can we expect?
('61', 374, 3, 7, 720231) G. I believe that certain virtues are essential for public workers.
('61', 374, 3, 8, 720299) If you or anybody from among you pass that test, then I can free them from financial worries.
('61', 374, 4, 9, 720393) I. Do you think it necessary that a paper like Harijan should be started for this work?
('61', 374, 5, 10, 720481) G. To start a newspaper is the next step, or rather the last step.
('61', 374, 5, 11, 720548) First of all an organization should start functioning, inspired by a particular ideal.
('61', 374, 5, 12, 720635) Only then would it be proper to start a paper.
('61', 374, 5, 13, 720682) That has been my attitude in regard to Harijan.
('61', 374, 6, 14, 720730) I. At present we lay great stress on the unification of all institutions engaged in goseva.
('61', 374, 6, 15, 720822) How far do you approve of this?
('61', 374, 7, 16, 720854) G. It is a very difficult task, but I totally approve of it.
('61', 374, 7, 17, 720915) If you succeed in it, I will congratulate you.
('61', 374, 8, 18, 720962) [From Gujarati]

('61', 374, 10, 20, 720990) 470. WAS IT COERCIVE?
('61', 374, 11, 21, 721012) In the current number of The Modern Review, amongst the notes which are always worth reading, there are some paragraphs on my most recent fast 1. The writer of these notes quotes the following from my letter 2 to the authorities dated 14th August last and then remarks 3:
('61', 374, 12, 22, 721284) But we .
('61', 374, 12, 23, 721293) are constrained to observe that, though fasts undertaken solely for one’s own purification and consolation are the exclusive concern of the individual fasting, fasts undertaken directly or indirectly to bring about political or social changes have coercive effect, even though coercion may not be intended.
('61', 374, 12, 24, 721600) Like other coercion, this sort of unintended coercion .
('61', 374, 12, 25, 721656) does not lead to universally sincere conduct and lasting reform.
('61', 374, 13, 26, 721721) 1 From August 16 to 23, 1933 2 Vide “Letter to Home Secretary, Government of Bombay”, 14 8 1933. 3 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('61', 375, 0, 1, 721855) 376 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATM GANDHI
('61', 375, 1, 2, 721896) I propose to deal with this criticism because it affects a matter that is by no means closed.
('61', 375, 1, 3, 721990) Fasting has been for years past an integral part of my life and I may have to resume it whether outside or inside prison walls.
('61', 375, 1, 4, 722118) I cannot, therefore, write too often on the science of fasting, if I may use the sacred word ‘science’ in connection with my fasts.
('61', 375, 1, 5, 722250) It is necessary to write on this matter as well for those who would thoughtlessly imitate me, as for those who criticize me sometimes without being in possession of full data.
('61', 375, 1, 6, 722426) With much of what the writer says I can readily agree.
('61', 375, 1, 7, 722481) I do admit that my fast of September 1 did unfortunately coerce some people into action which they would not have endorsed without my fast.
('61', 375, 1, 8, 722621) I do admit also that my last fast coerced the Government into releasing me.
('61', 375, 1, 9, 722697) I admit, too, that such coercion can and does sometimes lead to insincere conduct.
('61', 375, 1, 10, 722780) This is about the extent of my agreement.
('61', 375, 1, 11, 722822) These admissions do not cut at the very root of fasts.
('61', 375, 1, 12, 722877) They only show that there is great need for caution and that special qualifications are necessary for those who would resort to fasting as a method of reform or securing justice.
('61', 375, 2, 13, 723056) In any examination of moral conduct, the intention is the chief ingredient.
('61', 375, 2, 14, 723132) Being concerned with the morality of my action, I asserted that the intention behind the fast was not to exert coercion or pressure upon the Government.
('61', 375, 2, 15, 723285) I wanted the Government to take me at my word and let me die in peace, if they could not see the justice of granting me the facilities I desired.
('61', 375, 2, 16, 723431) The production of my letter would have absolved them from the charge of heartlessness, if I had died in prison.
('61', 375, 2, 17, 723543) I did, indeed, know that my fast was likely, in spite of the declaration of my intention to the contrary, to influence Government to some extent.
('61', 375, 2, 18, 723689) But one may not be deflected from the right course for fear of possible but unintended consequences.
('61', 375, 2, 19, 723790) If one were to be so deterred it could be shown that hardly any great action could be undertaken.
('61', 375, 3, 20, 723888) To make my meaning clearer, let me take the September fast.
('61', 375, 3, 21, 723948) It is a better illustration for examination seeing that it was unconnected with the Government.
('61', 375, 3, 22, 724044) It was intended to influence both the caste and the Harijan Hindus.
('61', 375, 3, 23, 724112) But there the intention was most decidedly not to induce, irrespective of merits, the decision I desired, but it was to stir
('61', 375, 4, 24, 724237) 1 September 20 to 26. 1932.
('61', 376, 0, 1, 724265) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 377
('61', 376, 1, 2, 724309) the Hindus to action on my submission.
('61', 376, 1, 3, 724348) The intention was completely fulfilled and to that extent the fast was not, therefore, from the practical standpoint, open to objection.
('61', 376, 1, 4, 724485) That it went beyond the intention and coerced some people into giving a decision against their conviction was unfortunate.
('61', 376, 1, 5, 724608) But such conduct is of daily occurrence in the ordinary affairs of life.
('61', 376, 1, 6, 724681) People do not always act independently of others or of surrounding circumstances.
('61', 376, 1, 7, 724763) But I am able to say that vast majority of people concerned with the Pact would not accept it without a full and free discussion, and that what they accepted was accepted because they considered it to be on the whole just and fair.
('61', 376, 1, 8, 724995) They did not sacrifice principle for saving my life.
('61', 376, 1, 9, 725048) And now whilst I am on the Pact I may observe parenthetically that, if any injustice was done, it is not yet beyond repair.
('61', 376, 1, 10, 725172) If injustice can be proved to the satisfaction of the parties concerned, it is not too late to redress it.
('61', 376, 1, 11, 725279) And I need hardly give the assurance that I should regard it as my sacred duty to exert myself to the best of my ability in helping to secure redress of any real injustice.
('61', 376, 1, 12, 725452) To revert to the issue under examination, I may say that I began my experiments in fasting on any large scale as an instru ment of reform in 1913. 1 I had fasted often enough before, but not in the manner of 1913. My definite opinion is that the general result of my numerous fasts was without doubt beneficial.
('61', 376, 1, 13, 725764) They invariably quickened the conscience of the people interested in and sought to be influenced by those fasts.
('61', 376, 1, 14, 725877) I am not aware of any injustice having been perpetrated through those fasts.
('61', 376, 1, 15, 725954) If Bengal proves injustice, it will be an exception.
('61', 376, 1, 16, 726007) In no case was there any idea of exercising coercion on anyone.
('61', 376, 1, 17, 726071) Indeed, I think that the word coercion would be a misnomer for the influence that was exerted by the fasts under criticism.
('61', 376, 1, 18, 726195) Coercion means some harmful force used against a person who is expected to do something desired by the user of the force.
('61', 376, 1, 19, 726317) In the fasts in question, the force used was against myself.
('61', 376, 1, 20, 726378) Surely, force of self suffering cannot be put in the same category as the force of suffering caused to the party sought to be influenced.
('61', 376, 1, 21, 726516) If I fast in order to awaken the conscience of an erring friend whose error is beyond question, I am not coercing him in the ordinary sense of the word.
('61', 376, 1, 22, 726669) The writer of the notes says that there can be fasts that have no “coercive effect”, but if the expression ‘coercive effect’ can be
('61', 376, 2, 23, 726801) 1 The reference is to the fast undertaken to atone for the moral lapse on the part of an inmate of the Phoenix Ashram.
('61', 377, 0, 1, 726920) 378 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATM GANDHI
('61', 377, 1, 2, 726961) lawfully used for my fasts, then in that sense, all fasts can be proved to have that effect to a greater or less extent.
('61', 377, 1, 3, 727082) The fact is that all spiritual fasts always influence those who come within the zone of their influence.
('61', 377, 1, 4, 727187) That is why spiritual fasting is described as tapas.
('61', 377, 1, 5, 727240) And all tapas invariably exerts purifying influence on those in whose behalf it is undertaken.
('61', 377, 1, 6, 727335) Of course, it is not to be denied that fasts can be really coercive.
('61', 377, 1, 7, 727404) Such are fasts to attain a selfish object.
('61', 377, 1, 8, 727447) A fast undertaken to wring money from a person or for fulfilling some such personal end would amount to the exercise of coercion or undue influence.
('61', 377, 1, 9, 727596) I would unhesitatingly advocate resistance of such undue influence.
('61', 377, 1, 10, 727664) I have myself successfully resisted it in the fasts that have been undertaken or threatened against me.
('61', 377, 1, 11, 727768) And if it is argued that the dividing line between a selfish and an unselfish end is often very thin, I would urge that a person who regards the end of a fast to be selfish or otherwise base should resolutely refuse to yield to it, even though the refusal may result in the death of the fasting person.
('61', 377, 1, 12, 728071) If people will cultivate the habit of disregarding fasts which in their opinion are taken for unworthy ends, such fasts will be robbed of the taint of coercion and undue influence.
('61', 377, 1, 13, 728252) Like all human institutions, fasting can be both legitimately and illegitimately used.
('61', 377, 1, 14, 728339) But as a great weapon in the armoury of satyagraha, it cannot be given up because of its possible abuse.
('61', 377, 1, 15, 728444) Satyagraha has been designed as an effective substitute for violence.
('61', 377, 1, 16, 728514) This use is in its infancy and, therefore, not yet perfected.
('61', 377, 1, 17, 728576) But as the author of modern satyagraha I cannot give up any of its manifold uses without forfeiting my claim to handle it in the spirit of a humble seeker.

('61', 382, 5, 9, 735298) 480. DISCUSSION WITH A FRIEND1
('61', 382, 6, 10, 735329) [Before September 10, 1933]
('61', 382, 7, 11, 735357) Don’t lose heart.
('61', 382, 7, 12, 735375) Of course I can understand your deep sentiment.
('61', 382, 8, 13, 735423) But how much you suffered!
('61', 382, 8, 14, 735450) Oh, it was the body that suffered, besides I had invited the suffering myself.
('61', 382, 8, 15, 735529) When God creates for us a situation involving suffering He also gives us the strength to bear it.
('61', 382, 8, 16, 735627) It would surely be painful for me if I did not act on His prompting to undertake a fast.
('61', 382, 8, 17, 735716) This is not a new thing in my life.
('61', 382, 9, 18, 735752) But what about [the risk to] your life?
('61', 382, 9, 19, 735792) The path of life is not straight and smooth.
('61', 382, 9, 20, 735837) It has so many turns and twists, so many ups and downs.
('61', 382, 9, 21, 735893) It is not like a railway track on which, once released, the train simply goes on.

('61', 383, 1, 2, 736206) 481. ADVICE TO GIRLS, PARNAKUTI KANYASHALA1
('61', 383, 2, 3, 736250) [Before September 10, 1933]
('61', 383, 3, 4, 736278) GANDHIJI: If in order to keep up and strengthen one’s faith in God man is called upon to undergo this much trouble, he should be prepared to do so.
('61', 383, 4, 5, 736426) A GIRL: Should prayers be compulsory or voluntary?
('61', 383, 5, 6, 736477) G. Is eating compulsory or voluntary?
('61', 383, 6, 7, 736515) A GIRL: one cannot do without it.
('61', 383, 7, 8, 736549) G. In that case, we should not be able to do without prayer too.
('61', 383, 7, 9, 736614) Just as our body cannot grow without food, our atman cannot grow without prayer.
('61', 383, 7, 10, 736695) Just as food is the nourishment for our body, prayer is the nourishment for our atman.
('61', 383, 7, 11, 736782) Without prayer the atman becomes lustreless.
('61', 383, 7, 12, 736827) How can we say that it is killed?
('61', 383, 7, 13, 736861) For, the Bhagavad Gita tells us that the atman is deathless.
('61', 383, 7, 14, 736922) But atman may be deluded.
('61', 383, 7, 15, 736948) There are countless people in the world who do not pray, they are as good as lost.
('61', 383, 7, 16, 737031) He who is not conscious of the atman is only an ignorant fool.
('61', 383, 7, 17, 737094) Prayer can never be said to be compulsory.
('61', 383, 7, 18, 737137) It can be only voluntary.
('61', 383, 7, 19, 737163) If anyone insists on making prayer compulsory, it will result in hypocrisy.
('61', 383, 7, 20, 737239) But we must make it compulsory of our own accord.
('61', 383, 7, 21, 737289) It is not one’s duty to eat.
('61', 383, 7, 22, 737318) One can do without eating for a while.
('61', 383, 7, 23, 737357) One can never eat when one has already eaten too much.
('61', 383, 7, 24, 737412) But one can never have too much of prayers.
('61', 383, 7, 25, 737456) We must make prayer so obligatory for ourselves that we can never do without it.
('61', 383, 7, 26, 737537) If you girls resolve that you would not tell a lie even if you get a kingdom in return, would it be called compulsory or voluntary?
('61', 383, 7, 27, 737669) What if you have decided on your own and made it a rule to offer your prayers at 4 o’clock in the morning and at 7.30 in the evening —even at the instance of the elders?
('61', 383, 7, 28, 737839) In such matters we must be hard on ourselves.
('61', 383, 7, 29, 737885) You can pray only if you have made such a rule.
('61', 383, 7, 30, 737933) Nothing in the world happens without a law of its own.
('61', 383, 8, 31, 737988) [From Gujarati]
('61', 383, 9, 32, 738004) Harijanbandhu, 10 9 1933

('61', 384, 6, 13, 738838) 483. WHAT SHOULD A BRAHMIN DO?
('61', 384, 7, 14, 738869) A Maharashtrian writes: 2
('61', 384, 8, 15, 738895) I hope not many persons have had the experience that this Brahmin has had.
('61', 384, 8, 16, 738970) Of course, no one should have it.
('61', 384, 8, 17, 739004) Anyone who is qualified for a job should get one.
('61', 384, 8, 18, 739054) There should be no discrimination in this regard, on the basis of caste, varna or religion.
('61', 384, 8, 19, 739146) It should be easy for any person belonging to this country to find himself a job, or practise a profession here.
('61', 384, 8, 20, 739259) This represents the ideal.
('61', 384, 8, 21, 739286) Ideas of ‘high’ and ‘low’ are deep rooted in our country and hence caste, varna and religion are given greater attention than merit or demerits.
('61', 384, 8, 22, 739431) Hence it is not surprising that Brahmins are not given employment where there is a ban on their recruitment.
('61', 384, 8, 23, 739540) Unfortunate incidents will persist, because of our sins and the rot that has entered our religion.
('61', 384, 8, 24, 739639) We should, therefore, suffer them in a spirit of atonement.
('61', 384, 8, 25, 739699) But then, why should one who wishes to observe the dharma ordained for a Brahmin look for employment?
('61', 384, 8, 26, 739801) Those who profess to be Brahmins, should spread Brahmavidya 3 amongst the people and for livelihood depend upon religiously inclined patrons.
('61', 384, 8, 27, 739943) A Brahmin
('61', 384, 9, 28, 739953) 1 Who had approached Gandhiji after the evening prayers.
('61', 384, 9, 29, 740010) This appeared under the sub title, “The Price of an Autograph”.
('61', 384, 9, 30, 740074) 2 The letter is not translated here.
('61', 384, 9, 31, 740111) The correspondent had pointed out that an educated gentleman had failed to obtain employment because of his being a Brahmin.
('61', 384, 9, 32, 740236) 3 Knowledge of Brahman
('61', 385, 0, 1, 740259) 386 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATM GANDHI
('61', 385, 1, 2, 740300) who is out to seek employment should find true consolation in the practice of his own dharma, so that he will have no cause for despair.
('61', 385, 1, 3, 740437) I hope I will not be criticized on the ground that I who assert that varnadharma has ceased to exist, take refuge in this system when faced with a difficult situation.
('61', 385, 1, 4, 740605) This is because, to say that varnadharma has disappeared does not imply that no one should observe it.
('61', 385, 1, 5, 740708) Anyone who believes in it ought to observe it studiously as far as he is personally involved.
('61', 385, 1, 6, 740802) fact that this Brahmin claims to be one suggests that he believes in varnadharma.
('61', 385, 1, 7, 740884) Hence, I would advise him to observe it and give up the lure of employment, Even in these difficult times, individual Brahmins have rendered no mean service to the country.
('61', 385, 1, 8, 741057) Compared with others, the sacrifice of Brahmins is indeed greater.
('61', 385, 1, 9, 741124) However, the supreme sacrifice on the part of Brahmins will be to give up all pursuit of wealth such as employment, etc.
('61', 385, 1, 10, 741245) The Brahmin’s dharma could shine only by paramartha 1. If the Brahmins understood the idea behind varnad harma and acted accordingly, it could easily be revived.
('61', 385, 1, 11, 741407) Hence my advice to this Brahmin and to those in a similar plight is that they should become worthy of practising their Brahmin dharma, act accordingly and give up the lure of wealth.

('61', 390, 1, 2, 747679) 493. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('61', 390, 2, 3, 747707) September 14, 1933
('61', 390, 3, 4, 747726) As a rule, during my long course of public service, the next moment’s step has been clear before me, but since my unexpected release from prison on August 23 last, darkness has surrounded me.
('61', 390, 3, 5, 747918) The path of duly has, therefore, not been clear to me.
('61', 390, 3, 6, 747973) My present state of health is such that it may yet take several weeks for me to regain my lost strength.
('61', 390, 3, 7, 748078) To seek imprisonment as soon as I was physically fit, or to restrain myself for the interrupted year of imprisonment was the question before me.
('61', 390, 3, 8, 748223) After hard praying and thinking, I have come to the conclusion that up to the termination of the period of my sentence, that is, up to August 3 next, I must not court imprisonment by offering aggressive civil resistance.
('61', 390, 3, 9, 748444) This, however, in no way affects the advice given in the statement issued by me after the informal conference 1 at Poona.
('61', 390, 3, 10, 748566) That I have to suspend action for myself is unfortunate but inevitable.
('61', 390, 3, 11, 748638) My release has placed me in a most embarrassing position, but as a satyagrahi, that is, as a humble seeker of Truth, somehow or other it offends my sense of propriety to court imprisonment in the circumstances created by my discharge.
('61', 390, 3, 12, 748873) Whatever the motive behind it, I may not quarrel with my release.
('61', 390, 3, 13, 748939) I must example examine act on its merits.
('61', 390, 3, 14, 748981) It appears to me to be petty to force the Government to re arrest me by taking aggressive action during the unexpired term of imprisonment, unless extraordinary circumstances, which I cannot foresee, arise compelling me to revise my decision.
('61', 390, 3, 15, 749224) There is no room for smallness in civil resistance.
('61', 390, 3, 16, 749276) This self imposed restraint is a bitter cup.
('61', 390, 3, 17, 749321) When I said at my trial 2 after arrest that to remain outside and be a helpless witness of the devastating and demoralizing effect of the Ordinance Rule was an unbearable agony, I stated a simple and unvarnished fact.
('61', 390, 3, 18, 749539) That agony is no less today than it was on August 4. But I must bear it.
('61', 390, 3, 19, 749612) I cannot be a willing party to an undignified cat and mouse game if Government have any such thing in contemplation.
('61', 390, 3, 20, 749729) Therefore, when and if I am arrested again and denied Harijan service,
('61', 390, 4, 21, 749800) 1 Vide “Speech at Leaders’ Conference, Poona I”, 12 7 1933 and “Speech at Leaders’ Conference, Poona II”, 12 7 1933. 2 On.
('61', 390, 4, 22, 749923) August 4; vide “Trial at Poona”, 4 8 1933.
('61', 391, 0, 1, 749966) 392 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATM GANDHI
('61', 391, 1, 2, 750007) I would not hesitate, if I had the inner urge, to undertake a fast to the finish which would not be broken even if Government released me, as they did on August 23 last, when the danger point had been reached.
('61', 391, 1, 3, 750217) I must state the limitations of my self restraint in clear terms.
('61', 391, 1, 4, 750283) Whilst I can refrain from aggressive civil resistance, I cannot, so long as I am free, help guiding those who will seek my advice, and preventing national movement from running into wrong channels.
('61', 391, 1, 5, 750481) It is an ever growing belief with me that truth cannot be found by violent means.
('61', 391, 1, 6, 750563) The attainment of national independence is to me a search after truth.
('61', 391, 1, 7, 750634) Terrorist methods, whether adopted by an oppressor or his victim can, I am convinced, never be effectively answered by violent resistance but only by civil resistance.
('61', 391, 1, 8, 750802) I would, therefore, be guilty of disloyalty to my creed, if I attempted to put greater restraint on myself than I have adumbrated in this statement.
('61', 391, 1, 9, 750951) If then Government leave me free, I propose to devote this period to Harijan service and if possible to such constructive activities as my health may permit.
('61', 391, 1, 10, 751109) It is needless to repeat here that peace is as much a part of my being as civil resistance.
('61', 391, 1, 11, 751201) Indeed a civil resister offers resistance only when peace becomes impossible.
('61', 391, 1, 12, 751279) Therefore, so far as I am concerned and so long as I am free, I shall make all endeavours in my power to explore every possible avenue of an honourable peace.
('61', 391, 2, 13, 751438) The Bombay Chronicle, 15 9 1933
('61', 391, 3, 14, 751470) 494. LETTER TO JAWAHARLAL NEHRU
('61', 391, 4, 15, 751502) ‘PARNAKUTI’, POONA, September 14, 1933
('61', 391, 5, 16, 751541) DEAR JAWAHARLAL,
('61', 391, 6, 17, 751558) I am glad you have written so fully and frankly.
('61', 391, 6, 18, 751607) When, on my return from London at the end of 1931, I found you to have been suddenly snatched away from me, 1 I felt the separation keenly.
('61', 391, 6, 19, 751747) I was, therefore, most anxious to meet you and exchange views.
('61', 391, 7, 20, 751810) 1 The addressee was arrested on December 26, 1931, while on his way to see Gandhiji.
('61', 391, 7, 21, 751895) 2 Gandhiji and Jawaharlal Nehru met and had long discussions from september 10.
('61', 392, 0, 1, 751975) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 393
('61', 392, 1, 2, 752019) With much of what you have said in your letter I am in complete agreement.
('61', 392, 1, 3, 752094) The experience gained after the karachi Congress has, if possible, strengthened my faith in the main resolution and the economic programme referred to by you.
('61', 392, 1, 4, 752253) I have no doubt in my mind that our goal can be no less than ‘Complete Independence’.
('61', 392, 1, 5, 752339) I am also in whole hearted agreement with you when you say that without a material revision of vested interests the condition of the masses can never be improved.
('61', 392, 1, 6, 752502) I believe, too, though I may not go as far as you do, that before India can become one homogeneous entity, the princes will have to part with much of their power and become popular representatives of the people over whom they are ruling today.
('61', 392, 1, 7, 752746) I can corroborate from first hand experience much of what you say about the Round Table Conference.
('61', 392, 1, 8, 752846) Nor have I the slightest difficulty in agreeing with you that in these days of rapid intercommunication and a growing consciousness of the oneness of all mankind, we must recognize that our nationalism must not be inconsistent with progressive internationalism.
('61', 392, 1, 9, 753108) India cannot stand in isolation and unaffected by what is going on in other parts of the world.
('61', 392, 1, 10, 753204) I can, therefore, go the whole length with you and say that ‘we should range ourselves with the progressive forces of the world’.
('61', 392, 1, 11, 753334) But I know that though there is such an agreement between you and me in the enunciation of ideals, there are temperamental differences between us.
('61', 392, 1, 12, 753481) Thus you have emphasized the necessity of a clear statement of the goal, but having once determined it, I have never attached importance to the repetition.
('61', 392, 1, 13, 753637) The clearest possible definition of the goal and its appreciation would fail to take us there if we do not know and utilize the means of achieving it.
('61', 392, 1, 14, 753788) I have, therefore, concerned myself principally with the conservation of the means and their progressive use.
('61', 392, 1, 15, 753898) I know that if we can take care of them, attainment of the goal is assured.
('61', 392, 1, 16, 753974) I feel too that our progress towards the goal will be in exact proportion to the purity of our means.
('61', 392, 1, 17, 754076) If we can give an ocular demonstration of our uttermost truthfulness and non violence, I am convinced that our statement of the national goal cannot long offend the interests which your letter would appear to attack.
('61', 392, 1, 18, 754293) We know that the princes, the zamindars, and those who depend for their existence upon the exploitation of the masses, would cease to fear and distrust us, if we could but ensure the innocence of our methods.
('61', 392, 1, 19, 754502) We do not seek to coerce any.
('61', 392, 1, 20, 754532) We seek to convert them.
('61', 392, 1, 21, 754557) This method may appear to be long, perhaps too long, but I am convinced that it is the shortest.
('61', 393, 0, 1, 754654) 394 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATM GANDHI
('61', 393, 1, 2, 754695) In the main I agree with your interpretation of Sjt.
('61', 393, 1, 3, 754748) Aney’s instructions and my note upon them.
('61', 393, 1, 4, 754791) I am quite clear in my mind that had those instructions not been issued, the whole movement of civil resistance would have collapsed through growing internal weakness; for Congressmen were deluding themselves into the belief that there were organizations effectively functioning to which they could look for guidance, when, as a matter of fact, under the organized terrorism which the Ordinance Rule means, organized functioning of Congress Committees had become impossible.
('61', 393, 1, 5, 755266) A false belief in the functioning of organizations, rendered illegal and largely impotent, was fast producing a demoralization which had to be arrested.
('61', 393, 1, 6, 755419) There is no such thing as demoralization in civil resistance properly applied.
('61', 393, 1, 7, 755498) You have said rightly that after all “civil disobe dience is essentially an individual affair”.
('61', 393, 1, 8, 755594) I go a step further and say that so long as there is one civil resister offering resistance, the move ment cannot die and must succeed in the end.
('61', 393, 1, 9, 755741) Individual civil resisters do not need the aid of an organization.
('61', 393, 1, 10, 755808) After all an organization is nothing without the individuals composing it.
('61', 393, 1, 11, 755883) Aney’s instructions were, therefore, I hold, an affective answer to the Ordinances and if only men and women belonging to the Congress will appreciate the necessity of those instructions with all their implications, the Ordinances will be rendered nugatory, at least so far as the resisters are concerned.
('61', 393, 1, 12, 756189) They can form a nucleus around which an army of invincible civil resisters can be built up.
('61', 393, 1, 13, 756281) Nothing ill Sjt.
('61', 393, 1, 14, 756298) Aney’s instructions or in my note would warrant the supposition that they preclude organized action by Congressmen in any shape or form.
('61', 393, 2, 15, 756435) I would like to warn you against thinking that there is no fundamental difference between individual cavil resistance and mass civil resistance.
('61', 393, 2, 16, 756580) I think that the fundamental difference is implied in your own admission that “it is essentially an individual affair”.
('61', 393, 2, 17, 756700) The chief distinction between mass civil resistance and individual civil resistance is that in the latter everyone is a complete independent unit and his fall does not affect the others; in mass civil resistance the fall of one generally adversely affects the rest.
('61', 393, 2, 18, 756966) Again, in mass civil resistance leadership is essential, in individual civil resistance every resister is his own leader.
('61', 393, 2, 19, 757088) Then again, in mass civil resistance, there is a possibility of failure; in individual civil resistance failure is an impossibility.
('61', 393, 2, 20, 757221) Finally, a State may cope with mass civil resistance; no State has yet been found able to cope with individual civil resistance.
('61', 394, 0, 1, 757350) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 395
('61', 394, 1, 2, 757394) Nor may much be made of my statement that an organization which feels its own strength can at its own risk adopt mass civil resistance.
('61', 394, 1, 3, 757530) While, as an opinion, it is unexceptionable, I know that at the present moment there is no organization that can shoulder the burden.
('61', 394, 1, 4, 757664) I do not want to raise false hopes.
('61', 394, 2, 5, 757700) Now about the secret methods.
('61', 394, 2, 6, 757730) I am as firm as ever that they must be tabooed.
('61', 394, 2, 7, 757778) I am myself unable to make any exceptions.
('61', 394, 2, 8, 757821) Secrecy has caused much mischief and if it is not put down with a firm hand, it may ruin the movement.
('61', 394, 2, 9, 757924) There may be exceptional circumstances that may warrant secret methods.
('61', 394, 2, 10, 757996) I would forgo that advantage for the sake of the masses whom we want to educate in fearlessness.
('61', 394, 2, 11, 758093) I will not confuse their minds by leading them to think that under certain circumstances, they may resort to secret methods.
('61', 394, 2, 12, 758218) Secrecy is inimical to the growth of the spirit of civil resistance.
('61', 394, 2, 13, 758287) If Congressmen will realize that all property is liable to be confiscated at any moment, they will learn to be utterly independent of it.
('61', 394, 3, 14, 758425) I quite agree with you that it is ludicrous for individuals to send notices to the local authorities of their intention to offer a particular form of civil disobedience.
('61', 394, 3, 15, 758595) We do not want to make a great movement ridiculous.
('61', 394, 3, 16, 758647) Therefore when civil resistance is offered it should be offered seriously and in an effective manner, in so far as this is possible, in furtherance of the Congress programme.
('61', 394, 4, 17, 758822) I notice one gap in your letter.
('61', 394, 4, 18, 758855) You make no mention of the various constructive activities of the Congress.
('61', 394, 4, 19, 758931) They became an integral part of the Congress programme that was framed after mature deliberations in 1920. With civil resistance as the background we cannot possibly do without the constructive activities such as communal unity, removal of untouchability and universalization of the spinning wheel and khaddar.
('61', 394, 4, 20, 759242) I am as strong as ever about these.
('61', 394, 4, 21, 759278) We must recognize that whilst the Congressmen can be counted by hundreds of thousands, civil resisters imprisoned have never amounted to more than one lakh at the outside.
('61', 394, 4, 22, 759450) I feel that there is something radically wrong if paralysis has overtaken the remaining lakhs.
('61', 394, 4, 23, 759545) There is nothing to be ashamed of in an open confession by those who for any reason whatsoever are unable to join the civil resisters’ ranks.
('61', 394, 4, 24, 759687) They are also serving the cause of the country and bringing it nearer to the goal who are engaged in any of the constructive activities I have named and several other kindred activities I can add to the list.
('61', 395, 0, 1, 759896) 396 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATM GANDHI
('61', 395, 1, 2, 759937) Ordinance or no Ordinance, if individual Congressmen and Congress women will learn the art of contributing their share to the work of building of the house of independence and realize their own importance, dark as the horizon seems to us, there is absolutely no cause for despair or disappointment.
('61', 395, 2, 3, 760236) Finally, if I can say so without incurring the risk of your accusing me of egotism, I would like to say that I have no sense of defeat in me and the hope in me that this country of ours is fast marching towards its goal is burning as bright as it did in 1920; for I have an undying faith in the efficacy of civil resistance.
('61', 395, 2, 4, 760561) But as you are aware, after full and prayerful consideration, I have decided not to take the offensive during the unexpired period of the sentence of imprisonment that was pronounced against me on the 4th of August last by the court that met in Yeravda Jail.
('61', 395, 2, 5, 760820) I need not go into the reasons as I have already issued a separate statement about it.
('61', 395, 2, 6, 760907) This personal suspension, although it may be misunderstood for a while, will show how and when it may become a duty.
('61', 395, 2, 7, 761024) And if it is a duty, it cannot possibly injure the cause.
('61', 395, 3, 8, 761082) Yours, BAPU JAWAHARLAL NEHRU POONA

('61', 396, 9, 15, 762106) I am going to Bombay.

('61', 396, 9, 23, 762427) I can drink two pounds of milk and eat fruit and vegetables.
('61', 396, 9, 24, 762488) My weight is 100 pounds.

('61', 398, 6, 9, 765753) 497. SOME QUESTIONS
('61', 398, 7, 10, 765773) I have several letters from Harijans, lying in my file, putting a number of questions.
('61', 398, 7, 11, 765860) I take up the most important.
('61', 398, 7, 12, 765890) Before answering them, I would like to warn correspondents against putting questions for the sake of putting them, or what is worse, of advertising themselves.
('61', 398, 7, 13, 766050) I would beseech them to avoid the vices or shortcomings of the so called superior classes or the so called caste Hindus.
('61', 398, 7, 14, 766171) I would like the yet very few Harijan workers to be above board, incorruptible and selfless, for they have to shoulder a tremendous burden.
('61', 398, 7, 15, 766311) Whilst, as I have repeatedly said in these columns, it is the duty of caste Hindus to rid themselves of the curse of untouchability, ultimately the salvation of Harijans will have to come from within.
('61', 398, 7, 16, 766512) In pursuance of the advice tendered by me, I withhold the names of my correspondents in anticipation of their approval of my action.
('61', 398, 8, 17, 766645) The first question I pick up is as follows:
('61', 398, 9, 18, 766689) Generally social work is being done in town areas, but practically
('61', 398, 10, 19, 766756) nothing is being done in the villages, though the latter are admittedly more in
('61', 398, 11, 20, 766836) What is to be done?
('61', 398, 12, 21, 766856) I am afraid that what the correspondent says is very largely true.
('61', 398, 12, 22, 766923) Unfortunately, workers are very few compared to the magnitude of the task before the reformer, and, the majority of workers being town bred, they are disinclined to go to the villages and settle there.
('61', 398, 13, 23, 767125) 1 Ranchhodlal Amritlal Shodhan, a mill owner 2 The addressee used to make envelopes out of waste paper as a hobby.
('61', 399, 0, 1, 767240) 400 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 399, 1, 2, 767282) The Central Board 1 is quite alive to the problem, and effort is being made of penetrate the villages, not without some success.
('61', 399, 1, 3, 767411) The answer, therefore, to the question, ‘what is to be done’, is that the effort has to be intensified.
('61', 399, 1, 4, 767515) Village workers have to be found or made and, when once the fear of settling in villages is overcome, the response to the demand for a large number of workers will be much greater than it is today.
('61', 399, 1, 5, 767713) Given continuance of the effort, success is bound to attend it.
('61', 399, 1, 6, 767777) The second question is:
('61', 399, 2, 7, 767801) Will it not hasten the removal of untouchability if caste Hindus took Harijans as domestic servants?
('61', 399, 2, 8, 767902) This is no new advice.
('61', 399, 2, 9, 767925) Swami Shraddhanandji used to lay very great emphasis on the necessity of caste Hindus employing Harijans as domestic servants precisely on the same terms as any other.
('61', 399, 2, 10, 768093) But I fear that receiving Harijans as domestic servants will be, when it becomes at all general, not a spur to the removal of untouchability, but a sign of removal.
('61', 399, 2, 11, 768258) Nevertheless, it is the duty of every reformer who has got rid of untouchability from his own household to have a Harijan domestic servant.
('61', 399, 2, 12, 768398) No doubt, for the reformer it would be better still if he would take a Harijan boy or girl, not as a servant, but as a member of his family.
('61', 399, 2, 13, 768539) The third question is:
('61', 399, 3, 14, 768562) What should Harijans do in the present drive against untouch ability?
('61', 399, 3, 15, 768632) I can only repeat the answer I have given so often before.
('61', 399, 3, 16, 768691) They should carry on vigorous internal reform among themselves and remove every cause of reproach.
('61', 399, 3, 17, 768790) The fourth question is:
('61', 399, 4, 18, 768814) In two villages of Kaira, Harijans have been boycotted by caste Hindus because they asked for adequate remuneration for carrying carcasses.
('61', 399, 4, 19, 768954) What should the Harijans do in such cases?
('61', 399, 4, 20, 768997) I am happy to be able to say that in one of these villages, owing to the efforts of workers of the local Society, the boycott was lifted, and the information as to the other village, at the time of writing this, is that there is every probability of a similar amicable settlement.
('61', 399, 4, 21, 769278) But assuming that in some villages caste Hindus remain obstinate and persist in boycotting Harijans, if the latter have any self consciousness they would persist in their refusal to render service without adequate
('61', 399, 5, 22, 769492) 1 Of the Harijan Sevak Sangh.
('61', 400, 0, 1, 769522) VOL. 61 : 27 APEIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 401
('61', 400, 1, 2, 769567) remuneration, and, if the boycott proves to be too hot for them, they would quietly vacate the offending village.
('61', 400, 1, 3, 769681) I know that this is easier said than done.
('61', 400, 1, 4, 769724) And I know also that there is not sufficient awakening among the Harijans to induce them to adopt the method suggested by me.
('61', 400, 1, 5, 769850) But I have also no doubt that the time is coming soon when caste Hindus will have to think a hundred times before resorting to such boycotts.
('61', 400, 1, 6, 769992) The fifth question is:
('61', 400, 2, 7, 770015) What has come out of your proposal that there should be an all India advisory board of Harijans to advise the Servants of Untouchables Society?
('61', 400, 2, 8, 770159) The proposal referred to was made by me in Ahmedabad.
('61', 400, 2, 9, 770213) It had reference to the Provincial Board, but what is true of the Provincial Board is also true of the Central Board.
('61', 400, 2, 10, 770331) It should be remembered that the advice was given to the Harijans and it is for them to make a move and appoint such committees.
('61', 400, 2, 11, 770460) I have no doubt that the Central Board and the Provincial organizations will function in a proper manner.
('61', 400, 2, 12, 770566) Much good can be done through them.
('61', 400, 3, 13, 770602) The sixth question is:
('61', 400, 4, 14, 770625) Do you know that some temples which had been opened to Harijans were subsequently closed against them?
('61', 400, 4, 15, 770728) What is your solution?
('61', 400, 4, 16, 770751) For the time being, we have to assume that such temples were opened under some sort of coercion or that the trustees have been since coercd into closing them against Harijans.
('61', 400, 4, 17, 770927) I know one or two instances of the latter kind.
('61', 400, 4, 18, 770975) My solution in either case is that for the time being we should suffer this deprivation.
('61', 400, 5, 19, 771064) The seventh question is:
('61', 400, 6, 20, 771089) The temple entry movement seems to have come to a dead stop.
('61', 400, 6, 21, 771150) Do you contemplate any move?
('61', 400, 6, 22, 771179) I do not think that the temple entry movement has suffered any such stop as the correspondent suggests.
('61', 400, 6, 23, 771283) The spectacular part of it is, no doubt, under check, but the effort for opening new temples and re opening old temples is steadily going forward, as the pages of the Harijan can show.
('61', 400, 7, 24, 771468) The eighth question is:
('61', 400, 8, 25, 771492) Will you be a party to a modification of the Yeravda Pact, if all the parties to it come to a common understanding?
('61', 401, 0, 1, 771608) 402 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 401, 1, 2, 771650) Naturally the Pact would be modified, but, so far as I am concerned, it can never be modified to the detriment of Harijans.
('61', 401, 1, 3, 771774) The ninth question is:
('61', 401, 2, 4, 771797) Neither the Bombay Government nor the public are giving effect to the Council resolution as to the opening of public wells to Harijans.
('61', 401, 2, 5, 771933) Will you advise satyagraha on their part?
('61', 401, 2, 6, 771975) In the first place, I have no definite information in the matter.
('61', 401, 2, 7, 772041) Secondly, I am unable to advise satyagraha, at the present stage at any rate.
('61', 401, 2, 8, 772119) The tenth and last question is:
('61', 401, 3, 9, 772151) Do you favour the idea of an all India conference of Harijan leaders for dealing with the question of untouchability?
('61', 401, 3, 10, 772269) A thoroughly representative conference cannot fail to be helpful.
('61', 401, 3, 11, 772335) I should, therefore, welcome the holding of such a conference.
('61', 401, 4, 12, 772398) Harijan, 16 9 1933
('61', 401, 5, 13, 772417) 498. LETTER TO MARGARETE SPIEGEL

('61', 401, 7, 15, 772469) AMALA 1,
('61', 401, 8, 16, 772478) I have your several letters.

('61', 401, 8, 18, 772547) Whatever I said and did at the Ashram was said and done in pure love and for your good.
('61', 401, 8, 19, 772635) Why should you fear me, if you believe what I say?
('61', 401, 8, 20, 772686) You have therefore no need to avoid me or fear me.
('61', 401, 8, 21, 772737) I am keeping well in spite of blood pressure.

('61', 402, 1, 2, 773009) 499. TALK WITH WOMEN WORKERS 1
('61', 402, 2, 3, 773040) [September 16, 1933] 2
('61', 402, 3, 4, 773063) I have been saying for years now that those who understand must participate in the production of khadi.
('61', 402, 3, 5, 773167) But the suggestion has not been taken up.
('61', 402, 3, 6, 773209) Had it been adopted, khadi activity would have now become widespread and we would not have had to face a difficult situation.
('61', 402, 3, 7, 773335) What would we lose if we span for half an hour every day?
('61', 402, 3, 8, 773393) But today it seems as though it were a mere waste.
('61', 402, 3, 9, 773444) Weavers who are willing to use hand spun yarn do not get it.
('61', 402, 3, 10, 773505) I had to tell some of them that I would arrange to get some for them.
('61', 402, 3, 11, 773575) But if they could not get it, they may use mill yarn.
('61', 402, 3, 12, 773629) I did not want them to lose their trade.
('61', 402, 3, 13, 773670) This half an hour of spinning demanded of you should be regarded as easy.
('61', 402, 3, 14, 773744) If people do not talk flatteringly when you go to sell them khadi, you should put up with their harshness.
('61', 402, 3, 15, 773851) You deserve it.
('61', 402, 3, 16, 773867) But if you do as I say, there would be no question of having to hear harsh things from them.
('61', 402, 4, 17, 773960) Q. When women used to spin, there was no arrangement for weaving.
('61', 402, 4, 18, 774026) That is true.
('61', 402, 4, 19, 774040) It was brought to my notice.
('61', 402, 4, 20, 774069) But what the women used to spin was no yarn at all—what about that?
('61', 402, 4, 21, 774137) If women were to spin ropes, what should the weavers do?
('61', 402, 4, 22, 774194) We have so many weaving centres.
('61', 402, 4, 23, 774227) So, the women themselves are to blame since they did not attempt to learn spinning.
('61', 402, 5, 24, 774311) [From Gujarati] Harijanbandhu, 24 9 1933

('61', 403, 5, 27, 776666) 4 Self criticism can be useful only in so far as it helps progress.
('61', 403, 5, 28, 776734) If we are not committing now all the heinous crimes that we
