('61', 404, 0, 1, 777300) VOL. 61 : 27 APEIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 405
('61', 404, 1, 2, 777345) may have committed in the past it would be as good as piling up those crimes if we wrung our soul by brooding over them.
('61', 404, 1, 3, 777466) I agree that we must publicly acknowledge a major crime.
('61', 404, 1, 4, 777523) A votary of truth can do nothing less.
('61', 404, 1, 5, 777562) But owning up of the crime should not leave any burden on one’s mind.
('61', 404, 1, 6, 777632) Having once washed off the accumulated dross, does one burden oneself with it?
('61', 404, 1, 7, 777711) But you seem to be doing something of the sort.
('61', 404, 1, 8, 777759) It is only when truth reveals itself through us that untruth cannot remain hidden from us.
('61', 404, 1, 9, 777850) But we cannot always find out what untruth is hidden in which part of our being.
('61', 404, 1, 10, 777931) My sole purpose in writing this is that you must cast off this burden from your mind.
('61', 404, 1, 11, 778017) That is the mark of bhakti.
('61', 404, 1, 12, 778045) 1 After having sought protection from God a bhakta 2 would never feel choked.

('61', 407, 2, 15, 784194) 505. WHAT SHOULD A BRAHMIN DO?
('61', 407, 3, 16, 784225) In response to my article 1 under the above heading, the same correspondent who hails from Maharashtra writes again as follows.
('61', 407, 4, 17, 784353) Many questions arise out of this letter.
('61', 407, 4, 18, 784394) It is not that the others do not have to suffer the inconveniences which Brahmins do suffer.
('61', 407, 4, 19, 784487) Nowadays everyone finds it more or less difficult to get employment.
('61', 407, 4, 20, 784556) Till now, Brahmins could easily find jobs.
('61', 407, 4, 21, 784599) That is not the case now.
('61', 407, 4, 22, 784625) There is no doubt that the others faced earlier the same situation which the Brahmins are or appear to be facing now.
('61', 407, 4, 23, 784743) Where castes prevail, such rise and fall will always be.
('61', 407, 4, 24, 784800) Hence it is difficult to satisfy everyone.
('61', 407, 4, 25, 784843) At the root of this difficulty lies something, which deserves consideration.
('61', 407, 4, 26, 784920) The number of jobs will always be limited.
('61', 407, 4, 27, 784963) The number of candidates will go on increasing with time.
('61', 407, 4, 28, 785021) Hence the right way seems to be to learn to turn away from jobs, turn towards othere occu pations and qualify ourselves for these.
('61', 407, 4, 29, 785152) In attempting such changes, difficulties will certainly be experienced during the transit ional period, but the result can only be good.
('61', 407, 4, 30, 785289) Other countries have had similar experiences and, those who were hitherto confined to jobs have taken to professions.
('61', 407, 5, 31, 785407) 1 Vide “What should a Brahmin do?”, 10 9 1933 2 The letter is not translated here.
('61', 407, 5, 32, 785490) The correspondent had argued that Brahmins could not earn livelihood by imparting the knowledge of Brahman as the general public was not interested in it; the only alternative was employment.
('61', 407, 5, 33, 785682) Brahmins did not expect any privileges while seeking jobs but at the same time they expected that they would not be penalized for being Brahmins.
('61', 408, 0, 1, 785828) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 409
('61', 408, 1, 2, 785872) Another noteworthy point is to cut down our expenses, reduce our family’s as well as our own wants.
('61', 408, 1, 3, 785972) The need to make our lives simple is becoming more and more obvious to the whole world.
('61', 408, 1, 4, 786060) There is an English adage recommending ‘plain living and high thinking’.
('61', 408, 1, 5, 786133) In India, simplicity is not just a virtue, it is part of dharma.
('61', 408, 1, 6, 786198) It is imperative that the women in the family also contribute towards the household expenditure to the best of their abilities.
('61', 408, 1, 7, 786326) Women of the working class, in addition to housekeeping,earn a little bit by their own labour; why should not other women do likewise?
('61', 408, 1, 8, 786461) If there is a lone earning member in a family and many mouths to feed, the burden on him cannot but be too much.
('61', 408, 1, 9, 786574) Hence, those Brahmins who find it difficult to secure employment should consider this suggestion also.

('61', 415, 4, 26, 803570) 512. ANOTHER PLAGUE SPOT
('61', 415, 5, 27, 803595) The reader may remember that some months ago I drew public attention to the disgraceful condition of the bastis of Allahabad.
('61', 415, 6, 28, 803721) Professor Malkani 2 has now sent me his impressions of the Delhi bastis.
('61', 415, 6, 29, 803794) They are published in The Hindustan Times.
('61', 415, 6, 30, 803837) These impressions show that the Delhi bastis are not much better than the Allahabad
('61', 415, 7, 31, 803921) 1Vide “Immediate Duty”, 22 4 1933 2 N. R. Malkani
('61', 416, 0, 1, 803971) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 417
('61', 416, 1, 2, 804015) There is the same tale of indescribable filth and consequent degradation.
('61', 416, 1, 3, 804089) The scavengers, on whose careful labour largely depends the health of the inhabitants of Delhi, are housed in cells which are windowless and lightless holes.
('61', 416, 1, 4, 804247) I cannot do better than reproduce Professor Malkani’s closing sentences 1: So long as we tolerate such plague spots and so long as we continue to treat most useful servants of society as if they were beyond the pale of humanity, there need be no wonder that we have more than our fair share of diseases which are due to filth and insanitation.
('61', 416, 1, 5, 804591) Even as a rotten limb affects and corrupts the whole body, so does the condition of scavengers, representing a rotten limb of society, corrupt the whole of it.
('61', 416, 1, 6, 804751) Unless, therefore, we wake up betimes and adopt summary measures to improve the condition of the scavengers, God’s judgment must overtake us.
('61', 416, 1, 7, 804893) This question of providing decent habitations for the scavengers is not merely for Hindus to tackle but it is for the society at large to deal with.
('61', 416, 1, 8, 805042) In this matter, therefore, there need be no distinction between reformers and the orthodox, or between Hindus and non Hindus.
('61', 416, 1, 9, 805168) Let us hope that the Delhi Municipality, now that its attention is drawn to the disgraceful condition of its bastis, will waste no time in taking energetic measures and removing the disgrace.
('61', 416, 1, 10, 805360) Harijan, 23 9 1933

('61', 419, 1, 4, 810235) In that case, why should he not hand it over to the people?
('61', 419, 1, 5, 810295) I say this because I have acted on this principle.
('61', 419, 1, 6, 810346) I used to think that I had been practising law for the sake of the people.
('61', 419, 1, 7, 810421) But then I wondered why I should not devote to the service of the people the time I spent in practising law.
('61', 419, 1, 8, 810530) That is why I gave up my practice.
('61', 419, 1, 9, 810565) Whatever money I had in reserve, I used to spend for the people.
('61', 419, 1, 10, 810630) Then I thought, “Why not hand over to the people what is to be used for them?” Again, I thought why I should not form a trust for the use of money if it was to be given away.

('61', 419, 2, 29, 811926) God does not ask of us more than that.

('61', 419, 2, 33, 812100) That at least is the test I would propose.

('61', 419, 2, 39, 812488) If I wanted to serve the peole, what need did I have for money?
('61', 419, 2, 40, 812552) At least a few people must come forward who would voluntarily accept poverty.
('61', 419, 2, 41, 812630) Please forgive me for talking to you in such plain words.

('61', 420, 4, 5, 812900) [ Before September 24, 1933]
('61', 420, 5, 6, 812929) I would like to tell all the men and women who have come to attend the prayer that if the Government allows me to remain free, I would devote myself mainly to Harijan work.
('61', 420, 5, 7, 813102) And so, it is my duty to beg for the sake of the Harijans.
('61', 420, 5, 8, 813161) Men and women who come to attend the prayers may bring with them whatever they feel like and whatever they can afford.
('61', 420, 5, 9, 813280) It serves two purposes: some amount is collected for Harijans, and then, we have an idea as to how many persons give for the service of Harijans and how many approve of the work.
('61', 420, 5, 10, 813459) I do not want a single pie from those who do not approve of this work.
('61', 420, 5, 11, 813530) If anyone gave for my sake, it would be meaningless.
('61', 420, 5, 12, 813583) Hence, I wish that only those people who have faith in this work should donate money.

('61', 420, 8, 16, 813761) MY DEAR JAWAHARLAL, I had a talk today with Jamnalalji about the proposed match.
('61', 420, 8, 17, 813842) He seems to know the family well.
('61', 420, 8, 18, 813876) He is decidedly of opinion that the family, apart from Kasturbhai of course, is not as well off as they would appear to be.
('61', 420, 8, 19, 814000) He is even of opinion that they may be actually in want.
('61', 420, 8, 20, 814057) I thought I should pass this news on to you.

('61', 425, 1, 2, 822473) 521. APPEAL FOR FLOOD RELIEF IN ORISSA
('61', 425, 2, 3, 822512) September 24, 1933
('61', 425, 3, 4, 822531) Appealing for funds for the relief of flood stricken Orissa, Mr. Gandhi says that the affected area covers two thousand miles.
('61', 425, 3, 5, 822658) The people affected number three lakhs.
('61', 425, 3, 6, 822698) One thousand five hundred villages have been destroyed.
('61', 425, 3, 7, 822754) Twenty thousand houses have collapsed and the damage is estimated at Rs. 15,00,000. Mr. Gandhi says that it would be necessary to provide relief to people actually in want of food and clothing for twelve months, for they will not have, till the next year’s crops are ready, the wherewithal to keep body and soul together.
('61', 425, 3, 8, 823076) At least, five lakhs of rupees will be required to help those who can be proved to be clearly indigent.
('61', 425, 3, 9, 823180) The Indian Annual Register, July December 1933, Vol. II, p.

('61', 431, 7, 10, 831999) 533. LETTER TO AGATHA HARRISON
('61', 431, 8, 11, 832030) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, WARDHA, September 29, 1933
('61', 431, 9, 12, 832076) MY DEAR AGATHA,
('61', 431, 10, 13, 832092) I know I have not been fair to you.
('61', 431, 10, 14, 832128) You have been pouring letters on me, and I have been satisfied with merely sending you a line.
('61', 431, 10, 15, 832223) The fact is that I have not yet regained all the lost energy, and what there is of it has to be devoted to the immediate work at hand.
('61', 431, 10, 16, 832358) Hence, I have to neglect many things that I would otherwise have done.
('61', 431, 10, 17, 832429) Your letters have come under the category of neglected ones.
('61', 431, 10, 18, 832490) I have relied upon Andrews and Mira for writing to you.
('61', 431, 10, 19, 832546) But your two letters, those of 9th and 16th inst., demand a fairly full answer from me.
('61', 431, 10, 20, 832634) I understand all that you say and that you have omitted to say about the Midnapore incident.
('61', 431, 10, 21, 832727) I hope that you got copies of all the statements made by me.
('61', 431, 10, 22, 832788) I offer no apology for what I have said about Midnapore.
('61', 431, 10, 23, 832845) 1 I could say nothing less and nothing more; for that statement contained cent per cent truth.
('61', 431, 10, 24, 832940) But how is one to overtake the deliberate campaign of misrepresentation?
('61', 431, 10, 25, 833013) Every word that I say is distorted.
('61', 431, 10, 26, 833049) Where distortion is not possible they do not hesitate to cut out sentences from my statements, which would make them read differently from what they would if they were read in conjunction with the sentences cut out.
('61', 431, 10, 27, 833265) But I remain unmoved by these tactics.
('61', 431, 11, 28, 833304) 1 Vide “Statement to the Press”, 3 9 1933.
('61', 432, 0, 1, 833347) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 433
('61', 432, 1, 2, 833391) They are not new to me.
('61', 432, 1, 3, 833415) I have boundless faith in my mission and in my own truth.
('61', 432, 1, 4, 833473) The only thing, therefore, to do is not to enter into an elaborate explanation, for it means nothing, but on due occasion to repeat the same truth with added emphasis.
('61', 432, 1, 5, 833641) The position of friends in England is somewhat different.
('61', 432, 1, 6, 833699) They are naturally anxious to show some result.
('61', 432, 1, 7, 833747) I would, however, ask friends on such occasions to remain unperturbed, because at the present moment yours will be a voice in the wilderness, and if you attempted to be apologetic about what I might have said, you would be doing an injury to the cause.
('61', 432, 1, 8, 834000) I am trying a tremendous experiment.
('61', 432, 1, 9, 834037) Non violence regulates every breath of my life.
('61', 432, 1, 10, 834085) I do not embellish what I write.
('61', 432, 1, 11, 834118) I conceal nothing.
('61', 432, 1, 12, 834137) Therefore, I would not like friends excusing any action or word of mine.
('61', 432, 1, 13, 834210) When they do not understand it they may remain silent.
('61', 432, 1, 14, 834265) When they disagree, after having all the facts and after having weighed them, I would not mind their open disapproval.
('61', 432, 1, 15, 834384) It would really serve the cause.
('61', 432, 1, 16, 834417) Take this Midnapore statement.
('61', 432, 1, 17, 834448) I know that terrorism is taking a deeper root owing to the counterterrorism of the Government.
('61', 432, 1, 18, 834543) The counter terrorism is much more mischievous in its effect, because it is organized and corrupts a whole people.
('61', 432, 1, 19, 834658) Instead of rooting out terrorism it creates an atmosphere for the approval of terrorist methods and thus gives them an artificial stimulus.
('61', 432, 1, 20, 834798) It may not show immediate results, but it certainly prepares the future for wider activities along those lines.
('61', 432, 1, 21, 834910) Hence, it is necessary to bring out this point forcibly when any eruption takes place as that of Midnapore, and if the truth cannot be said forcibly, it is obvious that silence is the only alternative.
('61', 432, 1, 22, 835112) A half hearted operation is much more dangerous than no operation.
('61', 432, 1, 23, 835179) I say all this with my knowledge of non violence and of ascertained facts.
('61', 432, 1, 24, 835254) Then take my fast, or rather all the recent fasts.
('61', 432, 1, 25, 835305) If friends over there have not understood them to the extent of being able to justify them, they could ignore them, or, having procured all the materials for a judgment, if the judgment went against me, they should not hesitate to pronounce it, and if they endorse them, then their approval should be unequivocal.
('61', 432, 1, 26, 835619) You are there in a hopeless minority.
('61', 432, 1, 27, 835657) All I wish, therefore, for you is to be firm in whatever action you take, that is, if you have faith in yourselves, in the Indian cause and in me through whom today the cause is represented to you.
('61', 432, 1, 28, 835855) I shall never misunderstand you.
('61', 432, 1, 29, 835888) I know that whatever you, a mere handful, do you will do whole heartedly.
('61', 432, 1, 30, 835962) More than that I do not expect, no one can or should.
('61', 433, 0, 1, 836016) 434 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 433, 1, 2, 836058) I do not know whether I have made myself clearly understood by you.
('61', 433, 1, 3, 836126) If I have failed, you should dismiss this letter from your mind and tell me where you have not understood me.
('61', 433, 1, 4, 836236) As for my health I am slowly regaining strength.
('61', 433, 1, 5, 836285) I am supposed to have quiet and rest at least up to the 23rd October after which, if all goes well, a touring programme will be fixed up.

('61', 436, 4, 6, 840626) 540. NEED FOR A DEFINITION
('61', 436, 5, 7, 840653) A curious case was filed in the Court of the Munsif of Orai.
('61', 436, 5, 8, 840714) The suit was in respect of the official nomination of a Mussalman as a representative of the Harijans of Konch and was brought by three Harijans against the Secretary of State for India in Council and others, for unseating the nominated member and for a declaration that, under the Municipalities Act, only a Hindu Harijan could be nominated.
('61', 436, 5, 9, 841057) The judgment of the Court went against the plaintiff, owing to the proverbial uncertainty of law.
('61', 436, 5, 10, 841155) I do not propose to examine the merits of the judgment.
('61', 436, 5, 11, 841211) I simply want the public to know and realize that the law is not only uncertain about the definition of the Harijan class, described in the judgment as ‘depressed classes’, but there is as yet, if the judgment is correct, no legal definition at all of the term.
('61', 436, 5, 12, 841473) If such is the case, it is not difficult to understand that this want of definition may easily lead to gross injustice or even more deplorable results.
('61', 436, 5, 13, 841625) It can be a fruitful source of irritation and internal quarrels; quarrels between caste Hindus and Harijans, between Harijans and Harijans, and between Hindus and non Hindus.
('61', 436, 5, 14, 841800) If untouchability is not to be clothed with statutory sanction, it is surely necessary for the public to concentrate their attention on arriving at a proper defintition.
('61', 436, 5, 15, 841970) The reader will understand my meaning more fully,if he carefully studies the following extract 5 from the judgment I have referred to.
('61', 436, 6, 16, 842105) Harijan, 30 9 1933
('61', 436, 7, 17, 842124) 1 Nirmala, step sister of Mahadev Desai 2 Sharda, daughter of Chimanlal Shah 3 Son and daughter of Narhari Parikh 4 ibid.
('61', 436, 7, 18, 842246) 5 Not reproduced here.
('61', 436, 7, 19, 842269) It was stated in the judgment: “The phrase ‘depressed classes’ is nowhere defined in the body of the Municipalities Act.
('61', 436, 7, 20, 842390) The court is not aware that there exists any legal definition of this phrase as yet recognized by law...
('61', 437, 0, 1, 842495) 438 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 437, 1, 2, 842537) 541. HARIJAN BOARDING HOUSES
('61', 437, 2, 3, 842566) The manager of a Harijan boarding house writes: 1
('61', 437, 3, 4, 842616) This is an old tale.
('61', 437, 3, 5, 842637) I have no doubt that in every boarding house for students, all labour, including scavenging, should be performed by the boarders.
('61', 437, 3, 6, 842767) Such a plan does not interfere with the boarders’ studies.
('61', 437, 3, 7, 842826) Indeed, it adds reality to them and promotes the health of the students,and saves money into the bargain.
('61', 437, 3, 8, 842932) Those managers, therefore, who, for the sake of gaining cheap popularity, or, being too lazy to discuss such matters with their students, will not induce the latter to perform all the necessary labour for their homes, will be doing a distinct disservice to their wards.
('61', 437, 3, 9, 843202) Such labour should be regarded as part of the students’ education.
('61', 437, 3, 10, 843269) But there is one condition attached to the demand upon students to do the daily labour.
('61', 437, 3, 11, 843357) Then there will be no danger of “the low mentality worsening”.
('61', 437, 3, 12, 843420) Harijan, 30 9 1933
('61', 437, 4, 13, 843439) 542. LETTER TO G. D. BIRLA
('61', 437, 5, 14, 843466) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, WARDHA, September 30, 1933
('61', 437, 6, 15, 843512) DEAR GHANSHYAMDAS, As you are aware, the ‘Satyagraha Ashram’ grounds with the buildings in Sabarmati were abandoned on the 1st of August last by the Ashram people.
('61', 437, 6, 16, 843676) I had expected that the Government would, in view of my letter 2 addressed to them take charge of this abandoned property, but they did not do so.
('61', 437, 6, 17, 843823) It then became a question with me as to what was my duty in the circumstances.
('61', 437, 6, 18, 843902) I felt that it was wrong altogether to allow the valuable buildings to waste.
('61', 437, 6, 19, 843980) I consulted friends and co workers and came to the conclusion that the best use to make of the Ashram was to dedicate it once for all for the service of the Harijans.
('61', 437, 6, 20, 844147) I placed my proposal before the trustees 3 of the Ashram who are out, as also fellow members.
('61', 437, 6, 21, 844241) They have, I am happy to say, whole heartedly approved of it.
('61', 437, 6, 22, 844303) When the property was abandoned there certainly was the expectation that some day, whether through an
('61', 437, 7, 23, 844405) 1 The letter is not reproduced here.
('61', 437, 7, 24, 844442) The correspondent had asked if Gandhiji considered it objectionable “to ask the inmates to clean the vessels”.
('61', 437, 7, 25, 844553) 2 Dated July 26, Vide “Letter to Home Secretary, Government of Bombay” 26 7 1933. 3 Jamnala Bajaj and Chhaganlal Gandhi
('61', 438, 0, 1, 844673) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 439
('61', 438, 1, 2, 844717) honourable settlement or India coming to her own, the trustees would resume possession.
('61', 438, 1, 3, 844805) Under the new proposal, the trustees divest themselves entirely of the property.
('61', 438, 1, 4, 844886) This procedure is permissible under the Trust deed 1, service of the Harijans being one of the objects of the trust.
('61', 438, 1, 5, 845003) Therefore, the new proposal is wholly in keeping with the letter and spirit of the constitution 2 of the Ashram, as also of the Trust.
('61', 438, 2, 6, 845138) The question that the trustees and I had to consider was, to whom was the property to be tansferred for the specific use I have mentioned; and we came unanimously to the conclusion that it should be transferred to the all India Harijan organization for all India use.
('61', 438, 2, 7, 845406) The objects of the Trust are: (i) to settle on the Ashram ground approved Harijan families subject to regulations to be framed; (ii) to open a hostel for Harijan boys and girls with liberty to take non Harijans; (iii) to conduct a technological department for teaching the art of skinning carcasses, tanning the hide so obtained, curing it and mnufacturing leather so prepared into shoes, sandals and other articles of daily use; and lastly to use the premises as offices for the Central Board or the Gujarat provincial organization or both, and such other allied uses that the committee, referred to in the following paragraph, may think proper.
('61', 438, 2, 8, 846053) On behalf of the trustees, I suggest that the Servants of Untouchables Society should appoint a special committee with yourself and the Secretary as ex officio members, and three Ahmedabad citizens, with power to this committee to add to their number to take over this Trust and to give effect to its objects.
('61', 438, 3, 9, 846363) Two friends who have been always associated with the Ashram, viz, Sjts.
('61', 438, 3, 10, 846435) Budhabhai and Juthabhai, have offered to reside on the premises as honorary managers.
('61', 438, 3, 11, 846521) They have their own means and have been devoted to the service of the Harijans for a long time.
('61', 438, 3, 12, 846617) There is also an inmate 3 of the Ashram, who has dedicated his life to Harijan service, and who will gladly stay on the premises.
('61', 438, 3, 13, 846747) He has almost become a specialist as a teacher of Harijan boys and girls.
('61', 438, 3, 14, 846821) The committee I have suggested, therefore, should have no difficulty in managing the Trust; nor is it necessary that all the activities I have mentioned should be simultaneously and immediately undertaken.
('61', 438, 4, 15, 847027) 1 Vide “Ashram Trust Deed”, 2 2 1926. 2 Vide “Satyagraha Ashram”, 14 6 1928. 3 Bhagwanji Purushottam Pandya who had left Burma to settle in the Ashram
('61', 439, 0, 1, 847178) 440 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 439, 1, 2, 847220) Some Harijan families, as you are aware, are already living there.
('61', 439, 1, 3, 847287) It has long been a dream of the members of the ashram to establish a colony of Harijan families, but beyond having a few of them we were not able to make further progress.
('61', 439, 1, 4, 847459) Experiments in tanning were also conducted there.
('61', 439, 1, 5, 847509) Manufacture of sandals was going on up to the time of disbandment.
('61', 439, 1, 6, 847576) The buildings contain a spacious hostel easily accommodating 100 boarders.
('61', 439, 1, 7, 847651) It has a fairly big weaving shed and other buildings exceptionally fitted for the uses I have named.
('61', 439, 1, 8, 847752) The property contains 100 acres.
('61', 439, 1, 9, 847785) I venture to say, therefore, that the site is none too large for the fulfilment of the objects mentioned, but it is large enough for the response that may be reasonably expected for some time to come.
('61', 439, 1, 10, 847986) I hope that the Society will have no objection to accept the offer of the trustees and to take over the responsibility implied in the acceptance.

('61', 443, 6, 26, 854588) 549. VARNADHARMA OF THE FUTURE
('61', 443, 7, 27, 854619) A “Sanatani” 2 Writes: 3
('61', 443, 8, 28, 854644) It is difficult to give a straight answer to the question posed here.
('61', 443, 8, 29, 854714) Only a prophet could do it.
('61', 443, 8, 30, 854742) Others can only hazard a guess.
('61', 443, 8, 31, 854774) For me.
('61', 443, 8, 32, 854782) awareness of the present and conduct in accordance with it, are sufficient.
('61', 443, 8, 33, 854858) Theists as well as atheists can honestly sing: Enjoy who you
('61', 443, 9, 34, 854919) 1 This presumably is the note referred to by Gandhiji in “Letter to Amrital V. Thakkar”, 14 10 1933. 2 A pen name 3 The letter is not translated here.
('61', 443, 9, 35, 855070) The correspondent, referring to the article “To The Harijans of Gujarat” (vide “To the Harijans of Gujarat”20 8 1933) had expressed his doubts about the revival of varnadharma in its true spirit.
('61', 444, 0, 1, 855266) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 445
('61', 444, 1, 2, 855310) get today, for who knows about tomorrow?” Whereas the atheist’s pleasure merely consists of eating, drinking and enjoying himself, the theist would be pleased to forget himself in devotion to the Lord, that is, in the duty which falls to his lot.
('61', 444, 1, 3, 855557) I regard myself as a theist and find fulfilment in making the best of what I can do today.
('61', 444, 1, 4, 855648) As we sow, so shall we reap,that is, the future will follow the present— that is a certainty.
('61', 444, 1, 5, 855742) Hence, I am not worried about the future of varnadharma.
('61', 444, 1, 6, 855799) I would also ask “Sanatani” not to worry about it.
('61', 444, 1, 7, 855850) Those like me who believe in varnadharma and accept my definition of it should think and act accordingly, and they would be said to have observed their dharma in respect of varna.
('61', 444, 1, 8, 856030) Moreover, there is another thing which also deserves to be borne in mind.
('61', 444, 1, 9, 856104) The basic tenets of any religion should be such as could be applied universally.
('61', 444, 1, 10, 856185) Those which do not fulfil this condition cannot be regarded as the basic tenets.
('61', 444, 1, 11, 856266) If varnadharma is not such a principle, it owes its origin to certain time, place and circumstances, and, if one of them should change, it must itself change.
('61', 444, 1, 12, 856425) If the varna is a device which is so short lived, no thought need be given to whether it should continue to exist or not but I regard the varnadharma as defined by me as a universal principle.
('61', 444, 1, 13, 856618) The existence of human society depends upon it.
('61', 444, 1, 14, 856666) If my viewpoint is based on facts, varnadharma will certainly become universal in future, although it may then be called by some other name.
('61', 444, 1, 15, 856807) Varnadharma implies that everyone must ramain content with his hereditary means of livelihood.
('61', 444, 1, 16, 856902) At the root of this scheme of things there is non violence, the Divine law, simple economics and human reason.
('61', 444, 1, 17, 857013) If it is not followed, a civil war, the like of which as never been seen, is bound to overtake us.
('61', 444, 1, 18, 857112) As millions of people awaken, they will all want to become rich, they will all want to attain greatness, no one will want to take up professions which are regarded as low and class feelings will intensify.
('61', 444, 1, 19, 857318) I for one feel that this could lead to no result other than fratricidal conflicts.
('61', 444, 1, 20, 857401) However, as the instinct for self preservation is ingrained in human nature, man will escape this fate by taking recourse to varnadharma.
('61', 444, 1, 21, 857539) Everyone will live practising the profession to which he is born, without regarding any profession as high or low.
('61', 444, 1, 22, 857654) In that case it would matter little if people were to be known not as Brahmins or Kshatriyas but by some other names.
('61', 444, 1, 23, 857772) Instead of four, there may be only two varnas, or, even more than four.
('61', 444, 1, 24, 857844) One thing is obvious—that by observing the great law of varna, we guard ourselves against conflicts arising out of capitalism communism, etc, In such a structure,
('61', 445, 0, 1, 858007) 446 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 445, 1, 2, 858049) there would not be, on the one hand, excessive greed, concentration of wealth or arrogance and, on the other helplessness, destitution or poverty.
('61', 445, 1, 3, 858196) All would live in harmony and no one would regard anyone else as high or low.
('61', 445, 1, 4, 858274) Having written this, let my fancy range a little farther.
('61', 445, 1, 5, 858332) If anyone entrusted me with reconstructing a varna system and I happened to be in India, I would start with the Brahmins.
('61', 445, 1, 6, 858454) If they become the custodians of knowledge derived from experience and of the code of conduct to be based on it, the other varnas would automatically fall into position.
('61', 445, 1, 7, 858624) The Brahmins’ knowledge being self evident and themselves being free from selfish motives, others will readily follow them.
('61', 445, 1, 8, 858748) Besides, they will also have the power to influence others.
('61', 445, 1, 9, 858808) The question as to who should be called a Brahmin will not arise.
('61', 445, 1, 10, 858874) The so called Harijan of today may become a Brahmin respected by all and the so called Brahmin may not shrink from calling himself a Shudra.
('61', 445, 1, 11, 859015) I shall encounter no obstacle in this age of my fancy, because the feeling of ‘high’ and ‘low’ will then have been wholly uprooted and as all will be following their hereditary professions, they will soon take their own places.
('61', 445, 1, 12, 859243) There is not much point in prolonging the flight of my fancy.
('61', 445, 1, 13, 859305) Hence, I conclude after thus indicating the way.
('61', 445, 1, 14, 859354) However, this article of mine should mean that, since varnadharma has been accepted as a non violent institution, there is no room in it for penal measures or for the use of force.
('61', 445, 1, 15, 859535) If varnadharma is ingrained in human nature, it will revive spontaneously.
('61', 445, 1, 16, 859610) If it runs contrary to human nature, it is in the fitness of things that it has disappeared now.
('61', 445, 1, 17, 859707) Here we are talking of man, not as a certain species of animals, but as one that is progressively shedding the animal qualities and who, having come out of his delusion, is directing all efforts towards the realization of atman.
('61', 445, 1, 18, 859936) Man is an animal created to discover his atman, and as atman all men are one.
('61', 445, 1, 19, 860014) Hence, at some time or the other, man will rid himself of the mire of high and low and, of his own accord, accept varnadharma which fosters unity.
('61', 445, 2, 20, 860161) [From Gujarati] Harijanbandhu, 1 10 1933
('61', 446, 0, 1, 860202) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 447

('61', 449, 4, 8, 864194) 558. LETTER TO C. F. ANDREWS
('61', 449, 5, 9, 864223) Unrevised SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, WARDHA,
('61', 449, 6, 10, 864260) October 3, 1933
('61', 449, 7, 11, 864276) MY DEAR CHARLIE,
('61', 449, 8, 12, 864293) I have your letter.
('61', 449, 8, 13, 864313) I understand what you say about the better and responsive atmosphere is Orissa and I am glad of it.
('61', 449, 8, 14, 864413) Thakkar Bapa cannot possibly go to Orissa at least just now, but the next best man will be there within a short time.
('61', 449, 8, 15, 864531) I corrected your use of the expression ‘fast unto death’, but I see that you have returned to it again.
('61', 449, 8, 16, 864635) I told you that hitherto all my fasts have been conditional; even the last one 1 was conditional.
('61', 449, 8, 17, 864733) I can well understand anybody being repelled by an unconditional fast unto death, though I have told you that in my scheme of life even an unconditional fast, under very extraordinary circumstances, has a place, but I don’t need to argue out that extreme position.
('61', 449, 8, 18, 864998) All I want to say is that in your discussion with Gurudev you should take care to avoid arguments around a ‘fast unto death’, taking the expression literally.
('61', 449, 8, 19, 865157) Therefore, the best thing would be to centre your discussion around all my fasts which Gurudev has not been able to reconcile himself to, as perhaps the last one, and there too it would be one thing to say that the facts hitherto known will not justify the fast, and another thing to say that under no circumstances could a fast over the Harijan issue, such as I raised at Yeravda, be justified.
('61', 449, 8, 20, 865553) I have before me a most painful but interesting case in which I have invited a worker to take a penitential fast for the sake of truth and invited a worker to take a penitential fast for the sake of truth and honour.
('61', 449, 9, 21, 865770) 1 From August 16 to 23.

('61', 451, 8, 20, 868196) October 4, 1933
('61', 451, 9, 21, 868212) I was glad to be able to see you and have interesting conversations.
('61', 451, 9, 22, 868281) I have carefully gone through your long letter to me.
('61', 451, 9, 23, 868335) I can fully appreciate your desire to see that Buddhism is revived in India; only, I would like to point out to you that whatever Buddhism may mean, the substance of the teaching of Gautama, the
('61', 451, 10, 24, 868530) 1 Omission as in the source 2Vide “letter to G. D. Birla”, 30 9 1933, which appeared in Harijan, 7 10 1993. 3 Totaram Sanadhya, an Ashram inmate 4 The name is omitted in the source.
('61', 451, 10, 25, 868712) Fuji and Rev.
('61', 451, 10, 26, 868726) Okitsu met Gandhiji on October 4. A brief report of the interview appeared in The Hindu, 5 10 1933.
('61', 452, 0, 1, 868826) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 453
('61', 452, 1, 2, 868869) Enlightened One, has been incorporated in Hinduism, and in my opinion, comparatively speaking, the purity of the teaching of that great reformer has been best preserved in India.
('61', 452, 1, 3, 869048) In the countries of its adoption it has, as it seems to me, deteriorated: as for instance, Buddha’s teaching essentially was not merely Brotherhood of Man but the Brotherhood of all Life.
('61', 452, 1, 4, 869236) Nor is this to be wondered at.
('61', 452, 1, 5, 869267) In my opinion, Buddha did not found a new religion.
('61', 452, 1, 6, 869319) As a Hindu of Hindus, he gave a new orientation to Hinduism.
('61', 452, 1, 7, 869380) I would, therefore, suggest to you that you should amplify your knowlege of that teaching by studying Sanskrit and Pali.
('61', 452, 1, 8, 869501) A study of Sanskrit is necessary for knowing the setting in which the teaching was fitted and from which it was derived, and it is obvious that a study of Pali is necessary because the original scriptures are to be found in that language.
('61', 452, 1, 9, 869740) And, since you have decided to cast in your lot with the Indian people, I would commend to your attention the necessity of learning Hindi or Hindustani.
('61', 452, 1, 10, 869893) Lastly, may I suggest to you that whatever religious revival may be necessary, it can only be done not by eloquence, not by learning, but by daily increase in the purity of one’s life and a prayerful reliance upon the Great Intelligence, the Living Truth that animates, illumines and sustains the universe.
('61', 452, 2, 11, 870200) The Hindu, 12 10 1933

('61', 453, 1, 2, 870778) 563. LETTER TO AMRITLAL V. THAKKAR
('61', 453, 2, 3, 870813) WARDHA, October 6, 1933
('61', 453, 3, 4, 870837) BHAISHRI THAKKAR BAPA,
('61', 453, 4, 5, 870860) I got both your letters.
('61', 453, 4, 6, 870885) I am glad you reminded me about Bidhan Roy.
('61', 453, 4, 7, 870929) My memory seems to be slumbering.
('61', 453, 4, 8, 870963) If you had not reminded me, I would have cleanly forgotten about the matter.
('61', 453, 4, 9, 871040) Now a letter will go immediately tomorrow.
('61', 453, 4, 10, 871083) And now about the tour.
('61', 453, 4, 11, 871107) Ghanshyamdas writes and tells me that I should not start before November 15. Dr. Khare 1 also has been insisting that I should take rest for at least six weeks.
('61', 453, 4, 12, 871268) I, therefore, have agreed not to start before November 8. I will start on Wednesday, the 8th.
('61', 453, 4, 13, 871362) This has satisfied Jamnalalji.
('61', 453, 4, 14, 871393) I also feel that there will be no harm if I rest till the 8th.
('61', 453, 4, 15, 871456) Meanwhile, I will be able to attend to some work which has been pending with me.
('61', 453, 4, 16, 871537) I shall also have to think about the Harijan settlement.
('61', 453, 4, 17, 871594) Then there is the problem of the workers in Ahmedabad, and some matters here, too, which require my attention.
('61', 453, 4, 18, 871705) If, therefore, you think that this delay is justified, please make the necessary changes in the programme.
('61', 453, 4, 19, 871812) Draw up the entire programme of the tour as follows.
('61', 453, 4, 20, 871865) Let Jamnalalji draw up model programme for the Central Provinces in consultation with the local workers.
('61', 453, 4, 21, 871970) Assign to the other provinces their respective weeks and ask them to draw up their own programmes.
('61', 453, 4, 22, 872069) If this is done, it will not be necessary to make changes afterwards.
('61', 453, 4, 23, 872139) When the programme is ready, we need not publish the whole programme for nine months at a time but publish in advance the programme for one province only, so that, if we find it necessary to make minor changes, there may be no difficulty.
('61', 453, 4, 24, 872378) If we follow this method, we may publish the programme for just two provinces together and afterwards the programme for the next province as soon as we have finished one.
('61', 453, 4, 25, 872549) This will also make the work easier.
('61', 453, 4, 26, 872586) I will write more after Jamnalalji is ready with his suggestions.
('61', 453, 4, 27, 872652) And now about the Harijan settlement, namely, what name we should give to it.
('61', 453, 4, 28, 872730) I feel that we should not use the word Harijan, but that our aim should be clear in the name that we select.
('61', 453, 4, 29, 872839) Our ultimate aim is that we should stop using the name Harijan, or that all of us
('61', 453, 5, 30, 872921) 1 Dr. N. B. Khare
('61', 454, 0, 1, 872939) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 455
('61', 454, 1, 2, 872982) should become Harijans.
('61', 454, 1, 3, 873006) Hence Vinoba has suggested the name Sarvodaya 1 Mandir, or Samabhava 1 Mandir.
('61', 454, 1, 4, 873085) I naturally like the first name, for I called Ruskin’s famous book 2 by the name Sarvodaya as far back as 20 years ago.
('61', 454, 1, 5, 873205) That name, therefore, will include Harijans.
('61', 454, 1, 6, 873250) Discuss the suggestion with Ghanshyamdas and let me know.
('61', 454, 1, 7, 873308) Explain to him the other thing, too, which I have mentioned in this letter.
('61', 454, 1, 8, 873384) I am very happy that Bhai Babal 3 listened to your advice and mine.
('61', 454, 1, 9, 873452) If he had not withdrawn his name, a very embarrassing situation would have arisen.
('61', 454, 2, 10, 873535) BAPU [PS.] We need not make any provision for Delhi, as we need not make any for Kathiawar.
('61', 454, 2, 11, 873627) I had heard all about Shrivastavaji’s performance long ago.
('61', 454, 2, 12, 873687) But to whom can we complain when our own people turn against us?

('61', 457, 4, 5, 877835) 569. NOTES
('61', 457, 5, 6, 877846) HOW TO COLLECT FUNDS Many workers of institutions think that they can get funds for their institutions for the mere issuing of appeals.
('61', 457, 5, 7, 877982) But that is true only of very few well known and tried workers.
('61', 457, 5, 8, 878046) A Muller or a Ramakrishna has been known to get funds even for the silent praying.
('61', 457, 5, 9, 878129) Mere mute wishes of such rare saints reach people like irresistible wireless messages.
('61', 457, 5, 10, 878216) But the majority have to plod before they can get any response.
('61', 457, 5, 11, 878280) And the best way of plodding is to pay house to house visits.
('61', 457, 5, 12, 878342) When a cause is just, as ours undoubtedly is, and the worker is known for his or her integrity, response is assured.
('61', 457, 5, 13, 878459) Such house to house begging is also the best propaganda.
('61', 457, 5, 14, 878516) Donors are, and should be always exacting.
('61', 457, 5, 15, 878559) They want to know, or ought to want to know, all the needs of the institution they are called upon to support.
('61', 457, 5, 16, 878670) Therefore, workers who go on begging expeditions have to be well armed with facts and figures.
('61', 457, 5, 17, 878765) What is, however, most needed is patience.
('61', 457, 5, 18, 878808) They must be prepared even to put up with insults.
('61', 457, 5, 19, 878859) In the end they will find that funds cause the least difficulty when honesty and ability are assured.
('61', 457, 5, 20, 878961) In the absence of these two qualities, funds are a burden as we find today regarding many so called religious institutions which are decaying, though they have ample funds.
('61', 457, 5, 21, 879134) Unscrupulous and indolent trustees are ill able to discharge their trust, and the moneys in their hands are either locked up profitlessly or wasted on irreligious orgies or other superstitious practices.
('61', 457, 5, 22, 879338) A SUGGESTION FROM AMERICA An American friend, who knows Indian conditions somewhat and is deeply interested in Harijan work, writes in reply to a letter from me: 1
('61', 457, 6, 23, 879502) 1 Only extract from the letter are reproduced here.
('61', 458, 0, 1, 879554) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 459
('61', 458, 1, 2, 879597) I feel that where there is room the reports would be more effective if, in addition to telling what has been done, they would also compare it with the previous conditions.
('61', 458, 1, 3, 879769) Also to tell the approximate number of Harijans in each such locality, so as to show how many people the new facilities will serve and how adequate or inadequate even the improvement is.
('61', 458, 1, 4, 879956) Also to contrast it with corresponding facilities for upper caste people in the same place.
('61', 458, 1, 5, 880048) The underlying note of the American friend’s suggestion is a plea for more truth.
('61', 458, 1, 6, 880130) The reports of our work can never be too accurate.
('61', 458, 1, 7, 880181) They must be mirrors both of our strength and our weakness.
('61', 458, 1, 8, 880241) We may not, therefore, embellish them.
('61', 458, 1, 9, 880280) Too often reports are made attractive by rosy pictures of institutions to which they refer.
('61', 458, 1, 10, 880372) But not being true to life, they share the fate of ordinary newspaper paragraphs or advertisements.
('61', 458, 1, 11, 880472) Readers simply do not read them or, when they do, they distrust them.
('61', 458, 1, 12, 880542) Comparative statements, such as the writer suggests, will better enable the reader to grasp the meaning of figures and facts.
('61', 458, 1, 13, 880668) Reports should never contain declamations or writers’ opinions, except when the latter are relevant.
('61', 458, 1, 14, 880769) They should be brief and to the point.
('61', 458, 1, 15, 880808) When there is no apparent progress, workers very often say they have nothing to report.
('61', 458, 1, 16, 880896) Such men forget that waht is wanted is a truthful record of their activities.
('61', 458, 1, 17, 880974) if, therefore, systematic work has been done, a correct record of it cannot fail to be of great value to other workers.
('61', 458, 1, 18, 881094) We may not always command success, but we can always show increasing effort and concentration which are forerunners of success.
('61', 458, 2, 19, 881222) VALUE OF REPORTS
('61', 458, 3, 20, 881239) Thakkar Bapa has often complained to me that the various organizations do not send prompt periodical reports and those that are sent often contain opinions and declamations rather than facts and figures.
('61', 458, 3, 21, 881443) Secretaries and workers do not always realize that reports are required, not for the pleasure of the central organization, but for the guidance of the centre in framing its policy from day to day, for checking and co ordinating the work of the different organizations and for informing the public from time to time of the progress of the movement.
('61', 458, 3, 22, 881791) The duty, faithfully performed, of drawing up reports will automatically stimulate the activity of workers all round, and keep organizations up to the mark.
('61', 458, 3, 23, 881948) Thus, if all workers sent in their reports of work done on the Harijan Day (24th Septemeber last), it would be possible to have an idea of the successes and failures in the various
('61', 459, 0, 1, 882129) 460 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 459, 1, 2, 882171) provinces.
('61', 459, 1, 3, 882182) It would also be possible then to know what instructions to issue for the next Harijan Day.
('61', 459, 1, 4, 882274) I hope, therefore, that, if such reports have not already been, they will be, sent at once to the headquarters in Delhi.
('61', 459, 1, 5, 882395) And if any reader has anything striking to report about his experiences, I would ask him to send them directly to me.
('61', 459, 1, 6, 882513) I hope that all the reports would contain accurate account of takings and expenditure incurred in making preparations for the observance of the Day.
('61', 459, 1, 7, 882662) Harijan, 7 10 1933
('61', 459, 2, 8, 882681) 570. WHAT THEY BELIEVE
('61', 459, 3, 9, 882704) Rao Bahadur M. C. Rajah sent me some time ago a copy of his speech, delivered at the Legislative Assembly on 24th August last, in connection with the Temple entry Bill 1. The reader will find below copious extracts 2 from that speech, which interruptions, his repartees and some other non historical portions omitted.
('61', 459, 3, 10, 883022) The value of the speech consists, not so much in the accuracy of his historical statements, as in the fact that many people actually believe in them with as much tenacity as the so called sanatanists, who credit Harijans with hardly any human rights, believe in statements supporting untouchability.
('61', 459, 3, 11, 883322) The issue will ultimately be decided, not by historical evidence or by interpretation of Sanskrit texts of doubtful religious value, but by the prayerful and incessant labours of reformers of sinless purity.
('61', 459, 3, 12, 883530) No religion has ever lived on its past achievements.
('61', 459, 3, 13, 883583) It dies unless it is nourished and sustained by the continuing tapas 3 of its votaries.
('61', 459, 3, 14, 883671) Not by learning but by right conduct can religions flourish.
('61', 459, 3, 15, 883732) Untouchabilty, as we practise it today, crept in when watchfulness of pure custodians waned.
('61', 459, 3, 16, 883825) It will only go when an unbroken and unbreakable chain of continuing tapas is established.
('61', 459, 3, 17, 883916) Not even a unanimous verdict of all the pundits and shastris will remove the idea of high and low which has been dragged into the minds of the masses since generations past.
('61', 459, 3, 18, 884090) The latter will want the evidence of the practice of those whom they believe to be pureminded representatives of their religion.
('61', 459, 4, 19, 884219) 1 Introduced by Ranga Iyer.
('61', 459, 4, 20, 884247) 2 Not reproduced here 3 Austere effort
('61', 460, 0, 1, 884286) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 461
('61', 460, 1, 2, 884329) Nevertheless, I commend Rao Bahadur Rajah’s speech to the students of Hinduism form the historical standpoint.
('61', 460, 1, 3, 884440) It is of some importance to have it indubitably proved that the Harijans of the South, at any rate, represented a civilization which was destroyed by a conquering race, calling itself Aryan (noble) in contempt of the original inhabitants, whom it used for its own selfish ends and reduced to slavery.
('61', 460, 1, 4, 884741) I must confess that I have always entertained grave doubts as to the truth of the story.
('61', 460, 1, 5, 884830) I should refuse to credit such claimants of superiority with being repositories of a noble religion.
('61', 460, 1, 6, 884931) If the historical evidence is beyond question, one is forced to the conclusion that all that is noble in Hinduism came, not from the conquerors, but from the conquered and that untouchablitiy is a corruption which the conquerors superimposed upon it, whilst they adopted the religion and culture of the conquered.
('61', 460, 1, 7, 885245) Whichever way the truth lies between the two schools of thought, untouchability is a recognized evil that has to be removed if Hinduism is to live.
('61', 460, 1, 8, 885393) It is further clear that, according to the two schools, Hinduism,whether it is indigenous or imported, did not, in its orginal state, have any taint of untouchability about it.
('61', 460, 1, 9, 885570) And in any case, now that there is no distinction between the non Aryan and the Aryan, who is said to have come from outside India and has fused with the original inhabitants of the country, it is not of much, if any, practical importance to decide or even know who was truly Arya or noble.
('61', 460, 1, 10, 885861) What is of tremendous importance is the fact that the monster of untouchability will tax the resources of all Hindus before it receives its death blow.
('61', 460, 2, 11, 886013) Harijan, 7 10 1993

('61', 463, 8, 14, 889549) 576. SURRENDER OF THE ASHRAM 3
('61', 463, 9, 15, 889580) [Before October 8, 1933]
('61', 463, 10, 16, 889605) We have given up the trusteeship [of the Ashram].
('61', 463, 10, 17, 889655) We have given it up not out of rancour but out of a feeling of oneness with it, because we saw that while keeping it under our control we could not observe our dharma.
('61', 463, 10, 18, 889823) The Government may take it over, but are not doing so.
('61', 463, 10, 19, 889878) I do not want it to be ruined .
('61', 463, 10, 20, 889910) Giving up control of the Ashram does not mean that we would never be staying there.
('61', 463, 10, 21, 889994) I do hope we could stay there.
('61', 463, 10, 22, 890025) Even if the Government sells it away, I hope that the inmates of the Ashram would settle nowhere but on that land.
('61', 463, 10, 23, 890140) may it become a place of pilgrimage for Harijans.
('61', 463, 10, 24, 890190) May it be for them a temple.
('61', 463, 10, 25, 890219) May it also be a place which would remind the caste Hindus of their own dharma.
('61', 463, 10, 26, 890299) The caste Hindus should know that they have reason for atonement and that this will also mean service to themselves.

('61', 464, 2, 3, 890731) [Before October 8, 1933] 1
('61', 464, 3, 4, 890758) DEAR HARIBHAU, Received your letter.

('61', 464, 3, 6, 890843) You must be keeping good health.
('61', 464, 3, 7, 890876) Jamnalalji tells me that you are preparing for the yatra.
('61', 464, 3, 8, 890934) I am trying to be an ideal prisoner even here.
('61', 464, 3, 9, 890981) The ethical codes prescribed by you for Chaitanya Muni appear to be correct.
('61', 464, 3, 10, 891058) But if he does not have a spontaneous desire and depends on my advice, my duty is to prevent him from changing the dress, because the fault is not in that dress but in its misuse.
('61', 464, 3, 11, 891238) Chaitanya Muni can become a thorough scholar and render great service by pointing out his religion without fear and following it in practice.
('61', 464, 3, 12, 891380) He must endeavour to study in depth Sanskrit and Magadhi.
('61', 464, 3, 13, 891438) This is of primary importance in the dress of a Jain muni.
('61', 464, 3, 14, 891497) But the munis hardly follow it in practice.
('61', 464, 3, 15, 891541) Untouchability or what is today known as varnashramadharma has no place at all in the Jain philosophy.
('61', 464, 3, 16, 891644) They must vehemently point it out, and before they talk about it, they must be fully convinced about it.
('61', 464, 3, 17, 891749) There is no restriction on a Jain muni teaching anyone.
('61', 464, 3, 18, 891805) Hence, he must get around at least a few Harijan children and educate them.
('61', 464, 3, 19, 891881) If he has been convinced that Jainism is not different from Hinduism, he must establish it.
('61', 464, 3, 20, 891973) If this leads to boycott, he must lovingly face it and continue in his path of service.
('61', 464, 3, 21, 892061) I think this includes everything.

('61', 464, 6, 25, 892214) 578. DISCUSSION ON DANGER OF CIVIL STRIFE
('61', 464, 7, 26, 892256) [Before October 8, 1933]
('61', 464, 8, 27, 892281) Q. Do you think this problem is so important that it must be tackled just now?
('61', 464, 8, 28, 892360) Many people are afraid that this work will lead to fighting and civil strife among Hindus.
('61', 464, 9, 29, 892451) 1 This letter appears in “Answers to Correspondents”, Before 8 10 1933 as a reply to a correspondent under “Answer to Correspondents”.
('61', 464, 9, 30, 892586) The whole letter, with the exception of the first few sentences, has been Reproduced in Harijanbandhu, 8 10 1933.
('61', 465, 0, 1, 892700) 466 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 465, 1, 2, 892742) A. Without doing this work we cannot reach the road to swaraj.
('61', 465, 1, 3, 892805) And even supposing we did, that swaraj would not be true swaraj, but the reign of blind superstition and irreligion.
('61', 465, 1, 4, 892922) Today many Hindus believe that Hinduism would perish with the eradication of untouchability.
('61', 465, 1, 5, 893015) But I see the end of Hinduism unless untouchability is wiped out.
('61', 465, 1, 6, 893081) In this age people do not fight with swords for the sake of religion.
('61', 465, 1, 7, 893151) Religious awakening is not and should not be brought about nor religion protected at the point of the sword.
('61', 465, 1, 8, 893260) But religions will be compared and judged by our reasons and hearts.
('61', 465, 1, 9, 893329) Untouchability is opposed to reason and sentiment.
('61', 465, 1, 10, 893380) It is a great crime.
('61', 465, 1, 11, 893401) As Congressmen we must accept this.
('61', 465, 1, 12, 893437) If in consequence only a handful of Hindus remain in the Congress, let it be so.
('61', 465, 1, 13, 893518) The Congress will then be come a powerful organization.
('61', 465, 1, 14, 893574) Today there is only a risk of civil strife.
('61', 465, 1, 15, 893618) If, however, untouchability is not wiped out, civil strife is a certainty.
('61', 465, 1, 16, 893693) Unless we take bold measures against untouchability, civil strife is bound to follow.
('61', 465, 2, 17, 893779) [From Gujarati] Harijanbandhu, 8 10 1933
('61', 465, 3, 18, 893820) 579. TALK WITH A WORKER 1
('61', 465, 4, 19, 893846) [Before October 8, 1933]
('61', 465, 5, 20, 893871) Q. Since removal of untouchability is included in the Congress programme, why should we not do this work as a political activity?
('61', 465, 5, 21, 894001) A. The movement will fizzle out if it is carried on as a political activity.
('61', 465, 5, 22, 894078) It has political implications, and nobody can prevent them from following.
('61', 465, 5, 23, 894153) But the work itslef cannot be considered a political acitivity.
('61', 465, 5, 24, 894217) if it is so considered, it will not last, for, it is a pure religious cause.
('61', 465, 5, 25, 894294) Hence, to those who suggest that it should be restricted to a purely political aim and that such a difficult item like temple entry should be omitted from the programme, I would say that if this is done, the movement will lose its very life.
('61', 465, 6, 26, 894536) [From Gujarati] Harijanbandhu, 8 10 1933
('61', 465, 7, 27, 894577) 1 This appeared under the title “Purely Religious Work”.
('61', 466, 0, 1, 894634) VOL. 61: 27 APRIL 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 467
('61', 466, 1, 2, 894677) 580. TALK ON NEED FOR HUMILITY
('61', 466, 2, 3, 894708) [Before October 8, 1933]
('61', 466, 3, 4, 894733) After taking a vow, do not start soaring in the sky but remain on the earth.
('61', 466, 3, 5, 894810) We are but grains of sand, we are like particles of dust.
('61', 466, 3, 6, 894868) I truly believe the saying, “For dust thou art, and unto dust shalt thou return.” We are born out of dust, we are mere images of clay.
('61', 466, 3, 7, 895003) What should we be proud of?
('61', 466, 3, 8, 895031) We are not capable even of building anything like the artistic anthill that ants can build.
('61', 466, 3, 9, 895123) Sparrows, ants, etc., have attained perfection, which we have not.
('61', 466, 3, 10, 895190) We are imperfect.
('61', 466, 3, 11, 895208) We are not perfect even physically.
('61', 466, 3, 12, 895244) That is why we seek perfection elsewhere.
('61', 466, 3, 13, 895286) We are never content to be what we are.
('61', 466, 3, 14, 895326) This “divine discontent” is put in us by God.
('61', 466, 3, 15, 895372) Because of it, we keep on saying “not this, not this”, and endeavour to go further and further.
('61', 466, 3, 16, 895468) An ant is perfect, because it does not wish to become better.
('61', 466, 3, 17, 895530) But we have got to progress.
('61', 466, 3, 18, 895559) We should, therefore, be humble and live as particles of dust, be ciphers.
('61', 466, 3, 19, 895634) Modern physicists and astronomers tell us that each atom contains the entire universe within itself.
('61', 466, 3, 20, 895735) The seers of the Upanishads had known this truth thousands of yers ago.
('61', 466, 3, 21, 895807) That is why they said: “As in the individual so in the universe.” We can become part of the Divine when we become like an atom, become a mere cipher, for the atom is universal, imperishable.
('61', 466, 3, 22, 895998) We must, therefore, learn not to soar in the sky, but to become like a particle of dust.
('61', 466, 4, 23, 896087) [From Gujarati] Harijanbandhu, 8 10 1933
('61', 466, 5, 24, 896128) 581. ANSWERS TO CORRESPONDENTS 1
('61', 466, 6, 25, 896161) [Before October 8, 1933]
('61', 466, 7, 26, 896186) I believe in the system of the four varnas.
('61', 466, 7, 27, 896230) 2 But the aim of the varna system was to determine and limit the field of occupations.
('61', 466, 7, 28, 896317) Restrictions about marriage and dining were never regarded as part of the varnadharma., Ordinarily, people will naturally marry within their own varna but we know from historical evidence that there have always been inter varna marriages in certain circumstances.
('61', 466, 8, 29, 896581) 1 The report, which appeared under the title “From the Mail Bag”, gives only a gist of Gandhiji’s answers to the correspondents.
('61', 466, 8, 30, 896710) 2 A gentleman had asked why, since Gandhiji belived in the system of the four varnas, he approved of inter varna marriages.
('61', 467, 0, 1, 896834) 468 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 467, 1, 2, 896876) gradually come to the firm conclusion that as a result of complete confusion in the matter of the choice of occupations there is a total chaos in the functioning of the varna system as well.
('61', 467, 1, 3, 897067) Today varnadharma exists only in name; the beautiful varna system has been abused to spread the degrading notion of high and low.
('61', 467, 1, 4, 897197) I have no ready solution to the problem how true varnadharma can be established.
('61', 467, 1, 5, 897278) But I have no doubt at all that its reival will depend on the present generation following the right path.
('61', 467, 1, 6, 897385) Its outward form will perhaps have changed a little.
('61', 467, 1, 7, 897438) In religious matters it should be remembered that we have to seek the spirit behind the outward form, that mere form without spirit is of no use.
('61', 467, 1, 8, 897584) Thank you for your frank letter.
('61', 467, 1, 9, 897617) 1 No person can absolve another from the moral consequences of breach of vow.

('61', 469, 3, 4, 901942) The responsibility of the caste Hindus of Ahmedabad as also of the Harijans has increased as a result of the donation of the land and buildings of the Satyagraha Ashram for the service of Harijans.

('61', 469, 3, 6, 902263) However, land and buildings without men are no better than ruins.

('61', 470, 3, 4, 903026) INTERVIEW TO “THE TIMES OF INDIA1
('61', 470, 4, 5, 903060) May 2, 1933
('61', 470, 5, 6, 903072) I have received messages from dear friends in England, which make me happy.
('61', 470, 5, 7, 903148) They seem to have been convinced in their hearts about the propriety of the step I am going to take.
('61', 470, 5, 8, 903249) They have not said this in so many words but that is how I interpret their messages.
('61', 470, 5, 9, 903334) I was afraid that they might not be able to understand the uniqueness of this fast.
('61', 470, 5, 10, 903418) But my fear has been proved to be baseless.
('61', 470, 5, 11, 903462) Mr. Andrews has sent a message on his own behalf and on behalf of friends.
('61', 470, 5, 12, 903537) Another message is from Mr. and Mrs. Polak.
('61', 470, 5, 13, 903581) They have never hesitated to criticize me whenever they have not understood any of my actions.
('61', 470, 5, 14, 903676) I had a vague fear that they might not approve of my present step.
('61', 470, 5, 15, 903743) I have been receiving messages from friends in India too and I hope that in a few days’ time they will understand the propriety of my step.
('61', 470, 5, 16, 903883) Whatever it be, I am becoming more and more convinced that it was not possible for me to avoid this fast.
('61', 470, 5, 17, 903989) There was no other way if this movement was to be kept on a purely moral plane and saved from being besmirched by selfish and impure elements that have infiltrated into it.
('61', 470, 5, 18, 904162) Now I hope that those engaged in it will start working with redoubled zest and fulfil the various tasks connected with the removal of untouchability, including the task of educating public opinion in favour of the Bill for the abolition of untouchability.
('61', 470, 5, 19, 904418) I am convinced that the progress would have stopped if I had not taken the step.
('61', 470, 5, 20, 904499) I wish that the sanatanists and reformers should work in co operation during the coming weeks and remove whatever defects they find in the existing laws and come to a settlement.
('61', 470, 5, 21, 904678) You ask me [what I will do] if I am released.
('61', 470, 5, 22, 904724) This is a question I really cannot at the moment consider.

('61', 471, 2, 3, 904932) LETTER FROM V. S. SRINIVASA SASTRI1
('61', 471, 3, 4, 904968) Private
('61', 471, 4, 5, 904976) MYLAPORE, May 7, 1933
('61', 471, 5, 6, 904998) DEAREST BROTHER, After much thought and destruction of several drafts, I have decided that the best reply to your ‘begging’ and most touching letter of the 2nd instant is the enclosed extract.
('61', 471, 5, 7, 905191) I trust it will sustain you ever so little in the ordeal which will have begun when it reaches Yeravda.
('61', 471, 5, 8, 905295) It would have been useless and, as you said in your first statement, embarrassing for me to try to dissuade.
('61', 471, 5, 9, 905404) What remains for your friends and associates is to wish that you may come out of the ordeal not merely unscathed, but armed afresh with the strength of tapas for the struggle that seems without end.
('61', 471, 5, 10, 905603) I will not pretend for a moment that I approve of your fast.
('61', 471, 5, 11, 905664) To one like me, born in Hinduism and bred up in it for long years, the arguments pro and con are thoroughly familiar.
('61', 471, 5, 12, 905782) From sacred texts one might confute most of the reasoning in your statements.
('61', 471, 5, 13, 905860) But beyond texts and mere authority is reason and humanity, on which you habitually fall back.
('61', 471, 5, 14, 905955) Even in that ultimate court I fear we shall not be found on the same side.
('61', 471, 5, 15, 906030) Our values are different fandamentally.
('61', 471, 5, 16, 906070) The difference is radical, no sophistry can abolish it.
('61', 471, 5, 17, 906126) In spite of what you have said in the last revelation of your heart, I believe that too much self communion and internal debate have undermined your judgment.
('61', 471, 5, 18, 906285) The state of ecstasy when values are reversed, when day becomes night and night day, when pleasure becomes pain and pain pleasure, is rare even in the experience of mystics.
('61', 471, 5, 19, 906459) The attempt to make it habitual and to adopt the language appropriate to that state as the language of everyday speech is, if I may use the expression, to walk on moral stilts.
('61', 471, 5, 20, 906636) On occasions you appear to me, in strange contrast to your realism, to impose that mode of movement on the common men and women around you.
('61', 471, 5, 21, 906776) The atmosphere in such circumstances if apt to be thick with disappointment and grievous failure.
('61', 471, 5, 22, 906874) And if the only correction possible were self correction, the master must needs find himself doomed to the cell of penitence, which is next door to suicide.
('61', 471, 5, 23, 907031) You have enough philosophy to understand that to claim divine sanction for a course of conduct is to withdraw it from the field of discussion and deprive it of direct validity to other minds.
('61', 471, 5, 24, 907223) Whenever I come across the claim in your writing I cannot help quoting to myself the famous line of Kalidasa:
('61', 471, 6, 25, 907333) 1 Vide “Letter to V. S. Srinivasa Sastri”, 2 5 1933.
('61', 472, 0, 1, 907386) VOL. 61 : 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 473
('61', 472, 1, 2, 907431) ‘‘You appear to me to be confounded by anxious thought.”
('61', 472, 2, 3, 907488) Yours always,
('61', 472, 3, 4, 907502) V. S. SRINIVASAN
('61', 472, 4, 5, 907519) ENCLOSURE
('61', 472, 5, 6, 907529) ‘Revolution and Religion’ is a review by John Middleton Murry of a book called Moral Man and Immoral Society by Reinhold Neibuhr.
('61', 472, 5, 7, 907659) The review appears in the Aryan Path of this month.
('61', 472, 5, 8, 907711) Below are transcribed the concluding paragraphs in which reference is made to Gandhi.
('61', 472, 5, 9, 907797) ‘What then are those who are convinced alike of the material and spiritual necessity .
('61', 472, 5, 10, 907884) for the social struggle in the Western world?
('61', 472, 5, 11, 907930) There is our tragedy.
('61', 472, 5, 12, 907952) It is a most significant tribute to Gandhi that he should be the figure in whom the rigorous yet imaginative arguments of Neibuhr’s book inevitably culminate.
('61', 472, 5, 13, 908111) Of the book itself, I can only say that it seems to be of an altogether higher order than any other examination of the menacing problem of Western civilization with which I am acquainted.
('61', 472, 5, 14, 908299) It is a prophetic book; and I do not believe I shall be found the victim of romantic illusionism when I say that I believe it will prove to be the forerunner of a new and enduring political movement in the English speaking world.’
('61', 472, 6, 15, 908530) Letter s of Sriniv asa Sastri , pp.

('61', 472, 9, 18, 908609) DEHRADUN JAIL, May 5, 1933
('61', 472, 10, 19, 908636) MY DEAR BAPU, Your letter came today.
('61', 472, 10, 20, 908674) I was half expecting it for your large heart never permits you to forget anyone.
('61', 472, 10, 21, 908755) I have sent you a telegram already.
('61', 472, 10, 22, 908791) As my telegram will indicate, I feel utterly at a loss and do not know what I can say to you.
('61', 472, 10, 23, 908885) Religion is not familiar ground for me, and as I have grown older I have definitely drifted away from it.
('61', 472, 10, 24, 908991) I suppose I have something else in its place, something other than just intellect, reason, which gives me strength and hope.
('61', 472, 10, 25, 909116) Apart from this undefinable and indefinite urge, which may have just a tinge of religion in it but is wholly different from it, I have grown to rely entirely on the workings of the mind.
('61', 472, 10, 26, 909303) Perhaps they are weak supports to rely upon, but, search as I will, I can see no better ones.
('61', 472, 10, 27, 909397) Religion seems to me to lead to emotion and

('61', 473, 1, 2, 909530) sentimentality and they are still more unreliable guides.
('61', 473, 1, 3, 909588) Intuition—undoubtedly there is such a thing, though where it comes from I cannot say!
('61', 473, 1, 4, 909674) Perhaps from the stored up experiences at the back of the mind, the sub conscious self.
('61', 473, 1, 5, 909762) The Harijan question is bad, very bad, but it seems to me incorrect to say that there is nothing so bad in all the world.
('61', 473, 1, 6, 909884) I think I could point to much that was equally bad and even worse.

('61', 473, 1, 8, 910024) Is it not the outcome of special causes ?
('61', 473, 1, 9, 910066) Surely it is due to something more than mere ignorance and ill will.
('61', 473, 1, 10, 910135) To remove those causes or to neutralize their effect appears to be the only way to deal with the roots of the matter.
('61', 473, 1, 11, 910253) But why should I write of these matters now!
('61', 473, 1, 12, 910298) I do not want to argue in this letter as the stage for argument seems to be past.

('61', 473, 1, 17, 910758) I have loved life—the mountains and the sea, the sun and rain and storm and snow, and animals, and books and art, and even human beings—and life has been good to me.

('61', 473, 1, 19, 911044) But at close quarters, it is not pleasant to contemplate.

('61', 473, 1, 21, 911255) Life became fuller and richer and more worthwhile, and that is a dear and precious memory which nothing can take from me.
('61', 473, 1, 22, 911377) And whenever the future happens to be dark, this vision of the past will relieve the gloom and give strength.
('61', 473, 1, 23, 911487) All my love to you.

('61', 474, 2, 3, 911738) TALK WITH C. RAJAGOPALACHARI 1
('61', 474, 3, 4, 911769) May 4, 1933
('61', 474, 4, 5, 911781) GANDHIJI: Even jurisprudence admits the right of self destruction.
('61', 474, 4, 6, 911848) You will ask me whether Ramatirtha, Ramakrishna, Vivekananda did this sort of tapasya, whether the suicide of Ramatirtha—deliberate or resulting from a trance—produced any results, whether Jesus mounting the cross left any impact.
('61', 474, 5, 7, 912079) C. R. But Hinduism does not sanction suicide.
('61', 474, 6, 8, 912125) G. I don’t know.
('61', 474, 6, 9, 912142) But Mahadev was telling me that there is a practice of drowning oneself in the Ganga.
('61', 474, 7, 10, 912228) C. R. That is to purify oneself with the water of the Ganga.
('61', 474, 7, 11, 912289) I do admit that if you are the cause of all these sins you may commit suicide.
('61', 474, 7, 12, 912368) Logically it would be your victory, but then you do not seek such a victory, do you ?
('61', 474, 8, 13, 912454) G. I want to atone for the sins.
('61', 474, 8, 14, 912487) Moral ends require moral means.
('61', 474, 8, 15, 912519) Cardinal Manning was kept on three biscuits and water.
('61', 474, 8, 16, 912574) It is easier to undertake twenty one days’ fast than to die the kind of slow death as Cardinal Manning is said to have died.
('61', 474, 8, 17, 912699) A moral reform can be brought about only through tapashcharya and self purification.
('61', 474, 8, 18, 912784) We should learn from the experience of scientists who have gone through this.
('61', 474, 8, 19, 912862) My mother and I were born in families where such fasts were an everyday affair.
('61', 474, 8, 20, 912942) They were a part of their experience.
('61', 474, 8, 21, 912980) It is probable that my father did not approve of the severe fasts my mother used to undertake but she showed no ill effects from the fasting and they made us respect her all the more.
('61', 474, 9, 22, 913164) C.R. This is only an instance of association of ideas.
('61', 474, 9, 23, 913219) Can you defend your case by saying that just because your mother fasted you also must?
('61', 474, 9, 24, 913306) If someone pierces himself with a needle, how will that convince people that it is sinful to regard a person as an untouchable?
('61', 474, 10, 25, 913434) G. Then supposing I fast only for a few days?
('61', 474, 10, 26, 913480) Supposing I don’t die at the end of the fast?
('61', 474, 11, 27, 913526) C.R. The two things are not related at all.
('61', 474, 11, 28, 913570) You seem to believe that there is a secret connection between self mortification and people’s convictions.
('61', 474, 11, 29, 913677) Buddha was the first to raise his voice against such self mortification.
('61', 474, 12, 30, 913750) G. In a true fast the mind and the soul co operate with the body.
('61', 474, 12, 31, 913816) Buddha was against purely physical fasting.
('61', 474, 13, 32, 913860) C.R. Will you have the strength to think clearly after ten days?
