('61', 477, 6, 9, 919705) M. S. ANEY’S STATEMENT SUSPENDING CIVIL DISOBEDIENCE 1
('61', 477, 7, 10, 919760) POONA, May 9, 1933
('61', 477, 8, 11, 919779) I feel sure that although the news of the fast of Mahatma Gandhi is bound to cast a dark shadow of anxiety and gloom throughout the country, it will be some relief to his countrymen as well as to his friends and followers throughout the world to know that Government has, at any rate, released him unconditionally and allowed him to observe his vow and practise his great penance as a free citizen.
('61', 477, 8, 12, 920178) In a statement issued to the Press last night, after his release, he has expressed his views on the conduct of the civil disobedience movement which, I have no doubt, will receive the consideration they deserve from every civil resister.
('61', 477, 8, 13, 920416) It is perfectly true that during the period of fast, the civil resisters will be in a state of suspense and as a consequence he has advised me to declare officially and suspend the civil disobedience campaign for one month or even six weeks.
('61', 477, 8, 14, 920658) In his statement he has emphatically stated what I have been saying more than once during the last four months in reply to various critics of the civil disobedience movement that the civil disobedience cannot be withdrawn so long as many civil resisters are imprisoned, and no settlement can be arrived at so long as Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel, Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, Khan Abdul Ghaffar Khan and others are in jail.
('61', 477, 8, 15, 921074) ‘Indeed the withdrawal of the civil disobedience movement is not within the power of men who are out of prison.
('61', 477, 8, 16, 921186) It is possible only for the original Working Committee to do so.’ I repeat the position so lucidly and emphatically enumerated by Mahatma Gandhi above, which is the only rational an constitutional position for the Congressmen to take on the point of withdrawal of the civil disobedience campaign.
('61', 477, 8, 17, 921483) But the question of suspending the campaign to serve any definite object of a limited period undoubtedly stands on a different footing.
('61', 477, 8, 18, 921619) It is no doubt a serious responsibility which I have been called to shoulder.
('61', 477, 8, 19, 921697) But I am armed with a weapon—it
('61', 477, 9, 20, 921729) 1 Vide “Statement suspending Civil Disobedience Movement”, 8 5 1933.
('61', 478, 0, 1, 921798) VOL. 61 : 27 APRIL, 1933 7 OCTOBER, 1933 479
('61', 478, 1, 2, 921843) is an advice that comes from one who is not only the author of the present civil disobedience campaign but the originator and sole authority on the science and practice of civil disobedience itself.
('61', 478, 1, 3, 922042) In response to his suggestion which also strikes me as a proper thing to do at this time in order to eliminate from the atmosphere all The elements of excitement and render it pure for all of us to inhale, to be in a prayerful mood to invoke the blessings of the Almighty on the great cause for which Mahatma Gandhi is undergoing this penance and supply him with an abundance of spiritual food so necessary for him to sustain through this ordeal, I declare officially that civil disobedience shall be suspended for six weeks beginning with Tuesday the 9th of May.
('61', 478, 1, 4, 922606) In conclusion I repeat my appeal to every man and woman to utilize this period to the best of his or her ability and energy in the service of such work for the uplift of Harijans as may be most commending itself to him or her.
('61', 478, 2, 5, 922833) The Hindustan Times, 10 5 1933
('61', 478, 3, 6, 922864) APPENDIX VI
('61', 478, 4, 7, 922876) BREAKING OF THE FAST 1
('61', 478, 5, 8, 922899) So The Day arrived for which hundreds and thousands had prayed for.
('61', 478, 5, 9, 922967) The scenes were as solemn as on the 8th May.
('61', 478, 5, 10, 923012) Men and women of all faiths were represented there by those who were present on the occasion in response to the invitation of the door keeper, Shrimati Sarojini Naidu, who for once in her life had forsaken her extravagant generosity and become niggardly in the interest of the patient, for whom she had kept tireless vigil.
('61', 478, 5, 11, 923336) On any other occasion of rejoicing, she might have invited the whole city of Poona, but not that day.
('61', 478, 5, 12, 923438) I had been expecting the Harijan boy who had entered into that contract with Gandhiji on the 8th of May to appear punctually on the noon of the 29th.
('61', 478, 5, 13, 923588) I had entreated the door keeper to find him out and allow him in.
('61', 478, 5, 14, 923654) Unfortunately, I did not know his address; otherwise, I should have fetched him myself.
('61', 478, 5, 15, 923742) He did not turn up, and the orange juice was supplied not by him but by the kind hostess, Lady Thackersey, who perhaps felt the luckiest woman that day, as Dr. Ansari, the proudest man.
('61', 478, 5, 16, 923928) The Harijan boy was not there, but the door keeper had flung the doors open to all Harijans, and the first and only garland offered to Gandhiji before the break of the fast was that of a Harijan girl, who then sat in the midst of her sisters of rank and station.
('61', 478, 5, 17, 924191) In the centre and with Sjt.
('61', 478, 5, 18, 924219) Amritlal Thakkar and Seth Jamnalal Bajaj, sat the Harijans among whom there were some who had come from far off Ahmedabad.
('61', 478, 5, 19, 924342) With the name of Rama on our lips we began the
('61', 478, 6, 20, 924389) 1 Vide “Note to Mathuradas Trikumji”, 28 5 1933. This was extracted from “Sparks from the Sacred Fire VI by Mahadev Desai.
('61', 479, 0, 1, 924512) 480 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 479, 1, 2, 924554) function, which was inaugurated by Dr. Ansari with texts from the Koran on the spiritual meaning of fasting, during which the aspirant after grace had to feast himself on good and fast from all evil.
('61', 479, 1, 3, 924754) Brothers from the Christ Seva Sangha sang Gandhiji’s favourite: “When I survey the Wondrous Cross.” Prof.
('61', 479, 1, 4, 924860) Wadia sang the Parsi prayer which, as he said, could be the universal prayer; and Kakasaheb sang the verse in which the devotee offers his prayers to the embodiment of all good, of all freedom from passion and hatred, of all love and compassion, whatever be the name by which men call Him.
('61', 479, 1, 5, 925150) Then came the Poet’s song wherein he invokes the Almighty to come with a torrent of mercy when the springs of life dry up and with nectared music when all the sweetness is missing.
('61', 479, 1, 6, 925331) The Poet could not be there, as at the break of the September Fast, to sing it and so I sang it in his name.
('61', 479, 1, 7, 925440) Last came the hymn of ‘the true Vaishnava’, which is almost as life breath to Gandhiji and is sung on all occasions when we are called upon to face sorrow and joy with equanimity.

('61', 484, 4, 7, 938508) M. S. ANEY’S STATEMENT DISCONTINUING MASS CIVIL DISOBEDIENCE1
('61', 484, 5, 8, 938570) July 22, 1933
('61', 484, 6, 9, 938584) Having considered very carefully the recommendations of the informal conference recently held at Poona and the discussions among Congressmen in the Conference and outside, and the advice tendered by Mr. Gandhi, I have come to the conclusion that the country’s best interest will be served by the following instructions being carried out: Firstly, the civil disobedience campaign should not be unconditionally withdrawn in the existing circumstances..
('61', 484, 6, 10, 939035) Secondly, mass civil disobedience, including no tax and no rent campaign, should be discontinued for the time being, the right of individuals who may be ready for every suffering, and are prepared at their own responsibilities to continue civil disobedience being reserved.
('61', 484, 6, 11, 939309) Thirdly, all those able and willing to offer individual civil disobedience on their own responsibilities without expectation of any help from the Congress organization are expected to do so.
('61', 484, 6, 12, 939500) Fourthly, secret methods followed hitherto should be abandoned.
('61', 484, 6, 13, 939564) Fifthly, all Congress organizations, including the All India Congress Committee office, should cease to exist for the time being, provided however that wherever possible dictators in the provinces and all India dictators should continue.
('61', 484, 6, 14, 939802) Sixthly, all the Congressmen unable for any reason whatsoever to offer civil disobedience are expected to carry on individually or corporately such constructive activities of the Congress for which they are fitted.
('61', 484, 6, 15, 940017) I regret it has not been possible to call off the movement, and it has become necessary for me to issue these instructions.
('61', 484, 6, 16, 940141) I share with many others, Congressmen or others, the disappointment that Mahatma Gandhi’s very simple request, unaccompanied by any condition, for an interview with the Viceroy in order to explore peace possibilities, was summarily rejected.
('61', 484, 6, 17, 940383) His Excellency has very wrongly allowed himself to be influenced by unauthorized reports of confidential proceedings of the informal conference which for the sake of furthering peace efforts
('61', 484, 7, 18, 940574) 1 Vide “Interview on M. S. Aney’s statement”, 24 7 1933.
('61', 485, 0, 1, 940631) 486 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 485, 1, 2, 940673) were purposely held back from publication.
('61', 485, 1, 3, 940716) His Excellency should know that at the conference overwhelming opinion favoured seeking such an interview for honourable peace.
('61', 485, 1, 4, 940844) I hold it impossible for any Congress organization or its representative to accept the terms peremptorily laid down by His Excellency as a condition precedent to peace conversation.
('61', 485, 1, 5, 941026) I hope the nation will compel revision of this attitude by developing requisite strength, whatever the cost be.
('61', 485, 1, 6, 941138) Despite the instructions, suspension of the campaign till the end of this month stands.
('61', 485, 2, 7, 941226) The Indian Annual Regist er, 1933, Vol. II, PP.

('61', 490, 7, 13, 953183) LETTER FROM JAWAHARLAL NEHRU1
('61', 490, 8, 14, 953213) ‘PARNAKUTI’, September 13, 1933
('61', 490, 9, 15, 953245) MY DEAR BAPU, In our recent conversation you will remember that I laid stress on the reiteration and clearer definition of our national objective.
('61', 490, 9, 16, 953392) The objective of political independence has been finally laid down by the Congress and there is nothing to add to it or take away from it.
('61', 490, 9, 17, 953531) We stand for complete independence.
('61', 490, 9, 18, 953567) Sometimes a little confusion arises because of vague phraseology and misleading propaganda and it is therefore as well to remove this confusion by a reiteration of our political demand.
('61', 490, 9, 19, 953753) Even the word ‘independence’ is used with a variety of meanings.
('61', 490, 9, 20, 953818) Obviously it must include, as the Congress has clearly and definitely laid down, full control of the army and of foreign relations, as well as financial and economic control.
('61', 490, 9, 21, 953993) In regard to economic matters, the Karachi Congress by passing the important resolution on ‘Fundamental Rights and Economic Policy’ gave a lead and pointed out the direction in which we should move.
('61', 490, 9, 22, 954192) I attach great importance to that resolution but I would personally like to go much further and to clarify the position still more.
('61', 490, 9, 23, 954324) It seems to me that if we are to improve the condition of the masses, to raise them economically and give them freedom, it is inevitable that vested interests in India will have to give up their special position and many of their privileges.
('61', 490, 9, 24, 954566) It is inconceivable to me how else the masses can rise.
('61', 490, 9, 25, 954622) Therefore the problem of achieving freedom becomes one of revising vested interests in favour of the masses.
('61', 490, 9, 26, 954731) To the extent this is done, to that extent only will freedom come.
('61', 490, 9, 27, 954798) The biggest vested interest in India is that of the British Government next come the Indian Princes; and
('61', 490, 10, 28, 954903) 1 Vide “Letter to Jawaharlal Nehru”, 14 9 1933.
('61', 491, 0, 1, 954951) 492 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 491, 1, 2, 954993) others follow.
('61', 491, 1, 3, 955008) We do not wish to injure any class or group and the divesting should be done as gently as possible and with every effort to avoid injury.
('61', 491, 1, 4, 955146) But it is obvious that the divesting is bound to cause loss to the classes or groups which enjoy special privileges at the expense of the masses.
('61', 491, 1, 5, 955292) It is also obvious that the process of divesting must be as speedy as possible to bring relief to the masses whose condition, as you know, is as bad as it can well be.
('61', 491, 1, 6, 955460) Indeed economic forces themselves are acting with amazing rapidity today and breaking up the old order.
('61', 491, 1, 7, 955564) The big zamindari and taluqdari system in the United Provinces has largely collapsed, though it may be kept up for some time longer by outside agencies.
('61', 491, 1, 8, 955717) Even the condition of the zamindars is very bad and the peasantry of course are in a far worse position.
('61', 491, 1, 9, 955822) We are all agreed that the Round Table Conference and its various productions are utterly useless to solve even one of India’s many problems.
('61', 491, 1, 10, 955964) As I conceive it, the Round Table Conference was an effort to consolidate the vested interests of India behind the British Government so as to face the rising and powerful national and economic movements in the country which threaten these interests.
('61', 491, 1, 11, 956215) Essentially, in international parlance, it was a fascist grouping of vested and possessing interests, and fascist methods were adopted in India to suppress the national movement.
('61', 491, 1, 12, 956394) And because the mere preservation of all these vested interests in India cannot possibly solve our economic ills, whether those of the masses or even of the middle classes, the effort is foredoomed to inevitable failure.
('61', 491, 1, 13, 956615) Even from the point of view of a democratic nationalism, as you yourself stated at the Round Table Conference, democracy and autocracy can ill go together.
('61', 491, 1, 14, 956771) Another aspect has to be borne in mind.
('61', 491, 1, 15, 956811) The problem of Indian freedom cannot be separated from the vital international problems of the world.
('61', 491, 1, 16, 956913) The present crisis in the world’s affairs is having its repercussions in India.
('61', 491, 1, 17, 956993) At any moment it may result in a complete breakdown or in a violent international conflagration.
('61', 491, 1, 18, 957090) Everywhere there is a conflict and a contest between the forces of progress and betterment of the masses and the forces of reaction and vested interests.
('61', 491, 1, 19, 957244) We cannot remain silent witnesses to this titanic struggle for it affects us intimately.
('61', 491, 1, 20, 957333) Both on the narrower ground of our own interests and the wider ground of international welfare and human progress, we must, I feel, range ourselves with the progressive forces of the world.
('61', 491, 1, 21, 957523) This ranging ourselves at present can of course be ideological only.
('61', 491, 1, 22, 957592) These are some of the larger issues that fill my mind and I am convinced, not only that we ignore them at our peril, but that a true appreciation of them will vitalize and give new meaning to our struggle for freedom which we must continue till the full objective is achieved.
('61', 491, 1, 23, 957869) These wider issues are of great importance but at present, as you know, the minds of large numbers of our countrymen are greatly exercised over immediate national problems and especially the question of carrying on the struggle.

('61', 492, 1, 2, 958143) statements that you and Sjt.
('61', 492, 1, 3, 958172) M. S. Aney issued some time ago to guide the country have, I am afraid, produced some confusion and there has even been some resentment in regard to particular directions contained in them.
('61', 492, 1, 4, 958362) There is a vague talk, in quarters which ought to know better, that the Congress has been dissolved.
('61', 492, 1, 5, 958463) It is obvious that nothing of the kind has been done or could be done under the constitution.
('61', 492, 1, 6, 958557) Your directions and those of Mr. Aney were, I take it, in the nature of advice or suggestions to meet a certain position that had arisen.
('61', 492, 1, 7, 958695) The Congress continues as before but it is clear that it cannot function normally when Government declare its committees to be illegal.
('61', 492, 1, 8, 958831) There can be no regular offices or open activity.
('61', 492, 1, 9, 958881) To recognize this fact and to adapt ourselves to it is not to wind up any Congress Committee, much less the Congress organization as a whole.
('61', 492, 1, 10, 959023) A necessary consequence from this was to avoid the possibility of a few newcomers who formed committees, when the old members and other reliable workers went to prison, or even individuals, committing the Congress to an undesirable course of action.
('61', 492, 1, 11, 959273) As is known, we have had to face this risk in The past and unreliable persons have come to the helm of affairs in some local areas with the intention of obstructing and even stopping the very activities they were supposed to further.
('61', 492, 1, 12, 959507) It thus becomes desirable to prevent such unreliable persons from exploiting the name of the Congress Committee.
('61', 492, 1, 13, 959620) This of course does not prevent Congress workers in any area from co operating together in an organized way for the furtherance of our programme.
('61', 492, 1, 14, 959766) Confusion has also arisen in the country about the implications of individual and mass civil disobedience.
('61', 492, 1, 15, 959873) I appreciate to some extent the difference but this difference does not appear to me to be a fundamental one, as, in any event, civil disobedience is essentially an individual affair.
('61', 492, 1, 16, 960057) Individual civil disobedience can develop into mass civil disobedience.
('61', 492, 1, 17, 960129) Besides, you told me that if an organization felt strong enough to undertake the responsibility and the risk, it could, of its own initiative, take up mass civil disobedience.
('61', 492, 1, 18, 960305) Indeed you were of opinion that a local organization could, in this manner go ahead in any direction which was not contrary to Congress methods or policy.
('61', 492, 1, 19, 960460) Stress was laid in your previous statement on the undesirability of secrecy, although you pointed out that there was nothing inherently illegitimate in secret methods.
('61', 492, 1, 20, 960628) I think that most of us agree, and certainly I am of that opinion, that our movement is essentially an open one and secret methods do not fit in with it.
('61', 492, 1, 21, 960782) Such methods, if indulged in to any large extent, are likely to change the whole character of the movement, as it has been conceived, and produce a certain amount of demoralization.
('61', 492, 1, 22, 960964) Agreeing with this, some of us feel that, to some extent as for instance in communicating with each other or sending directions or keeping contacts, a measure of secrecy may be necessary.
('61', 492, 1, 23, 961152) Perhaps secrecy is hardly the word for those activities and privacy would suit them better.
('61', 492, 1, 24, 961244) Privacy of course is always
('61', 493, 0, 1, 961272) 494 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('61', 493, 1, 2, 961314) open to all groups and individuals.
('61', 493, 1, 3, 961350) Secrecy or the avoidance of it, as you said, cannot be made into a fetish.
('61', 493, 1, 4, 961425) But secrecy is certainly involved in the production of printed or duplicated news sheets and bulletins.
('61', 493, 1, 5, 961529) These bulletins have often served a useful purpose in the past in keeping contact between headquarters and districts and in sending information or directions.
('61', 493, 1, 6, 961688) You pointed out to me the difficulties and undesirable consequences of running these secret presses and duplicating machines.
('61', 493, 1, 7, 961814) Many good workers are tied up and have to avoid aggressive action; money has to be invested in such machines and frequently they are taken away by the police.
('61', 493, 1, 8, 961973) Even from the practical point of view this continuous rain and tying up of workers is not desirable, and undoubtedly it sometimes results in demoralization.
('61', 493, 1, 9, 962130) You suggested that the best way was to have hand written copies of bulletins, etc., containing the name of the publisher.
('61', 493, 1, 10, 962252) Generally, I agree with all this and appreciate the force of your argument.
('61', 493, 1, 11, 962328) But I do feel that under certain circumstances it may be desirable for a local or Provincial committee or group to issue bulletins of directions, etc., secretly.
('61', 493, 1, 12, 962490) This must not be encouraged; indeed it should be discouraged, but a certain latitude in exceptional circumstances might be permitted.
('61', 493, 1, 13, 962624) There is one other small matter which seems to me rather ridiculous.
('61', 493, 1, 14, 962693) It was right and proper, if I may say so, for you to court imprisonment by giving previous intimation of your intention to do so to the authorities.
('61', 493, 1, 15, 962842) But it seems to me to be perfectly absurd for others, and even Congress volunteers, to send such notices or communications to the authorities.
('61', 493, 1, 16, 962985) Any person desiring to offer civil resistance should openly carry on activities which further our cause and thus court arrest.
('61', 493, 1, 17, 963112) He must not forget or ignore these activities and merely ask to be arrested.
('61', 493, 1, 18, 963189) This letter has become long enough.
('61', 493, 1, 19, 963225) I do not mention here the many other matters which I had the privilege of discussing with you.
